Response Message: Patient Presentation  Name: Mr. David Johnson Sex: Male Age: 67 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Residence: Suburban home Insurance: Medicare  Current Presentation: Mr. Johnson presents today with progressive left leg edema  tenderness  warmth  and erythema observed for the past four days. The patient reports calf pain worsened by standing and walking. He denies any recent trauma  surgery  or prolonged periods of immobilization. The pain is non-radiating  and there is no associated fever  shortness of breath  chest pain  or palpitations.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for Stage II hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He underwent a partial colectomy for colon cancer five years ago and has since been cancer-free. He has a 40-pack year smoking history but quit two years ago.  Medications:  1. Metformin 500mg twice a day 2. Amlodipine 5mg once daily 3. Atorvastatin 20mg once daily  Family History: His mother died from a myocardial infarction and his father from stroke. Both parents had hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His older brother has type 2 diabetes.   Social History: He lives with his wife and has three children. He is a former smoker  with a history of heavy smoking (40 pack-years). He reports moderate alcohol consumption (1-2 drinks per day) and denies illicit drug use. He is retired and reports leading a typically sedentary lifestyle.  This patient's demographic details and clinical picture align with the representation found in literature for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Aging  sedentary lifestyle  personal and family history of vascular diseases  and smoking all contribute to increased risk.   It is crucial to interpret these symptoms in the context of risk factors  and immediate diagnostics should be pursued due to the potential for life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism. It will be imperative to educate Mr. Johnson about potential changes in lifestyle and medication regimen depending upon the confirmation and severity of his diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Today  we are discussing Mr. Thomas T. Anderson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented with symptoms suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Mr. Anderson is a retired engineer  hailing from a suburban community in Fargo  North Dakota.  Demographic information: Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Residence: Fargo  North Dakota  Chief Complaint: Mr. Anderson presented with progressive swelling and pain in his right lower leg that began about two days ago. He reports no recent trauma to the leg. He describes the pain as a continuous  dull ache that intensifies with movement.  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a significant past medical history for hypertension and type II diabetes  both of which are well controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg/day for hypertension; Metformin 1000mg twice daily for Type II Diabetes). Additionally  he has a past history of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)  for which he takes daily Aspirin 81mg as a preventive measure.  He underwent right hip arthroplasty 5 years ago. Further  6 months ago  he was admitted to another hospital for pneumonia  where he was treated and discharged without any reported complications.  Social History: Mr. Anderson is a divorced male  with two adult sons residing in another state. He is a former smoker - quit 20 years ago. But he admits to drinking alcohol occasionally  but insists it is moderate and socially.  Risk Factors: Given his age  history of immobility associated with pneumonia hospitalization  orthopedic surgery  and sedentary lifestyle due to retirement  Mr. Anderson is at a marked risk for DVT. Furthermore  his hypertension  diabetes  and history of TIAs cumulatively contribute to his overall increased risk.  Clinical Outlook: A Doppler Ultrasound is planned to directly visualize and confirm if a DVT has occurred. If confirmed  Mr. Anderson would be at risk for developing pulmonary embolism  a feared complication of DVT. An appropriate anticoagulant regime will be initiated aiding thrombus resolution and reducing the risk of embolization. Patient education and lifestyle modifications will form the backbone of his long-term management plan  to prevent recurrence of DVT.

Patient Presentation:  Patient's Name: Mr. Steven Harper Age: 60 years-old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Financial Advisor Residence: New York City  NY  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Harper presents with discomfort  swelling  and redness in his right lower leg. He reports having experienced calf pain and light-headedness for the past three days. He mentions having recently undertaken a long-haul flight after a business trip.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Harper has a medical history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril. He is also a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago but smoked one pack per day for 25 years. He drinks alcohol socially and participates in moderate exercise twice a week.  Family History:  His family history reveals that both his parents had cardiovascular issues. His mother experienced an ischemic stroke at 70 and his father died due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 68. Given this history  Mr. Harper has been under regular medical supervision for cardiovascular risk assessment  with a significant effort placed on managing his hypertension.  Medications and Allergies:  Apart from Lisinopril for hypertension  Mr. Harper also reports taking aspirin for heart health. He has no known drug allergies.  Discussion:  This demographic information aligns with literature suggesting the incidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) increases with age and are more common among Caucasians. This patient's past history of smoking  sedentary occupation  long-haul flight  uncontrolled hypertension  male sex  and family history of cardiovascular disease all indicate a high risk for DVT.   Therefore  based on his symptoms and risk factors  Mr. Harper's clinical presentation is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis  and appropriate diagnostic tests should be ordered to confirm this. Timely detection and treatment are crucial to prevent further complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Title: Patient Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction: Today we will be discussing the case of Mrs. Maria Lopez  a 68-year-old Hispanic female. According to research  the incidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) increases with age  and DVT can occur in any race or ethnicity but appears to be slightly more common in individuals of European descent. However  cases among Hispanic populations are not uncommon  and thus  our patient represents a fair demographic representation.  Demographics: Mrs. Lopez is a long-time resident of Los Angeles  California. She is retired and lives with her husband. She is a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol use. She is bilingual  speaking both English and Spanish fluently. She has two adult children and four grandchildren.  Medical History: Mrs. Lopez has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been well-managed with medication. She also underwent a total knee replacement surgery six months ago and since then  she has been relatively immobile  being most of the time in her house due to her fear of falling. Family history reveals that her father had a stroke at the age of 73  but no known history of any coagulation disorders.  Presenting Issue: Over the past week  Mrs. Lopez has noticed increasing pain and swelling in her right lower leg  prompting her to seek medical attention. Upon physical examination  the calf was warm to the touch  erythematous  swollen  and tender which are common symptoms of DVT.   Given her recent orthopedic surgery and subsequent immobility  Mrs. Lopez would be considered high-risk for the development of a DVT due to prolonged immobilization leading to venous stasis.   Preliminary tests including a Doppler ultrasound are being arranged to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out any possible pulmonary embolism which can be a severe complication of DVT.   Summary: In summary  we have presented the case of Mrs. Lopez  a patient who is at increased risk factors for deep vein thrombosis due to her advanced age  recent knee surgery and subsequent period of immobility. Further diagnostic investigation will confirm the diagnosis and guide the appropriate treatment plan to reduce her risk of complications.

Title: Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female Patient  Slide 1: Introduction Our patient  Mrs. Alice Johnson  is a 56-year-old Caucasian female  originally from Chicago  IL  who presented with symptoms indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Slide 2: Demographics and Risk Factors As per literature  DVT is slightly more common in females  with the risk increasing with age. Mrs. Johnson falls under the demographic frequently seen in DVT cases. Furthermore  she is overweight with a BMI of 30  an inactive lifestyle  and a history of long periods of immobility due to her occupation as a software programmer. These factors collectively put her at an elevated risk for developing DVT.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Mrs. Johnson's past medical history is significant for smoking and high blood pressure. Additionally  she had undergone hormone replacement therapy post her menopause. This information is critical as these conditions can also contribute towards hypercoagulability  making Mrs. Johnson susceptible to thromboembolic diseases.  Slide 4: Current Presentation Upon presentation  Mrs. Johnson described experiencing progressive discomfort and swelling in her left lower leg for one week. The pain was described as a cramping soreness which increases with physical activity and alleviates with rest. Her calf was tender to touch  with visible redness and warmth on physical examination. No signs of tissue damage or necrosis were observed.  Slide 5: Assessment and Findings A Doppler Ultrasound highlighted an obstructive clot in her left femoral vein  confirming the clinical diagnosis of DVT. Necessary laboratory investigations  including coagulation profile  were ordered. Her D-dimer levels were elevated  a common finding in DVT patients.  Slide 6: Conclusion Given the demographic representation  the patient's lifestyle and medical risk factors  the diagnosis of DVT for Mrs. Johnson is consistent with what is found in the current literature. A thorough assessment  early diagnosis  and a proper treatment plan are vital in managing DVT to prevent severe complications.  Slide 7: Patient Management Currently  Mrs. Johnson is undergoing anticoagulation therapy and has been educated on the need for regular follow-ups  lifestyle modifications such as dietary changes  regular exercise  cessation of smoking  managing her blood pressure  and reducing prolonged periods of inactivity.

Title: Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Presentation  The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian female  named Ms. Smith  from a middle-class socio-economic background. She is statistically the most common demographic for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  according to existing literature. She is a non-smoker but has a sedentary lifestyle due to her profession as an editor at a publishing firm.  Presenting Complaint  Ms. Smith presents with symptoms indicative of deep vein thrombosis  primarily of her left leg. The symptoms had begun few days ago and have progressively gotten worse. She reported persistent pain in her left calf  noticeable swelling in her leg  the skin over the area is warm to the touch and there's a slight reddening.  Medical history  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and obesity (BMI of 33 kg/m2)  but these have been well managed through medication and diet changes over the past decade. However  she does not engage in regular physical exercise due to her sedentary job. Both hypertension and obesity are known risk factors for DVT.   She has not had any surgeries  but she recently (2 weeks ago) had a long-haul flight from New York to Sydney which may have increased her risk for developing DVT due to prolonged immobility.   Family history revealed that her mother had a history of recurrent DVT  indicating a possible genetic predisposition.   Pharmaceutical History  Ms. Smith is currently under medication for hypertension  taking amlodipine 10 mg once daily. She is also on a low dose aspirin regimen for prevention of heart disease. For her obesity  she has been advised lifestyle modifications and low calorie diet by her dietician and primary care doctor.  Based on her symptoms  past medical history  and risk factors  it is crucial to confirm the diagnosis of DVT and start appropriate treatment at the earliest.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Slide 1: Introduction Patient Initials: T.L. Age: 70 years old Sex: Female Ethnicity: White Occupation: Retired nurse Marital Status: Widow Home Residence: Lives alone in a suburban neighborhood.  Slide 2: Current Presentation  Onset: Complaining of progressive unilateral leg pain  swelling  and tenderness for the past 7 days. Noted increased warmth over the affected area  no other reported symptoms. Influencing factors: Recent long-haul air travel (2 weeks ago) returning from a family visit. Managing factors: Symptoms partially relieved by rest and leg elevation.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Smoking Status: Past smoker  quit 15 years ago. Alcohol Consumption: Moderate drinker (1-2 glasses of wine per week). Chronic Disorders: Hypertension (well-managed with medication). Previous venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism: None reported. Surgeries: Uncomplicated knee replacement surgery 2 years ago  uncomplicated cholecystectomy 10 years ago.   Slide 4: Family history  Mother died of stroke at age 75  father died from myocardial infarction at age 80. Older brother diagnosed with DVT at age 72.  Slide 5: Medication and Allergies Current Medication: Lisinopril for hypertension. Self-medication: Over-the-counter painkillers for arthritis pain. Allergies: None reported.  Slide 6: Social History Lives alone  has a close relationship with children who live nearby and visit regularly. Actively engages in knitting and gardening. Used to be a nurse but is now enjoying retirement.   Slide 7: Relevant tests and conclusion Recommended diagnostic tests: Doppler ultrasound  D-dimer test. Patient is at high risk due to age  recent long-haul travel  history of surgery and hypertension  and a family history of venous thromboembolism. Early diagnosis and treatment are vital to prevent pulmonary embolism  post-thrombotic syndrome  and recurrence of DVT.  Please note that DVT is more common in older adults  particularly those over the age of 60. It is equally common in both genders  but certain risk factors such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives can increase the risk for women. The disease prevalence varies among ethnic groups  with the lowest rates reported in Asians and the highest in Caucasians and African Americans.

Title: Case Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Subject: Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  Demographics: Mr. Doe hails from the rural northern part of the United States  specifically North Dakota. He is a retired farmer  overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 29  which classifies him as pre-obese. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol rarely.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe presents with a history of swelling  warmth  and pain in his left calf persisting for the past four days. He also reports shortness of breath  particularly on exertion  and occasional cough  but denies any chest pain.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has been previously diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus and managed with oral hypoglycemic agents for 15 years. He also has a history of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  controlled with loop diuretics and statins respectively. Seven years ago  he was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer  for which he underwent radiation therapy  achieving complete remission.  Family History: There is a history of heart disease in his family  with his father passing away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 72. His mother  currently in her late eighties  has been diagnosed with stroke and hypertension.  Surgical History: Mr. Doe underwent prostatectomy seven years ago. No other surgical procedures in the past.  Social History: Mr. Doe is a widower  living alone in his family house. He has three children who maintain regular check-ins with him. His diet predominantly consists of processed and high-fat foods.  Clinical Assessment: Based on the patient's age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  cancer history  and presenting symptoms  a provisional diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is being considered. Further diagnostic tests including Doppler Ultrasound  D-dimer  and possibly a CT scan are advised to confirm the diagnosis.  DVT is more common in individuals over 60 and those having conditions that increase the thickness of the blood or hinder circulation. Moreover  obesity is a recognized risk factor for DVT. Thus  Mr. Doe's demographic and clinical features are consistent with existing literature on DVT risk profiles. Current management to include anticoagulation therapy  lifestyle modification counseling  and regular monitoring.

Title: Patient Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: Our patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female  residing in suburban areas. She is post-menopausal  has a body mass index (BMI) of 30.3  classifying her as obese  and works at a sedentary desk job. She is a non-smoker but has a history of excessive alcohol consumption. Furthermore  she has only occasional physical activity and reports a consumption of a high-fat  high-sugar diet.  Past Medical History: Our patient has a chronic history of type 2 diabetes mellitus which is managed with metformin. She also suffers from hypertension  controlled by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. Recently  she had an orthopedic surgery for a hip replacement and subsequent prolonged bed rest. She has a family history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Her mother suffered from recurrent DVTs and her elder sibling experienced a pulmonary embolism. She is not on any kind of hormone therapy and does not have any known malignancies.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reports acute-onset left leg swelling  increased warmth  redness  and pain which intensify upon standing or walking. She has been experiencing these symptoms for approximately two days.  Overall  the patient's demographic profile  personal and medical history correspond to documented risk factors for deep vein thrombosis. These include age over 60 (with a peak incidence in the seventh decade)  obesity  physical inactivity  surgery with the subsequent immobility  personal and familial history of venous thromboembolism  comorbidity with hypertension and diabetes  and additionally an excessive alcohol consumption history. Her profile underscores the importance of monitoring and appropriate preventative measures  like blood-thinning medication and compression stockings  in populations with similar at-risk features.

Title: Patient Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Subject: Mrs. Maria Gonzalez  64-year-old Hispanic female   Primary Complaint: Swelling in the left leg  specifically in the calf region  severe pain in the same area  and noticeable warmth and redness in the skin over the-swollen part of her leg.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Gonzalez is a retired school teacher with a past medical history of Hypertension (HTN) for which she has been on thiazide diuretics for the past 8 years. She has been smoking half a pack per day for the past 30 years and suffers from Obesity (BMI=32). She has no documented history of diabetes or any heart disease. She had an uncomplicated knee replacement surgery 4 weeks ago.  Family History: Her mother died at the age of 68 due to a stroke. Her father died at 74 due to lung cancer.   Socioeconomic Status: Living with her husband in a suburban neighborhood  retired with a pension plan. She has two daughters living in the same city.  Current Medications: Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg OD for HTN and over-the-counter multivitamin tablets.   Clinical Findings: Findings were consistent with a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Mrs. Gonzales's left lower leg was swollen  red  warm to the touch  and tender  especially at the back of her calf. She had a positive Homan's sign. Pulses were palpable and symmetrical lower limb reflexes were normal. Her blood pressure was slightly elevated at 140/90mmHg and her BMI categorized her as obese.  Discussion: Due to her recent surgery  prolonged immobility  history of long-term smoking  hypertension  and obesity Mrs. Gonzalez is at a significantly increased risk of developing DVT. She shows signs consistent with those of DVT and will be referred for an immediate ultrasound to confirm this initial diagnosis. If positive  she will be commenced on an appropriate anticoagulation regimen. She will also be strongly advised to quit smoking and an appropriate weight loss program will be arranged to help manage her obesity and HTN that can further aggravate her condition.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Profile:  The patient  Mr. Johnson  is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  retired  from suburban surroundings  and is currently on Medicare. He is a former smoker  quit smoking 10 years ago  and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a detailed past medical history that includes the following conditions: hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. His hypertension and diabetes have been successfully managed for ten years with Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. There have also been no prior instances of coagulopathy.    Presenting Symptoms:  Recently  the patient began to experience unexplained swelling  warmth  and redness on one leg  particularly in the calf area. Associated symptoms include mild to moderate pain in the affected leg  fatigue  and shortness of breath. The onset of symptoms was sudden with the patient noting that his discomfort and swelling seemed to progressively worsen over a two-day period.  Risk Factors: Mr. Johnson has multiple risk factors for DVT including advanced age  a sedentary lifestyle since retirement  overweight status (BMI of 27)  and a recent history of air travel. His history of Type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension also predispose him to vascular diseases.  In Summary: Our patient  Mr. Johnson  a 62-year-old white male with a significant past medical history and risk factors  presents with typical symptoms of DVT. His profile is consistent with epidemiological studies  identifying male gender  advanced age  obesity  and history of smoking as significant risk factors for DVT. Immediate investigations are recommended to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate therapeutic strategies.  References: • Heit JA. Epidemiology of venous thromboembolism. Nature Reviews Cardiology. 2015;12(8):464. • Grosse SD  et al. Healthcare expenditures for venous thromboembolism in older Americans. Thrombosis research. 2016;141:146-153. • Samama MM. An epidemiologic study of risk factors for deep vein thrombosis in medical outpatients: the Sirius study. Archives of internal medicine. 2000;160(22):3415-3420.

Title: Case Presentation on Deep Vein Thrombosis   Introduction: Ms. Jane Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian female  presented to our clinic today with symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis.  Patient Demographics: Ms. Smith is an office worker living in the urban area of Indianapolis  Indiana. She is a current smoker and reports a sedentary lifestyle because of her job nature. Her BMI is 29 indicating overweight. She lives alone  separated from her husband 15 years ago. She consumes alcohol occasionally and has no known drug abuse history.   Past Medical History: Patient has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is on chronically antihypertensive medication and statins. Ms. Smith underwent a total knee arthroplasty five years ago due to severe osteoarthritis but her postoperative period was uneventful.   Current Clinical Status: Ms. Smith has been experiencing swelling in her right leg for a week now  and recently she started to feel moderate to severe pain  warmth  and redness around the swollen area. She also has board-like rigidity and is unable to bear weight on the affected limb.   Risk Factors: Risk factors for deep vein thrombosis in Ms. Smith's case include advanced age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  smoking  history of joint surgery  and chronic hypertension. She does not report any family history of clotting disorders.  Evaluation: Urgent Doppler ultrasound has been ordered to confirm the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.   The above case is not uncommon because Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) predominantly occurs in individuals over the age of 40  is most common in Caucasians and slightly more common in females. It is also associated with sedentary lifestyle  obesity  smoking  and surgery  all common amongst the general population.  Discussion: If Ms. Smith's DVT is confirmed  she will need immediate treatment to prevent serious complications like pulmonary embolism. This generally involves anticoagulant medications and lifestyle modification strategies. Her case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and intervention in patients at risk of deep vein thrombosis. It is important to educate such individuals about the risk factors and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis to expedite diagnosis and treatment.   Conclusion: By presenting this case  we hope to raise awareness about the importance of early detection and the management of DVT  particularly in individuals with multiple risk factors like Ms. Smith.

Title: Clinical Presentation for a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) Patient  Patient Profile: Mr. John Smith  a 62-year-old male of Caucasian descent  presents with symptoms suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis.  He is married  retired  and lives with his wife in a suburban area. His body mass index (BMI) is 30 kg/m2 which qualifies him as obese based on CDC standards.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Smith reports experiencing about one week of progressive pain and swelling in his right lower leg. He characterizes the pain as a deep  constant ache. Affected right calf has a circumference measurement approximately 3 cm larger than the left. He denies any trauma or unusual activity.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. He has a history of coronary artery disease and successfully underwent triple bypass surgery eight years ago. His cardiovascular risk factors have been well-managed since the surgery with Cardiac Rehab  diet  and medications. He has been taking a daily aspirin as per his cardiologist's advice. His blood pressure control has been excellent on his current regime of Lisinopril and Amlodipine. His most recent lipid levels were excellent.  He was recently hospitalized for hernia repair three weeks ago  for which he received prophylactic subcutaneous Heparin  as per protocol.   Family History: Mr. Smith reports his father had a pulmonary embolism in his 80s.  Summary:  This portrait of Mr. Smith takes into account both WHO and CDC demographics. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prevalence trends show increased susceptibility with age  particularly in Caucasian individuals. Other risk factors include obesity  post-surgery periods  and prolonged immobilization. His significant family history and past cardiovascular health issues make his case noteworthy. As smoking also increases the risk of DVT  the patient’s former lifestyle is noteworthy; despite having quit  his risk may still be increased based on his past consumption. Mr. Smith's case highlights the importance of considering risk factors  demographics  and lifestyle factors in the possibility of developing deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Case Presentation:  Patient Initials: L. J.  Age: 62  Sex: Female  Race/Ethnicity: African American  Occupation: Retired Physical Education Teacher  Presenting Condition: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Medical History:  The patient is a 62-year-old postmenopausal African American female  nonsmoker  with a past medical history of obesity (BMI 33)  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  not previously diagnosed with any thrombotic or coagulation disorder. The patient had an uncomplicated total knee arthroplasty six weeks ago.   Current Medications:  - Lisinopril for hypertension - Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  Presenting Complaint:  L. J. came to the hospital complaining of a gradually worsening and persistent pain in her right calf over the past four days  associated with visible swelling and slight redness. She also reported a sensation of warmth in the same area. She denied any shortness of breath  chest pain  or recent long travels.  Physical Examination:  Mild distress due to lower extremity pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. The cardiovascular exam reveals well-preserved peripheral pulses without any signs of peripheral ischemia. The right lower extremity appears markedly swollen  erythematous  and is warm to touch. Dorsiflexion of the foot elicits calf discomfort (positive Homan’s sign). No ulcers or skin changes  and the remaining physical exam is nondescript.  This patient’s symptoms  recent knee surgery  uncontrolled hypertension  and hyperlipidemia increase her risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Given her symptoms and risk factors  it would be reasonable for further investigation with duplex ultrasonography or D-dimer testing to confirm the suspected diagnosis of DVT.

Title: Presentation of a Deep Vein Thrombosis Patient  Patient Details: Name: John Rodriguez Age: 57 Sex: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic Occupation: Law Enforcement Officer Location: Miami  USA  Overview: John is a Cuban-American middle-aged male  a demographic that is vulnerable to Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) due to lifestyle factors. John has been leading a sedentary lifestyle further aggravated by his long work hours and extensive seated periods  raising his risk of developing DVT.  Past Medical History: John has an established history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for 10 years. He has been adherent to his antihypertensive and statin medications. He smokes around ten cigarettes a day for about 20 years  which has compounded his DVT risk. He is obese with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32 and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  He has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 5 years ago and managed well on oral hypoglycemic agents. There is no family history of coagulation disorders.  Presenting Symptoms: John sought medical intervention following pain and swelling in his left leg that had become progressively worse over a week. He also reported experiencing lower leg discomfort while walking. There were no reported symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath or coughing up blood  which could point towards a pulmonary embolism.   Conclusion: Given John is above 50 years of age with a routine lifestyle involving prolonged periods of immobility and a history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes  he is at increased risk of DVT. Upon physical examination  the left leg was visibly swollen and warmer to touch compared to the right. D-dimer lab test and a duplex ultrasounds were recommended to confirm the DVT diagnosis.  This patient presentation demonstrates how deep vein thrombosis tends to manifest among middle-aged  sedentary individuals with underlying chronic conditions and unhealthy habits. Early detection and intervention are crucial to prevent complications like pulmonary embolism.   References: (Refer to the most recent publications on Deep Vein Thrombosis presentations and implications on middle-aged  Hispanic men with underlying chronic conditions and lifestyles).

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis Case Presentation   I. Patient Demographics  The patient being discussed is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who hails from a semi-urban community in Nebraska. She is a retired school teacher and lives with her husband of 40 years. She has a sedentary lifestyle since retirement and she is a non-smoker. No known drug allergies.  II. Medical History  The patient has a history of obesity with a BMI of 32  and hypertension  for which she is currently on Lisinopril 10mg once daily. She is also currently managing type 2 diabetes mellitus with Metformin. She visited the emergency department 3 weeks ago for a total knee replacement surgery.  III. Patient Symptoms  Four days ago  she started feeling pain and tenderness in her right calf  which has progressively gotten worse. She is also reporting moderate swelling and the skin around the area is noticeably warmer and oddly discolored (reddish). There is no reported fever but she has been feeling fatigued for the last couple of days. No reported shortness of breath or chest pain.  IV. Preliminary Diagnosis  Considering the recent orthopedic surgery  her sedentary lifestyle  and her history of obesity and hypertension  her symptoms suggest the possibility of postoperative deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The calf pain  swelling  warmth  and discoloration are classic signs of DVT  though further diagnostic tests are required to confirm the diagnosis.  V. Literature Prevalence  According to available literature  the risk factors for DVT include major surgery  prolonged immobility  obesity  advanced age (over 60 years)  and medical conditions like cancer  heart and lung diseases  and inflammatory bowel diseases. Women are slightly more likely than men to develop DVT  and Caucasians are found to have a higher prevalence compared to other races.  It is crucial to note that this presentation represents a typical DVT patient as highlighted in the scientific literature. Final diagnosis and treatment will be based on further diagnostic tests and the patient's response to treatment. As Healthcare Providers  ensuring all variables are considered is essential in patient management.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in Postmenopausal Women  Patient Presentation:  Ms. Sarah Johansson  a 58-year-old Caucasian female  presents with recent complaints of swelling and pain in her right lower extremity  specifically the calf region  which she has been experiencing for the past few days. As an office administrative assistant  her occupation involves prolonged sitting. She had menopause at age 50 and is currently on Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT).   Patient History:  Her past medical history reveals that she is a long-term smoker  consuming about a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. She has no history of alcohol or drug abuse. She has a history of Hypertension and is being treated with antihypertensive medications. She has a family history of thromboembolic diseases – her mother had a pulmonary embolism in her late sixties.  Her BMI is 28 indicating overweight  and her diet is typically high in saturated fats. She reports leading a sedentary lifestyle  having little to no regular physical exercise. She reports no known drug allergies. She had a surgical history of hysterectomy done 2 years ago due to fibroids.  On Physical Examination:  Her vital signs are stable. Examination of the right lower extremity reveals erythematous  warm  swollen  and tender calf which is positive for Homan's sign. There are no signs of superficial vein inflammation.   Based on the history and physical examination  a preliminary diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is suspected. A Doppler ultrasound is advised to confirm the diagnosis and establish the extent of the thrombosis.   Discussion:  Ms. Johansson presents classic circumstances for the development of DVT. Postmenopausal women  particularly those on HRT  have an increased risk of DVT. Her sedentary job  smoking history  and family history of thromboembolic diseases all elevate her risk.   Research indicates that Caucasian individuals have a higher proclivity for DVT compared to other racial and ethnic groups. Hypertension  obesity  and consumption of a diet rich in saturated fat also contribute to her risk. Furthermore  her age group (50-60 years old) is when the occurrence of VTE (Venous Thromboembolism) starts to significantly escalate. Careful consideration of her case is critical in preventing possible severe consequences of untreated DVT  such as a pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Today I am presenting a 60-year-old  African-American female patient named Mrs. T. According to current literature  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) has a higher prevalence among African Americans  particularly older females. Mrs. T. weighs 195 lbs. and has a height of 5’4’’  indicating her BMI falls into the ""obesity"" range which increases the risk for DVT.  Mrs. T. is a retired school teacher who complains of experiencing persistent unexplained pain and swelling in her left lower leg over the past week. She has noticed that her leg has changed colors to a reddish-blue and feels warm to the touch. She denies experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath or cardiac symptoms.  Mrs. T. has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes and has been on hormone replacement therapy for the past seven years following her menopause. She recently had a total knee replacement surgery on her right leg about six weeks ago. According to her pharmaceutical records  Mrs. T. was regularly taking Metformin  Lisinopril and Prempro  and finished a course of Ibuprofen prescribed post-surgery.  According to the National Blood Clot Alliance  patients with a recent major surgery  especially orthopedic surgeries  have an increased risk of developing DVT. Elevated risk is also associated with hormone replacement therapy  hypertension  and diabetes.  Mrs. T. does not smoke tobacco and consumes alcohol on rare social occasions. She admits to a fairly sedentary life since her retirement and her recent knee surgery  and claims to have a diet high in processed foods.  In conclusion  Mrs. T.’s demographic profile  past medical history  recent surgery  prolonged inactivity  obesity and current symptoms collectively suggest a high risk for deep vein thrombosis. More diagnostic tests are required to confirm this preliminary diagnosis.  In light of her symptoms and risk factors  steps must be taken to facilitate rapid diagnosis and appropriate management to mitigate the associated risk of a pulmonary embolism or other vascular complications.

Title: Case Presentation on Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 67 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Location: Colorado  USA  Presentation: Mr. Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents with unilateral swelling  tenderness  and redness in his left lower extremity. He reports being physically inactive due to the recent snowstorms in Colorado. His mobility was further reduced due to a slight fall about three weeks ago when he sustained a minor fracture in his right foot  which is now on the mend. Notably  Mr. Smith  who recently retired from a sedentary job as an engineer  has a BMI of 30 kg/m2 and is classified as obese.  History: On enquiry  Mr. Smith admits to occasional episodes of chest discomfort and shortness of breath. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 72  while his elder brother was diagnosed with DVT at the age of 65.   Mr. Smith also admits to being a smoker for around 30 years  although he has tried to cut back in the last couple of years. He enjoys an occasional glass of wine but denies any substance abuse. He has been diagnosed with high blood pressure which is controlled by medication. His lipid profile indicates borderline high levels of cholesterol and low-density lipoproteins (LDL)  suggestive of dyslipidemia.  In Summary: Based on his age  gender  and race  Mr. Smith belongs to a demographic that is commonly affected by DVT  as documented in various studies. His recent physical inactivity due to his injury and extreme weather conditions  obesity  history of smoking  hypertension  dyslipidemia  and positive family history of heart disease and DVT  considerably increases his risk of developing DVT. Evaluation and management strategies should be considered keeping these risk factors in mind  and treatment should be initiated promptly to reduce the risk of potential complications such as pulmonary embolism.      This case presentation is an excellent opportunity to educate and discuss strategies for DVT prevention in high-risk individuals  along with the importance of managing modifiable risk factors such as obesity  smoking  physical inactivity  and hypertension.

Title: A Case Study on Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 56-year-old Caucasian male  employed as an IT professional  has shown up at the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of pain and swelling in his right lower leg. Mr. Smith lives in a suburban area in New York  lives alone  and has no dependent children. He is a former smoker but quit about five years ago. He is moderate in alcohol  with occasional indulgence during social events. He reports not having any recent travels or periods of prolonged immobility.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension  controlled with medications. He also had a myocardial infarction three years ago for which he underwent an angioplasty  and since then  has been on cardiovascular medications  including antiplatelets. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus two years ago and since then  he has been taking metformin. He also reports a family history of blood clotting disorders. His father suffered from deep vein thrombosis and his mother developed a pulmonary embolism.    Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith complains of increasing pain  swelling  and warmth over his right calf for the past three days. He denied any trauma to the leg  abdominal or chest pains  dyspnea  hemoptysis or neurological deficits. He has noticed the swelling is increasing in size; however  he avoided medical attention until the pain became severe today. He also notes an uncomfortable throbbing sensation  and that the pain gets worse when bending his foot.   The information available displays a clear grouping of risk factors for deep vein thrombosis such as age  sedentary lifestyle associated with his profession  history of myocardial infarction  hypertension  and diabetes. His familial history of blood clotting disorders cannot be disregarded. Considering these  the pain and swelling around the right calf could be indicative of deep vein thrombosis; however  further diagnostic tests and investigations are needed before a definitive conclusion is drawn.

He is a former smoker who quit smoking five years ago after a 40-year pack-a-day habit.   Slide 3: Recent History Mr. Evans recently underwent a total hip replacement six weeks ago and noticed the problem started a week after the surgery when a swelling appeared on his right leg  accompanied by moderate pain. He also notes mild-to-moderate pain on the right side  which becomes severe upon walking or standing. He does not report shortness of breath  chest pain  or symptoms reflective of a possible pulmonary embolism  reducing the immediate risk of life-threatening complications. His demographic background and recent immobility put him at a higher risk of experiencing this condition. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial in his case to prevent further complications.

Slide 1: Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Case Presentation  Slide 2: Patient Introduction: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith.  Slide 3: General Information: Mr. Smith resides in a suburban area of Chicago. He's retired from a managerial job confirming a sedentary lifestyle and he is a non-smoker.  Slide 4: Demographics: The chosen demographic is supported by literature stating that DVT most commonly occurs in adults over the age of 60 years  with a slightly higher predominance in males  and more frequent among Caucasians.  Slide 5: Pathophysiology: DVT occurs when a blood clot forms in one of the deep veins  usually in the leg. This condition can be life-threatening when clots break off and travel to the lungs  causing a pulmonary embolism.  Slide 6: Symptom Presentation: Mr. Smith presented with a swollen left leg  complaining about a cramping pain. He also mentioned a warm feeling on the area along with skin discoloration.   Slide 7: Risk Factors: Mr. Smith's sedentary lifestyle and recent history of a 7-hour long-haul flight before the symptoms appeared contributed to the risk of DVT.  Slide 8:  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and was under medication for the same. There is no history of any major surgeries or injuries. He is not on any blood thinning medications or hormone therapies and no past occurrences of DVT. Detailed medical history did not identify any genetic predisposition to clotting disorders.  Slide 9: Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  noticeable swelling in the left leg was observed. Doppler Ultrasound confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep vein of his affected leg.  Slide 10: Treatment Plan: Mr. Smith was admitted for inpatient management of his condition. Treatment started with anticoagulants to prevent the clot from getting bigger  and to stop the formation of new clots.   Slide 11: Prevention: Lifestyle modifications recommended including encouraging a more active lifestyle to prevent future episodes and instructions given not to sit for long periods.  Slide 12: Conclusions: DVT is largely preventable and manageable  but timely diagnosis is important for optimal outcomes. This case of Mr. Smith highlights the need for awareness of risk factors and early symptom recognition.

Slide 1: Introduction  Today  we will be presenting a case of a patient diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).   Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient is a 60-year-old white female  living in an urban area with a job in administration. According to research  DVT is more common in older people  with the highest rate among individuals aged 60 years and above  signaling a plausible incidence in our patient.  Slide 3: Medical History  She has a past medical history of obesity and hypertension  two conditions associated with an increased risk for DVT. These risk factors  combined with her sedentary lifestyle due to her job specifics and two recent long haul flights  greatly increased her chances of developing blood clots.  Slide 4: Symptoms and Diagnosis  She presented to the clinic with a one-week history of unilateral swelling and pain in her right leg. On examination  the leg was warm  swollen  and tender  particularly along the course of the deep veins. Title: Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged African-American Female  Introduction: Today we will be discussing the case of a 55-year-old African-American female presented in the emergency department with a 2-day history of bilateral leg swelling and calf pain  predominantly on the left side.  Demographics: The patient  Mrs. Aaliyah Thomas  is a native resident of Queens  New York. She is married  is a non-smoker  and works in a department store where she spends long periods standing. She lives with her husband and has no children.   Medical History: Mrs. Thomas has a body mass index (BMI) of 33  which classifies her as obese. She has a known medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus and high blood pressure  both currently being managed with medication. Unfortunately  she has a poor history of compliance with regular physician visits or maintaining her prescriptions due to financial constraints. There is no family history of thromboembolic events  but her mother had a stroke at the age of 68.  Presenting Issue: She reported a progressively worsening left calf pain and noted visible swelling in both legs  more pronounced on the left. She did not report any recent trauma  injuries  or long periods of immobilization that might have triggered the symptoms. There was no prior history of similar episodes. She has also noticed a mild shortness of breath but no cough  chest pain  or hemoptysis.   Preliminary Examination: Upon arrival  her blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg  pulse rate 91 beats/min  respiratory rate 20 breaths/min  and temperature 37.3 °C. Her oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. Physical examination demonstrated notable swelling of the left lower extremity with palpable cords  warmth  redness  intense pain on movement  and significant tenderness on calf muscle compression.  Given Mrs. Thomas's clinical presentation and her risk factors  including age  obesity  and her long hours of standing at work  a suspected diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made. Further investigations  including laboratory and imaging studies  were ordered to confirm the diagnosis and manage her condition effectively.  This case presents a common clinical demographic for DVT: middle-aged  African-American women with a number of risk factors  such as obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and prolonged periods of immobilization due to her work conditions.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) Patient Presentation  [Slide 1]   Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. Anderson - Age: 65 Years - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired  previously engaged in a sedentary job  [Slide 2]   Past Medical History: - Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Hypertension - Past transient ischemic attacks  no residual deficits - Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32  indicating obesity   [Slide 3]  Presenting Complaint: - Acute onset of left leg swelling and pain  primarily in the calf area - Leg feels warm to touch  [Slide 4]  Risk Factors: - Age over 60 years - Personal history of cardiovascular disease - Obesity - Sedentary lifestyle - Recent prolonged travel (long-haul flight)  [Slide 5]  Physical Examination Findings: - Localized swelling on the left leg - Redness and warmth over the swollen area - Positive Homan’s sign: Pain in the calf or popliteal region with forced dorsiflexion of the foot - Vital Signs: Blood pressure: 140/90mmHg  Heart rate: 92 bpm  Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 98% on room air  Temperature: 37.8°C  [Slide 6]  Laboratory and Imaging Results: - D-dimer: Elevated - Ultrasound Doppler of the lower extremity: Positive for DVT in left popliteal vein  This representation is in line with the epidemiological data which suggests that DVT is more common in individuals over the age of 60  with risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  cardiovascular disease and recently prolonged travel (long-haul flights).

Subject: Presentation of Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  1. Introduction (Demographics and initial presentation)     Patient's Name: Mr. James Wilson     Age: 68 years     Gender: Male    Race: Caucasian    Occupation: Retired Engineer     Initial Claim: Mr. Wilson presented to the family practice clinic with complaints of unexplained  persistent pain  and swelling in his right lower leg. He also reported a warmth sensation  red or discolored skin  and visible surface veins.   2. Past Medical History     Mr. Wilson's past medical history is notable for several risk factors commonly associated with DVT: an episode of hospitalization for congestive heart failure two years ago  a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity  and a 40-year history of smoking  for which he quit five years ago. He's also  notably  overweight with a BMI of 30 kg/m^2. Additionally  he has been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both are well-controlled with medications.  3. Family History     There's significant family history  as Mr. Wilson's father suffered from deep vein thrombosis and later died from pulmonary embolism. His older sister was diagnosed with factor V Leiden  a genetic clotting disorder. No other relevant family medical history is noted.  4. Social History     Mr. Wilson has been living with his wife since he got retired. His alcohol intake is moderate and reported no illicit drug use. He previously smoked one pack/day for 40 years but had quit smoking since last five years.  5. Assessment and Plan     Given Mr. Wilson's clinical presentation and his background risk factors including older age  obesity  former smoker  chronic conditions and relevant family history  a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is warranted. Further diagnostic evaluations including a D-dimer test and a Doppler ultrasound scan have been proposed. Additionally  consultations with a cardiologist and possibly a hematologist are planned.   We aim to reinforce lifestyle modification advice  particularly concerning diet and exercise  and to review Mr. Wilson's smoking cessation status. If a confirmed diagnosis of DVT is made  he will likely require an anticoagulant regimen and close outpatient follow-up. Patient education efforts will focus on awareness on importance of medication adherence  preventive measures and signs of potential complications such as pulmonary embolism.  In summary  Mr. Wilson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a high index of suspicion for DVT  primarily due to his risk factors and presenting symptoms. A systematic approach to confirm his diagnosis and manage his potential DVT will be taken to ensure optimum patient outcomes.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Case Presentation  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male named Mr. Thompson. He resides in the urban area of Detroit  Michigan  and is a retired automobile factory worker with a history of smoking.  Presenting Issue: Mr. Thompson presented to our medical department complaining of pain and swelling in his left lower extremity that had been worsening over the past week. The pain was described as a dull aching sensation  especially when standing or walking. He also reported a slight increase in shortness of breath over the same period.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson's past medical history includes Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both controlled through medication. He also has a history of obesity with BMI above 30 kg/m2. His family history includes father who died of stroke and a sister diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Observations & Diagnosis: Upon examination  noticeable edema was present in Mr. Thompson's left leg. A Doppler ultrasonography subsequently confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the deep veins of his left lower extremity. When combined with reported symptoms  the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made.  Risk Factors: According to the literature  patients who are older  particularly those over 60 years of age and those with a history of obesity  diabetes  and a sedentary lifestyle are at increased risk for developing DVT. Mr. Thompson’s age and medical history align with the typical demographic representation for this condition. His African-American ethnicity and male gender are also noted as risk factors in certain studies  with DVT prevalence reported higher amongst African-American population.  Note: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a serious condition requiring timely diagnosis and appropriate management to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome. It predominantly affects individuals in their middle and older years  with greater incidences amongst men and certain ethnic groups.  References: Kim  S.  & Kuroda  T.  2018. The Role of Race and Ethnicity in Venous Thromboembolism. American Journal of Hematology  21(6)  pp. 514-520.   Heit  J.A.  2015. Epidemiology of Venous Thromboembolism. Nature Review Cardiology  12(8)  pp. 464-474.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Demographic Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  who is currently residing in New York City. He lives with his wife in a private home. His primary language is English and he's a non-smoker with a moderate alcohol consumption.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a complaint of increasing swelling and pain in the left calf over a period of three days  without any history of injury. He also reports recent shortness of breath and intermittent chest discomfort.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of obesity  notably inactive lifestyle  prolonged mobility due to recurrent gout  and has taken several long-distance flights recently. Additionally  he has a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both managed with medications. The patient underwent right hip replacement surgery approximately 15 months ago. His family history reveals that his mother had an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after a prolonged bed rest following a stroke.  Examination: Physical inspection showed a visibly swollen and tender left calf  slightly warmer than the right calf. There was no observed wound  discoloration or signs of infection. No recorded fever and vital signs were within a normal range.  Impression: Considering the patient's symptoms  medical history  and clinical examination  there is a high degree of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The recent history of immobility  coupled with the persistent calf pain and swelling  could indicate the formation of a clot in the deep veins of the left leg. In addition to DVT  there is also a significant risk of pulmonary embolism (PE)  due to associated shortness of breath and chest discomfort.  Plan: Further investigations including Doppler ultrasonography of both lower limbs  D-dimer test  and possibly a CT pulmonary angiogram  are necessary to confirm DVT and exclude PE. Pending results  immediate anticoagulation therapy would be initiated.

Patient Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  I am presenting Mrs. Grace Thompson  a 60-year-old Caucasian female residing in the Midwest region of the United States. She has a BMI indicative of obesity with a value of 32  placing her in a high-risk category for various health conditions.   Mrs. Thompson has a known past medical history of factor V Leiden mutation and has been on long-term hormonal replacement therapy. Both of these factors notably increase her predisposition towards thrombotic events. Furthermore  she was a chronic smoker until her diagnosis five years ago with COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease)  of which she has had multiple exacerbations requiring hospitalizations. Mrs. Thompson was also recently hospitalized for a total hip arthroplasty  which further increases her risk of blood clot formation due to immobilization during recovery.  She presents with pain  swelling  and redness in her left calf that has gradually worsened over the past week. The patient notes the pain intensifies with standing or walking and alleviates somewhat when she elevates her leg. There is no noted fever  however  she expressed concern over the warmth of her lower limb.  Upon physical examination  her left calf appears swollen with a clear circumference difference compared to the right calf. Homans' sign was positive  eliciting pain when her foot was dorsiflexed. No ulcers or signs of any skin infection were noted.  Given her presenting symptoms  coupled with her high-risk factors such as obesity  recent orthopaedic surgery  hereditary clotting disorder  and long-term use of hormonal therapy  it is highly suggestive that Mrs. Thompson may be suffering from deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  The next step will be to confirm the diagnosis with a Duplex ultrasound  the first-line imaging procedure  and treat it early to prevent life-threatening complications such as a pulmonary embolism. The long-term management will involve anticoagulant therapy  lifestyle modifications including weight management  and smoking cessation if not already achieved. Also  post-discharge orthopedic follow-up is warranted concerning her recent hip surgery.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Name: Ms. Lopez Age: 65-years-old Sex: Female Race: Hispanic Occupation: Recently retired school teacher  Presenting complaint: Ms. Lopez reports experiencing recent onset pain and swelling in the left leg  which worsened over the past week.
