Risk factors include a recent history of travel  hereditary predisposition  sedentary lifestyle  and personal history of hypertension.

Title: Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  I. Demographic Information Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. E. He is a current smoker with a 30 pack-year history and does not use any illicit drugs or alcohol. He is a retired industrial worker  currently living with his wife in a suburban area. He is moderately overweight with a BMI of 27 and has a low activity level  being mostly sedentary.   II. Presenting Complaint Mr. E has presented with a three-day history of right leg pain and swelling. He indicates the pain is a dull ache located in the calf region and gets worse when standing or walking. He also reports feeling warm to the touch in the affected area.  III. Past Medical History Mr. E has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is taking anti-hypertensive and statins. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and has been managing it through diet and oral medication for the past 8 years. Additionally  he has a history of varicose veins. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 67  and his mother had a stroke at age 70.  IV. Risk Factors Several established risk factors are present: advanced age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  a history of varicose veins  and significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. His history of smoking and lack of exercise further increase his risk.   The patient's signs  symptoms  risk factors  age  and comorbidities point towards a high suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Despite constituting a relatively small proportion of patients with DVT  Caucasian males  particularly those above 60 years with prevalent lifestyle diseases and inactive lifestyles  are at significant risk. The most commonly reported symptoms among patients with DVT include leg pain and swelling  symptoms Mr. E presented with. Urgent evaluation is warranted in this case.  Reference: Heit  J. A. (2015). Epidemiology of venous thromboembolism. Nature reviews. Cardiology  12(8)  464–474. https://doi.org/10.1038/nrcardio.2015.83

Patient Presentation:   I present to you Mr. James McDonald  a 67-year-old Caucasian male from rural Midwestern United States. He is a retired school teacher  weighs approximately 85 kg  and stands at height of 175 cm  leading to a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 27.7. He has been married for 40 years  has three adult children  and is a non-smoker. Regarding socio-economic status  he is in the low to medium income bracket with a pension as his main source of income.  Medical History:  Mr. McDonald's medical history is significant  including chronic type II Diabetes Mellitus poorly controlled by oral hypoglycemic agents  and Hypertension controlled fairly well with ACE inhibitors. Over the past five years  he has recurrent history of venous stasis ulcers on his left lower leg  which indicates underlying chronic venous insufficiency. He also underwent a total right knee replacement eight months ago  largely due to osteoarthritis.  Presenting Condition:  Mr. McDonald presents to us today with complaints of increasingly severe pain and swelling in his left leg over the past week. The pain is in his calf and thigh  with the calf pain resembling a cramping sensation. He reports that the pain is more pronounced upon physical movement  especially when walking. He also mentions a noticeable warm sensation over the calf region  but denies any open sores or discharges. He reports that he has been progressively less mobile due to the discomfort  which has resulted in his dependence on his wife for getting around and attending to his basic needs.  On physical examination  his left lower leg is indeed swelling and red  with increased temperature compared to the right side. His pulse rates are within the normal range  and his respiratory rate is slightly increased.   Given his prior history of venous insufficiency  recent surgery  sedentary lifestyle  advanced age  and current symptoms  there is high clinical suspicion for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Mr. McDonald appears to be a classic case  as the likelihood of developing DVT increases with age  and his other risk factors are widely recognized. He needs immediate diagnostic testing for confirmation and appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of possibly fatal pulmonary embolism.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis - A Case Study Presentation  Patient Profile:  Patient's Name: Mr. William Johnson Demographics: Age: 65 years  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Veteran (previously sedentary job) Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Residence: Urban area  Past medical History: - Chronic smoker for 40 years  - Obese with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32 - Hypertensive  on medication - Underwent total knee replacement surgery 3 weeks ago  Presenting Complaints: The patient visited the emergency department with complaints of: - Progressive onset of localized swelling in the left lower leg over the past week - Warmth and tenderness over the area - Reddish discoloration of the afflicted leg - Difficulty in walking due to pain and discomfort  Given his recent surgery  these symptoms indicate a high suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  a condition that is more common among older adults  particularly those with risk factors such as surgery  obesity  prolonged immobility and hypertension.  Upon physical examination  the left leg appeared swollen and red compared to the right  and there was a pain on palpation.   To diagnose the condition  a D-Dimer test and subsequent ultrasound were ordered. The outcomes of these tests would be paramount in determining the presence and severity of DVT in the patient's left leg.  If diagnosed  the patient will likely benefit from anticoagulant therapy to dissolve the clot and prevent further occurrences. However  the treatment plan will be firmed up based on the diagnosis and the health profile of the patient.   Regular monitoring and follow-up appointments will be necessary to prevent potential complications  like Pulmonary Embolism.   Lifestyle modifications will also be suggested  such as quitting smoking  adopting a healthier diet for weight loss  and general physiotherapy for enhanced mobility and blood flow.   This case illustrates the importance of incorporating a thorough patient assessment and history taking  especially in individuals with multiple risk factors  to ensure timely diagnosis and treatment of Deep Vein Thrombosis.

Presentation of Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  - Patient Name: John Smith - Age: 60 Years old - Sex: Male - Height: 5’10” - Weight: 220 lbs. - Occupation: Accountant  Demographic Information: Mr. Smith is of Caucasian ethnicity and resides in an urban setting. He is a college graduate and lives with his wife and two children. His lifestyle is relatively sedentary due to his deskbound job and his preferred leisure activities include watching television and reading.   Medical History: Mr. Smith has a background of Type 2 Diabetes that is controlled by metformin. He also has a history of hypertension which is managed by lisinopril  and hypercholesterolemia controlled with atorvastatin.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith presents with unilateral leg swelling  specifically in his left lower leg. The swelling has been increasing progressively over the past few days. The patient mentions a constant  dull aching pain in the affected leg. He also reports feeling warmth over the area of swelling and discoloration in the skin - it appears a bit redder than the other leg.  Risk Factors Present: Given Mr. Smith's history  several risk factors can be identified. This includes his sedentary lifestyle  obesity (BMI 31.6)  existing comorbid conditions of Diabetes  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. He has no known family history of DVT or other relevant conditions.   Preliminary Diagnosis:  Based on these symptoms and risk factors  a preliminary diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is suggested.   This presentation is a typical case of DVT. DVT has a higher prevalence in individuals over 50  and males. Physical inactivity due to deskbound jobs  existing diabetes  and hypertension are common risk factors as per medical literature. It's important to note that diagnosis should be confirmed through medical imaging  preferably Doppler Ultrasound  and appropriate treatment should begin promptly to prevent potential complications like pulmonary embolism.

Presentation of Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis    Demographics:  Patient John Doe is a 53-year-old  Caucasian male  currently employed as a truck driver. He resides in a suburban setting and is a smoker with a 30-pack year smoking history. He reports no alcohol or drug use. He lives with his wife and two children.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a past medical history of long standing hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed 7 years ago  currently managed with antihypertensive medications and statin therapy. Furthermore  he also has obesity with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 54.  Presentation:  Mr. Doe presents today with a swelling in his left leg which he has noticed gradually increasing over the past week. Additionally  he mentions experiencing pain in the swollen leg  describing it as ‘aching’ and ‘cramping’  primarily in the calf area. He reports no shortness of breath  chest pain  cough  or fever. However  he did mention experiencing recent sedentary behavior due to long haul truck drives at his job. His daily routine involves sitting for prolonged periods  with limited opportunities for walking or stretching.  Considering the patient's demographics  clinical presentation  past medical history  and lifestyle factors  a provisional diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is considered. DVT is a serious condition  primarily affecting the large veins in the lower leg and thigh. It’s more common in older adults  and risk factors include immobility (as in Mr. Doe's professional lifestyle)  obesity  smoking  certain underlying conditions such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and a positive family history.  Further diagnostic workup needs to be performed  including a D-dimer test and color Doppler ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis. If the diagnosis is confirmed  the treatment goal for John would be to prevent the clot from getting bigger  prevent the clot from breaking off and moving to his lungs  and reduce the risk of future clots. This will include anticoagulant medication and lifestyle modifications. Referral to a vascular specialist might be necessary for further evaluation and management.

Slide 1: Patient Overview  We are discussing a 65-year-old Caucasian female who has recently been diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). She is a retired office worker living in rural Wisconsin  United States. She has a history of sedentary behavior and a 20 year history of smoking  though she quit 10 years ago.   Slide 2: History of Present Illness   Our patient started complaining of a sudden onset of pain and swelling in her left leg. The pain got worse when she was standing or walking. She also reported warmth over the area and redness of the skin.   Slide 3: Past Medical History   She has a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  and hyperlipidemia. Unfortunately  her compliance to prescribed medications (metformin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril) is poor. She also has a history of varicose veins.   Slide 4: Family and Social History  The patient's father had a history of stroke  and her mother died from a heart attack. She lives alone and admits that her physical activity is minimal. Her nutritional status is poor  with most meals consisting of processed and fast foods.  Slide 5: Current Medications   The patient is currently on metformin for her diabetes  atorvastatin for her high cholesterol  and Lisinopril for her hypertension.   Slide 6: Risk Factors  In summary  the risk factors for developing DVT in this patient include her age  personal history of diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  as well as a sedentary lifestyle  smoking history  and a family history of cardiovascular disease.   Slide 7: Conclusion   The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy after diagnostic confirmation of DVT. She has been counseled on the importance of medication compliance and maintaining good glycemic and blood pressure control. She was also advised to increase physical activity  maintain a balanced diet  and avoid prolonged periods of immobility.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 68 year-old Caucasian male  presenting with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). John has been experiencing increasing pain and swelling in his right lower leg over the past few days  which worsens with physical activities. He also exhibited skin discoloration around the area. However  no observable symptoms of general unwellness is noted such as fever or shortness of breath.  John is retired  lives with his wife  and he has been generally active. He quit smoking 10 years ago  drinks alcohol occasionally  and has a diet high in saturated fats. His family history is positive for thromboembolic diseases. His sister experienced a pulmonary embolism in her late 60s.  Past Medical History:  John is diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension. He has been managing his diabetes with Metformin and his hypertension with Lisinopril. Both conditions have been reasonably controlled  but his compliance to lifestyle modification has been poor. He also has a history of prostate cancer which was treated with surgical removal five years ago. He is on low-dose aspirin for prophylaxis.   About 10 days prior to the onset of his current symptoms  John underwent a right total knee replacement surgery at another hospital. The surgery was uneventful  and he was discharged home on post-operative day 3.  The present picture with a history of recent surgery  sedentary lifestyle  Cancer history  diabetes  and high fat diet  makes him an ideal candidate for possible DVT. These risk factors contribute to an increased chance of blood clot formation as indicated in abundant clinical literature. Further diagnostic efforts should be directed towards confirmed diagnosis of DVT  evaluation of possible pulmonary embolism as a complication  and correction of modifiable risk factors.

Title: CASE PRESENTATION OF DEEP VEIN THROMBOSIS  Patient Profile: Name: Mrs. Jane Davis Age: 65 years Gender: Female Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Geographic Location: Seattle  Washington  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Davis presents with swelling in the left lower leg that started gradually over the last four days. The leg is noticeably warm and tender to the touch  with a level of discomfort rated at 6 on the pain rating scale of 0-10. She reports difficulty in walking due to the pain and swelling.  Medical History: Mrs. Davis has a well-documented medical history. She is obese with a BMI of 31  and she is also hypertensive  with blood pressure currently controlled under medication. There is a history of Type II diabetes for which she is taking oral hypoglycemics. She was previously diagnosed with varicose veins three years ago  but did not have any surgery.  In terms of her family history  her mother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at an older age  thereby making her genetically predisposed.  Recent History: Mrs. Davis had a right total hip replacement surgery six weeks ago. Post-surgery  she remained sedentary most of the time due to fear of falling  and did not participate in the physiotherapy that was recommended.  Current Medications: Anti-hypertensives- Lisinopril 10mg once daily   Oral Hypoglycemic- Metformin 500mg twice daily.  Review & Assessment: Considering the recent surgery  the family history  the prolonged immobilization  and current signs and symptoms  there is a strong clinical suspicion of left lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in Mrs. Davis. Further clinical and investigational assessments are planned to confirm the suspicion and to rule out potential complications such as pulmonary embolism.  Although DVT can affect anyone  certain factors like age  obesity  surgery  sedentary lifestyle  and genetics increase the risk. Statistically  DVT is more common in Caucasian women over 60 years old who are overweight or obese.   Conclusively  this case presentation emphasizes the importance of preventive measures such as regular movement and physiotherapy  particularly after surgeries to reduce the incidence of deep vein thrombosis  especially in high-risk populations  as represented by Mrs. Davis.  Next Steps: Diagnostic tests including D-Dimer blood test and Doppler ultrasound of the lower limb  as well as consultation with a vascular specialist are advised for definitive diagnosis and treatment planning.

Patient Presentation:  Today I'm presenting Mr. Jack Curtis  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who is a resident of Seaside  Oregon. Mr. Curtis is a retired Navy officer and a non-smoker  and his BMI suggests overweight  around 27. He reports being fairly sedentary since his retirement and has a history of occasional alcohol intake.   Mr. Curtis presents with complaints of swelling  pain  and warmth in his left lower leg  symptoms that began approximately two days ago. The pain seems to intensify when he stands or walks. There is no obvious trauma  bleeding  or visual skin infection presented in the area.   His past medical history reveals that he is a diagnosed Type II Diabetic  and he has been on metformin for the past 10 years. He also has a history of hypertension from the last 5 years  which is managed by amlodipine and lisinopril. His family history includes his father who suffered from a stroke at age 75 and a brother with a history of pulmonary embolism.   In addition to these  other relevant medical history is that Mr. Curtis underwent a total knee replacement on his right leg three years ago  after which he had an uneventful course of recovery. However  he did not participate in regular physical activity post-surgery. Importantly  he has taken two long-haul flights (over 4 hours) in the past month.   Upon clinical examination  there is no immediate distress  but clear discomfort while mobilizing  primarily related to the left calf area. The left lower leg is visibly swollen and slightly erythematous as compared to the right. The calves are asymmetrical in size  with the left being 3cm larger in circumference at the widest point.   Mr. Curtis’ presentation is most consistent with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). His age  sedentary lifestyle  recent long-haul flights  obesity  hypertension  diabetes  knee surgery  and family history of thromboembolic events put him at high risk for DVT. Precise diagnostic testing like a D-Dimer test  followed by ultrasound examination of the lower limbs  will clarify the presumption.

Title: Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  I. Demographics: Patient Name: Ms. Jane Doe Age: 63 years Gender: Female  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired nurse Country of Residence: United States of America  II. Patient History:  Presenting Complaint: Ms. Doe presented with a three-day history of progressive pain and swelling in her left lower leg. She noticed the pain is worsening when she stands or walks around her home and is slightly relieved by elevating the leg. She also reported a general sense of malaise.  Past Medical History: Ms. Doe has a 5-year history of hypertension and was diagnosed with type-2 diabetes mellitus two years ago. Both conditions are well-controlled with medication  including telmisartan for her hypertension and metformin for diabetes.  Family History: The patient has a positive familial history of cardiovascular diseases  particularly her mother who suffered from a stroke at the age of 70.  Social History: Ms. Doe is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. She admits to leading a mostly sedentary lifestyle  given her retirement status and physical activities limited mainly to gardening.  Travel History:  Ms. Doe recently returned from a month-long road trip across the country. She describes being sedentary for several hours during the long drives.   III. Differential Diagnosis: Provisional diagnosis considering the clinical symptoms  and her recent prolonged travel is a deep vein thrombosis. Other possible diagnoses need to be excluded such as cellulitis  calf strain  and Baker cyst rupture.   In summary  we are dealing with a 63-year-old retired female patient with controlled hypertension and diabetes  who presents with a unilateral swollen calf and recent history of prolonged car travel  likely indicative of deep vein thrombosis. Prompt investigation and intervention are required to confirm the diagnosis and begin appropriate treatment.

Title: Patient Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  I. Demographic Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who has been living in the urban setting of Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania. He is a retired engineer who has been leading a sedentary lifestyle post-retirement. His BMI is 30.5 classifying him as obese. He is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago but has a 30-year smoking history.   II. Chief Complaint: The patient presented with complaints of pain and swelling in his right lower leg that has progressively increased over the last two days. He also reports a feeling of warmth and redness over the area  with faint discomfort when walking.  III. Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension that has been well-managed by medication (lisinopril) for the past 15 years. Apart from this  his medical history includes occasional bouts of gout but he has not had an attack in the last year. He has never had surgeries or hospital admissions apart from treatment for a small car accident 20 years ago.  IV. Family History: The patient reported that his father had coronary heart disease  and his mother suffered from type 2 diabetes. There is no known family history of any hematological condition or venous thromboembolism.  V. Personal History: The patient lives with his wife and is generally sedentary  apart from daily walks with their dog. He consumes alcohol moderately and denies any illicit drug use. He has been adhering to a high-fat diet for the majority of his adult life.  VI. Recent Activity: The patient flew back from a visit to his son in California three days ago  a trip involving about 5 hours of flight time which he admits to having spent seated. This information is significant as prolonged immobilization  such as long flights or bed rest  can pose a risk for DVT.  Summary: This patient's age  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  history of long flights  and his previous smoking history  along with his current symptoms of leg pain  swelling  and warmth  suggest a potential diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The medical history of hypertension  although well-managed  increases his risk for DVT. Therefore  this case will need to be further evaluated and confirmed by necessary investigations  and if required  managed appropriately to prevent complications  such as pulmonary embolism.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Johnson. He is a resident of Dallas  Texas  where he lives with his wife. He formerly served in the army but is currently working as an accountant. He smokes up to a pack of cigarettes daily  and his alcohol consumption is  by his account  moderate.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department with a one-week history of increasing pain and swelling in his right lower limb. He described the pain as dull aching  non-radiating  and exacerbated by walking.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has been hypertensive for 10 years treated with Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  managed with Metformin. He underwent a total knee arthroplasty on his right knee two weeks ago after an injury while gardening. He has a history of intermittent claudication but no previous history of venous thromboembolism. His family history revealed his father suffered a pulmonary embolism in his sixties.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed an edematous  erythematous  warm  and tender right calf which measured 3 cm more in circumference than the left. There was a positive Homan's sign. His vitals were stable with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  heart rate of 88 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and temperature of 37.3 C. Auscultation of the heart  lungs  and abdomen was unremarkable. His BMI was calculated to be 29 indicating overweight.  Investigations: A D-dimer test was positive. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right popliteal vein.   This case presentation depicts an individual with multiple risk factors for the development of DVT—including recent surgery  obesity  smoking  hypertension  and diabetes—thus embodying the typical high-risk profile characterized in the literature.

Title: A Presentation of a Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Profile:  The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian female named Ms. Smith  who is originally from Denver  Colorado. Ms. Smith is a divorced homemaker with two grown children.   Health History: Ms. Smith was overweight and led a sedentary lifestyle  with a body mass index (BMI) of 28. She is a former smoker  having quit five years ago. She has a medical history of Type II diabetes and hypertension  both managed with medication  but with inconsistent control. Her medications include Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. Ms. Smith also has a familial history of cardiovascular disease; her mother had a stroke at age 75  and her father had his first heart attack at age 68.  Presentation: Ms. Smith presented to the emergency department with symptoms that had begun two days ago  including swelling  pain  and warmth over the left calf area. The pain is described as a dull ache that worsens with walking and leg elevation. Ms. Smith also mentioned that she had just returned from a long international flight twelve days ago.  Investigations: Physical examination revealed left calf circumference was 3 cm greater than the right calf  warmth over the area (left calf)  and extensive edema. Lower extremity Duplex ultrasound showed a non-compressible left popliteal vein  consistent with a diagnosis of DVT. Other lab results showed elevated D-Dimer levels  but liver function tests  kidney function tests  CBC  and coagulation profile were largely unremarkable.  Clinical Impression: Given the patient's medical and family history  recent lengthy travel  clinical findings  and investigation results  she was diagnosed with acute left-sided deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Treatment: Anticoagulation therapy was initiated with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)  followed by oral warfarin. Patient education on DVT  its risks  importance of medication adherence  and lifestyle modifications such as achieving a healthy BMI  maintaining regular physical activity  and controlling her underlying conditions (diabetes  hypertension) were emphasized. Ms. Smith will have regular follow-ups for INR checks and to manage her diabetes and hypertension.   In conclusion  Ms. Smith's case underscores the importance of recognizing the interplay of both genetic and lifestyle factors in DVT development  especially in patients with existing co-morbidities like diabetes and hypertension.  References: 1. Goldhaber  Samuel Z. ""Risk factors for venous thromboembolism."" Journal of the American College of Cardiology 56.1 (2010): 1-7. 2. Heit  John A. ""Epidemiology of venous thromboembolism."" Nature reviews Cardiology 12.8 (2015): 464.

Presentation of Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Our patient  Mr. Thomas Smith  is a 62-year old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He is a retired truck driver who has been generally in good health  but has been experiencing unusual leg pain for the last four days. His occupation consisted of long hours of seated immobility  a risk factor for the development of DVT.   Mr. Smith currently lives in Chicago  Illinois with his wife of 37 years  Mrs. Linda Smith. He has two grown children and three grandchildren. His lifestyle is moderately active  he walks for half an hour daily and enjoys swimming on weekends. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially.   As per the report  Mr. Smith has been experiencing a persistent calf pain  and his left leg appears slightly swollen and red. He also described feeling warmth over the affected area. He stated the pain worsens when he stands or walks. He initially believed the pain was a muscle strain  but with its persistence and worsening  he thought it necessary to seek medical advice.  In terms of past medical history  Mr. Smith had a moderately severe myocardial infarction (heart attack) six years ago  for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He takes regular medications which include a low-dose aspirin and a statin. He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is not known to have diabetes  cancer  or any blood clotting disorders.   Mr. Smith’s father had a history of stroke at the age of 75  which makes a genetic predisposition possible for thromboembolic diseases.   In summary  Mr. Smith is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a risk profile suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. His predisposing factors include his age  prior history of heart disease  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  potential genetic predisposition  as well as prolonged periods of immobility due to his occupation. Considering the typical symptoms and the presence of several risk factors for DVT  immediate diagnostic testing is advised to confirm the suspected diagnosis.

Presentation Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Elderly Female Patient  Slide 1: Patient Introduction We are presenting the case of a 75-year-old African-American female who presents with a complaint of acute onset left leg swelling and pain for the past 48 hours. She also reports feelings of warmth over the affected area and slight shortness of breath.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics This patient represents a common demographic for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The condition is prevalent in patients above 60 years. Furthermore  multiple studies indicate African-Americans have a higher rate of DVT when compared with other racial/ethnic groups.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  The patient has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 5 years ago for which she was placed on aspirin for anticoagulation. She has had no previous episodes of thrombosis and no known family history of thrombotic events. She is a non-smoker and has moderate alcohol use.   Slide 4: Current Medications The patient is currently on Metformin for Diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Aspirin for atrial fibrillation.  Slide 5: Possible Risk Factors This patient's risk factors primarily consist of her age  African-American ethnicity  her diagnosed hypertension and diabetes  and atrial fibrillation.   Slide 6: Discussion  In conclusion  this case exemplifies the importance of appropriate assessment and early intervention in elderly patients presenting with signs of DVT. Considering her age  pre-existing medical conditions  and ethnicity  she presents a high-risk profile for DVT. It is essential that preventative strategies and risk assessment tools are utilized to reduce the risk of DVT in such patients.

Title: Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient: Mr. Rodriguez  Age: 68 Years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic  Mr. Rodriguez is a 68-year-old Hispanic male who presents to the outpatient clinic with a three-day history of progressive swelling and persistent pain in his left lower extremity. The pain is described as a dull ache  increased with walking  and somewhat relieved with elevation of the limb.  Mr. Rodriguez is diabetic and hypertensive  both conditions diagnosed twelve years ago and fairly well-controlled with medication. Five years ago  he had a transient ischemic attack but recovered well with no residual deficits. His BMI falls in obese category (BMI = 31). He has a 30-pack year smoking history but quit about ten years ago.   Despite his health issues  he maintained a reasonably active lifestyle until quite recently. Over the past six months  however  he noticed increasing fatigue and shortness of breath with his regular walking routine. In today's visit  Mr. Rodriguez also mentioned a recent long-distance travel (flight journey of approximately 8 hours)  post which he started noticing these symptoms.  He reports no known allergies  and his current medication regimen is metformin for type 2 diabetes  losartan for hypertension  and aspirin for primary stroke prevention.  Based on these symptoms  Mr. Rodriguez's past medical history  and his risk factors such as age  obesity  diabetes  and recent long-distance travel  there is a strong suspicion of deep vein thrombosis. Further investigations  including a Doppler ultrasound  would be needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Today  I'd like to present the case of a 68-year-old Caucasian male who has been diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Patient Demographics: Research shows that DVT tends to be more common in older adults  especially those above the age of 60 years. The incidence also appears to be slightly higher in males compared to females. Our patient's demographic background  therefore  is representative of the typical DVT patient population. Further demographic breakdown reveals that he's a retired manual laborer living in a suburban area. He's a widower and has two grown-up children.  Medical History: In terms of past medical history  the patient has a known case of hypertension  which has been controlled with medication. He underwent a knee replacement surgery about a year ago. Postoperatively  he also developed a blood clot in the same leg  which resolved following a course of anticoagulants. He is also a former smoker but quit about 20 years ago.  Recent Presentation: He has recently presented with pain and swelling in the left leg  which is his operative leg. He reports that the pain significantly increases when he stands and tries to walk. He has experienced no recent trauma to the affected limb and denies any changes in medication  alcohol use  or recent traveling.  On physical examination  there was significant pitting edema of the left leg. His heart rate and blood pressure were within normal limits  and lung examination revealed no abnormal findings. An ultrasound doppler was subsequently performed  which confirmed the presence of a blood clot in a deep vein of the left leg consistent with DVT.  In summary  considering his age  past history of surgery  and earlier DVT incidence  the patient exemplifies important elements of pathophysiology related to DVT  and further exemplifies the importance of risk stratification and early management for this serious condition in primary care.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis - Patient Presentation   I. Introduction  The presentation will focus on a patient with deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a common yet dangerous venous thromboembolic event in which a thrombus forms in the deep veins  typically within the lower extremities.  II. Demographics  Our illustrative patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  John  representative of the typical age and racial demographic for DVT as per literature. DVT is more common among the elder aged 60 and over  with rates higher in males compared to females. Caucasians are at a slightly higher risk for DVT compared to the liquid population.  III. Past Medical History  John leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle  he's a retired office worker and his physical activities are minimal. He has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both controlled through medication. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. Unfortunately  he recently experienced a hip fracture during a fall  which required post-surgical immobilization. This combination of factors  particularly the recent orthopedic surgery  places John at an increased risk for DVT.  IV. Presenting Symptoms  John reports having noticed swelling in his left leg for the past week. The swelling has been progressively worsening  making it difficult for him to walk comfortably. He also mentions experiencing a dull ache in his leg  especially when standing for extended periods. He hasn't recorded any fever  nor has there been any noticeable discoloration in the area.  V. Conclusion  Given the clinical presentation and past medical history  a provisional diagnosis of DVT is quite prudent. It is necessary to conduct further diagnostic procedures  including ultrasound imaging  D-dimer testing  and possibly anticoagulant treatment  under the direct guidance of a healthcare specialist.  Through this presentation  we aim to emphasize the importance of recognizing the risk factors  including ageing  sedentary lifestyle  past surgical procedures  and certain chronic conditions  to effectively diagnose and manage DVT. Early identification of these factors and patient complaints can ensure better prognosis and hopefully  prevent the occurrence of a fatal pulmonary embolism.   This case underlines the quintessential need for preventative measures  especially among high-risk groups  to prevent DVT and its associated complications.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 64-year-old White Caucasian female with a history of obesity and sedentary lifestyle who presents with unilateral  severe and painful swelling in her right lower leg. She reported a subjective fever and stated that the swelling has been progressively increasing for the past two weeks. She is a non-smoker  reports occasional alcohol use  and has a family history of deep vein thrombosis.  Patient History:  Past medical history is significant for Type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  well controlled with diet  metformin  and lisinopril therapy. She underwent total knee arthroplasty on her right knee three years ago. She denies any history of malignancy  autoimmune diseases  or coagulopathies. Family history is significant for first-degree relatives having deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.   Social History:  She worked as a school teacher for 30 years and has been retired for 4 years now. She lives with her husband and is generally sedentary with limited physical activities since she retired  possibly exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic related restrictions.   Demographic Details:  It's noted in the latest data that deep vein thrombosis is relatively common in the Caucasian population and women are slightly more likely to be affected. The patient’s age also puts her at an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis  as the risk tends to increase with age particularly after 60 years. Further  factors like obesity  history of surgery  sedentary lifestyle  diabetes  and hypertension increase her risk of developing thrombosis.    For this patient  it is crucial to initiate immediate therapeutic interventions following accurate diagnosis  given her increased risk profile and characteristic presentation. The patient will also benefit from education regarding lifestyle modifications and preventive measures.

Title: Case Study of a Patient Presenting with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Presentation:   The patient is Mrs. Brenda Clarke  a 67-year-old Caucasian female from rural Minnesota. She is retired  lives alone but has a good social system as she has her children living nearby. They confirm there is no hereditary risk in the family.   Past Medical and Social History:  Her past medical history includes Obesity (BMI 30)  high blood pressure (hypertension) being controlled with Lisinopril 10mg daily  and she quit smoking ten years ago. She does not consume alcohol. She had a total knee replacement surgery 1 month ago. There is no known allergy.   Recent Health Status:  Mrs. Clarke presented to the ER complaining about warmth  redness  and painful swelling in her right lower leg  which she first noticed three days ago. She thought it would go away but the discomfort increased over time. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath or any neurological symptoms.  Medical Literature:  According to literature  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) incidents are more common among patients above 60 years. Particularly  postoperative patients are at higher risk. Studies also tell us that DVT is more common among caucasians and obese individuals. Hypertension is found to be a risk factor  even though the association is weaker. Lastly  smoking favours coagulation and inhibits fibrinolysis  making ex-smokers more susceptible to DVT.   Risk Factors:  In the case of Mrs. Clarke  her risk factors include older age  recent knee replacement surgery  obesity  hypertension  and a history of smoking. This  along with her presenting symptoms  makes DVT a high possibility. Immediate diagnosis  typically using ultrasound followed by suitable treatment including anticoagulants  is advisable to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism.   Patient Education:  Mrs. Clarke needs to be educated about lifestyle changes to prevent future DVT  including maintaining a healthy weight  increased physical activity  and blood pressure control. She needs to be taught symptoms of Pulmonary embolism to seek immediate medical help if experienced. She should continue her prescribed anticoagulant medications to prevent the formation of new clots and growth of existing ones.   Team Communication:  Prompt communication with the interdisciplinary team including primary physician  orthopaedic  dietician  physiotherapist  and nurse is necessary to devise a comprehensive management plan including anticoagulation  diet plan  and regular exercise regimen.

Title: Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis in Patient   Patient Information:   Mr. Brown is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with a constellation of symptoms suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Presentation Information:  Mr. Brown reports he recently took a long-distance flight before noticing a swelling in his left lower leg for the past few days. The patient also complains of tenderness and warmth over the same leg in addition to slight pain when walking. Mr. Brown does not report chest pain or dyspnea. He mentions noticing his leg changed color to a bluish-purple and felt harder than usual.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Brown has a recorded history of type 2 diabetes  managed by oral hypoglycemic agents  and high cholesterol for which he's taking statins. He underwent a total knee replacement surgery two years ago. He also reports a family history of venous thromboembolism. Mr. Brown is a former smoker and has been alcohol abstinent for five years.   Socioeconomic History:  He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban community. His wife reports that he enjoys reading and gardening but has been relatively inactive since his knee surgery.   Current Medications:  Mr. Brown's current medications include Metformin and Atorvastatin. He is not on any anticoagulant medication.   This presentation and the patient’s demographics are consistent with the epidemiological data  which show that DVT incidence increases with age and is more common in males. Additionally  known risk factors for DVT including recent travel  post-surgical status  personal and family history of thromboembolism  diabetes  high cholesterol  and sedentary lifestyle are present.  This warrants a thorough evaluation for deep vein thrombosis to rule out the same and initiate prompt treatment if confirmed to avert any severe complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  I'd like to present a case of a 60-year-old Caucasian female patient who was recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient lives in an urban environment and was mostly sedentary  owing to her jobs as an accountant. She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 30  which categorizes her as overweight.   Her past medical history reveals early onset type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which have been fairly well-controlled with medication over the years. Patient also has a genetic history of thrombotic disease  as her father had pulmonary embolism. She underwent a total knee replacement surgery about a month ago  after which she was mostly immobile due to progressive knee pain.   The patient reported to the clinic with acute onset of pain in her left lower leg which was stated as a heavy ache along with swelling  warmth  and redness over the area. The pain was reportedly accentuated on walking and rated as 7/10 in severity. She denied chest discomfort  shortness of breath  hemoptysis  or palpitations.   Given the reported symptoms consistent with that of deep vein thrombosis  the physical immobility  her genetic predisposition and her recent knee surgery  she was diagnosed with DVT after appropriate diagnostics including a Doppler ultrasonography. She has been immediately started on anticoagulant therapy aimed at preventing the formation of new clots and preventing the current clot from becoming larger.   This case exhibits some important risk factors for deep vein thrombosis  such as her age  her overweight status  her type 2 diabetes and hypertension  her recent knee operation  and her long period of inactivity due to knee pain. She has no history of cancer and has taken birth control in the past. Consequently  regular follow-ups with her primary care physician and careful response to medication are crucial in her case.

Slide 1: Title: Patient Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Slide 2: Patient Introduction: Our patient is a 53-year-old Caucasian male. He works as an accounting manager  requiring prolonged periods of sitting. He has a history of smoking  moderate alcohol consumption  and a sedentary lifestyle. He is married and has two children.   Slide 3: Presenting Complaint: The patient reported a sudden onset of unilateral leg pain and swelling in the left calf region  noticed after a long period of immobility during a recent cross-country flight. The area is slightly warm to touch and is tender. There is also some noticeable reddish discoloration.    Slide 4: Past Medical History: • Hypertension: Treated with Lisinopril. • High cholesterol: Managed with diet and statin medication (Atorvastatin). • Obesity: BMI of 30.4 kg/m2. • Occasional shortness of breath but no official diagnosis of COPD or any other respiratory illnesses. • No history of diabetes  heart disease  or cancer. • No surgery or trauma in the past.   Slide 5: Family History: The family history is positive for deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in his mother  who was diagnosed at age 63. His father passed away at 72 from heart disease. One sibling is alive and well  with no history of clotting disorders.  Slide 6: Lifestyle Risk Factors: He is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history and drinks alcohol moderately. Sedentary lifestyle due to nature of work and has a diet high in processed  fatty foods.  Slide 7: Age & Demographics: Studies have shown that deep vein thrombosis is more common in older adults  particularly those over age 50  and in white populations. This patient’s demographic and lifestyle factors place him in a high-risk category for DVT.   Slide 8: Conclusion: Given his age  race  sedentary lifestyle  family history  and other health conditions (hypertension  high cholesterol  obesity)  this patient presents a typical case of DVT. The recommendations include immediate hospital admission  pharmacological intervention  and lifestyle changes.

Slide 1: Introduction - Our patient today is a 67-year-old African-American man presenting with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Slide 2: Demographics - Ethnicity: African-American - Age: 67 years old - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired truck driver  Slide 3: Chief Complaint - Chronic swelling and pain in the left lower limb.  Slide 4: History of Present Illness - The patient reports increased swelling and discomfort in his left leg over the past week. - His symptoms have progressively worsened over the course of the week.  - He denies any recent trauma  long-distance travel  or history of immobilization.  Slide 5: Past Medical History - History of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both controlled with medication. - He was a smoker but quit 15 years ago. - No previous history of venous thromboembolism (VTE) or major surgeries.   Slide 6: Family History - Father had a stroke at age 75. - Mother diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.  Slide 7: Social History - The patient has retired from his long-haul truck driving job 2 years ago. - He is widowed  living alone  and has a support structure in place from his 2 children who live nearby. - He reports a previous history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Slide 8: Physical Examination - Presence of edema  warmth  and tenderness characterized the physical exam of his left lower extremity. The rest of the physical examination was normal.  Slide 9: Conclusion - Given his symptoms  medical history  and risk factors  we suspect deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further diagnostic testing will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis and to consider appropriate treatment options.  Slide 10: References - Any relevant references used for the presentation.   Please note that African-American ethnicity and older age are associated with increased risk of DVT. Male sex and occupations requiring prolonged immobilization like truck driving could also elevate the risk. Conditions like hypertension and diabetes can contribute to the development of DVT. The above depicted case is thus a representative demographic profile as per the literature.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in Middle-aged Caucasian Male  Introduction: Presenting a case of a 53-year-old male  Mr. John Park  who has been diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). He is a Caucasian from Los Angeles  California  working in a white-collar job with a sedentary lifestyle.   Demographic Information: Mr. Park is married with two children and lives in a suburban locality. He does not have any habits of substance use  such as smoking or alcohol consumption. His diet consists mostly of processed food  and he has a low intake of fresh fruits and vegetables.  Past Medical history: Mr. Park was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  and he is currently under medication with Metformin. He also has a history of hypertension  controlled with antihypertensives. There's no known genetic predisposition to cardiovascular diseases within his family. However  Mr. Park had a sedentary lifestyle for the last 10 years  with little or no physical activity  possibly contributing to his current vascular condition.  Presenting Complaints: He presented to the ER with complaints of tenderness  swelling  and pain in his left lower leg  which gradually developed over a week. As the pain became acute and mobility was impaired  it triggered him to seek medical care.  Preliminary Diagnosis: As per the physical examination and Doppler ultrasonography  deep vein thrombosis has been confirmed.   Conclusion: Considering Mr. Park's past medical history  his current sedentary lifestyle and recent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis  immediate intervention and lifestyle modification are strongly recommended with necessary pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatment to manage the existing condition and prevent further complications.  This case represents the large demographic of middle-aged  sedentary adults with lifestyle induced co-morbidities who are at high risk of DVT. Consequently  the importance of regular exercise  healthy dietary habits and regular health check-ups cannot be emphasized enough in this demographic group.

Title: A Case Presentation on Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Profile:  Patient Initials: J.S  Sex: Female  Age: 58  Race & Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Office clerk  Location: Urban area  Midwest USA   Presenting Issue:  The patient presents with unilateral swelling and discomfort in her left leg - noticeable redness  warmth  and tenderness along the course of the vein. The symptoms started gradually  about a week ago.   Medical History:  The patient has a known medical history of obesity and hypertension. She also states that she has been relatively immobile in recent weeks due to her desk job and due to COVID-19 stay-at-home measurements. Her BMI is within the obese range. She had a surgical procedure (hysterectomy) more than a decade ago. There is no reported history of smoking or alcohol abuse  however  the patient has been on birth control pills for hormone replacement therapy since her surgery.   Family History:  Her mother suffered from varicose veins and her father had a history of coronary artery disease. Both maternal and paternal grandparents had stroke histories.  Assessment:  Given the patient's presenting symptoms and her personal medical history along with the family history of cardiovascular diseases  the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is suspected.  Note:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a common condition  affecting approximately 1 in 1 000 persons per year  with comparable incidence across the developed world. Approximately two-thirds of DVT cases occur in individuals aged over 60 years  and incidence decreases with youth. Evidence shows DVT can disproportionately affect individuals with a history of obesity  hypertension  prolonged immobility or use of hormonal pills  as seen in this patient.

Title: A Case Presentation on Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Profile:  Our patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male identified as Mr. X. He is a resident of Chicago  Illinois and is a retired mechanical engineer by profession. He has a history of smoking  with an estimate of 30 pack-years. His family background is significant  as both his father and older brother had venous thrombosis. He is married with two children  and he lives with his wife  leading a sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting History:  Mr. X walked into the Emergency Department complaining of persistent sharp pain and swelling in his right calf muscle  which has been escalating over the past few days. The pain intensifies upon standing or walking. There have also been noted changes in the skin color around the painful area  tending towards a bluish-purplish hue. He reports episodes of breathlessness  primarily following physical exertion.  Past Medical History:  The patient was previously diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes 5 years ago  which he manages with prescribed medications. He additionally underwent a hernia surgery two years back. He has a history of occasional alcohol consumption  though moderate  and reports high consumption of red meat in his diet. He has not previously experienced or been diagnosed with any clotting disorders.  Pertinent Demographics and Epidemiology:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) incidence typically peaks in those aged 60-70 and is slightly more common in male patients. Caucasians and those with a family history of thrombosis are at a higher risk. Notably  lifestyle factors such as smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and a diet rich in red meat have all been linked to higher DVT incidence.  This patient case presentation is a characteristic representation of typical high-risk demographic factors for DVT  underpinning the importance of managing modifiable risks and maintaining diligent surveillance in older patients with predisposing factors. Interventions should focus on lifestyle modification and effective disease management  alongside appropriate therapeutic measures.   References:  1. Heit JA  et al. Trends in the Incidence of Deep Vein Thrombosis and Pulmonary Embolism: A 25-Year Population-Based Study. Arch Intern Med. 1998;158(6):585–593. 2. Naess IA  et al. Incidence and mortality of venous thrombosis: a population-based study. Journal of Thrombosis and Haemostasis 2007;5(4):692-699.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in an Elderly Caucasian Male  Introduction:   Today  I present a case study of Mr. Henry McDonald  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  who presents with signs and symptoms associated with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Demographics:  The patient was born and lives in Springfield  Illinois. He's married with 3 children and recently retired from his work as a truck driver. His primary language is English  and he completed a high school education.   Presenting symptoms:  Mr. McDonald reported swelling  pain  tenderness  and redness in the affected leg  more specifically in his left calf. He also stated that the discomfort worsened when he flexed his foot or stood up. He noticed these symptoms about a week ago  but he thought it was just muscle cramps due to his age.   Past Medical History:  Mr. McDonald was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia at the age of 62 and was put on antihypertensive and statin therapy. The patient also has a significant history of 35 years of smoking but quit 8 years ago. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a diet low in fruits and vegetables  favoring processed and fried foods.  In 2017  he underwent hip replacement surgery for which he was immobilized for an extended period. His family history shows a significant correlation  with his father experiencing a pulmonary embolism  and his grandfather suffering from recurrent DVTs.   His current medications include atenolol for his hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.   Inference:  The age of the patient  his personal medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  major surgery  immobilization  smoking history  and strong family history of DVT and embolism predispose him to high DVT susceptibility. Given his demographic and clinical presentation  early recognition and appropriate management of Mr. McDonald's case are necessary to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Martinez is a 65-year-old Hispanic female with a past medical history of obesity (BMI: 32)  hypertension  and a recent total knee replacement surgery one month ago. She presents to the emergency department complaining of progressive left leg pain and swelling for a week  which is not alleviated by rest or over-the-counter analgesics. She notes her leg appears to be a reddish-purple color  feels warm to touch and has become increasingly difficult to move due to discomfort.  The pain is a constant  dull ache  which is gradually getting more severe  rating it 7 out of 10 today compared to a 4 out of 10 a week ago. She denies any recent trauma  falls  or injury but admits to prolonged periods of immobility since her knee surgery. Further  she has no history of smoking  special dietary habits  or drugs  but states she was on an oral contraceptive pill a few years ago. She is currently on medication for her hypertension and post-surgical pain management.  There is no history of a similar episode in the past and denies chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  or syncope. She denies any recent travel. No known allergies. Family history is significant for a brother who suffered a stroke in his seventies.  This patient’s presentation  combined with her recent orthopedic surgery and significant immobility  raises concern for a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:  Edward Roberts  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency room with complaints of pain  tenderness  warmth  and swelling in his left calf muscle that started 2 days ago. He describes the pain as dull aching and mentions that it amplifies when he stands or moves his left leg. He denies any trauma to the area.  Patient Demographics:  Edward is a retired mechanic who still manages a small garage from his home. He lives with his wife and pets in a rural town. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history  having quit five years ago. His body mass index calculates to 29  which implies being overweight. He has a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement.  Past Medical History (PMH):  Edward was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago  for which he takes a daily regimen of Lisinopril. He also has Type II diabetes managed with Metformin. Last year  he underwent total knee arthroplasty of the left knee due to a longstanding history of osteoarthritis. Postoperatively  he was on prophylactic anticoagulation with Enoxaparin for a month.   Edward admits that he has not been moving or walking as much since his surgery. He admits that for the last few weeks he has mostly been sitting or lying down because of some ongoing personal stress and depression  which was diagnosed by his primary care physician a month ago. He also notes a recent long car trip which lasted for about 6 hours.  Family History (FH):   Edward's mother suffered from chronic venous insufficiency and his brother developed a deep vein thrombosis following a surgical procedure.  Given his PMH and current complaints  the physician is concerned about the potential for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Robert Johnson is a 62-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with his wife  complaining of increased redness  pain  and swelling in his left lower leg over the past 2-3 days. He describes the pain as a soreness and states it feels ""tight"" and ""heavy."" The pain is aggravated by standing and lessened somewhat when he elevates his leg.   Mr. Johnson is a retired truck driver and has a 50-pack year history of smoking  for which he quit about five years ago. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he is on medication. He also underwent a left knee replacement surgery about five years ago due to severe osteoarthritis. His family history is relevant for both parents having some form of cardiovascular disease.   Mr. Johnson denies any recent long-distance travel or period of immobility. However  he did recently have an outpatient procedure to remove a mole about two weeks ago. Despite discontinuing aspirin prior the procedure as advised  he reports non-adhering to clinician's advice to restart the medication afterwards.  Mr. Johnson came to the ER because his wife was worried as he seemed slightly out of breath from walking across the room though it may also be due to him being generally worried about the pain and swelling in his leg.

A 65-year-old African-American female presents to the clinic complaining of unilateral leg pain in her left calf  which she notes has been persistent and worsening over the last three days. The pain is described as a constant  dull ache with occasional sharp twinges. She denies any recent trauma to the leg but mentions general fatigue and shortness of breath. The patient also reports mild swelling and erythema in the same area of discomfort.   She mentions a history of sedentarism due to her job as an administrative assistant. She takes no regular medications and has no known drug allergies. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension  obesity (BMI: 35)  and a hormonal contraceptive use for the last five years. In addition  her mother had a history of pulmonary embolism.  On inspection  there is visible swelling  redness  and tenderness along the line of the left calf. The patient demonstrates pain on dorsiflexion of her left foot (Positive Homan's sign). Examination findings and symptoms indicate a possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Genetic predisposition  elevated BMI  and contraceptive use raise additional concerns for DVT.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Robert Mitchell  a 58-year-old African American man  presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of progressively worsening pain and swelling in his right calf. He also complained of tenderness in the same area. The pain was described as a constant aching sensation  rated at 6/10 on the visual analogue scale. Moreover  he reported a low-grade fever of 38.1°C (100°F) for the past day.  He denied any recent injury  travel  or surgical intervention but did admit to being sedentary due to his job as a truck driver. No other associated symptoms such as chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations were reported. There were no skin changes other than swelling. He mentioned the similar presentation happened three years ago  which was diagnosed as deep vein thrombosis after investigation.  He has a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and was an ex-smoker (quit 5 years ago). He is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  and low-dose Aspirin. There is no history of known drug allergies. His family history is significant with both parents being diabetic and his father had a stroke at the age of 65. He does not consume alcohol and denies any illicit drug use.   On examination  there was noticeable swelling on the right leg compared to the left  warm to touch with visible veins. The area was tender to palpation and Homan’s sign was positive. His vital signs were stable aside from the slight fever. The rest of physical examination was unremarkable.   Considering his symptoms and past medical history  there is strong suspicion of a recurrent episode of deep vein thrombosis. The patient is likely to require a Doppler ultrasound exam to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department with his wife  complaining of progressive pain and swelling on his left lower limb for the last 48 hours. The pain has increased significantly in intensity with any kind of movement. He also reported mild breathlessness for the last 5 hours.  Relevant History:   The patient is a retired school teacher who has remained largely sedentary since retirement 5 years ago. He has a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension maintained under control with oral medications. He has a known history of recurrent DVT episodes after a bilateral knee replacement surgery 6 years ago and takes oral anticoagulants  but he admits inconsistent use due to forgetfulness. He also reports he recently traveled a long journey by car. The patient is a smoker and also consumes moderate amounts of alcohol.   Family History:   His father had a history of peripheral artery disease and his mother suffered from recurrent episodes of DVT. His older brother died from a pulmonary embolism following a hip replacement surgery.   Social History:  The patient lives with his wife and is currently retired  indulging in sedentary activities like reading and gardening. The patient's wife reports concern with his habit of sitting with his legs crossed for prolonged hours. He smokes a pack of cigarettes a day and consumes a moderate amount of alcohol  mainly in the form of red wine in the evening.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  his left leg appeared to be swollen with warmth and redness evident in the calf area. There was tenderness to touch  and he winced in pain during passive dorsi-flexion of the foot (positive Homan's sign). His vital signs were slightly elevated with a heart rate of 98 bpm and a blood pressure of 145/95. His respiratory rate was slightly high at 20 breaths/min and his oxygen saturation was slightly low at 92% on room air.  No other significant findings were noticed in his chest  cardiovascular and gastrointestinal examination. His neurological examination was largely normal except for the pain in the involved leg.  Given his symptoms  relevant medical history  recent travel and the physical findings  a likely diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was considered and confirmed with a Doppler ultrasound which showed a clot in the left posterior tibial vein.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Helen is a 66-year-old African-American female presenting to the emergency department with a three-day history of pain  swelling and redness in her left lower leg. The pain appears to be worsening  and she is experiencing difficulty walking.  She reported that she has been recently immobile due to a one-week hospital stay for pneumonia. Further history reveals that she does not have a history of smoking or use of oral contraceptives  but she was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension about 8 years back. She has been compliant with her medication. She had a normal mammogram and colonoscopy within the past five years. She has no known drug allergies. She reports no history of venous thromboembolism but her father and brother both had DVT.  On examination  her left calf appeared swollen  red and slightly warmer than the other leg. The swelling extended from the calf to just below the knee. There was marked calf tenderness. Her heart rate was 88 beats per minute  blood pressure 135/90 mmHg  and her BMI was 30.5.  Upon further investigations  elevated D-dimer levels and an abnormal Doppler ultrasound of the left leg  confirmed the diagnosis of deep venous thrombosis. She was subsequently admitted for anticoagulation therapy and a further workup for hereditary thrombophilia  considering her familial history of DVT.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old African-American female presents to the emergency department complaining of acute onset  severe left leg pain that has been worsening over the last few days. She describes the pain as a constant  deep ache in her left calf  rating it as an 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain gets worse when walking and is associated with warmth and erythema. The left leg appears noticeably swollen.  Past Medical History: Hypertension controlled with lisinopril  diagnosed 10 years ago. She also has a history of type II diabetes mellitus which is well-controlled with metformin. She had hip replacement surgery on her left leg six months ago.  Social History: Patient is a retired schoolteacher  currently living alone. She is non-smoker and only drinks alcohol occasionally. She says she has been less active in the past few months due to pain from her hip surgery.  Family History: Mother and older sister had a stroke. Father died of a heart attack.  Medications: She takes her prescribed medications regularly - Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for type II diabetes.  She has no known drug allergies.   The patient is worried because she has recently been reading about blood clots and their complications and is concerned her symptoms may be related.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian female presents with complaints of a one-week history of increasing pain in her left leg  which is visibly swollen and discolored. She describes the pain as ""aching "" and reports it has steadily gotten worse over the past few days. She has also noticed a slight increase in her body temperature. She denies any recent physical injury  trauma  or prolonged periods of immobilization.   She has a past medical history that includes type II diabetes and obesity  with a body mass index (BMI) of 32. She has a 40 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking approximately one month ago. She also mentions recently started hormone replacement therapy (HRT)  prescribed by another practitioner for post-menopausal symptoms. She has a family history of deep vein thrombosis  with both her mother and grandmother having suffered from the condition. She is currently on Metformin for her diabetes.  Her vital signs are within normal limits  except for a slightly elevated body temperature of 37.7 C˚. On examination  there is visible edema  warmth  and erythema of the left lower limb. There is tenderness along the path of the deep venous system. A D-dimer test is ordered which comes back positive. Given her signs  symptoms  and risk factors  a provisional diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis is considered.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Robert Johnson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with a complaint of swelling and pain in his right leg of 3 days duration. The pain is described as constant  aching in nature  rated as about 6/10 in intensity  and is not relieved by rest or over-the-counter pain medications. Examination reveals erythema  warmth  and increased calf circumference in the right leg compared to the left.   The patient has a significant  albeit moderate  smoking history of 15 pack-years but quit 10 years prior. Past medical history is relevant for well-managed hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Additionally  he reveals that approximately 6 weeks ago  he underwent a total hip replacement surgery on the right side. Since then  he has been largely sedentary  spending most of his time in bed or sitting.   Mr. Johnson does not report any history of other cardiovascular or clotting disorders. He denies any recent travel  trauma  current medication  or over-the-counter supplement use. His surgical procedure had no post-operative complications and was conducted with perioperative DVT prophylaxis  which was discontinued upon discharge.  Consideration for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis is of high priority based on the clinical findings  his advanced age  recent major surgery  prolonged immobilization  and his smoking history convincing risk factors for venous thromboembolism.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson  a 68-year-old African-American female  presents to the clinic with a complaint of new onset unilateral leg swelling and discomfort  predominantly in her right calf. She reports symptoms began five days ago after a 6-hour car drive from visiting her daughter. Ms. Johnson reports the swelling has progressively worsened  accompanied by a deep-seated pain  described as an ""ache"" that worsens with walking. She denies any trauma  injury or insect bite to the area.   Ms. Johnson's past medical history is significant for hypertension and obesity (body mass index of 30 kg/m2)  and she had an uneventful knee replacement surgery 4 years ago. Additionally  she had been on oral contraceptives for a period during her early 50s to manage symptoms of menopause. She has a notable family history of a brother who had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 72. She stopped smoking 10 years ago  consumes alcohol occasionally  and is not currently on any regular medications  except for occasional acetaminophen for osteoarthritic pain.  Considering her advanced age  history of orthopedic surgery  recent prolonged travel  obesity and family history  Ms. Johnson is at a heightened risk for deep vein thrombosis. Her clinical presentation also indicates a possible deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jackson is a 66-year-old retired African American firefighter who presented to the emergency department late Sunday evening with complaints of a swollen and painful right leg which he noticed gradually worsening over the last four days. He also reported mild shortness of breath which he initially attributed to his sedentary lifestyle since his retirement. He denies any history of chest pain  coughing  or trauma to his legs.   Mr. Jackson has a medical history of controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type II diabetes mellitus. He underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting three years ago. He doesn't smoke cigarettes but admits to regular moderate alcohol consumption.   A review of his systems indicated that he had not been feverish  nor had he experienced other respiratory symptoms like a cough. He mentioned recently making a long-distance car travel to visit his daughter and grandchildren. He denies any recent surgeries or immobility that could contribute to his symptoms.   On examination  his right leg appeared red and was warmer than the left one. Homan’s sign was positive on the right side.  His initial vital signs in the emergency department are as follows:  - Temperature: 98.6 F - Blood Pressure: 132/84 mmHg - Heart Rate: 98 beats per min - Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths per min - O2 Saturation: 97% on room air  Given his symptoms  clinical presentation  recent history of prolonged car travel  and his cardiovascular medical history  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is suspected. The emergency department physician orders appropriate diagnostic tests.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Ms. Johnson  a 68-year-old African-American female  retired teacher.  Primary Complaint: Ms. Johnson presents with acute onset left calf pain that has become progressively worse over the past few days.  History of Present Illness: The pain reportedly began 3 days ago  which she initially described as a mild discomfort. Since yesterday  it has progressively become more severe and is presently associated with calf redness and a feeling of warmth over the area. The pain periodically increases in intensity when walking or moving her leg.  Past Medical History: Ms. Johnson has a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI of 32)  and she underwent a total right knee replacement surgery 10 days ago. She is also a smoker and has type II diabetes controlled via oral hypoglycemic agents. There is no personal or family history of clotting disorders. There's also a history of intermittent atrial fibrillation for which she is on chronic anticoagulation with warfarin.  Social History: Patient lives with her husband in the upper floor of a two-story home. Currently  she is mostly sedentary post-her recent knee surgery  which is a significant change from her usual activity level where she took daily walks and was involved in community activities. Her diet is now predominantly prepared by her husband  who while well-meaning  may not consider all her dietary restrictions all the time. She continues to be a smoker  smoking half-a-pack per day.  Physical Examination: Patient is afebrile  blood pressure is 142/88 mmHg  the heart rate is 78 bpm  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Swelling  erythema  and tenderness are noted in the left calf region. The calf diameters are unequal  left calf three centimeters larger than the right calf.  Impression: Given the recent surgery  change in mobility  and her clinical presentation  there is a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James Eaton is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the Emergency Department with complaints of a significantly swollen  warm  and painful right lower leg which has been worsening over the past week. He reports a dull ache in the calf  slightly relieved with rest but exacerbated by standing or walking. He denies trauma to the leg.  He works as a software engineer and spends long hours in a sedentary position. He recently embarked on a 12-hour international flight for a business meeting 10 days ago and noticed the swelling upon returning home. He is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year history  but quit smoking ten years ago. He consumes alcohol socially.  His past medical history includes controlled hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has no known allergies but is on a daily regimen of Amlodipine and Atorvastatin. There is a family history of venous thromboembolic diseases; his mother suffered from recurrent DVTs in the later years of her life.  Based on the history provided and physical examination  Mr. Eaton's presentation is suggestive of a possible Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).
