A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a history of obesity  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents with a 2-day history of right calf pain and recent swelling. She denies having any injuries or trauma to her leg. Over the past 48 hours  the patient has noticed progressive pain in her right calf  especially when standing or walking. Her past medical history is significant for sedentary lifestyle and a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg 10 years ago. She has been postmenopausal for 15 years  doesn't smoke  and doesn't consume alcohol. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or any abnormal bleeding. Her medications include lisinopril  atorvastatin  and a daily aspirin. She denies any allergies to medication. She used to work as a secretary until she retired 5 years ago. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease.

Patient Presentation: Ms. Nicole Thompson  a 58-year-old Caucasian woman  presents to the emergency room with a complaint of increasing pain  swelling  and warmth in her right calf since the last three days. Ms. Thompson mentions the pain worsening upon walking in the last 24 hours which raised her concerns and made her decide to visit the ER.  Ms. Thompson works as an executive and has a recent history of prolonged air travel two weeks ago where she flew from New York to Sydney  and back within a span of 5 days. She reports residing primarily sedentary lifestyle due to her work demands and has recently gained significant weight.   Past medical history: She is a nonsmoker but has been on oral contraceptives for the last 4 years due to menopausal symptoms. She also has a history of hypertension  hypercholesteremia  and a family history that includes a sister who had a pulmonary embolism in her 40s.  Examination shows the right leg is visibly swollen compared to the left and slightly erythematous. Vital signs are within normal limits. D-dimer test is ordered and she is advised to undergo a Doppler ultrasound of the leg due to the high suspicion of deep vein thrombosis.   This clinical presentation is relevant given the risk factors including age  recent long-haul travel  sedentary lifestyle  oral contraceptive use  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and family history of clotting disorders that all significantly increase the likelihood of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Profile:  A 65-year-old  obese Caucasian female presents to the clinic with a two-day history of increasing pain  warmth  and swelling of the left lower extremity.  Presenting Complaint: Unilateral swelling and pain in the left calf that has been gradually worsening. She notes that the pain is more severe when she is walking and eases when she elevates the leg. She also has reported a mild fever.  Past Medical History:  Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago and has been on Metformin since. She had a total knee replacement on the left side two months ago. She reports medication compliance but has poor control of her blood sugar. Additionally  she has a 30 pack-year smoking history.  Family history:  Father had a stroke at age 72  and mother had varicose veins.  Social History:  Retired school teacher  lives alone. She admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in processed foods. Denies alcohol or drug use.   Review of Systems: Recently had a urinary tract infection (UTI) that was treated with antibiotics. No other significant findings.  Given the patient's prolonged immobilization following her knee replacement surgery  her obesity  a history of smoking and diabetes  she is at increased risk for Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Physical examination:  Vital signs within normal limits; Slight fever of 100.2 F; Warm  erythematous and swollen left calf; Palpable cord felt along the line of the left calf veins; Negative Homan’s sign. Remaining examination unremarkable.  Based on the clinical presentation  the patient is suspected to have left-sided deep vein thrombosis and further investigations like a D-Dimer test and venous Doppler of the left lower extremity will be ordered to confirm the diagnosis. Urgent treatment with anticoagulants would be initiated to prevent the clot from extending and breaking off  which could lead to a pulmonary embolism  a serious and life-threatening complication of DVT.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of noticeable left leg swelling and pain. He describes the pain as dull and constant  rating it 4 on a scale of 10. In addition  he has also noticed slight redness and warmth over his left calf muscle. Mr. Thomas denies any recent injury or trauma to the lower extremities but admits to a prolonged car journey of about 6 hours two weeks ago. He has not experienced any shortness of breath or chest pain.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a previous episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) approximately 5 years back which was managed with anticoagulation therapy. Patient is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago  but reports occasional social alcohol use.   Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases with his father suffering from myocardial infarction at the age of 70. The patient is overweight with a BMI of 30 and he lives a sedentary lifestyle. He is retired  lives with his wife  and has a strong social support network.   This information makes Mr. Thomas at high risk for recurrent deep vein thrombosis. He should be further investigated with appropriate diagnostic imaging studies  such as Doppler ultrasound of the leg.

A 50-year-old Caucasian male  John  comes in for consultation complaining of pain in his left calf  associated with erythema and mild edema. The pain tends to get worse when he stands or walks  but improves slightly when lying down. John is a former smoker  with a 20-pack-year smoking history. He is currently an executive in a multinational corporation leading a sedentary lifestyle.   John also shares a significant past medical history of recent surgery for hip replacement 3 weeks ago. He also has a family history of venous thromboembolism where his mother had pulmonary embolism at the age of 60. John is obese with a BMI of 31 and was recently treated for hypertension. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or other concerning symptoms. He has been using a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for post-operative pain relief.   He has been non-compliant with prolonged immobilization as he returned to work soon after surgery and travelled internationally by air for business meetings. This travel involved long flights of over six hours. He denies any history of trauma  illicit drug use or recent infections. His medications include aspirin  a stationary blood pressure tablet  and the occasional NSAID when he has flare-ups of pain post his hip surgery.

Patient Presentation:  John Doe  an overweight 57-year-old caucasian male truck driver  presents to the emergency department with complaints of a progressively worsening  unimanual  red swollen leg that is warmer than the rest of his body. The patient says the pain is primarily in the calf area of his right leg  rating it as 7 out of 10 on the pain scale  and has been present for around three days.   He reports a slight fever of 37.5℃ and fatigue but denies having recent trauma  surgery  or prolonged periods of bed rest. He also denies any respiratory symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain  as well as existence of similar symptoms in the past.   John has a past medical history of type II diabetes and hypertension  and he has been taking metformin and an ACE inhibitor respectively for the last 5 years. Family history reveals his mother had a stroke at the age of 73.   His resting pulse rate is 92 BPM and BP is 140/90 mmHg. He has a BMI of 29  and this puts him in the overweight category. He is a non-smoker but admits to drinking a glass of wine every other night. He reports low physical activity due to his long work hours spent mostly sitting in his truck.   Given the potential for deep vein thrombosis with his symptoms  and considering his lifestyle and family medical history  appropriate medical follow-ups and diagnostic tests  such as a D-dimer test or an ultrasound scan  are recommended.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Maria Rodriguez  a 53-year-old Hispanic female  arrives at the emergency department presenting with a two-day history of increasing left calf pain and swelling. She notes that the pain is worse when she stands and walks and somewhat relieves on leg elevation. She also reports a sensation of warmth over the swollen region and mild dyspnea. She has noticed her left leg appearing red and a bit enlarged compared to her right leg.  Maria recently underwent a total knee replacement surgery on her left knee three weeks ago  and her recovery was uncomplicated. She has a history of obesity (BMI of 32.6)  and she has been under medication for Hypertension since the past six years.  She does not have any known allergies but admits a 30 pack-year smoking history  although she quit smoking two years ago. She confesses that she has been bedridden for the most extended period after her knee surgery. The review of systems was significant for increased night sweats. She denies chest pain  cough  or hemoptysis.  The patient lives with her husband  has two children  and works as a school teacher. Her father had an episode of stroke at 65  and her mother has type 2 diabetes.  Upon physical examination  her left calf measurement is significantly larger than her right. Her vitals are stable - blood pressure is controlled  but the heart rate slightly elevated at 92 bpm.  Based on her recent surgery  immobility  personal history of smoking  and the physical symptoms she presents  Maria is at a high risk of having a Deep Vein Thrombosis. The medical personnel should  therefore  carry out further diagnostic procedures such as a Doppler Ultrasound test or D-dimer test to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 62-year-old overweight Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with complaint of unilateral leg swelling and pain that's been present for the past week. The pain is described as a constant dull aching sensation  at about a 6/10 on a pain severity scale  located in the calf area of the right leg  which worsens after being on his feet for extended periods. No history of trauma to the area. The patient also reports mild shortness of breath but no chest pain  cough or hemoptysis. Physical examination revealed redness  warmth  and tenderness in the affected leg.   The patient has a significant past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which are controlled with medication. He underwent hip replacement surgery two months prior on the opposite side and was not ambulating as regularly as before. His family history includes his father who had a stroke and a brother with a history of blood clots in the legs. He reports mild alcohol use and is a former smoker  with cessation three years ago. He denies illicit drug use.   This patient profile is representative of typical deep vein thrombosis (DVT) cases which often occur in those over 60 who are overweight  with additional risk factors such as recent surgery  family history of blood clots  and other chronic conditions.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Cook is a 56-year-old white male from New York City who presented to the emergency department with complaints of swelling  warmth  and pain in his left lower leg since the last two days. He states that he noticed a slight cramping feeling and aching in the region of his left calf muscle initially  which has progressively worsened over time. He mentions that he was recently on a long return flight from Melbourne and felt some leg discomfort during and after the flight. The patient works as a lawyer and leads a sedentary lifestyle  with minimal physical activity.   Mr. Cook has a past medical history significant for hypertension  obesity (BMI 30.2 kg/m2) and he is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history. He has been compliant with his antihypertensive medications. He denies any history of trauma  surgery  or a family history of blood clots. He has not been regularly monitored for cholesterol due to his intense workload  but last check a year ago showed borderline high levels.   The swelling in his left leg is not associated with any shortness of breath  chest pain  hemoptysis  or cough. He denies any recent change of diet or medication  except his doctor recently increased his dose of antihypertensive medication due to poorly controlled blood pressure. He has had no fever or infectious symptoms  and no similar episodes in the past.   In summation  Mr. Cook's demographics  medical history  recent long-haul flight  sedentary profession  and current symptoms are all suggestive of a strong possibility of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Immediate evaluation is required.

Patient Presentation:   A Caucasian woman  aged 63  presented to our clinic complaining of a persistent and gradually worsening pain in her left calf over a period of two weeks. Notably  the patient reported some mild swelling and redness starting around five days prior. The pain reportedly increased when walking or standing for prolonged periods  which led to her seeking help.   She denied any recent injuries or surgeries. She doesn't smoke but she consumes alcohol occasionally. She's not taking any birth control pills or hormone replacement therapy. She is overweight with a BMI of 31  has moderate hypertension which is well-managed with amlodipine and a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus under control with metformin.  Her family history includes a brother who had a pulmonary embolism in his late fifties and a mother who had varicose veins. She also reported a sedentary lifestyle as she recently retired as an office clerk and tends to sit for prolonged periods reading or watching TV.  This patient's risk factors for DVT mainly include her higher age  family history of venous thromboembolism  sedentary lifestyle  overweight obesity  hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and perhaps the reported prolonged sitting in her daily activities.   Summarizing the case  this middle-aged  overweight woman with a relevant past medical history and relevant behavioral risk factors presented with symptomatology highly consistent with a possible deep vein thrombosis.+

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Adah  a 65-year-old African American woman  presented to our ambulatory care clinic complaining of a 3-day history of unilateral left leg swelling  pain  warmth  and redness. She described the pain as a persistent  throbbing ache that has been gradually intensifying and is notably worse when standing or walking.   Her past medical history includes obesity with a BMI of 35  history of stage II breast cancer for which she underwent cancer treatment (chemotherapy and radiation) approximately 4 years ago. She is currently in remission. Mrs. Adah also mentioned that she recently recovered from a mild ischemic stroke  for which she had been hospitalized about six weeks ago.   Her family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. She is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol regularly. She is currently taking aspirin  a statin for her elevated cholesterol levels  and a calcium supplement.  Mrs. Adah used to work as a school teacher and currently enjoys a sedentary lifestyle due to her retirement and overall health conditions. Due to her history of breast cancer  she has been on hormonal therapy.  After initial assessment and considering her past medical history  obesity  recent immobility  and possible inherited risk of thrombosis  a possible diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was considered and she was sent to the emergency department for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female presented to the clinic with a two-day history of progressive  unilateral swelling and pain in her left lower leg. The pain is described as aching and is more severe when standing. The patient noticed the onset of symptoms after a 6-hour long haul flight. Mild diffuse erythema is localized to the affected leg  which was warm to touch but without any discernible cord.    The patient is a homemaker  is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history. She quit smoking 10 years ago. She has a history of hypertension under control with lisiniopril  uses hormone replacement therapy for her menopausal symptoms  and had an uneventful total knee replacement surgery 5 years prior. No known drug allergies. There is a family history of thrombosis in her sister who developed a pulmonary embolism in her fifties.   Her vital signs are stable  with a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  heart rate 70 bpm  respiratory rate 14/min  temperature 37°C  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. The swelling was measured at about 3 cm greater circumferential dimension than the asymptomatic leg. The patient denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  recent surgery  injury or malignancy.   Given her history and presentation  the patient is assessed to be at high risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation  Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female. She is a retired school teacher  a wife  and a mother of two adult children and presents to the clinic accompanied by her daughter. She resides in Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania. She has recently returned from a long-haul flight from Europe where she vacationed with her family.  She has a BMI of 28  indicating overweight status and does not smoke. Her medical history is notable for hypertension managed on Lisinopril and hyperlipidemia managed on Atorvastatin. She also has a past medical history of hormone replacement therapy post-menopause.   She reports experiencing unilateral and unexplained swelling in her left lower leg for the past 2 days. In addition  she indicates the area is sensitive to touch and has a constant dull ache that intensifies with foot movement.   She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. She also denies any previous personal or family history of clotting disorders or similar symptoms.   She is concerned initially thinking her symptoms might be related to her long flight  but anxious as she has read about the risks of blood clot disorders on the internet.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old African American female  employed as a long-haul truck driver  presents to the emergency department with symptoms she first noticed 3 days ago. She complains of swelling and discomfort in her left leg which has progressively worsened. The patient states the pain is a constant aching feeling  rated at a 7 on a scale of 0-10  and has limited her mobility. The leg appears larger than the other  and is warm and red to the touch.  Known risk factors are present in her medical history. She is obese with a body mass index of 35  and has a previous medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. She also has a family history of DVT; her mother experienced a similar issue when she was around the same age. The patient explains she spends long hours sitting while driving  often up to 6-8 hours at a time without a break. She does not report any recent surgeries  hospitalizations  or pregnancies.  Patient has quit smoking 5 years earlier and drinks alcohol socially. She is a widow and lives alone. She has travelled out of state last week by driving 5 hours each way for a family event. She is currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  and a statin as per her primary care physician's prescription.   Overall  the presenting symptoms  along with her occupational behavior  obesity  and family history  suggest suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient has been educated on the urgency of her condition and potential course of action  and agrees to further diagnostic testing.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jones is a 68-year-old African-American female presenting with complaints of pain  swelling  and a warm sensation in her right leg. The pain has been progressive in nature since the past four days and is mainly in the calf region. Ms. Jones mentions that the pain seems to be more noticeable when she stands or walks. She has no significant complaints to report related to her left leg. There is no history of trauma or injury to the legs. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or any neurological abnormalities.  She has a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include glyburide for her diabetes and hydrochlorothiazide for her hypertension. She has no known drug allergies. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. She also mentions being largely sedentary due to limited mobility caused by knee pain.  Her family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis in her mother. She has been menopausal for 15 years and has a past history of hormone replacement therapy  although she discontinued it about five years ago. She flew overseas about two weeks ago  a long journey with limited leg movement.  The patient appears to be in mild distress secondary to pain. On physical examination  her right calf appears noticeably swollen and is warm to touch compared to the left. There is noticeable tenderness on deep palpation of the calf muscles in the leg. No significant abnormal findings are noted elsewhere.

A 67-year-old African American male  Mr. Martin  presents to the clinic with a complaint of a 3-day history of progressive swelling and pain in his left leg. The pain is reported as a constant dull ache  rated 6 on a scale of 10  and increases with movement or palpitation. The patient noticed that the leg is slightly warmer than usual and he has had trouble putting on his shoes due to the swelling.   Mr. Martin lives with his wife in Chicago and retired two years ago after a long career as a truck driver. His medical history consists of well-controlled hypertension for the past 10 years and a recent total hip replacement on the left side 6 weeks ago  post which he has been largely sedentary. He is a former smoker but quit 15 years ago  and continues to be moderately overweight with a BMI of 28.7.   He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  recent travel  or history of clotting problems. His mother suffered from stroke at the age of 75. He is currently only on antihypertensive medication. He denies any allergies to medication.  The patient's demographic and past medical history of recent surgery and prolonged immobility  along with the presentation of unilateral leg pain and swelling  brings DVT into consideration.

Patient Presentation  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with a complaint of a one-week history of gradually increasing pain and swelling in his left lower extremity. He also mentions he recently noted the skin of his left calf appearing redder than usual. He denies any history of trauma or injury.   The patient has a known medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes Metformin  and hypertension controlled by Lisinopril. He has prior surgical history  including an elective hip replacement performed six months ago. He is a non-smoker but admits to averaging 2-3 glasses of wine per week.   The patient has a sedentary life as a retired office worker  spending most of the days seated. He recently returned from a cross-country flight two weeks ago. A family history reveals his father had a 'heart attack' at 70 and his sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 62.   Overall  he is worried about the swelling  which has never happened before  and is causing discomfort while walking. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitation  dizziness  or fainting spells.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas is a 67-year-old African-American male who comes to the emergency department complaining of a painful  swollen  red  and warm right leg  which has been persisting for the last three days. The swelling is present from his knee down to his ankle. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  cough or hemoptysis. He does not recall any recent trauma  prolonged periods of inactivity or long trips.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Thomas has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker but quit over 10 years ago. His medication history includes antihypertensives and statins. He reports no drug allergies. He had a surgical history of right hip replacement certainly 1 year ago. He has never had any similar symptoms before.  Demographics:  Mr. Thomas is a retired school teacher and leads a moderately sedentary lifestyle. He lives at home with his wife and has two adult children living out-of-state. He does not consume alcohol. He is 5'9"" inches tall  weighing 198 pounds  which indicates obesity based on his BMI calculation. He seems to be compliant with his medications. His family history is significant for a sister who had a stroke aged 72.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Arminda Cruz  a 61-year-old Hispanic female  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of recent onset of severe pain and swelling in her left calf since yesterday. The pain  according to her  is a dull  aching discomfort that seems to intensify when she stands and decreases with rest. Associated symptoms include subtle warmth over the region and a mild reddish discoloration of the skin.  Ms. Cruz has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which she takes Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily and Metformin 500mg twice a day  respectively. She has a history of prior DVT in the same leg 10 years ago  while she was receiving hormone replacement therapy. She also has a family history of both DVT and Pulmonary Embolism (PE).   She is recently post-operative  having undergone an elective abdominoplasty procedure approximately one week ago. Since the surgery  she reports being relatively immobile with most of her days spent sitting or lying down  watching TV. She denies smoking  excessive alcohol consumption  or illicit drug use. She reports adherence to her medications  and no known drug allergies.  Ms. Cruz's vitals upon presentation are: temperature 36.7°C  blood pressure 142/90mmHg  pulse 88 beats/minute  and respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute. Her BMI calculated at 32 indicating she is obese. She appears uncomfortable due to the pain  but not in acute distress.   Her routine blood tests including coagulation profile were ordered  and an urgent lower extremity Doppler ultrasound was planned for further evaluation.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department complaining of progressive swelling  pain  and tenderness in her left calf that has been getting worse over the past five days. She reports that the pain increases upon walking or standing. She also reports shortness of breath and mild chest discomfort  especially when taking deep breaths.  She has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which are well-managed on medication. She admits to being a smoker for nearly 35 years but quit 3 years ago. She lives with her husband and is retired. Four weeks prior to presentation  she underwent a total knee replacement surgery on her left knee. She was immobilized for a few days post-operatively and noted to be non-compliant to the prescribed anticoagulation prophylaxis.   Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; her father passed away from myocardial infarction at an early age and her older brother has a history of stroke. She denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.  On examination  her left calf is visibly swollen and warm to touch. There is pitting edema up to the knee level. Her vitals on presentation are blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  pulse is 88 beats per minute  respirations are 22 per minute  and temperature is 37.1 degrees Celsius.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room with complaints of a new onset of pain in his left lower extremity that started two days ago. The pain is localized in the calf  characterized as aching and constant  and worsened upon standing or walking. The patient also reports mild swelling in the same leg and mild shortness of breath. He denies any chest pain  cough  or neurological symptoms. His past medical history is notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and recent left knee arthroplasty performed three weeks ago. He adds he was a farmer by occupation  and recently retired. He denies smoking or recreational drug use  but acknowledges daily alcohol consumption. His medications include Lisinopril  Simvastatin  Aspirin  and occasional Acetaminophen for post-operative knee pain. Reviewing his family history reveals his mother had ‘blood clots in her legs’ and his father passed away suddenly due to a myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Jackson  a 68-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressive pain  swelling  and redness in his right lower limb. He also reports occasional palpitations but denies chest pain or shortness of breath.   About 6 years ago  he was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus  for which he takes metformin regularly  along with dietary and lifestyle modifications. In terms of surgical history  Mr. Jackson underwent a total hip replacement on the same right leg  2 years ago  which led to a prolonged period of immobility.  Mr. Jackson used to be a regular smoker  working as a long-haul truck driver for almost 40 years; primarily sedentary. He consumed alcohol occasionally but quit both habits 3 years ago. He doesn't have a family history of stroke or clotting disorders but his mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Based on his history and symptoms  he is suspicious for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Jacqueline Turner is a 62-year-old African American female who presents to the emergency department with ongoing pain  warmth  and swelling predominantly on her left leg for the last two- three days. She also mentions feeling short of breath  especially when climbing stairs or walking short distances  which is unusual for her.   She is a retired school teacher  lives with her husband  and is a non-smoker. She endorses staying inactive for extended periods while reading or knitting. Recently  she took a long-haul flight 10 days ago to visit her son  which involved around 10 hours of sitting.  Her medical history includes hypertension  diabetes  and one episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 6 years ago. She's currently on lisinopril  metformin  and low-dose aspirin.   Her family history includes an elder sister who had a pulmonary embolism and a father with a history of varicose veins and recurrent deep vein thrombosis. She denies any known inherited clotting disorders in the family.  On physical exam  her left leg appeared erythematous  more distended than the right  with noticeable pitting edema and tenderness along the femoral and popliteal regions. Her vitals are BP: 152/92 mmHg  HR: 98 bpm  RR: 22 bpm  SpO2: 94% on room air.   Given her clinical presentation and risk factors  a deep vein thrombosis is highly suspected. Immediate diagnostic and therapeutic measures need to be taken to avoid complications.

Patient Presentation:  Wendell  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of acute-onset  unilateral leg pain  and visible right leg swelling. The patient noticed a subtle cramp three days ago which has progressively worsened and is now rated 8/10 on the pain scale. The right leg appears red and is warmer to touch than the left leg. He denies any recent trauma or injury but reported taking a 6-hour non-stop flight about 5 days ago on a business trip.  The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension being managed with lifestyle modifications and occasional use of antihypertensives when needed. He also has obesity with BMI at 31 and type II diabetes mellitus which is on oral hypoglycemic agents. The patient's father suffered a pulmonary embolism in his late 60s and died  and the patient recalls that his father had similar symptoms prior to his diagnosis. The patient has no known allergies. He does not smoke  consume alcohol  or use illicit drugs.  In conclusion  Wendell appears to present a classic case of Deep Vein Thrombosis with risk factors including his recent flight (prolonged immobilization)  obesity  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and a family history of venous thromboembolism (VTE).

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Maria Gomez  a 68-year-old Hispanic female  presented to the Emergency Department complaining of progressive and persistent left leg swelling for the past five days. She reports onset of acute  localized pain in her calf muscle  described as a dull ache  worsened with touch or movement. The pain is rated 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. She denies any trauma or injury to the area.   Ms. Gomez expresses concern as she noticed the raised skin temperature and slight redness around the same area. She also complains of feeling slightly short of breath during routine chores  which is unusual for her.  Her medical history reveals that she underwent a total right hip arthroplasty three weeks ago  after which she was mostly bedridden. She does not have a history of smoking  but she was on hormone replacement therapy for hot flushes since the onset of menopause six years back.  Medication review shows she's on daily aspirin and her post-surgery medication has been completed. The patient's family history reveals her mother and her elder sister suffered from DVT  and they both had two episodes.   Ms. Gomez's BMI is 28; she's overweight but not obese. She doesn't regularly exercise but follows a balanced diet. She doesn't have a history of alcohol or drug misuse. She's retired and lives with her elder son and his family  who support her.

Patient Information: A 64-year-old African American female presents to the Emergency Department.  Chief Complaint: Left leg pain and swelling over the past four days.  History of Present Illness: Patient reports a dull aching pain in her left calf which has become progressively worse over the past four days  specifically noticing heat and swelling. The patient denies any recent trauma  insect bites or known injury. The patient did take a 7 hour plane ride two weeks ago. She states that the pain is 7/10 in severity  and is not relieved by over the counter pain medication or by elevations of the leg. She adds that she experienced a shortness of breath this morning while walking for a brief period in her garden.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She has no history of any clotting disorders  surgeries or any malignancy. She is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol.  Medications: Patient is on Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension.  Family History: Her father had coronary artery disease and passed away at 75. Her mother died of a stroke at 70 years old.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  her left calf appears swollen and warm to touch with a positive Homan's sign.   Based on the symptoms  medical history  and physical examination  a preliminary diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis is suspected. Further investigation  including a doppler ultrasound of the left leg  is recommended.

Patient Information: A 64-year-old  overweight Caucasian male  working as a long-haul truck driver  presents with symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis.  Chief Complaint: Swelling  redness  and tenderness in his left lower leg  which started suddenly two days prior.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports he has been experiencing a dull ache in his left calf  which intensifies when he walks or flexes his foot. Patient denies any recent trauma  surgery  immobility  medications  or similar symptoms in the past. He noted that the swelling increased after a cross-country truck drive.   Past Medical History: Patient has a 15-year history of uncontrolled hypertension  along with type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago. He has no known drug or food allergies. His father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his mother had suffered from a stroke in her late sixties  which he reports is due to her chronic atrial fibrillation.  Medications: Lisinopril and Metformin  Family History: As said earlier  cardiac disease in father who died from myocardial infarction  mother had stroke because of chronic atrial fibrillation.  Social History: The patient reports a sedentary lifestyle due to his job  with little physical activity. He consumes alcohol moderately  and quit smoking 10 years ago.   Review of Systems: General - No fever  chills  weight loss. Cardiovascular - No chest pain  palpitations. Respiratory - No cough  dyspnea  or hemoptysis. Gastrointestinal - No nausea  vomiting or diarrhea. Musculoskeletal - Pain in left leg.  Physical Examination: The patient is overweight with a BMI of 32. Bilateral lower extremity examination shows significant swelling  tenderness  and erythema to the left lower leg. There are no signs of an open wound or ulceration. The right lower extremity is unremarkable.  This above case features risk factors typically associated with deep vein thrombosis: older age  being overweight  history of hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  sedentary lifestyle  and prolonged periods of immobility due to his job as a long-haul truck driver.

Patient Presentation  Ms. Jane Doe  a 62-year-old African-American female  presents to the emergency room. She has had progressive discomfort and swelling in her right leg for the past three days. She has rated her current pain level as a 7/10. Her discomfort escalates after she is mobile for prolonged periods of time and slightly alleviates when she rests or elevates her leg.  She is currently on hormone replacement therapy and has a past medical history significant for 2 unprovoked deep vein thrombosis at ages 45 and 56. There is a relevant family history  with her mother and older sister also having experienced deep vein thrombosis multiple times in their lives.  The patient has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. She reports that she does not regularly exercise and spends most of her time working from home in a sedentary role. She states that she does not consume alcohol.  Her current medications besides hormone medications include low-dose aspirin and atorvastatin. She has no known drug allergies. Her BMI is 31.2  which classifies her as obese.  On examination  her right leg appears noticeably larger than her left leg. Palpation of the right calf induces pain and the area is warm to the touch. There is pitting edema in her right lower limb. Her vital signs are stable but her heart rate is elevated at 102 beats per minute. Lab testing and further diagnostic studies including a venous Doppler ultrasound are suggested to evaluate the potential deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old  African-American female has presented to the clinic with progressive pain and swelling in her left leg for the past week. She rates the pain as 7 on a scale from 0-10. The patient also reports feeling warmth over the swollen area and mild shortness of breath. The symptoms have gradually worsened over the past few days and have become quite severe  affecting her ability to walk.  She has a past medical history of hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and had right hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. She is a former smoker with a history of 30 pack-years but quit smoking around 10 years ago. She also reports a family history of thrombosis  with her sister having had an unprovoked clot during pregnancy.  On examination  the left leg was observed to be significantly swollen with a slight increase in skin temperature compared to the right leg. The patient also displayed tenderness along the distribution of the deep venous system.   This patient is considered high-risk due to her recent orthopedic surgery  personal and family past medical history of thrombotic issues  age  and African-American ethnicity  which has been reported to have a higher prevalence of venous thromboembolism compared to some other ethnic groups.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Miller  a 45-year-old African-American female  presented to the emergency room complaining of pain and swelling in her left leg  specifically the calf area. The pain was described as a ""pulling sensation"" that worsened when she walked or stood for extended periods. She also reported difficulty in striding due to painful swelling and a slight fever of 38°C.  Ms. Miller has a 16-year sedentary job as an accountant and recently completed a long-distance flight from Australia to the United States. She is overweight with a BMI of 31 and has a history of hypertension controlled by Lisinopril.  In her family history  she mentioned that her grandmother had a blood clot in her leg and her older brother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis approximately 6 months ago. She does not smoke or drink but did use oral contraceptives up to three years ago.   Ms. Miller's presenting symptoms  coupled with her prolonged sedentary lifestyle  recent travel history  family history of DVT  obesity  and previous estrogen use  heightens the likelihood of deep vein thrombosis.

A 68-year-old African-American male  Mr. James  presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of increasing pain and swelling in his left leg. The patient noticed the pain after a 10-hour flight from Atlanta to Hawaii  at first dismissing it as cramps. The pain has progressively worsened over time  accompanied by swelling and slight skin discoloration towards the calf region.   Mr. James is currently on medication for hypertension and high cholesterol. He also has a history of smoking over 35 years but quit approximately 10 years ago. The patient underwent a right hip replacement about two years ago without any complications. Mr. James has never undergone any surgeries for venous diseases  and there is no family history of the same.  He is a retired lawyer  lives with his wife  and has three adult children. He regularly attends annual health check-ups  but missed his last appointment due to the pandemic. He maintains a moderate diet but has been struggling with obesity. His BMI is 32.0.   There is no history of drug or alcohol abuse. He doesn’t mention any allergies to food or drug. He denies having chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. His wife  present with him  confirms his historical details and current health complaints.

Patient Presentation:  African-American female patient  age 67  presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of gradually worsening pain and swelling in her right calf. Pain characterised as cutting  gnawing pain worsening with leg movement. She also reported feeling uncharacteristically fatigued.  Demographic Details: Widowed  retired school teacher living alone. Non-smoker  mild alcohol drinker  socioeconomically middle class. BMI falls in the overweight category. Lives in an urban area and leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus controlled with metformin and diet modifications. She underwent a total right knee replacement five weeks ago. The patient also has a familial history of DVT and Pulmonary Embolism (PE). The patient had been using contraceptive pills for 20 years (stopped 10 years ago).  Recent History: The patient travelled cross country (6-hour flight) one week ago to visit her children. She reports not getting up during the flight.  Summarizing  Age  obesity  diabetes  recent orthopedic surgery  prolonged immobility (due to flight and sedentary lifestyle)  female gender  hormonal therapy history  family history of DVT/PE and African-American ethnicity are some of the risk factors that can make this patient prone to DVT.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Name: Jane Doe Age: 60 Sex: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired (mostly sedentary lifestyle)  Chief Complaint: New onset of unilateral leg swelling  calf pain  and tenderness.  History of Present Illness: Mrs. Doe presents with a 2-day history of inflammatory signs in her right lower leg  including warmth  tenderness  redness  and swelling. She rates her pain as 5/10 dull aching pain centered in the calf region. She denies having any trauma. She travelled across the country for a family occasion about 7 days ago and reports a prolonged period of immobilization including a 6-hour flight and long car rides during the trip. She denies experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations.  Medical History: Mrs. Doe is known to have Hypertension  which is well controlled with medications. She was also taking hormone replacement therapy until about 5 years ago  when her doctor asked her to discontinue due to potential risk factors associated with long-term use. She went through menopause at the age of 51. She has no history of clotting disorders or malignancies  and she denies any history of similar episodes.  Family History: Her father had a history of strokes while an elder sister had breast cancer. No family history of thrombo-embolic diseases reported.  Social History: She is a non-smoker and almost non-alcoholic (1-2 glasses/month). She lives with her husband and has 2 adult children. She is largely sedentary due to arthritis  upon which she became an avid reader.  Current Medications: Lisinopril for Hypertension  After reviewing Mrs. Doe's presentation  demographic information  recent travel history  and personal medical history  she is a classic example of a patient with risk factors for developing deep vein thrombosis. An urgent Doppler Ultrasound is the next step required to further evaluate for DVT.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. P  a 63-year-old Asian male  retired truck driver  presents to the ER with complaints of a 3-day history of an increasingly painful  swollen  and warm right calf. The patient reports that he first noticed the discomfort after a long-distance flight from Hong Kong to New York five days ago.   He denies any recent surgeries  trauma  or personal history of malignancy. He also denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. He has a significant past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes but no previous history of thromboembolic events. Mr. P also reports his father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 68. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally.   His current medications include metformin for diabetes and amlodipine for hypertension. On physical examination  his vital signs are stable  but there is noticeable edema in the right calf which is tender to touch. His right calf is slightly reddish and warmer than the left. The veins of the affected leg are barely visible.  Given his recent long-distance flight  the unilateral symptoms  and family history  Mr. P is at high risk for deep vein thrombosis and requires further investigation to confirm the diagnosis and start appropriate treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Howard is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with complaints of left calf pain  warmth  and redness for the past 3 days. Mr. Howard describes the pain as progressively worsening  rating it at an 8/10. He denies any trauma or injury to his leg  but admits to recent long-distance travel  of more than five hours  on an economy flight.   Regarding his past medical history  John has a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia that he has been managing for approximately 15 years. He is currently on oral hypoglycemics  a statin  and ACE inhibitors. He underwent hip replacement surgery 8 years ago. He is an ex-smoker and quit about ten years ago  having smoked one pack/day for around twenty years. He denies any history of thrombotic events but mentions that his father had a deep vein thrombosis in his late 50s.   Upon physical examination  his left calf appears swollen and erythematous compared to the right  and palpation elicits tenderness. His vital signs are stable  with a heart rate of 84 beats/min  blood pressure 128/84 mmHg  temperature 37.2 degrees C  respiratory rate 16 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air.   This detailed presentation and history raise the clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis. An urgent duplex ultrasound of the lower extremity to confirm this suspicion and assess the extent of the thrombus will be beneficial.   Further risk assessment for thrombophilia might be required considering his family history. Monitoring of INR as part of follow-up  and evaluating his medication  especially considering any potential interactions with anticoagulants that may be used in DVT management  will be important.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is an African-American female  aged 68 years old with a BMI of 32. She presents today with a complaint of acute onset  unilateral leg swelling  redness and tenderness since yesterday evening. The complaint is prominently in her left lower limb. The pain seems to worsen when she stands or walks. She has not experienced any trauma recently. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough.  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes  and three pregnancies  last one being 30 years ago. She underwent hip replacement surgery two years ago and was on bed rest for quite some time afterwards. Patient is a current smoker with a 30-pack year history. She is currently on Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. She has no known allergies.   Family history reveals her mother had a stroke at the age of 75  and her younger brother had a deep vein thrombosis few years ago. Social history includes smoking  but no alcohol or recreational drug use.  Overall  her additional risk factors include smoking  obesity  previous orthopedic surgery  prolonged immobility  prior family history of hypercoagulable states  and multiple pregnancies.  This presentation suggests a possible deep vein thrombosis  and additional diagnostic tests should be done to confirm this.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with a complaint of sudden onset pain in the left lower extremity  localized primarily in the calf region. He also notes accompanying redness and mild swelling in the limb  which began 5 days prior  gradually worsening over time. Mr. Johnson states that the pain increases with standing and walking  and his left calf seems warmer compared to the right one. He denies experiencing any recent trauma to the area  but he does mention a recent period of reduced mobility after a long-hour trans-Atlantic flight from London to New York two weeks ago.  Significantly  Mr. Johnson reports a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus well-managed with metformin for the past 10 years. He also suffers from hyperlipidemia  for which he takes statins. Mr. Johnson underwent a knee arthroscopy for an old sports injury about 3 years ago  but recovery was uncomplicated. He stopped smoking cigarettes 15 years ago but had a 30-pack year history. He admits to current occasional alcohol use but denies any illicit drug use. His family history is notable for a brother who had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after a knee surgery. His parents both had cardiovascular diseases  and his mother had a stroke at age 75.  On physical examination  vital signs are stable. The left calf appears slightly swollen and erythematous with increased warmth compared to the right. Palpation reveals pain and tenderness in the left calf. No superficial vein dilation is palpable. A Homan’s sign (pain at the back of the knee during forced dorsiflexion of the foot) was positive on the affected side. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Given his recent flight  reduced mobility  family history of DVT  and diabetes  Mr. Johnson is at high risk for developing DVT. At present  his pain and swelling suggest a potential DVT that requires further investigation and immediate treatment to prevent dangerous complications  such as pulmonary embolism.

A 58-year-old African American woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of persistent left lower extremity swelling and discomfort. She reports that the pain is aching in nature  6 out of 10 in severity and localized mainly in the calf area. Her leg is warm to the touch and she recently noticed a reddish-bluish discoloration.   She denies any injury  weight bearing  or recent travel. She also denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or other systemic symptoms. Her past medical history is significant for obesity with a BMI of 35 kg/m^2 and type 2 diabetes for which she is taking Metformin. Additionally  she has a history of varicose veins but no previous deep vein thrombosis or any family history of clotting disorders.   She is post-menopausal and used oral contraceptives for 15 years before shifting to hormone replacement therapy for her menopausal symptoms 7 years ago. She occasionally drinks alcohol but has no history of smoking or recreational drug use.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presented to the clinic with a three-day history of worsening sharp  non-radiating pain and swelling in her left lower extremity. The pain seems to intensify when the patient is on her feet and lessens while sitting. She denies trauma to the area but notes that she recently returned from an international flight of 6 hours  approximately six days ago. She denies chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  cough or hemoptysis. No fever or chills. The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension and high cholesterol for which she takes Lisinopril and Rosuvastatin respectively. She quit smoking 10 years ago after being a one-pack-a-day smoker for about 30 years. She occasionally drinks alcohol. She denies any known family history of blood clots. Her only surgery was a caesarean section 35 years ago. She is currently retired  but she previously worked as a bank teller. She lives alone but is typically active within her community.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Clarisse Mendoza  a 59-year-old Hispanic woman  is being presented today in a clinic with chief complaints of ongoing pain and swelling in her right lower limb for several days. The pain is described as a steady dull ache and does not radiate. She confirms no recent injuries or traumas. She notes that the swelling has progressively worsened  which caused her to seek medical attention.  Ms. Mendoza is a banker by profession  which involves extended sitting periods. She has no regular physical activity regimen and she also recently completed a long haul flight back from a business trip to Asia  which lasted approximately 14 hours. The symptoms started presenting 3 days after her return.  Her past medical history reveals that she is overweight (BMI 28) and has been recently diagnosed with Hypertension and Type II Diabetes for which she is on medication. In addition to this  there is a history of recurrent miscarriages reflecting a probable thrombophilic profile. She’s a non-smoker and drinks socially. Her family history discloses that her mother had a venous thromboembolism following a total knee replacement surgery.   In summary  considering her age  obesity  long period of immobilization  and probable thrombophilic tendency (personal and family history)  Ms. Mendoza is a high-risk case suspecting deep vein thrombosis and requires immediate clinical investigation.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressive pain and swelling in her left lower leg. The patient describes the pain as a continuous dull ache which is aggravated on movement. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  traumatic injury  or recent surgery.   The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication. She does not smoke and drinks alcohol only socially. Her mother had a history of stroke at age 75  but she denies any other significant family medical history including blood clotting disorders.   Five weeks prior to presentation  she traveled from the United States to Australia which involved extended periods of immobilization. Her weight is 220 lbs (Body Mass Index 35 kg/m2  indicating obesity) and she leads a sedentary lifestyle  these exacerbating the risk of thromboembolism.  On physical examination  her left calf is swollen  erythematous  and warm to touch  but without any superficial venous varicosities. Radial and dorsalis pedis pulses are palpable bilaterally.   This presentation is typical of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a condition commonly seen in elderly  obese  sedentary subjects following periods of prolonged immobilization.

Patient Presentation:  John  a 54-year-old Caucasian male presents to the office with a painful  swollen left leg. He is a corporate executive with a sedentary lifestyle  sitting for several hours a day. He recently flew in from a lengthy business trip  about 6 hours in total. He reports severe  cramping pain in his left calf that started 2 days ago  rating the pain a 7 out of 10. The pain is constant even at rest and exacerbated upon palpation. He also reports noticing that the affected leg appears slightly red and feels warm compared to the other leg.  John has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He has been on Metformin and Lisinopril for the past 5 years. He has no prior history of clotting disorders or cardiovascular disease. He quit smoking a year ago. Family history reveals that his father had a pulmonary embolism at age 67.   John's BMI is 30 indicating obesity. He doesn't engage in regular physical activities and admits to enjoying fast food and his social drinking occasionally borders on heavy drinking. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness. However  he expresses concern regarding the risk of pulmonary embolism.   This presentation and relevant history point towards the possibility of deep vein thrombosis possibly due to prolonged periods of immobility associated with his sedentary lifestyle and long flights  possible inherited predisposition  and lifestyle risk factors such as obesity  and type 2 diabetes.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Brenda Thompson  a 65-year-old African American female  presents to the emergency department complaining of an abrupt onset unilateral leg swelling  redness  and pain in her left calf that started 3 days ago. The pain is constant  described as throbbing  worsens on walking  and partially relieved by rest. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or lightheadedness.   Ms. Thompson has a medical background significant for stage-II hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus for the last 15 years  well-controlled on metformin  lisinopril  and hydrochlorothiazide. She is also morbidly obese with a BMI of 35. She had a total knee replacement surgery six months ago. Her family history is significant for pulmonary embolism in her mother. She quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30 pack-year history but denies any alcohol or drug abuse.   Risk factors for DVT include obesity  recent surgery  lack of mobilization  long-term hypertension  and family history of clotting disorders. Given that the patient falls into these risk categories  a clinical assessment for deep vein thrombosis is warranted.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Walter Johnson  a 68-year old African-American male  presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of warmth  redness  pain  and swelling in his left calf. His pain has progressively worsened  rating it at a 7 on a scale of 10  causing significant discomfort during walking. He reveals that he recently underwent a total hip replacement surgery on the same side 10 days ago.  Mr. Johnson has a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both well-controlled with appropriate medication (Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively). He lives with his wife in an apartment and has retired from his job as a truck driver. Mr. Johnson shares that he has a 30-pack year smoking history but quit five years ago. He admits to enjoying alcohol socially but states this occurs no more than once a week and typically with meals.   As per the medical records  he has a body mass index of 29  indicating he is overweight. Review of medications revealed that he is not on any anticoagulation post-surgery. He has no known drug allergies and no family history of coagulation disorders or deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  The patient's overall clinical presentation  recent orthopedic surgery  immobility  and history of smoking make him a strong candidate for the possibility of deep vein thrombosis. Therefore  immediate diagnostic testing such as ultrasound and D-dimer testing is being considered.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Benjamin Matthews  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  is a retired truck driver who presents with a three-day history of progressively worsening left leg swelling  redness  and moderate pain. The pain is dull  concentrated around the calf area  and has a severity around 6/10. He denies any associated fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath.   Mr. Matthews has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin for the past 15 years and hypertension controlled by Lisinopril  as well as a pack/day smoking habit for the past 40 years. He reports a sedentary lifestyle and his job required prolonged sitting. He denies any recent long-distance travel. Around 6 months back  he suffered a minor fracture in his left ankle  which was managed conservatively.   His family history is positive for venous thromboembolism in his older brother. He takes aspirin for occasional headaches  but no other over-the-counter medications. He denies drinking alcohol.  The patient appears to be in mild distress due to leg pain and has elevated blood pressure on examination. Physical assessment reveals unilateral left leg swelling  erythema  tenderness on palpation in the calf  and a positive Homan's sign. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits.

Demographic Details: Patient: Mrs. Lisa Thompson Age: 63 years Gender: Female  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired schoolteacher   Presenting Complaint:   Mrs. Thompson has come to the outpatient ward complaining of an uncomfortable swelling in her left leg that she has noticed growing over the past week  characterized by tenderness  redness  warmth  and pain.  She also reports feeling mildly short of breath.  Past Medical History: 1. Known case of Hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  stable on medication 2. History of breast cancer  post lumpectomy and radiation therapy 3 years ago 3. Non-smoker but with history of cigarette smoking in the past (quit smoking 10 years ago)  Focused Family History: Mother had a history of stroke at the age of 68 years. Father had heart disease.  Drug History: 1. Metformin 500mg twice daily 2. Losartan 50mg once daily 3. Atenolol 25mg once daily  Allergies: No known drug allergies  On examination: Temperature: 98.6°F Pulse: 78 beats per minute (Regular) Blood pressure: 130/80 mmHg  Physical examination shows her left calf has local tenderness on palpation  increased warmth and it is swollen in comparison to the right calf. There were also signs of slight skin discoloration. Lungs were clear on auscultation  heart sounds were normal  and abdomen was soft and non-tender.  Summary: Mrs. Thompson is a retired 63-year-old Caucasian woman with history of hypertension  diabetes  and previous breast cancer  now presenting with pain and swelling in the left leg suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Given her medical history  she is at an increased risk of DVT and a thorough evaluation is required.

Patient presentation:   Mr. Smith  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  employed as a long-haul truck driver  presents to the emergency department. The patient reports progressive swelling  pain  and warmth in the right leg over the past 3 days. He denies history of trauma  recent surgeries  or any history of venous disease.    His medical history is significant for Type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both controlled with medications. Mr. Smith has a 30-pack-year history of smoking and admits to a sedentary lifestyle due to his occupation. Family history revealed his father had a Pulmonary Embolism after a long-distance flight at the age of 65.  On examination  there is noticeable swelling and apparent erythema on the right lég comparison to the left leg. His vitals are stable. His pulmonary exam  cardiovascular system  and abdominal exams are all within normal limits.  Notably  the patient recently completed a cross-country trip on his heavy goods vehicle  involving extended periods of time sitting and driving  with minimal opportunity for frequently leg movement or walking around. His occupation and lifestyle appear to contribute to prolonged immobility  thus increasing his risk for DVT.    A D-dimer test followed by a compression ultrasonography of the affected limb were ordered to confirm the suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis. Laboratory findings (blood glucose  lipid profile  renal function  liver function etc.) and proper management plan (e.g.  anticoagulants) will be established based on the results. The patient is advised of the need for immediate medical intervention  lifestyle modifications  and the serious implications if left untreated.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  John  retired coal miner and a known smoker for more than 40 years. He presents to the emergency room with complaints of a right calf pain and swelling for the past 2 days. The pain is described as a constant  aching tightness that is exacerbated by walking and is not relieved by rest.  He further reports an unexplained fatigue and mild shortness of breath on exertion over the last week. John denies any trauma to the leg  fever  chest pain  cough or any recent surgery. No significant past medical history  but family history includes father deceased due to myocardial infarction. His vitals are stable but exhibits elevated heart rate and reports he's feeling quite anxious due to the pain and discomfort.  On examination  the right calf is noticeably swollen and reddened compared to the left  with measureable difference in circumference. The area is tender to touch  warm  and pain significantly increases with dorsiflexion of foot  indicating positive Homans' sign. Respiratory and cardiac examination are unremarkable.   John lives with his wife  he enjoys working on his farm and going for fishing trips. He consumes alcohol occasionally. Despite multiple attempts to quit  he has been unsuccessful in giving up smoking. He admits that his activity level has decreased significantly over the last few months  due to gradual onset of generalized fatigue and breathlessness.  His blood tests and a subsequent Doppler ultrasound of his lower extremities have confirmed diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient has been started on anticoagulation therapy and has been advised to elevate the leg and to use compression stockings. John and his family have been counselled on the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation  increased physical activity and maintaining hydration.

Patient Presentation: Mrs. Johnson  a 63-year-old African American woman with a past medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and obesity  presents with a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling in her left lower extremity. She works as a financial adviser and reports a sedentary lifestyle with prolonged periods of sitting.   She returned from a transatlantic flight a week ago and noticed a slight discomfort in her calf which she attributed to her extended period in a seated position during the flight. However  over the past few days the pain has grown steadily worse and is now associated with swelling  warmth  and a slightly bluish discoloration  prompting her to seek evaluation.  Mrs. Johnson denies chest pain  shortness of breath  recent surgeries  trauma or family history of clotting disorders. She is a non-smoker but takes oral contraceptives for menopausal symptoms. Her routine medications include metformin  lisinopril  and daily aspirin.   On examination  the left calf is observed to be swollen  red  and warmer when compared to the right calf. The leg circumference is significantly larger on the left compared to the right. The patient expresses tenderness when the calf is palpated. A preliminary physical examination suggests the possibility of a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 60-year-old African American male employed as a long-distance truck driver  presenting today with a one-week history of increasing left leg discomfort  edema  and erythema. He reports the swelling began gradually but has progressively increased over the past two days and is accompanied by a dull aching pain.   He has a past medical history significant for obesity with BMI 32  type II diabetes managed with Metformin  and hypertension under control with Lisinopril. He has no history of surgeries or hospitalizations and is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption. Family history reveals his mother had a similar presentation in her 60s that was diagnosed as a deep vein thrombosis.  Mr. Johnson reports no chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. However  he admits to prolonged periods of immobility due to his job as a truck driver during the COVID-19 pandemic which has seen him working longer hours. He denies any recent travels that involve long flights or car rides. He admits that he does not get to exercise as he should.   On physical examination  Mr. Johnson’s left leg is noticeably swollen with warm  erythematous skin. There's tenderness along the distribution of the left femoral vein. There are no signs of skin breakdown or ulceration. His vitals are stable with a blood pressure of 140/85mm Hg  a heart rate of 78 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and a body temperature of 98.4°F. The remainder of the exam  including cardiovascular and respiratory examinations  are essentially normal.   Considering his clinical presentation and risk factors (obesity  sedentary lifestyle due to occupation  age  and family history)  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) needs to be highly suspected.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Diane Thompson Age: 62 years Sex: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Weight: 80 kg Height: 5'3"" Occupation: Retired school teacher  Presenting Symptoms:  Mrs. Thompson presents with acute left leg pain and swelling that began suddenly 2 days ago. She describes the pain as constant  cramping  and rated it as a 7/10 on the pain scale. She also reports mild shortness of breath and light-headedness.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Thompson has a significant history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  which are well controlled with medication. She had a hysterectomy 40 years ago due to endometriosis  and has had no surgeries since. Three months ago  she fractured her right wrist in a fall  leading to immobility and sedentary lifestyle. She also mentions a family history of blood clot disorders. Her cousin had a pulmonary embolism at a relatively young age.  Current Medications:  She is currently on Metformin for her diabetes  Losartan for hypertension  and a daily aspirin. She has no known drug allergies.  Social History:  She is a widow who lives alone but has a home care nurse who visits three times a week. She used to be a smoker but quit 15 years ago. She doesn't consume alcohol or illicit drugs.  Assessment:  Based on her age  family history of blood clot disorders  current symptoms  and sedentary conditions due to recent injury and lack of mobility  Mrs. Thompson fits into the classic demographic and risk profile for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). High index of suspicion for DVT is warranted and further diagnostic evaluation will be strategically beneficial.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Carla Vasquez is a 55-year-old Hispanic woman presenting to the ER with a complaint of severe right leg swelling  pain  and warmth that began abruptly two days ago. She also mentions that the affected leg appears reddish-blue. Symptoms worsen when she is standing or walking.   The patient has a known history of obesity  Type 2 diabetes mellitus which is partially controlled on Metformin and hypertension managed on Lisinopril. She does not smoke but reports a sedentary lifestyle  working as an accountant with prolonged hours of sitting. No history of surgical procedures in the last six months.   Ms. Vasquez had oral contraceptive use during her early forties. There is no family history of blood clotting disorders. After a recent long-haul (cross-country) flight  she didn't mobilize much during or after the flight.  This patient seems at risk for deep vein thrombosis due to her obesity  sedentary lifestyle  history of long-distance travel  age  female gender  and history of oral contraceptive use.

Patient Presentation:  A 66-year-old Caucasian female presents to the clinic complaining of left lower leg pain for the past three days. The pain is constant  and she rates it as a 7 on a 10-point scale. She notes that the pain increases on standing and walking. She denies any recent trauma/injury to the leg  but reports a recent long-distance international flight lasting more than 6 hours. On examination  her left calf is swollen  warm and tender to touch  consistent with a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT).    Past Medical History:  This patient has a history of type 2 diabetes for 15 years  controlled with metformin. She had an episode of pulmonary embolism 8 years ago  that was treated with anticoagulation therapy. She is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago after smoking one pack daily for 40 years. Additionally  she has been post-menopausal for 16 years and has been on hormone replacement therapy for hot flashes and night sweats. She reports no known drug allergies. She does not have a family history of blood clot disorders.   EI: Physical inactivity and immobility during her recent long-distance travel  her age  previous history of pulmonary embolism  her use of hormone replacement therapy  and her long history of smoking puts her at a heightened risk for DVT. Coupled with her presenting symptoms of a painful  swollen lower leg  this patient should be worked up for a DVT.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 51-year-old African American woman who presents to the emergency department with complaints of a red  swollen  warm  and tender right calf that she first noticed two days ago. Her symptoms have gradually worsened  and she describes the pain as aching and constant.   She has a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI 35.2)  hypertension controlled with lisinopril  and a total knee replacement surgery on the same leg one month ago after a fall at home. She has been relatively sedentary  spending a significant proportion of time in bed post-surgery. Family history reveals her mother had a pulmonary embolism in her late fifties.  She’s a former smoker who quit approximately 10 years ago. She consumes alcohol occasionally and doesn't use illegal drugs. She is also on birth control pills for menopausal symptom control.   On physical examination  she is in moderate distress due to pain  right lower extremity is erythematous and edematous  with a palpable 'cord-like' structure in the muscle. Her vital signs are stable  though her heart rate is slightly elevated. No other abnormalities are noted.   Considering her demographic details  past medical history  surgery  and current medication use that increases risks of clotting  she is likely presenting with deep vein thrombosis in her right lower extremity.

Patient Presentation:  Sarah  a 72-year-old Caucasian woman  presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of increasing pain and swelling in her left leg. She has noticed that her left calf is significantly larger than her right and that it is red and warm to touch. She denies any history of trauma. However  she reports a dull ache in the affected leg  which is worse upon standing and walking short distances.  Sarah's past medical history is relevant and suggestive too. She has been living with hypertension and type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years. She had a right hip replacement surgery a month ago following which she spent most of her time lying in bed. She has a 35 pack-year smoking history but quit a year ago. She has no known allergies.  She has been taking Metformin  Lisinopril  and aspirin daily with no changes in her normal regimen recently. She denies alcohol  illicit drug use. She lives with her daughter who aids her in daily activities and accompanies her to the doctor's appointments.  On physical examination  her left calf is tender to palpate  with noticeable edema and erythema. Her vital signs are stable: blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg  heart rate is 78 beats/min  respiratory rate is 16 breaths/min  and body temperature is 98.7 F. Oxygen saturation on room air is 96%.  The presentation suggests possible deep vein thrombosis  given her recent surgery  immobility  older age  and past medical history of diabetes and hypertension  which are risk factors. Further testing and management in this case would follow these suspicions.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Laura Jones  a 55-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the emergency department with significant left leg pain  which she describes as a deep  persistent ache. She notes the pain began suddenly a couple of days ago. She also reports her left leg appears markedly swollen  slightly red and warm to touch for the same duration. She denies any injury to the area. Mrs. Jones also mentions experiencing mild shortness of breath over the past day  which she initially attributed to anxiety.  Mrs. Jones works as an accountant and describes her job as sedentary  where she sits for extended periods of time. She is married  does not smoke or drink alcohol  and has two adult children with no major health issues. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is in the overweight range at 29.  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus for which she is on medication. She recently underwent a total right hip replacement three weeks ago  which involved post-operative immobilization. She also has a family history of coagulation disorders - her mother had recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and her father passed away from a pulmonary embolism.   Compliance to her medication regimen is reported to be satisfactory  though she has not been dedicated to a regular physical activity routine for many years.  Summary:  Mrs. Jones' presentation is highly suggestive of DVT  which is more prevalent in older adults especially post-surgery. Her sedentary lifestyle and conditions such as obesity  hypertension  and diabetes further elevate the risk. Moreover  the presence of thrombotic disorders in the family significantly increases her predisposition towards clot formation. The sudden onset of breathlessness might indicate a complication of DVT  pulmonary embolism  which requires immediate attention.
