He has a past medical history of obesity and sedentary lifestyle  and cigarette smoking for over 40 years. There is no personal or family history of clotting disorders  cancer or recent trauma. He underwent a total knee replacement surgery about 5 months ago but didn't follow up with postoperative physical therapy. Vital signs at presentation are stable. Physical examination of the left leg shows a markedly swollen  warm  erythematous calf that is tender to palpation. Homans' sign is positive. There is no evident chest pain  shortness of breath  or other systemic symptoms. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Given his risk factors and clinical presentation  the patient is highly suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  presents with unilateral leg swelling and pain in the right calf which started a few days ago. He describes the pain as a dull ache which intensifies with standing or walking. His past medical history is significant for a recent total hip replacement surgery on the right side a month ago  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled by medication. He reports non-smoker and non-drinker status. He has been compliant with appropriate post-surgical physical therapy but admits to struggling with prolonged periods of immobility due to the surgery. Examination reveals a visibly swollen  erythematous  and warm right lower limb. There is tenderness along the deep venous system and positive Homans' sign. The patient denies chest pain  palpitations  or shortness of breath. He has no known drug allergies. His mother had a stroke and his father had coronary artery disease.

A 69-year-old  overweight Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  and a recent hip replacement surgery presents to the emergency department. He reports an increasingly significant left leg pain and swelling for the past 3 days. He also noticed a slight increase in the temperature over his left calf. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history and quit 3 years ago. He lives alone and is relatively sedentary  he does not exercise regularly. His medication regimen includes lisinopril and acetaminophen for pain as needed. Despite the absence of respiratory symptoms  the patient's age  postoperative condition  sedentary lifestyle  and obesity contribute to the high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient is a 45-year-old Caucasian male  office worker with a significant past medical history of obesity (BMI 32)  hypertension  smoking  and a recent long-haul flight (14 hours) three days ago. He presented with a 48-hour history of unilateral right lower leg pain and swelling not associated with any recent trauma or injury. The patient also noted mild shortness of breath with occasional chest tightness. Physical examination revealed a palpable cord in the right calf  local warmth  erythema  and a positive Homan's sign. He denied any family history of thrombotic events. Vital signs are within normal limits except for slightly elevated blood pressure. The patient’s symptoms and history may be indicative of deep vein thrombosis and potential pulmonary embolism.

A 57-year-old African American woman  with a known history of obesity and recent hip replacement surgery  presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of gradually worsening  painful swelling in her right lower leg. She denies any recent trauma or injuries to the leg  but reports prolonged bed rest due to her postoperative condition. The patient notes she's been unable to escalate her activity level in the past week due to persistent pain post-surgery and now experiences significant distress upon exertion  initiating a self-imposed sedentary lifestyle. She also recalls a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her first-degree relative. On her physical examination  the right lower extremity is markedly swollen  red  and tender on palpation. The Homans' sign was positive. She does not report any chest pain  but has a slight shortness of breath. She denies any previous or active use of tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drugs. Doppler ultrasound is pending. There's a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.

A 61-year-old overweight Caucasian male  a smoker with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with a 3-day history of unilateral swelling and progressive pain in his right lower leg. No history of recent long-distance travel  surgery  hospitalization  or immobilization. The patient denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent trauma. His father had a history of venous thromboembolism in his late 50s. Clinically  the right calf is red  warm  swollen  and tender to touch as opposed to the left one. He is currently taking antihypertensive medication and a statin. The presumptive diagnosis is deep vein thrombosis. He reports not taking any anticoagulants or known blood thinners.

A 55-year-old Caucasian woman with a past medical history of obesity and recent total hip replacement 3 weeks prior  presents with a 2-day history of swelling  warmth  redness and tenderness in her right calf. Patient rates pain in her calf  when walking or standing  as a 8 out of 10. She denies any recent trauma or injury. She takes no regular medications and denies smoking or alcohol consumption. She also reports having noticed decreased urine output since the onset of the calf pain. Upon examination  her vitals are stable  but her right calf is visibly swollen  erythematous  and painful upon palpation. She additionally has a positive Homan's sign. These symptoms suggest possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  particularly given her recent orthopedic surgery and obesity  both known risk factors for DVT.

A 63-year-old overweight Caucasian female presents with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. This retired school teacher has a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient is a nonsmoker  but takes no regular exercise and admits to a diet rich in fats. She underwent a total knee replacement 3 weeks ago and reports compliance with prescribed post-operative physiotherapy. However  she has not been prescribed or taking any prophylactic anticoagulants post-surgery. She complains of acute onset pain in her left lower limb over the last 48 hours  describing it as a constant  aching pain that worsens with movement. Additionally  she has noticed swelling and redness over the same area. She denies fever or breathing difficulties. Earlier last week  the patient embarked on a 12-hour long road trip  during which she reported prolonged periods of being seated. No family history of coagulation disorders or malignancies.

A 62-year-old  white  non-Hispanic  overweight female  non-smoker with a history of multiple long-haul flights in the past month and past medical history significant for hypertension and oral contraceptive use  presents with a three-day history of progressive  unilateral  painful swelling and warmth in her left leg  specifically in the calf region. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis but does report a recent long period of immobilization during her cross-country flight and frequent flights due to her job. Furthermore  she also mentioned recent changes in oral contraceptive medicines suggested by her gynecologist due to menopausal symptoms. There are no known allergies. On examination  she is afebrile  with stable vital signs  but examination of the left calf reveals erythema  swelling  and a positive Homan's sign. Her mobility is reduced due to pain. Laboratory tests  including D-dimer  and imaging studies are pending.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  presents with swelling  warmth  and pain in his right lower limb of 2 days duration. No trauma was reported but he was recently hospitalized for a lengthy hip replacement surgery. He has a medical history of hypertension  managed with beta blockers and aspirin  and obesity with BMI 33 kg/m2  both of which he has had for 10 years. He is a current smoker with a 40-year pack history. He has a family history of deep vein thrombosis as his father had it at the age of 70.   The patient complained of a sudden onset of pain in the right calf  which increases upon flexing his ankle. Along with the pain  there is also noticeable edema in his legs  especially in the painful area  and warm  red skin over the area of the swollen and painful veins. Vital signs are blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  heart rate of 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and temperature of 36.7 Celsius. The patient denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or other symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism. He has reduced mobility due to the painful lower leg and the recent hip replacement surgery. He takes no regular medications other than his hypertension drugs  and has no known drug allergies.

Subject is a 62-year-old Caucasian female who presents with symptoms of progressive swelling  warmth  and dull aching pain in the left lower extremity  primarily in the calf area. The patient's medical history is significant for obesity  hypertension  and smoking. She recently traveled on a six-hour flight. She denies any prior personal or familial history of clotting issues or malignancy and has not undergone any recent surgeries. Patient is not on any hormonal birth control  but takes antihypertensive medication. On clinical examination  the left lower limb appeared swollen with mild redness and was warm to touch. Homan's sign is positive.    Based on the patient's history and clinical findings  the primary concern is deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Additionally  the risk factors - advanced age  obesity  immobility during the flight  and smoking - support this concern. It would require confirmation with an imaging study like a Doppler ultrasound and consideration of anticoagulant therapy after assessing for contraindications.

A 62-year-old Caucasian woman presents with a 4-day history of increasing pain  warmth  and swelling in her left lower leg. The patient is overweight with a BMI of 30  and has a medical history significant for systemic lupus erythematosus and two episodes of superficial venous thrombosis. She is also a current smoker with a 20 pack-year history. She recently underwent a total knee arthroplasty 7 weeks ago on the same side. She denies experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath or hemoptysis but acknowledges a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Upon physical examination  there is notable tenderness along the distribution of the deep venous system  palpable cords (hard  thickened areas under the skin)  and unilateral pitting edema in her left lower leg. Given the history of recent surgery  prolonged immobilization  and a family history of DVT  it is presumed that she is presenting with deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation: A previously healthy 56-year-old Caucasian female  an active smoker with an unremarkable medical history except for obesity and occasional travel cross-country for work  presents with pain and swelling in her left calf that has progressively worsened over the past few days.   History of Present Illness: The patient describes the pain as a constant throbbing  rated 7 out of 10  not associated with activity or position  and not relieved by over-the-counter NSAIDs. She reports noticing a slight warmth and red color to the area  with associated swollen firmness. She denies any recent injuries  surgeries  or prolonged periods of immobility that might have precipitated the swelling. There is no history of bleeding disorders  recent medication changes  or active malignancies. She does mention that she recently flew cross-country for a work meeting but did not notice symptoms until a couple of days after returning home.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for BMI in the obese category  though no diagnosed metabolic disorders. She has a smoking history of 20-pack years. There are no past surgical interventions or past history of thrombotic events.  Review of Systems: The patient denies shortness of breath  cough  chest pain  or other respiratory symptoms. She has no gastrointestinal  urinary  or other systemic symptoms.   In summary  this patient is a middle-aged  obese  active smoker with recent prolonged travel  presenting with a clinical picture suggestive of left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis.

A 62-year-old African American female presents with unilateral leg pain  swelling  and warmth. The patient reports that these symptoms have been increasing in intensity during the past few days. She also mentions experiencing slight shortness of breath. She has a past medical history significant for obesity and hypertension  well-controlled with medication. Patient denies recent travel  immobilization  or surgeries. However  she does take hormone replacement therapy for menopausal symptoms. There is no significant family history of clotting disorders. Upon examination  her left calf is noticeably swollen and tender on palpation compared to the right calf. Her vital signs are stable. Given her symptoms and risk factors (older age  obesity  hypertension  and hormone replacement therapy)  a deep vein thrombosis is suspected.

Demographic Information: A 64-year -old  Caucasian female  sedentary lifestyle  nurse by profession with BMI of 30.  Medical History: The patient has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus. She has been on therapy with oral metformin (500mg 1-1-1) and lisinopril (20mg od) for 5 years. Patient has a history of heavy smoking for past 25 years but no known drug allergies. Patient reports a family history of a brother with a pulmonary embolism.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with progressive left leg pain and swelling that started suddenly a week ago  following a 12-hour long haul flight. The pain is worse upon moving the foot or walking. On examination  the left leg is significantly swollen  red  and warm to touch. Difficulty in leg movement due to pain is noted.   This patient's advanced age  female sex  sedentary lifestyle  obesity and personal/family history of thromboembolism make her more prone to Deep Vein Thrombosis. Her symptoms of leg pain  swelling along with the history of recent long haul travel suggest a possible diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis that needs to be promptly investigated and managed. Her significant history of smoking could also have contributed to her current condition and cardiovascular comorbidities.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  overweight  with a history of hypertension and sedentary lifestyle.  Medical History: The patient is known to hypertension  for which he is on medication (losartan). The patient also has a chronic history of smoking (40 pack-years). His lifestyle includes prolonged periods of inactivity  often sitting for several hours a day. He has no prior history of surgery  no known malignancies  and no known genetic predispositions. His mother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at the age of 70.  Presenting Issue: The patient presented with complaints of sudden onset  unilateral pain and swelling in the calf of his right leg. The pain reportedly intensifies when standing or walking. He also mentioned about a feeling of warmth over the swelled area  which is also redder than the rest area. The patient denied any recent injury  travel or changes in his daily routine. He also denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism.  Suspected Diagnosis: Considering the patient's risk factors (age  prolonged immobilization  hypertension  smoking  family history)  together with his symptoms  our primary suspicion is deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Further diagnostic tests  including a Doppler ultrasound  D-dimer test  and/or venography will be done to confirm the diagnosis.

Medical Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian male smoker  who is overweight and works in a sedentary office job.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He recently underwent a hip replacement surgery  following which he had been less mobile than usual.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with a one-week history of increasing left leg pain  along with swelling  warmness  redness  and tenderness along the inner side of the leg. No symptoms suggestive of a pulmonary embolism (e.g.  chest pain  shortness of breath). Mildly elevated temperature of 37.9°C.  Based on the demographic  history and symptom profile  there is high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg  potentially secondary to postoperative immobilization. Immediate diagnostic workup and appropriate management need to be initiated.  (Source: References are based on gender and age group susceptibility to DVT. Clinical manifestation and predisposing factors are generally accepted features of the condition in medical literature).

A 65-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher  presents with unilateral swelling  redness  and pain in the left calf for approximately 3 days  consistent with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's medical history includes obesity (BMI 31)  type II diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin  and a history of varicose veins. She also notes a sedentary lifestyle since retirement  especially recently due to COVID-19-related lockdowns. The patient has never smoked and reports no regular alcohol consumption. She has no known drug allergies. Her family history reveals both parents died of cardiovascular diseases in their 70s. She has been taking 81mg aspirin daily after encountering an episode of chest pain 2 years ago  but she was never formally diagnosed with ischemic heart disease. On examination  her left calf circumference is significantly greater than the right. Homan's sign is also positive. The swelling is warm to touch and there is slight tenderness in the calf muscle. She denies recent trauma  surgery  or prolonged travel  but mentions being more sedentary than usual due to lockdown constraints. Note: this patient is at high risk for the development of pulmonary embolism (PE)  as approximately 1/3 of untreated DVT patients can develop a PE which can be potentially life-threatening based on her risk factors including her age  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle.

A 60-year-old Caucasian female  married and retired school teacher  currently on hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for postmenopausal symptoms  presents with a 2-day history of swelling and pain in her left leg. The pain is described as a constant and dull  6/10 on the pain scale and doesn't alleviate with rest. She denies any recent travel  surgeries  or hospitalizations  but admits experiencing uncharacteristic lethargy and shortness of breath over the past week.  She has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with metformin  and hyperlipidemia  managed with statins. She has a family history notable for myocardial infarction in her father and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her mother. She used to smoke in her 20s but quit 30 years ago; she admits to occasional alcohol consumption.    On examination  her left calf appears noticeably swollen and tender compared to the right  and is warm to touch with mild erythema over the calf muscle. The patient's breathing rate seems a bit increased but her O2 sat levels are normal. Her remaining vital signs are in the normal range. No other abnormalities are found on the general physical examination. Her concern for her symptoms along with her clinical findings highlight a high likelihood of deep vein thrombosis with potential pulmonary involvement.

A 68-year-old  Caucasian female presents to the clinic feeling severe pain and warmth in her left lower leg for the past 1 week. She shared that her leg is also swollen and turned red. She has a 10-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension and underwent total hip replacement surgery 1 month ago. She mentions being noncompliant with mobility recommendations post-surgery. She is a retired teacher  denies any history of tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. Her BMI falls within the overweight range. Her only medication is Metformin for her diabetes. She does not have a genetic history of clotting disorders but reports her older sister experienced a pulmonary embolism in her seventies. She lives with her husband and is mostly sedentary after her surgery. The symptoms as elucidated  with the history of recent orthopedic surgery  older age  and low mobility state indicate a possibility of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower extremity.

A 65-year-old heavy smoker  Caucasian male presents with a five-day history of left leg pain and swelling. He has a 10-year medical history of poorly controlled Type II Diabetes and had undergone a hip replacement surgery 2 months ago post a fall at home. He also has a known allergic reaction to penicillin. The patient has noticed increasing redness and difficulty in walking due to the swelling. He also complains of mild shortness of breath for the past two days. On physical examination  the left leg is visibly swollen and red and is significantly warmer than the right leg. Physical palpation elicits pain. No chest pain  cough  or fever have been reported. Family history reveals that his mother suffered from a venous thromboembolic event in her late 60s. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle post-surgery and reports non-adherence to his prescribed physiotherapy and mobility schedule. The patient’s history  immobility  and clinical presentation are strongly suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Urgent diagnostic management and evaluation are needed given his respiratory symptoms which may suggest possible pulmonary embolism.

Patient is a 65-year-old overweight Caucasian male with a history of sedentary lifestyle  recent orthopedic surgery (hip replacement) two weeks ago and chronic smoking. The patient presented with complaints of a unilateral (right) swollen  warm and painful leg. The pain in the leg has been progressing over the last two days and is described as aching type occurring mainly in the calf. Further respiratory examination revealed a slightly elevated respiratory rate and low oxygen saturation levels on room air. The patient denies any chest pain  hemoptysis or recent travel history. However  he does report shortness of breath on exertion  which is unusual for him. Given the patient's recent orthopedic surgery  sedentary lifestyle  and symptom presentation  there is a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis potentially complicated by a pulmonary embolism.

A 63-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher  presents with an acute onset of severe pain  redness  and swelling in the left calf that started three days ago. She reports feeling generally unwell with mild shortness of breath but denies any chest pain  cough  or hemoptysis. She has a past medical history of type II diabetes managed with metformin  and hypertension controlled by lisinopril. She was on a 10 hours long haul flight two weeks ago. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol infrequently. She lives with her husband  and their home has no pets or environmental hazards. Her father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 70. The patient is overweight with a Body Mass Index of 31. She denies any recent surgeries or trauma. She is not on any hormone medications. Her vitals on examination: BP 130/85 mmHg  HR 98 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  SpO2 96% on room air  and temperature of 98.5 F. The left calf is tender  warm  erythematous with mild edema  approximately 3cm bigger in circumference than the right calf. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.

Patient Presentation: A 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presents with a three-day history of progressive pain and swelling in his left leg. The pain is predominantly in the calf region  extending up to the thigh. He reports the pain worsening when standing and describes it as a deep-seated vigorous ache. He denies any trauma or recent surgeries.   Medical History: His medical records reveal a five-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  well-managed with oral antihyperglycemics. He is also on low-dose aspirin for primary prevention of Cardiovascular diseases. He has a 35 pack-year smoking history but quit 3 years ago. There is no known history of coagulation disorders in the patient or his family.   Symptoms: On examination  his left leg is erythematous  warmer than the right leg and noticeably swollen with a positive Homan's sign. There is no associated chest pain  dyspnea  or hemoptysis. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits  and cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are unremarkable.  This patient's symptoms of unilateral leg swelling  pain  and erythema  in the context of significant risk factors such as advanced age  diabetes  and a history of heavy smoking  are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

A 62-year-old overweight Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and oral contraceptive long-term use presents with acute onset of left leg discomfort and visible swelling. The patient reveals that she leads a sedentary lifestyle  especially in the recent weeks due to restrictions of her remote work. She also reports a family history of deep vein thrombosis. The pain in her leg is described as persistent  dull  and is not associated with any trauma. Visual examination reveals skin over her left leg to be warm  with mild erythema. The patient denies any chest pain  shortness of breath or cough. However  there is some discoloration of left calf suggesting possible venous engorgement.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents with left leg pain  redness  and swelling that has been progressively worsening over the past 3 days. He reports no recent trauma or injury. His past medical history is significant for obesity  hypertension  and prostate cancer treated with surgery five years ago. He is currently prescribed lisinopril  aspirin  and atorvastatin and reports compliance with his medications. He denies any family history of clotting disorders. He does not smoke and drinks alcohol only socially.  On examination  his left leg is noticeably swollen  warmer than the right leg  and tender in the calf area. No visible venous distention. There is no shortness of breath  chest pain  or other symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism.  The patient has been sedentary for most days after retiring from his desk job last year and spends majority of his time at the computer at home. With the recent COVID-19 pandemic  he confirmed further reduction of physical activity and gain of few pounds of weight. This sedentary lifestyle and obesity place him at a higher potential risk for deep vein thrombosis.

A 63-year-old African American female with a past medical history of hypertension  obesity  and recent hip replacement surgery 4 weeks ago  presents with one week of swelling  warmth  and pain in her right lower leg. She denies any recent trauma but notes increased sedentary behavior since her surgery. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or distal neuropathy but appears anxious about her condition. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day. She takes hydrochlorothiazide for her hypertension and hasn't had any recent changes in her medication. On physical examination  her right leg appears to be slightly more swollen than the left  with mild erythema and increased warmth. A palpable cord is not appreciated. Her BMI is calculated as 32. Lab work is ongoing. The presentation is concerning for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a vascular condition that frequently occurs in the postoperative period  especially after orthopedic surgeries and in individuals with risk factors such as obesity  advanced age  and smoking. Urgent imaging studies and potential anticoagulation therapy are being considered for her treatment.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a history of obesity and sedentary lifestyle presents to the clinic complaining of a recent-onset swelling and pain in her right lower leg. She reports no history of trauma to the area but notes that she recently took a long-haul flight three days ago. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. Family history is significant for a sister who had deep vein thrombosis in her 50s. On examination  she displays a tender  swollen right calf which is warm to touch with some skin discoloration  and a positive Homan's sign. Pulse  blood pressure  and respiratory rate are within normal limits  and she does not exhibit any signs of respiratory distress. She reveals that she has recently been feeling excessively fatigued but had attributed it to adjusting back to her time zone post-flight. This patient presents with high suspicion of deep vein thrombosis.

A 63-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher  non-smoker  presents to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of increasing swelling  pain and warmth in her left calf. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent trauma. It is concerning for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Relevant medical history includes being on combined oral contraceptives  hypertension controlled with lisinopril  and no prior surgeries. Family history is positive for venous thromboembolic events  with her mother having had a pulmonary embolism in her late 60s. The patient is otherwise sedentary  rarely exercises and recently took a long-haul flight (12+ hours) for vacation  returning 72 hours prior to when symptoms began. There were no prolonged immobilization periods or major surgeries recently.   She demonstrates tenderness in the calf muscle and a positive Homan's sign (calf pain upon dorsiflexion of her foot). There's significant edema in the left lower limb with a notable difference in calf diameter compared to the right side. There is no peripheral pitting edema in the other leg  jugular venous pressure is not elevated  and the cardiovascular examination is otherwise unremarkable. No color changes or ulcers noted  and the pulses are symmetric.  The rest of her physical examination  including her pulmonary and abdominal examinations  show no significant findings. There's no hemoptysis  new neurological deficits  or any other recent or severe changes.

A 60-year old obese Caucasian female with a long-term history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with left lower leg swelling  redness and a palpable 'cord-like' structure along her venous path  which developed progressively over the last three days. The patient informs that the pain in her leg increased by standing and decreased when her leg was elevated. She also reports a recent long plane ride about ten days ago  and she smoked for 20 years  which she quit 10 years ago. There is no family history of blood clotting disorders. The patient is currently on Metformin for her diabetes and Amlodipine for hypertension but is not on any form of anticoagulants or antiplatelet drugs. She denies history of injury  trauma  or surgery in the last six months. Her vital signs on presentation reveals a blood pressure of 144/90mmHg  pulse rate of 84 beats/min  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air  with a BMI of 33 indicating clinical obesity.

A 60-year-old white  overweight female presents with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She has a known personal 20-year history of type II diabetes mellitus that is poorly controlled  along with a 35-year smoking history. Over the past five days  the patient notes an increasing pain in her left lower leg  scoring it at a 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain is described as constant and cramping in nature  which is exacerbated during walking. The leg is also warm and noticeably swollen. Patient reports no recent traveling or immobilization  but does note difficulties with controlling her blood sugar levels recently. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or similar symptoms in the other leg. Her medication list includes Metformin and Humulin N. Her family history is noteworthy for her father who suffered from recurrent deep vein thrombosis and her mother who had pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  Ms. Thompson  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  with a medical history significant for obesity (BMI 35)  hypertension  and previous right knee replacement surgery 10 days ago  presents to the emergency department with intense pain and swelling in her right lower leg. Over the last 3 days  she also reported a gradually increasing warmth and redness in the same area. There are no symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath or loss of consciousness. On examination  the right calf is markedly swollen and warm to touch and there is tenderness along the distribution of the deep venous system. The remaining examination is unremarkable. She does not have any known allergies and is taking antihypertensives regularly. She is an ex-smoker and stopped 5 years ago. She lives with her husband and has two children. She is retired and used to work as a schoolteacher. No history of any similar symptoms in the past. Screening for inherited thrombophilia has never been done. Her father had a history of stroke at an elderly age. Her mother is healthy. She denies any familial history of blood clots.

A 62-year-old African American female presents to the Emergency Department with swelling  pain  and a slightly raised temperature in her left leg  which has been worsening over the past couple of days. She is slightly overweight with a BMI of 28.6 and has a medical history of hypertension  which she manages with medication. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She recently undertook a long-haul flight without regular activity  which might have contributed to the deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Additionally  she has a family history of DVT; her sister had a similar condition five years ago. She is currently taking an oral contraceptive  which she mentioned was prescribed to her approximately one year ago. The patient doesn’t use any recreational drugs  but she does have a sedentary lifestyle because she works as an accountant. At present  she is not experiencing chest pain or shortness of breath  and her vitals are within normal limits. However  her left leg appeared erythematous  warmer  and more swollen than her right leg. An urgent D-dimer test was subsequently ordered  which returned positive  and a Doppler ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of DVT.

A 65-year-old  Caucasian female with a medical history of Grade II obesity (BMI of 35)  Type 2 diabetes  and hypertension  presents with a 3-day history of swelling  pain  redness  and warmth in her left lower leg. Patient noticed these symptoms after a long-haul flight returning from vacation. She reports the pain as being constant  and increasing with walking or standing for long periods. She denies having chest pain  shortness of breath  or other systemic symptoms. No history of trauma  injury  or recent surgeries. She's currently taking Metformin for her diabetes and Lisinopril for her hypertension. She has no known drug allergies and she reports no alcohol  smoking  or illicit drug use. Her family history is significant for Type 2 diabetes and hypertension  but negative for clotting disorders.

A 60-year-old Caucasian female presents with a 5-day history of severe  localized calf pain and swelling in her right leg. The patient also reports feeling slightly short of breath and experiencing occasional sharp chest pains. Medical history is significant for obesity (BMI 30.2 kg/m2)  inactive lifestyle and prior unprovoked deep vein thrombosis (DVT) episode 5 years back. She has been taking daily oral contraceptive pills for menopausal symptoms for the last year. On examination  the right calf is visibly swollen compared to the left and is warm and tender to touch. The Homans’ sign was positive. She is afebrile  with a blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg and a heart rate of 100 beats per minute. There is no relevant family history or indication of recent prolonged immobilization  surgeries  or malignancy.

A 56-year-old Caucasian woman with a past medical history significant for obesity and recent total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago presents with persisting and significant pain and swelling in her surgically replaced right knee. The pain is sharp  non-radiating  and is associated with warmth and redness. She also mentions she has been less mobile than usual due to postoperative pain. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. She does not smoke nor has a family history of blood disorders. She has been taking some prescribed painkillers and anticoagulants but admits she has skipped a few doses. On examination  her right lower limb is visibly swollen and warmer to touch in comparison to the left one. The patient's symptoms and medical history suggest a probable case of postoperative deep vein thrombosis.

Patient is a 65-year-old obese Caucasian female with a history of high blood pressure and recent right leg orthopedic surgery  who presents with redness  warmth  swelling  and pain in her right lower leg that started 3 days ago. She is currently taking antihypertensive drugs  but not taken any prophylactic anticoagulants. Patient has no family history of clotting disorders  but she had 2 previous episodes of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) one year ago. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol regularly. She has been largely sedentary since her surgery  which was performed 2 weeks ago. She denies chest pain or shortness of breath  but acknowledges experiencing mild fatigue over the past few days.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents with a 3-day history of progressive left calf pain and mild swelling  associated with increasing redness. She works as an accountant  leading a fairly sedentary lifestyle including long periods of sitting at her desk. Medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medication. She is a former smoker  and her family history is significant for her father having a pulmonary embolism. She also recently took a long-haul flight (12 hours) two weeks prior to symptom onset. On exam  her left calf appears erythematous and mildly swollen compared to her right. Homans' sign is positive. She denies fever  dyspnea or chest pain. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal vein.

A 60-year-old  overweight  post-menopausal Caucasian woman  non-smoker  with a past medical history of oral contraceptive use and a recent long distance air travel. She presents with a 3-day history of progressive left leg pain and swelling. Patient describes the pain as aching and cramping  located in the calf but extending to the thigh. The left leg is noticeably swollen and warm to the touch compared to the right leg. No associated chest pain  breathlessness  or any other systemic symptoms. Her grandmother had history of DVT. She has no known drug allergies.

A 65-year-old African American male with a history of obesity  hypertension  and a recent orthopedic surgery in his left knee presents with a 3-day history of swelling  redness  pain  and warmth on the lower left leg. Patient also complains of shortness of breath  which started a day before the leg symptoms. He reports difficulty in putting weight on the affected leg and experiences increased pain when he tries to move his foot. Patient is a former smoker  having quit tobacco 5 years ago. As a truck driver  he spends long periods seated. He denies chest pain  cough  fever  trauma to the leg or any history of cancer. Family history includes a brother who experienced a similar condition after a surgical procedure. Patient's symptoms are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) involving the left leg  potentially complicated by a pulmonary embolism.

Patient: 55-year-old Caucasian female  Medical History: The patient has a history of ovarian cancer for which she was treated 3 years back. She is overweight (BMI of 32)  has been on oral contraceptives for 10 years and she has been leading a sedentary lifestyle due to her current job. Patient also has family history of blood clot and reports occasional smoking.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with pain  redness  and swelling in the left calf area. The pain worsens when she tries to flex her foot. She also reports a recent discomfort and mild chest pain which made her apprehensive leading to the present consultation. In the past 2-4 days  she also reports of increased breathlessness and fatigue.  This presentation coincides with a higher prevalence of DVT which is found to be more common in women  especially with a history of obesity  cancer  tobacco use  family history of blood clot and hormone use.

Problem Representation:  Patient  a 60-year-old Caucasian female  current smoker with a health history of oral contraceptive use  obesity and a known familial thrombophilia  presents to the clinic with feelings of discomfort in her left lower extremity  including localized warmth  redness  and swelling of the calf. Reported symptoms developed over the past few days. Patient did not report any shortness of breath  chest pain  coughing or haemoptysis. She indicates that she's been less active than usual recently due to work-from-home orders. There is a marked asymmetry between the two calves in favor of the left one. There's also a posiotive Homan sign (calf pain at dorsiflexion of the foot).   This patient's overall clinical picture along with risk factors and familial history of thrombophilic conditions suggest a possible diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of hypertension and recent total hip replacement surgery  presents to the Outpatient Department with left leg pain and swelling that initially started 4 days ago. The patient states the pain is a constant  dull ache that intensifies when he tries to move his leg. He also describes his left calf as feeling warm and apparently larger than the right. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately. He has not been very mobile since his surgery  spending the majority of his time in bed. His current medications include atenolol for hypertension. On physical examination  his left calf is found to be erythematous  swollen and tender upon palpation. He speaks clearly  denies any chest pain or shortness of breath but reports feeling slightly dizzy. He has no known allergies. His hypertension has been well controlled with medication  no previous history of blood clots or familial history.

A 68-year-old African American woman presents with a chief complaint of worsening pain and swelling in her left lower extremity for the past 5 days. The pain is described as a constant  aching pain localized to the calf and is associated with noticeable edema. She denies any recent long travels or history of immobilization. She has a past medical history of hypertension controlled with Lisinopril and is also post-menopausal. She is a nonsmoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and is overweight with a BMI of 32. She does not report any changes in her medication or diet. She denies any chest pain  lightheadedness  or shortness of breath. She has no known drug allergies. Her mother underwent hip replacement surgery and developed a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) postoperatively. Physical examination reveals warmth  erythema  and swelling over the left calf  but no signs of superficial thrombophlebitis  such as tenderness along a superficial vein. The remainder of her examination is unremarkable.   Diagnostic consideration: Given the patient's presentation and clinical findings  the most likely diagnosis is deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  particularly given her history of obesity  age  race  hypertension  and family history of DVT.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female  with a history of obesity (BMI 35)  type 2 diabetes and sedentary lifestyle  presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of pain  swelling and warmth over the left lower limb. She also reports a sensation of heaviness in the same limb. She recently had a long-distance travel (flight) of more than 5 hours and has been on oral contraceptive pills for menopausal symptoms. She denies any recent surgeries or traumatic injuries. She admits to an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of possible atrial fibrillation but does not smoke nor report any family history of thromboembolic disorders. These symptoms are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker  with a significant medical history of obesity (BMI: 32)  and recent total left hip arthroplasty 4 weeks ago for osteoarthritis  presents with a 2-day history of a progressively painful  swollen and warm left lower extremity. The patient denies fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath but admits to limited mobility post-operatively. She also reported unintentional weight gain of 10lbs over the past month despite a decreased appetite. Clinical examination was remarkable for a tender left calf with positive Homan's sign. There were no visible ulcers on the calf  however pitting edema was present. No axillary or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy was noted. She has no family history of venous thromboembolism. She did not use hormonal therapy and there is no history of malignancy. She takes paracetamol and cholecalciferol regularly. Her oral temperature was 98.4°F  blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg  pulse rate 90/minute  respiratory rate 12/minute  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. All these findings strongly point towards deep vein thrombosis (DVT) status post hip arthroplasty. Further workup  including duplex ultrasonography and D-dimer assay  is required to confirm the diagnosis.

A 65-year-old African American male  retired truck driver and ex-smoker for 10 years  presents with a 5-day history of increasing pain and swelling in the right calf. The patient denies any recent trauma  surgery  or extended periods of immobilization. He mentions a recent long-haul flight 2 weeks ago. He also reports a family history of clotting disorders  as his sister recently was diagnosed with Factor V Leiden disorder. He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are well-controlled with amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. He denies experiencing chest pain or dyspnea. On physical examination  the right calf appears visibly swollen and is warm to touch  with tenderness elicited upon palpation  but without any signs of superficial vein varicosities or ulcers. Pulmonary and cardiovascular examinations are within normal limits.

A 62-year-old  overweight Caucasian male presents to the clinic with ongoing severe calf pain  redness  and recent onset of unilateral leg swelling in the past few days. He has a history of smoking and is currently on medication for hypertension. He recently underwent hip replacement surgery and has spent a prolonged period of time being sedentary post-surgery. On examination  his left leg appears notably swollen  warm to touch compared to the other leg  and the patient reports tenderness. No evidence of varicose veins  skin lesions  or ulcers. The patient also reports mild shortness of breath when climbing the stairs. He has no known allergies and his family history includes father who suffered from recurrent DVT and a maternal aunt who died of pulmonary embolism. He lives alone  is a retired engineer  and does not engage in regular exercise due to limited mobility post-surgery.

Problem Representation:  A 70-year-old African American male presents to the hospital with a 3-day history of pain  swelling  and warmth in the left calf. His medical history is significant for hypertension and a history of smoking for over 30 years. He states that he recently had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy two weeks ago  after which he has been relatively immobile. On examination  the left calf appeared swollen and warmer than the right one. A positive Homan's sign was also noted. There have been no past occurrences of similar symptoms  no respiratory symptoms  and no family history of blood clot disorders. The patient does not take any regular medications and has no known drug allergies. Given his recent surgery  immobilization  and symptoms  a presumptive diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was made. This was supported by the findings of a D-dimer test and subsequently confirmed by a Doppler ultrasound which showed a clotted blood vessel in the left calf region.

A 65-year-old  white  postmenopausal woman presents with complaints of swollen  red  warm and painful calf in the right leg for the past 3 days. She reports recent immobility following a total hip replacement surgery two weeks ago. She has a known history of obesity (BMI 30) and type 2 diabetes  which is under fair control with metformin and lifestyle modifications. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. No prior history of venous thromboembolism (VTE). Her family history is significant  with a sister who has had deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or other systemic symptoms. On clinical examination  her right calf is noted to be swollen  warm  erythematous  and tender to touch  with a positive Homan's sign. Upon further examination  her vitals are stable and other systems are unremarkable. She has laboratories ordered and an ultrasound scheduled to confirm DVT.

A 60-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden onset of left lower extremity pain and swelling for the past two days. The patient notes an increased difficulty walking due to the pain and swelling. She also reports having a minor laparoscopic surgery in the lower abdomen three weeks ago after which her mobility was greatly reduced  spending most of her time either sitting or lying down. She has a 30-pack year smoking history and has been on oral contraceptive pills for the past five years. She denies recent travel  trauma  or family history of blood clotting disorders. Physical examination reveals a warm  erythematous  and swollen left calf with a positive Homan’s sign. No superficial venous distension or varicosities are noted. She has normal vital signs with no evidence of tachypnea or tachycardia. No chest pain or shortness of breath is noted. These findings are highly suspicious for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the clinical setting.

A 57-year-old Caucasian female  with a known history of prolonged immobility due to hip replacement therapy  presents to ER with complaints of a two-day history of progressive swelling  pain  and redness in her left lower leg. She also reports noticing the leg is a bit warmer compared to the right one. The patient also discloses she has been on hormone replacement therapy for post-menopausal symptoms. She has a family history of blood clotting disorders  specifically Factor V Leiden deficiency  but has not been tested herself. She denies any history of cancer  recurrent miscarriages  or travels on long flights. She is a non-smoker and denies alcohol consumption. On clinical examination  the left leg appears swollen and pale compared to the right. She has a palpable cord in the popliteal area  tenderness along the involved veins  and pitting edema of the left leg. These clinical findings suggest a possible diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).

Patient Demographics: A 72-year-old Caucasian female.  Medical History: The patient has a significant history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and a recent right hip arthroplasty 3 weeks ago. She is currently overweight with a BMI of 31 and is a nonsmoker. Her medication history includes Metformin and Lisinopril. She has a known surgical history of a hysterectomy and appendectomy in her early 50s. There is a family history of myocardial infarction in her father who died at the age of 62.  Problem Presentation: The patient presents with acute onset of right leg pain and swelling that began suddenly in the morning. She describes the pain as constant  aching  and non-radiating. She also reports that the pain intensifies with standing or ambulation. The patient denies any trauma or injury to the area  but she states she did recently take a 6-hour car ride two days ago. Additionally  she has remained relatively immobile following her hip replacement surgery. She denies any other associated symptoms such as chest pain  shortness of breath  changes in skin color  cough  or urinary symptoms. Physical examination reveals tenderness  erythema  warmth  and edema of the right calf. There are no signs of superficial vein thrombosis or cellulitis.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a recently identified history of obesity (BMI: 34) and immobility due to a broken leg sustained two months ago presents with complaints of localized pain and swelling accompanied by warmth and redness in her left calf. The patient reports she has been experiencing these symptoms for the past 5 days  rapidly increasing in severity. She notes that her left leg feels slightly heavier than her right and she has also been experiencing mild shortness of breath in the past 2 days. She has no past record of any thrombotic events  and no known family history of clotting disorders. She does not use tobacco but occasionally drinks alcohol. An ultrasound reveals a blood clot in one of her deep veins  confirming a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history significant for obesity (BMI of 32)  and recent right total knee arthroplasty presents to the clinic for follow-up consultation. She reports experiencing some unusual symptoms over the past week  most notably progressive right leg pain and swelling. She also mentions that the leg has taken on a warm  reddish discoloration  and she’s noticed some faint paresthesia. The patient denies any recent trauma to the leg. However  she confesses that she hasn't been as mobile since her knee surgery  spending most of her time sitting or lying down. Also noteworthy is that she hasn't been using the anticoagulant medication (as prophylaxis against DVT) prescribed after the surgery because she was worried about its bleeding side effects. Her only known drug allergy is to penicillin  which causes rash. On examination  the right leg is significantly swollen and warm to touch compared to the left one. She is afebrile with normal vital signs. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. A clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis is raised.

Patient is a 65-year-old obese Caucasian male  former smoker  with a past medical history of metabolic syndrome including hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Patient also has a known history of prostate cancer  for which he underwent surgery two years ago  with subsequent chemotherapy. He presents to the emergency department with a recent onset of sudden pain and swelling in the left lower extremity  which has increased over the last 3 days. He also reports increased warmth over the swollen area and slight discoloration. The patient has no history of leg injury and denies any recent travels or prolonged immobility. He also denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness.

A 65-year-old obese  Caucasian woman with a history of recent hip replacement surgery and hormonal replacement therapy presents with a 4-day history of sudden-onset  persistent pain and swelling in her right lower leg which is worse when standing or walking. She also reports experiencing some occasional shortness of breath.   She has a medical history significant for hypothyroidism managed with levothyroxine  and her surgical history includes a recent total right hip replacement surgery  3 weeks ago. The patient's social history reveals that she is a non-smoker and takes occasional alcohol. She is a retired teacher who is currently less mobile due to surgery. Her family history is positive for pulmonary embolism in her mother. She describes the pain as constant  aching  deep pain in her calf which is exacerbated with the movement of the foot. On examination  there is pitting edema  redness  warmth  and tenderness over the right calf muscle. She rates the pain as 8 out of 10 on the pain scale.  In context  these symptoms could represent a postoperative deep vein thrombosis  potential risk factors for which include her hip replacement surgery  obesity  hormonal replacement therapy  and a family history of venous thromboembolism. The calf pain  redness  warmth  and swelling are symptoms of deep vein thrombosis while shortness of breath is a concerning symptom for a potential pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  who is a current smoker with a sedentary job as a truck driver  presented to the clinic complaining of pain  edema  and warmth in his right lower leg for the past 3 days. He has a known medical history of obesity (BMI 32)  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  but no surgeries apart from back surgery 3 years ago. He has never had any previous instances of venous thromboembolism. On examination  his right calf appears red  swollen  and is noted to be warmer than the left. He also demonstrates a positive Homan's sign. Taking into consideration the patient's symptomology  risk factors  and physical examination findings  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is suspected.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male  an office worker  with a history of obesity (BMI of 30) and recent extended air travel  presents with new-onset left leg swelling  redness  tenderness  and pain that intensifies with standing/walking. He is a former smoker with a 10 pack-year history and is on medication for hypertension but has no other significant medical history. He denies any recent trauma  family history of clotting disorders or recent surgeries. He has no associated symptoms like shortness of breath  chest pain  or calf tenderness. His vitals are stable except for slightly elevated blood pressure. He is not on oral anticoagulants but takes aspirin occasionally for headaches.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a 3-day history of increasing pain  swelling  and warmth in his left leg. The patient describes the pain as constant and worsening with movement. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or other symptoms. He has a medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and obesity  and reports a sedentary lifestyle with base levels of immobilization. He has no personal or family history of blood clotting disorders. On examination  there is unilateral (left) leg swelling that is tender to touch  with localized redness and warmth. The patient also notes that he recently had a hip replacement surgery. The symptoms and history suggest a potential diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  with risk factors including his recent surgery  advanced age  obesity  and limited mobility.

Problem Representation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents with unilateral swelling and redness of the lower extremity. She reports experiencing severe  cramp-like pain in her right calf for the past 4 days  which has been progressively worsening. She mentions that the pain increases while walking. She denies experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis. She has a past medical history of varicose veins and was previously on hormone replacement therapy for post-menopausal symptoms. She also mentions an episode of superficial venous thrombosis 8 years ago. On review of medications  she only takes a daily aspirin for heart disease prevention. The patient sits most of the day at her work and recently took a long car trip. On physical examination  her right leg is visibly swollen and warm to touch compared to left  with a positive Homans' sign. Her vital signs are stable  and cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are within normal limits. Based on her age  gender  past history of venous thrombosis  sedentary job  varicose veins  and hormone therapy  the patient is potentially at high risk for deep vein thrombosis. The symptoms of unexplained swelling  leg pain  warmth  and redness prompt the need for further investigation to rule out DVT.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history notable for obesity (BMI 32) and hyperlipidemia presents with pain  inflammation  and redness in her lower left leg that has been worsening for the past 5 days. She reports that the pain is noticeable at rest and feels worse when walking. She denies any recent travel  surgery  or history of immobilization. There is a positive history of hormone replacement therapy for the past 3 years due to post-menopausal symptoms. She reports no personal or family history of clotting disorders or venous thromboembolism but did have a maternal aunt who had a stroke at age 67. On physical examination  the patient was noted to have a fever and an overlying warmth on the affected part of the leg. The calf on the involved side was noticed to be larger than the unaffected side. She reports that she had noticed a slight difficulty in breathing and mild chest pain for the past two days  which she did not initially associate with her leg issue. She was otherwise healthy and had no other chronic medical conditions. She denied any history of smoking or excessive alcohol drinking. She lives with her husband and works as a kindergarten teacher. This patient's overall clinical picture raises concerns for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  potentially with pulmonary embolism due to the recent onset of respiratory symptoms.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents with a 3-day history of increasing left calf pain and swelling. The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a recent right hip replacement surgery four weeks ago. She reports no prior history of any similar symptoms. In the past  she was a smoker but quit about 15 years ago. The family history is negative for venous thromboembolic events. Vitals on presentation are within normal limits except for a mildly elevated heart rate of 105 bpm. Physical examination shows left lower limb edema  tenderness  warmth  and positive Homan’s sign  raising suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). No signs of pulmonary embolism  such as shortness of breath or chest pain  are present. Her current medications include metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension. She was not on any anticoagulants post-surgery.

Patient is a 47-year-old Caucasian male  previously healthy but with a positive family history of thromboembolic conditions presenting with symptoms consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient noticed gradual onset of unexplained pain  tenderness  and swelling in his left leg particularly around the calf area a week ago. He recently had a long-haul flight (15 hours) with sedentary behavior and no breaks for exercise. He denies any history of trauma  infections or surgeries. The patient is a current smoker  consumes alcohol socially  and works a desk job requiring him to sit for extended periods. He reports no previous medications or known allergies. Physical examination illuminates a warm  erythematous  and tender left lower limb with a notable calf circumference difference compared to unaffected side. No significant findings in other systems on examination.

A 65-year-old white male with a known history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and overweight  arrives with complaints of unexplained swelling and persistent pain in his left calf for the past 4 days. There are no traumatic events reported. He also mentions a recent long-distance flight 2 weeks ago. The pain has been increasing gradually and is particularly noticeable while standing or walking. He denies shortness of breath  chest pain  headache  or visual disturbances. There's no history of venous thromboembolism or malignancies. On examination  his left calf is red  swollen  warm  and tender to touch. Pulses in the lower limb are intact. Currently  he receives oral metformin for diabetes and statins for hyperlipidemia. His BMI is 29.

Patient Representation:   A 60-year-old Caucasian female presents to the clinic with complaints of a unilateral swollen and painful right leg over the past two weeks. The patient describes the pain as a sudden onset  cramping  and isolated to her calf. She denies any trauma or recent injury to her leg  but admits to having recently taken a long-distance overseas flight. She states that she is generally inactive  does not perform regular exercise  and has been on oral contraceptive therapy for the past decade.   Relevant medical history includes controlled hypertension for which she is on medication  obesity with a BMI of 32  and hypothyroidism. The patient's father had a history of deep vein thrombosis. Patient denies any other medical conditions  surgeries or known allergies.  Physical examination revealed a warm  tender  erythematous and swollen right lower limb  primarily in the calf area  with localized pain on deep palpation. The patient's vital signs were stable  and the rest of the examination was unremarkable.   In light of her age  obesity  long-flight history  contraceptive use  and presence of unilateral leg pain and swelling  deep vein thrombosis is suspected.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian woman with a past medical history significant for obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic with a one week history of left calf pain and swelling. The patient reports that the affected leg feels warm to touch and its color has turned red. She also reports recent immobility due to a 10-hour road trip a week ago. She denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough or fever. She has a 40 pack-year smoking history and takes oral hypoglycemic agents. Family history is notable for a brother with a previous deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Physical examination shows a tender and swollen left calf with erythema. An ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. The patient is started on a course of anticoagulants for treatment.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the emergency department experiencing unrelenting  increasingly severe pain and swelling in his right leg over the past week. The edema is strikingly asymmetrical  presenting solely in the right leg  which also feels warm to the touch with visible skin discoloration. He denies any history of trauma or injury to his leg  but notes persistent discomfort when moving his ankle or walking.   He has a medical history of recent hip replacement surgery 6 weeks prior  intermittently controlled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and he is a former heavy smoker with a 30-pack year history. The patient currently takes metformin and lisinopril daily. He followed post-surgery anticoagulation protocol following his surgery but discontinued the use of prophylactic anticoagulant agent two weeks ago.   This combination of recent surgery  personal history of smoking  and advancing age  together with the clinical symptoms of unilateral leg pain  swelling  and discoloration prompt concern for possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

A 64-year-old Caucasian female presents with acute onset of left leg pain  swelling  and warmth for 5 days' duration. She also reports mild shortness of breath without any associated chest pain. The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension and obesity with a BMI of 32. For the past six months  she had been taking hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for menopausal symptoms. Three months ago  she took a long-haul flight to visit her family overseas. Physical examination reveals erythema  warmth  swelling  and tenderness in the left calf. On questioning  the patient denies any previous history of thrombotic events or known family history of clotting disorders. The patient is a nonsmoker and moderately sedentary. She reports she has been adherent to her antihypertensive medication. Her Framingham Score indicates a low 10-year risk for coronary artery disease. Considering her age  HRT use  recent long-haul flight  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle  the patient is experiencing symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis.

A 63-year-old Caucasian female presents with left lower extremity pain and swelling for the past 3 days. The pain is constant and aching  and the patient notes that her leg feels heavy. She has a history of obesity (BMI 32.4)  type two diabetes mellitus well controlled with metformin  and has been on oral contraceptives for the past one year due to menopausal symptoms. She denies any recent trauma  travel  or surgery. She is a non-smoker and denies any family history of thromboembolic disease. On physical examination her left calf is visibly swollen and warm to touch compared to the right. Her pulses are equally strong in both legs  and there is no skin discoloration. There is tenderness in the calf muscle on deep palpation. She presents a positive Homan's sign elicited during the examination.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired factory worker  presents with a 2-day history of pain  swelling  and warmth in his left lower leg. The symptoms started suddenly and have progressively worsened. No history of recent trauma  surgery or prolonged immobilization. He has a past medical history of hypertension controlled using losartan 50mg daily  and Type II Diabetes Mellitus managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily. He is a heavy smoker  consuming more than 20 cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. The patient denies any symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath or dizziness. However  he mentions a family history of deep vein thrombosis  as his father was diagnosed at the age of 70. He denies any known hemorrhagic disorders and has no known drug allergies. Physical examination reveals a swollen  warm and erythematous left calf that is tender on palpation. No obvious superficial venous dilations are visible. Lower extremity pulses are normal and equal bilaterally. Homan's sign is positive on the left side. No other signs of systemic illness are identified. The patient's Weight is 90 kg and Height is 175 cm with a BMI of 29  suggesting he is overweight.

A 62-year-old Caucasian woman with a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and obesity presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of a persistently swollen  red  and warm right lower leg for the past 4 days. She mentions an increasing heaviness and discomfort in her leg while walking but denies any injury. She recently returned from a 14-hour long-haul flight  during which she remained seated most of the time. She denies any chest pain  palpitations or shortness of breath. On physical examination  her right calf appears noticeably swollen and warm to touch  with mild tenderness. Her vital signs are within normal ranges. Her BMI is 33 kg/m2  denoting obesity. Her medications include metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension. Further testing is conducted to rule out deep vein thrombosis considering her risk factors of obesity  long travel  and limited mobility during the flight.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female from obesity prevalent area  presents with a complaint of one-week history of increasing left leg pain and swelling. She reports a recent 10-hour flight a week ago  followed by overall reduced mobility related to a sedentary lifestyle and an office desk job. Her medical history is significant for well-managed hypertension  obesity (BMI 30)  and she's on oral contraception. She denies any history of smoking  cancer  or previous clotting issues. Reports familial history of Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) in her father. Current symptoms include left calf tenderness  swollen and reddened left leg with increased warmth  which is significantly different from the right extremity. On examination  a positive Homan's sign was identified. The patient's heart rate was slightly elevated (110 beats/min)  but otherwise vitals were stable (BP: 130/85 mmHg  Temperature: 98.6 F  RR: 15 breaths/min  SpO2: 98% on room air). There are no significant findings on pulmonary  cardiovascular and abdominal examination. Findings are more suggestive of a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  warranting further investigations.

A 52-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient is a non-smoker  overweight (BMI 32)  and recently underwent a total hip arthroplasty 3 weeks ago. She reports an acute onset of unilateral swelling  warmth  and pain in her left calf over the past 48 hours. The patient rates her pain as a 7 on a scale from 1 to 10  with 10 being the most severe. On examination  she presents positive Homan's sign. She additionally reveals she has been largely immobile post-surgery due to pain and reliance on her husband for mobility assistance. She has no personal or family history of clotting disorders but took oral contraceptives up until five years ago. Her vital signs are within normal limits but her left calf is visibly swollen compared to her right calf  and significantly tender to touch. No signs of chest pain or dyspnea are noted. She denies any known exposure to COVID-19 and she had a negative PCR test prior to her recent surgical procedure.

A 60-year-old  Caucasian male  ex-smoker  with a history of sedentary lifestyle and recent hip replacement surgery  presents with sudden onset of pain  swelling  and warmth over his left lower limb. The patient expressed that his calf muscle is very tender and hurts when he tries to extend his leg. He also mentions a general feeling of heaviness in the affected leg. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the region. He reports shortness of breath with a slight cough but denies any chest pain. He has no personal or family history of clotting disorders. The patient's BMI is 28  and he has a history of high cholesterol level. He recently traveled long distance post his hip surgery. All these symptoms are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents with pain  swelling  and tenderness in her right lower leg. On inquiry  she mentions a warm sensation and slight skin discoloration in the region of discomfort. She denies injury or trauma to the leg recently. She also feels slightly short of breath which is new and has palpitations. Her medical history is significant for obesity (BMI 31) and sedentary lifestyle. Additionally  she also shares she underwent a total hip replacement surgery 6 weeks ago and has been relatively immobile post-surgery. She has a smoking history of 30 pack years and no known drug allergies.  Tentative Diagnosis:  Given her age  recent orthopedic surgery  immobility  obesity  as well as presenting symptoms including pain  swelling  slight discoloration  warmth in the lower leg and shortness of breath—all are collectively suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The shortness of breath and palpitations could signal a potential pulmonary embolism  which would warrant immediate investigation and possible treatment.

A 67-year-old African American male presents with the chief complaint of unilateral swelling  pain and warmth in his right leg for the past three days. He reports the sensation of heaviness and discomfort in the right leg which is exacerbated on standing or walking. Additionally  he reveals worsening dyspnea for the same duration. His medical history is significant for stage II hypertension  obesity with a BMI of 32  and a recent total knee replacement surgery on the right side two weeks ago. He is a former smoker but quit five years ago. He denies history of any known bleeding or clotting disorders in the family. Currently  he is on antihypertensives. He denies any allergy to drugs. On examination  his right lower limb is found to be distended  erythematous and tender with a positive Homans’ sign. Pulses are palpable in the right leg. The cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with a heart rate of 105 bpm. The rest of the systemic examination is unremarkable. The presenting symptoms  coupled with the medical history of surgery suggests a high probability of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher .  Medical History: She has a 20-year history of hypertension  for which she is on medication and it is well-controlled. She also has a history of Factor V Leiden mutation  which increases her risk for clotting. She has been treated for a DVT once before  three years ago.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient has presented with a red  swollen  tender calf and complains of ongoing pain. She reports being increasingly immobile recently due to a self-quarantine for COVID-19 and having undergone a recent knee surgery 5 weeks back. The patient also mentions feeling slightly short of breath.   This summary represents a commonly seen demographic for deep vein thrombosis (DVT): older  Caucasian females with a history of hypertension  surgery  prolonged immobility  genetic predisposition (Factor V Leiden mutation)  prior DVT episode  and potential signs of pulmonary embolism (shortness of breath).

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of obesity  hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  and recent hip replacement surgery presents with a three-day history of unilateral lower leg pain  swelling  and redness. The pain concerns her as it seems to worsen with walking or when standing. She reports no history of smoking  no use of hormonal therapies  and does not have a family history of clotting disorders. She did not have any previous episodes of venous thromboembolism. On examination  the left leg appears to be noticeably swollen and warmer than the right  with mild tenderness along the calf. Pulses are preserved. She is afebrile  with blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  heart rate of 85 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation at a stable 98% on room air. She denies shortness of breath or chest pain. Considering the patient's postoperative status  symptoms and risk factors suggest deep vein thrombosis.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of obesity (BMI: 31)  current smoker (20 pack-years)  and recent 15-hour international flight. She presents with a 3-day history of unilateral leg pain  redness  and swelling  particularly in the right calf region. She also reports shortness of breath that has worsened over the past day. The patient denies any history of cancer  genetic coagulation disorder  or previous venous thromboembolism. No known family history of clotting disorders. No surgical procedures within the past six months. The patient does not use hormonal contraception. She lives alone and functions independently. She has no known drug allergies and is not on any chronic medications. She is urgently interested in figuring out what could cause these symptoms and if it could be serious.

A 60-year-old  overweight Caucasian female with a known medical history of hypertension and the use of hormonal replacement therapy presents with complaints of persistent right leg pain and swelling over the past week. She reports the pain as dull  progressively worsening and localized in the calf region. Along with this  she reveals that she recently undertook a long-haul flight from Australia to the United States around 10 days ago. On examination  her leg appears edematous and slightly erythematous. There are no visible signs of injury  but calf tenderness is noted. She has a normal temperature and heart rate  a slightly elevated blood pressure reading of 145/85 mmHg  and her breathing rate is unremarkable.
