Her recent sedentary lifestyle along with her medical background raises suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of obesity and recent hip replacement surgery presents with increasing pain and swelling on her left leg  which began two days ago. She shared that the pain feels like a cramp or charley horse and denies any trauma to the leg. She also noted that the skin over the area has turned warm and reddish. Furthermore  she mentions having a non-productive cough and mild shortness of breath upon exertion in recent days. She denies chest pain  palpitations  or spells of lightheadedness. She is a non-smoker  has a sedentary lifestyle  and has no known allergies. She is on regular acetaminophen for postoperative pain control following her hip surgery. Her family history is notable for a father who died from complications related to deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Upon examination  there is noticeable swelling  warmth  and redness over the left lower leg with tenderness on palpitation. Her vitals are normal except for slightly elevated blood pressure. Her body mass index (BMI) is calculated as 32 kg/m2  indicating obesity. Due to her combined risk factors - recent surgery  lack of physical activity  obesity  family history  and presenting symptoms - there is a high clinical suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient is a 65-year-old overweight Caucasian female with a history of prolonged immobilization due to a fractured right hip 6 weeks ago and hormone replacement therapy. She presents with unilateral leg swelling  warmth  redness  and tenderness  more pronounced in the right leg  for the past two days. She also reports transient shortness of breath. She denies chest pain  cough  abdominal pain  joint pain or recent surgery. She confirms her grandmother has a history of ""blood clots"". Examination reveals an edematous  erythematous  and warm right lower extremity with a positive Homans' Sign. Cardiovascular exam shows tachycardia  but no other abnormalities are noted. Pulmonary exam reveals decreased breath sounds at the base of the right lung. There are no abnormalities found on abdominal examination. She denies smoking  alcohol use and any allergies. Her medications include estrogen and progesterone for hormone replacement therapy and vitamin D supplements.

A 45-year-old Caucasian male  manual laborer  presents with a unilateral  painful swelling in his left leg  specifically in the calf area  that has been present for the last three days. Patient states the swelling is accompanied by mild redness and localized warmth. He denies any trauma  recent surgery  or long distance travel. Patient has a ten-year history of type II diabetes  which is being controlled by Metformin. He also has a 20-pack year smoking history but quit smoking one year ago. There is no known history of coagulation disorders in his family. Upon physical examination  Homan's sign is positive on the left side. The patient has never experienced such symptoms before.   Given the patient's occupational history  diabetes  and previous smoking habits  the leading concern is for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  which will require an imaging study like Doppler Ultrasound for confirmation.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presents with a 3-day history of swollen  tender  red  and warm right calf. The patient has a medical history of obesity with a BMI of 32 kg/m2  sedentary lifestyle  and has recently undergone a hip replacement surgery 10 days ago. He is a former smoker  quit 20 years ago. His father had a pulmonary embolism at 66. The patient denies shortness of breath  chest pain  coughing  or hemoptysis. He also denies any history of malignancy or use of hormonal therapy. He is non-alcoholic and denies illicit drug use. He has been adherent to his short-term low molecular weight heparin prophylaxis since his hip surgery. His vital signs are stable. On physical examination  the patient's right calf circumference is 4 cm greater than the left  with pitting edema and superficial venous dilation noted. He states that the pain is worse with dorsiflexion of the foot (Homans' sign). This case fits the clinical picture of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) likely postoperative  secondary to his recent hip replacement surgery and possible genetic factors.

Problem Representation:  Ms. M  a 57-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman  has presented to the emergency department with a complaint of increased right leg pain and swelling  that has been progressively worsening over the past 5 days. The pain is located in the calf region and is described as a dull ache which is exacerbated on movement or standing. There are no obvious deviations such as deformity or bruising but the entire leg is noticeably larger than the left.   She recently underwent a total right hip replacement surgery two weeks ago  after which she was largely sedentary. Patient reports compliance with post-operative anti-platelet prescription (aspirin) but did not use the prescribed mechanical prophylaxis (compression stockings).  Apart from long-standing hypertension and hyperlipidemia  her past medical history is unremarkable. She denies any history of clotting disorders or recent travel. She does not smoke and takes her hypertension medication (lisinopril) and statins regularly.   Given the recent hip replacement surgery  patient's age  postmenopausal status  and the absence of prophylactic measures  Ms. M has greatly increased risk for developing a deep vein thrombosis in her right leg. This is suggested by her presenting symptoms of unilateral swelling  pain and warmth of the affected leg.

Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency room noting an abrupt onset of swelling  pain  and a feeling of warmth in her left lower limb over the last two days. She has prior medical history of type-2 diabetes and Hypertension which is relatively controlled with Metformin and Lisinopril respectively.   History of Present Illness: She reports chronic sedentary behavior secondary to her job as a long-distance truck driver. She also reports occasional smoking and alcohol use. However  she has no known allergies. The patient recently completed a cross-country haul  during which she drove 8+ hours daily for seven days with minimal activity breaks.   Examination: On physical examination  her left leg appears swollen  erythematous  and is tender on palpation  especially in the calf region. Moreover  pitting edema is noted in the same leg. She has no fever or tachycardia. The rest of her physical examination is unremarkable.  Assessment:  Given the patient's prolonged periods of inactivity  together with hypercoagulability from her diabetes  and her age: these factors suggest that she has an increased risk for development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Plan:  Further confirmatory investigations are necessary  including a Doppler ultrasound of the leg to verify the diagnosis and determine the extent of the thrombosis. If the diagnosis is confirmed  she should be started on anticoagulation therapy as per clinical guidelines for DVT management.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents with a three-day history of increasing pain and swelling in her right lower leg  along with localized warmth and redness. She denies recent trauma  surgery but has history of long-distance travels. She reports light-headedness but denies chest pain or shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which she is on medication. She has no known allergies. She reports a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Patient currently takes aspirin for cardiovascular protection and atorvastatin for her hyperlipidemia  and she is a nonsmoker. She has no previous history of DVT or pulmonary embolism. Her body mass index is 29 and she is sedentary. Given her clinical symptoms  history of long-distance travel  obesity and family history of DVT  this patient is highly suspected for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male  retired truck driver.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with lisinopril and metformin respectively. He is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago  but smoked a pack a day for 30 years. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 32  indicative of obesity. He has no known allergies.  Presenting Issue: He presents with a 2-day history of discomfort in his right calf. The pain feels like a cramp and is exacerbated by walking. His wife noticed that the right calf is visibly swollen and slightly redder than the left leg.  Physical Examination: His right calf circumference is 3 cm larger than the left one. He has mild pitting edema on his right leg and foot. His right leg is warmer and redder than the left one. The Homans' sign is positive. He also has reduced breath sounds at the lung bases which could be indicative of small pulmonary emboli secondary to DVT.   Clinical Impression: The patient's symptoms are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His age  obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and prior history of smoking are risk factors that make him susceptible to DVT. A Venous Doppler Ultrasound is recommended to confirm the diagnosis.  Plan: The patient will promptly be initiated on anticoagulation therapy pending the results of the Doppler Ultrasound.

A 67-year-old caucasian female with a medical history significant for class I obesity and recent hip replacement surgery presents with warmth  redness  and swelling in her left lower extremity  which is notably tender to palpation. She reports no known drug allergies and is only on a medication regimen of daily aspirin and occasional ibuprofen for arthritis pain. The pain and swelling have worsened over the past week. She has not experienced any chest pain or shortness of breath. She denies any trauma to the area but has been mostly non-ambulatory since her hip surgery 2 weeks ago. These findings suggest a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) on her left lower extremity secondary to her recent hip surgery and reduced mobility.

A 65-year-old Caucasian woman  Mrs. Miller  with a BMI of 28 who is a current smoker and has a medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and varicose vein surgery  presents with a 2-day history of left calf pain and swelling. She reports the pain as a constant  dull ache and she rates it as a 6 on a 10-point scale. She also notes increasing tightness in the left leg  as well as warmth and redness over the calf. She denies any recent injury  fever or shortness of breath. She accompanied her partner on a cross-country RV trip last week where she was mostly seated and has recently begun to take birth control pills. Her left lower extremity is swollen  erythematous  with mild tenderness upon palpation corresponding to deep venous distribution. Her vital signs are normal. D-dimer level is high. These symptoms suggest the possibility of a deep vein thrombosis.

A 63-year-old Caucasian woman presents with a 3-day history of pain and swelling in her left lower leg. She is a former smoker with a history of hypertension and obesity (BMI 30.4). Additionally  she recently had a hip replacement surgery conducted about 3 weeks ago. On physical examination  her left calf is swollen  warm  reddish  and tender on palpation compared to her right calf. She has an elevated heart rate at 99 bpm  blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg  respiratory rate and oxygen saturation within normal range. Her symptoms are suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

A 65-year-old Caucasian female  who is a retired teacher  presents with deep vein thrombosis. She has a relevant medical history of hypertension  obesity with a BMI of 31  and non-insulin dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has been on oral contraceptives for the past 5 years for menopausal symptoms. She recently undertook a long-haul (8+ hours) flight around 5 days back. She comes in today with complaints of unexplained swelling  warmth  redness  and pain in her left  lower leg  which have gradually worsened over the past 2 days. She denies any history of chest pain  dizziness or breathing difficulties. She has not had any similar episodes in the past. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. There are no known drug allergies. Family history is notable for a maternal aunt diagnosed with venous thromboembolism.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a one-week history of progressive pain and swelling in his left lower extremity  more pronounced in the calf region. The patient also reports a sensation of warmth around the swollen area. He denies any previous trauma  recent travels  or immobility. Medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both under pharmaceutical control. He is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago. The patient reveals a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his mother and brother. He is currently on medication for hypertension (lisinopril) and hyperlipidemia (simvastatin). He denies any history of surgeries or hospitalizations. He has no known drug-related allergies. Physical examination reveals erythematous  edematous left lower leg which is warm to the touch  a palpable cord along the superficial veins  and a positive Homan's sign. His vital signs are stable.

Patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female  retired high school teacher  with a relevant medical history of one instance of transient ischemic attack  hypertension regulated by medication (Amlodipine 5mg/day)  and obesity (BMI 31). She is a former smoker  quit 5 years ago with a total of 30-pack year history. She lives with her husband  has moderate alcohol intake (one glass of wine 3-4 times a week)  and maintains a diet low in vegetables and high in fat. In summary  J.M. is a 65-year-old retired  obese  Caucasian male with sedentary habits  prior history of pulmonary embolism  and a family history of deep vein thrombosis who presents with unilateral lower extremity swelling and pain  highly suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. His age  high BMI  previous personal and family history make him a typical patient according to the demographic data found in the literature regarding deep vein thrombosis. Further diagnostic tests will be needed for a definite diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of swelling and pain in his right lower leg.  Signs and Symptoms: The patient has been experiencing progressive pain in his right leg  along with swelling and warmth over the past one week. The pain becomes worse with standing or walking. He also describes mild shortness of breath which has slowly worsened over the past few days.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is taking medication. Approximately one year ago  the patient underwent a total left hip replacement surgery due to osteoarthritis. He has not reported any previous episodes of venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. The patient reports that he is a former smoker and quit 5 years ago. There are no reported allergies.  Family History: The patient's mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis  and his father died of stroke. He has two siblings  both of whom have been diagnosed with heart disease.  Social History: The patient is retired and lives with his wife. He used to work in an office environment which required prolonged sitting. Since his retirement  he has been leading a rather sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Risk Factors: Based on the information provided  the risk factors for deep vein thrombosis in this patient are advanced age  personal history of orthopedic surgery  family history of DVT  prolonged immobility due to his sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and the history of smoking.  Epidemiology: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a condition that primarily occurs in adults over the age of 60. In the United States  it's estimated that 1 in 1000 adults are diagnosed with DVT each year. It's more common in men  and in Caucasians as compared to other racial/ethnic groups. It's also more prevalent in individuals with specific risk factors like prolonged immobilization  recent surgery or trauma  hypercoagulable disorders  certain medical conditions  and certain lifestyle factors.

This comprehensive medical history helps in building the case for the treatment plan for DVT considering her risk factors and helps to pinpoint areas where lifestyle modification could decrease risk. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Age: 70 years - Gender: Female - Ethnicity: Caucasian (Data trends show a slightly higher predisposition in this ethnicity)  - Occupation: Retired  - Living Situation: Lives alone  with regular visit from health worker  - Location: Urban residential area   - Lifestyle: Sedentary  due to age and limited mobility - BMI: 29 (Slightly overweight)  Past Medical History: - Prior record of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) episode: Patients who have had DVT once are at a higher risk of developing it again. - Recent hip or knee replacement surgery: DVT can often occur after certain types of surgery. - Prolonged bed rest or immobility due to a recent surgery or injury. - History of malignant cancer: Cancer can increase the risk of blood clots. - Previous stroke  which has reduced mobility and necessitated the use of a wheelchair. - Use of oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy: These can increase the risk of clotting. - Family history of venous thromboembolism.   Vitals and Clinical Picture: - Unilateral leg pain  swelling  warmth  and discoloration: These are typical symptoms of DVT. - Elevated D-dimer levels: This is a common marker indicating possible presence of blood clots. - Doppler Ultrasound showing a blood clot in the deep vein system of the leg. - Shortness of breath or chest pain: This could suggest a possible pulmonary embolism  a serious potential complication of DVT.     Risk Factors: - Age: Risk increases after age 50. - Obesity: Higher body mass can increase pressure on the veins in your pelvis and legs  increasing risk. - Prolonged immobility: Long bouts of inactivity increase pooling of blood in legs  raising risk.  Demographics sourced from literature suggest Caucasian women over 60  particularly those overweight or with limited mobility  have greater risk for DVT.

Demographic Characterization:  Mr. John Smith is a 55-year-old Caucasian male  a heavy-smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history. He is a financial analyst and leads a sedentary lifestyle as the nature of his job involves prolonged sitting. He is married and belongs to a middle-income family. Mr. Smith is also a social drinker and enjoys one to two drinks per day. He recently joined a weight loss programme due to a BMI of 31 kg/m^2  indicating obesity.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol level which has been managed with medication for the past ten years. He also had hip replacement surgery one year ago  which required a prolonged period of immobilisation. His family history includes his father  who had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 60  and his mother  who was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her late sixties.   Presenting Problem:  Mr. Smith has complained about swollen  painful and warm to touch right calf over the past two days. He also reported a dull ache in the same leg when standing or walking. Upon further questioning  he mentions he just returned from a business trip that involved a long flight. His symptoms and risk factors raised a high suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.   This profile has been crafted in accordance with demographic literature on DVT  which shows that risks are higher for individuals over the age of 40  those who are overweight or obese  individuals with a sedentary lifestyle or prolonged immobilisation  those with a family history of DVT or pulmonary embolism  and smokers. In addition  long-distance travelers are highlighted as an at-risk group due to prolonged sitting during travel.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: Patient: 58-year-old Caucasian female  Occupation: office work  predominantly sedentary lifestyle Residential Location: urban area  Presenting Problem: The patient complains of swelling  pain and warmth over the area of the right lower leg for the last three days.   Past Medical History: 1. Unresolved varicose veins for 10 years. 2. History of oral contraceptive use for 15 years. 3. Non-smoker. 4. BMI: 26 (Overweight) 5. No past record of surgeries  trauma or injuries. 6. Family history of thromboembolic disease - mother had pulmonary embolism (PE) at age 60.  Relevant Physical Exam Findings: 1. Physical examination reveals localized swelling  redness  and warmth over the right calf region.  2. Positive Homan's sign - pain in the calf with forced dorsiflexion of the foot. 3. No distinct respiratory distress  chest pain  or arrhythmias.  Laboratory findings yet to be obtained. The physician suspects Deep Vein Thrombosis based on the clinical presentation and past history.  This case indicates classic symptoms of deep vein thrombosis. Several demographic factors and items of the medical history draw attention as major risk factors of DVT: female gender  older age  sedentary lifestyle due to office work  unresolved varicose veins  the history of oral contraceptive use  overweight and family history of thromboembolic disease. While the patient is not a smoker  her sedentary lifestyle and being overweight still contribute to an increased risk factor for DVT.

Patient Profile:  1. Demographics:      - Age: 65      - Gender: Female      - Race: Caucasian - Studies find that deep vein thrombosis (DVT) has a higher prevalence rate among Caucasians.      - Occupation: Office worker - Prolonged sitting may increase the risk for DVT      - Lifestyle: Sedentary - Little physical activity such as regular exercise could increase the likelihood of DVT.  2. Medical History:       - Past history of DVT or PE: Patients with a past incidence of DVT are more likely to develop DVT again.      - Family history of clotting disorder: Certain inherited conditions such as Factor V Leiden or prothrombin gene mutation can increase the risk of DVT.      - Comorbid conditions: Hypertension and obesity.      - Smoking: It's known to raise the risk of developing blood clots.      - Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT)/Contraceptive Pill: These medications increase the level of certain clotting factors in your blood.      - Past surgeries: Particularly hip  knee or female reproductive organ surgery.      - Cancer: Certain types of cancer or cancer treatments can increase levels of certain substances in your blood that help blood clot.      - Varicose veins: Varicose veins can cause venous stasis  increasing the chances of a clot.  3. Current Symptoms:       - Swelling in one or both legs      - Pain or tenderness in a leg  which may only happen when standing or walking      - Increased warmth in the area of the leg that's swollen or painful      - Red or discolored skin on the leg      - Veins you can see      - Tiredness in your legs  4. Present Medications:       - Antihypertensive Medications      - Hormone Replacement Therapy Drugs.  This problem representation aims to present a typical picture of a patient who could be at high risk for developing DVT. The factors included span across demographics  personal and medical history  as well as active symptoms and medications  all of which could play a role in the development and diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. However  it is important to remember that each patient is unique and may not exactly fit this profile. The problem representation thus serves as a guide rather than a definitive checklist.   Note that this is a hypothetical profile. Each patient's presentation may contain some of these characteristics and may lack others based on the individual's specific circumstances and medical history. Discussing possible risk factors and symptoms with a healthcare provider is necessary for proper diagnosis and treatment.

Patient Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female who is overweight with a BMI of 35. She has been a heavy smoker (1 pack/day) for the past 25 years. She has a sedentary lifestyle with a desk job that requires 8 hours of continuous sitting per day. She has rarely participated in physical activities for the past 10 years. In addition  she reports frequent cross-country flights for her job in the last 5 years.   Past Medical History: She has a documented history of hypertension  which has been inconsistively controlled by her medication regime due to poor adherence. She also has suffered from varicose veins for several years and was recently diagnosed with intermittent claudication. She takes oral contraceptives for menopausal symptoms. Her father died of a pulmonary embolism in his sixties  and her mother suffered a stroke at the age of 79. There is no documented history of any malignant diseases.  This patient's demographic profile fits one that is more susceptible to developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Factors such as her age  sex  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and smoking habit increase her risk. Her varicose veins  intermittent claudication and history of hormonal therapy are additional vascular risk factors. Finally  her family history of venous thromboembolism (VTE) and cerebrovascular accidents is a concerning genetic factor. This information suggests that her risk for DVT is significantly elevated  warranting further investigation and preventive strategies.

Problem Representation:  Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female Patient   Demographical Characteristics:  1. Age: 56 years old 2. Sex: Female 3. Ethnicity: Caucasian 4. Occupation: Office work (sedentary lifestyle) 5. Social History: Non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  BMI: 29 (Overweight)   Relevant Medical History:  1. Recent Surgery: Patient had a total knee replacement surgery 4 weeks previous. 2. Comorbidities: Hypertension and Type-II Diabetes Mellitus. 3. Medication: Regular medication includes anti-hypertensives and insulin. 4. Previous DVT: No history of previous DVT or pulmonary embolism.  5. Family History: Father expired due to pulmonary embolism associated with undiagnosed DVT  mother with type-II diabetes mellitus. 6. Trauma: No significant injury or trauma in the past. 7. Pregnancy and Birth Control Pills: Patient is post-menopausal and does not take birth control pills.  Clinical Presentation:  Patient presents with unilateral leg swelling  tenderness  redness  and warmth (right leg). She also complains of mild difficulty in breathing which started a few days prior.  Literature suggests that deep vein thrombosis is common in individuals remains on bed rest or immobilization after orthopedic surgeries. It is more common in older individuals  particularly over the age of 60  and slightly more common in women. Risk factors include a family history of DVT or PE  long periods of immobility (such as long flights or bed rest)  presence of blood clotting disorders  obesity  and presence of other underlying conditions such as cancer or inflammatory conditions  among others. In this case  the patient's recent knee replacement surgery  age  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and family history put her at a higher risk for DVT.  It is crucial to diagnose and manage DVT promptly since it can lead to severe complications like pulmonary embolism (PE)  which is life-threatening. Diagnosis is usually based on presenting symptoms in combination with diagnostic tests such as ultrasound  blood tests  and sometimes  venography. Treatment is primarily based on anticoagulant medications  which can help to prevent further growth of the blood clot and reduce the risk of PE.

Patient Profile: --------------  Name: Mrs. Jane Smith   Age: 69 years old  Sex: Female  Race: Caucasian  Marital Status: Widowed   Occupation: Retired supermarket cashier   Education: High school graduate  Residence: Lives alone in a suburban house  has a part-time caregiver  Insurance: Medicare  Problem Presentation: -----------------------  Chief Complaint:  -Mrs. Smith reports experiencing a persistent ache and swelling in her left lower leg for the past week. Relevant Past Medical History: -Right total knee arthroplasty performed eight years ago  -Recent hospitalization for pneumonia three weeks ago; was immobile for a few days and received antibiotics for the treatment.  -Active smoker with 45 pack years -Mrs. Smith takes a daily low-dose aspirin for cardiovascular disease prevention  -Has hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide  -Recently started on omeprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease -Denies previous history of blood clots or similar issues in the lower extremities. -Family history of stroke in her mother   Physical Examination:  -General: appears distressed due to pain -Left lower extremity: Warm to touch  visibly swollen (compared to the right)  tenderness along the distribution of the left medial thigh and calf veins. Patient Profile:  Patient ID: 1001 Name: John Smith Age: 65 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Demographic Information: John is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who is retired. He lives alone in a suburban area. He has two children who are both married and live out of state. He is a widow  his wife passed away three years ago. John is a former smoker  but he quit 15 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially.  Medical History:  John has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes which is managed with medication. He was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago. Both of these conditions are well controlled with his current medication regimen.   He experienced a mild myocardial infarction five years ago  which was treated with angioplasty and stent placement in the coronary arteries.   In terms of surgery history  John underwent hip replacement surgery six months ago and has been largely immobile since the operation due to post-operative complications.   John has a familial history of cardiovascular diseases. His father died of stroke at age 70 and his mother had-bypass surgery at age 67.   John was recently hospitalized due to unexplained swelling and pain in his right leg  his medical tests revealed deep vein thrombosis.  Current Medications:  1. Metformin for Type 2 diabetes 2. Losartan for hypertension  3. Low-dose aspiring for prevention of heart attacks 4. Statin for managing high cholesterol  Findings: It is suspected that John's immobility due to his recent hip surgery possibly combined with his history of cardio-vascular disease and hypertension might have contributed to the development of deep vein thrombosis. The family history of cardiovascular disease also places him at a higher risk. Further diagnostic tests and medical consultation would be needed to confirm and examine the degree and location of clot.   Risk factors contributing to his condition are his age  history of heart disease  hypertension  diabetes  recent major surgery and immobility  with a familial predisposition.  John's clinical condition requires a specific therapeutic approach in addition to educating about lifestyle modifications for better management of his existing diseases and prevention of deep vein thrombosis cardiopulmonary complications.

Patient Problem Representation  Subject Summary:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female with an average BMI and a non-smoker. She is moderately active and has partially retired from her job as a school teacher. She drinks alcohol moderately and denies any recreational drug use. Her family history is positive for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and cardiovascular diseases.   Presenting Complaints:  She presented to the emergency room complaining about consistent  throbbing pain in her left calf for the past week that worsened over time. She also reports noticeable swellings  redness  and warmth in the same area. The patient disclosed experiencing excessive sweating and mild shortness of breath during minor physical activities  which was irreconcilable with her usual level of physical fitness.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Reviewing her medical history  the patient had a total knee replacement 6 weeks ago and was mostly bedridden during the recovery period  which was complicated with post-operative infection. She is managed for congestive heart failure secondary to her past history of ischemic heart diseases  for which she had undergone coronary artery bypass grafting 8 years ago. She has also been on chronic hypertension treatment for the past 15 years  with her blood pressure levels under control lately. Furthermore  she has a known history of hyperlipidemia.  Medications:  She is currently on low-dose aspirin  atorvastatin  lisinopril  and recently completed her antibiotics course for the post-operative infection. She was also recommended compression stockings following her surgery.  Risk Factors:  The patient's age  post-operative state  family history  prolonged immobility  and history of cardiovascular problems are all significant risk factors that markedly increase the likelihood of deep vein thrombosis.  Plausible Diagnosis:  Considering the symptoms presented  her past medical history  and known risk factors  the patient may likely be suffering from deep vein thrombosis affecting her left leg. The presence of shortness of breath may also raise concerns about potential pulmonary embolism. It is crucial to establish the definitive diagnosis urgently and treat promptly due to the severe possible complications.   This patient representation signifies a typical clinical presentation for DVT and incorporates key demographic and clinical evidence  as commonly reported in literature.

Problem Description:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presents with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The symptoms became apparent about two weeks ago and have gotten progressively worse  provoking her to seek medical treatment.  Patient Demographics:  The patient is married  has two adult children  and lives with her husband in a suburban neighborhood. She retired from her job as a high school teacher 6 years ago. The patient is a non-smoker but consumes alcohol moderately. She does not have any known drug allergies.  Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  for which she has been taking medication for the last 8 years. She was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 3 years ago and was placed on anticoagulants as a part of her treatment regime. The patient underwent a total knee replacement surgery approximately 2 years ago. She maintains a mostly sedentary lifestyle due to moderate osteoarthritis in her hip.  Current Symptoms:  Patient reports a painful  red  and swollen region in her left lower leg  slightly below the knee. The pain has been worsening slowly over two weeks and is exacerbated on walking or extending the leg. Over the last couple of days  she has developed a mild fever and feels fatigued.  This presentation is consistent with a recent study showing that deep vein thrombosis (DVT) typically occurs in patients aged between 60 and 70  those who lead a sedentary lifestyle  post-surgery cases  as well as those with a history of hypertension  atrial fibrillation  and diabetes. DVT is also more common in women.   The chosen demographics and medical history for the patient outline one of many possible scenarios for a patient who might present at a health facility with DVT. These descriptors serve as important predictors and risk factor evaluators before initial diagnosis and subsequent therapeutic decision-making.

Patient Representation:  Name: John Doe  Age: 65 years  Sex: Male   Race: White  Socioeconomic Status: Middle class  retired   Geographical Location: Urban area  USA  Occupational History: Ex-Truck driver  used to take long uninterrupted drives  Lifestyle Choices: Sedentary lifestyle  former smoker  Family History: A father with past myocardial infarction  a mother with varicose veins  Medication History: On aspirin for cardioprotection  Allergies: No known drug allergies  Past Medical History:   1. Mild hypertension (since last 10 years) - controlled with medication 2. Hyperlipidemia - managed with statins  Presenting Complaints:  1. Painful  swollen right leg since last three days 2. Pitting edema in right leg 3. Mild fever   On Examination:  1. Tenderness along the line of right femoral vein 2. Warmth over right thigh 3. Erythema over right leg 4. Positive Homan’s sign  Diagnosis:  1. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in right lower limb  Problem Identification:   1. Pain and swelling in right leg - possibly due to DVT 2. Hyperlipidemia- suggests a risk factor for cardiovascular diseases 3. Hypertension - might indicate an increased risk of cardiovascular disorders 4. Sedentary lifestyle  long-distance truck driving  and former smoking history - significant risk factors for developing DVT 5. Family history of cardiovascular disease  Problem Treatment & Management Plan:  1. Immediate imaging (Doppler Ultrasound) to confirm suspected DVT 2. Start anticoagulation therapy to prevent clot propagation 3. Encourage leg elevation  4. Use of compression stockings to reduce edema 5. Regular blood pressure and lipid levels monitoring 6. Encourage regular exercise and healthy diet 7. Educate about the harm of long periods of uninterrupted sitting/ laying and benefits of mobility 8. Regular follow-up visits to monitor the progress and side effects (if any) of medication.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Jane Doe Age: 60 years old Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired office clerk Marital Status: Married Children: Two adult children Country of Residence: United States  Problem Representation:  Chief Complaint: Mrs. Doe presents with swelling  warmth  and pain in her left calf  which is visibly red and swollen. She denies any alcohol use and has quit smoking five years ago.  This profile allows us to infer that Mrs. Doe has multiple risk factors for DVT  including advanced age  previous orthopedic surgery  personal and family history of venous thromboembolism  ERT  sedentary lifestyle  and past history of smoking. We are concerned about the presence of DVT given her symptoms and the risk of a possible pulmonary embolism due to her reported shortness of breath. Representation:  Patient Profile ID: 001   Demographic Data:  - Age: 68 years - Gender: Female - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher  Sedentary lifestyle - Weight: 220 lbs - Height: 5'3"" - BMI: 39 (Obesity)  Past Medical History:  - History of Orthopedic Surgery (Hip Replacement) 6 weeks ago. - Chronic Heart Failure - Hypertension  controlled with medication  - Past smoking history. Quit 20 years ago  smoked for 30 years. - Family history of blood clotting disorders  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient came into the clinic complaining of one sided leg pain and swelling in her left leg that has been persistent for a week. The location of pain and swelling is in the calf muscle. The pain gets worse when bending the foot. The skin over the left leg is warm to touch. She also noted a mild fever and general feeling of being unwell.  Diagnostic Notes:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is highly suspected due to her recent orthopedic surgery  sedentary lifestyle  age  obesity  history of chronic heart failure and hypertension. These factors increase the risk of blood clot formation. The persistent pain  swelling  and warmth over the calf muscle are classic symptoms of DVT. Family history of blood clot disorders also raises the possibility of a genetic predisposition.  Considerations for further diagnostic and therapeutic actions:  1) Confirmation of DVT via diagnostic tests such as D-Dimer  ultrasonography (gold standard)  Venography etc. 2) If DVT is confirmed  immediate initiation of anticoagulant therapy will be necessary. 3) Due to her history of heart failure  consideration of potential pulmonary embolism should be part of the clinical decision-making process. 4) Genetic testing for clotting disorders could be considered given her family history. 5) Patient education on lifestyle modifications to address obesity and improve overall cardiovascular health. 6) Regular follow-ups to monitor the response to the treatment.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  Age: 65 Years Old Gender: Female  Race: Caucasian  Weight: Overweight (BMI: 30) Social History: Sedentary lifestyle  non-smoker  and occasional alcohol consumer.   Presenting Complaint:   The patient presents with leg pain and swelling in the calf  which has gradually worsened over past weeks. The patient also reports a warmth and redness over the area of pain.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of prolonged bed rest after orthopedic surgery 3 months prior. Her past medical history also includes use of birth control pills  Hypertension and occasional flights across the coast. She has no known allergies.   Family History:   Mother had a blood clot in her late 60s and father died of heart disease.   Possible Diagnosis:   Given the episodes of long-lasting inactivity  recent surgery  family history  use of birth control pills  history of hypertension  and characteristic symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is highly probable.  Suggested Tests:  To confirm the diagnosis and rule out other differential diagnoses  some of the tests suggested include Doppler Ultrasound Exam of the extremity  D-Dimer Test  and possibly a Venography. These tests would help to visualize the thrombus or clot in the vein and measure clot-dissolving substances in the blood.  Management:  In case DVT is confirmed  anticoagulant therapy or blood thinners such as heparin  warfarin  or direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) would be initiated. The focus would also be on the patient's lifestyle changes including increased physical activity  weight loss  and quitting oral contraceptive pills.  Note: The statistical representation included here is broadly adequate but individual variations may occur.

Patient Background and Demographic Details  Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Smith  retired from a clerical job and lives in suburban Northeastern USA with his wife of 44 years.   Clinical Presentation  Mr. Smith presents with a 3-day history of increasing pain  swelling  and redness in his lower right leg. He describes the onset as sudden  with no apparent injury or triggering event. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  and any other systemic symptoms. Unfortunately  he waited a few days to come in because he thought it was just age-related aches and pains.   Past Medical History  Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history including type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) which is managed by oral antidiabetic drugs  hypertension controlled by beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors  and a prior myocardial infarction 10 years ago  from which he made a good recovery. He also suffers from obesity with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. He underwent hip replacement surgery on the right side 3 years back and recovered well after a slightly prolonged post-operative period. He has no known allergies. He used to be a smoker but quit 15 years ago.  Family History  There is family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father having passed away due to a stroke and his elder brother underwent angioplasty for blocked coronary arteries. He does not have any siblings or first-degree relatives who have been diagnosed with venous thromboembolism.   Social History  Since retirement 8 years back  he leads a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity. He enjoys reading and painting. He admits to alcohol intake  mostly wine during dinner. He has never used illicit drugs. He lives with his wife who is his primary caregiver.  Current Medications  1. Metformin 1000 mg twice daily 2. Lisinopril 20mg once daily 3. Metoprolol 25mg twice daily 4. Atorvastatin 40mg once daily at bedtime 5. Aspirin 81mg once daily  Physical Examination  Physical examination reveals a swollen  warm  and erythematous right lower extremity. There is a noticeable size difference compared to the left leg. The patient also displays tenderness along the distribution of the deep femoral vein.    Clinical Problem Representation or Summary  Mr. Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of T2DM  hypertension  prior myocardial infarction  obesity and hip replacement surgery  presents with symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (swollen  warm  and erythematous right lower extremity) likely due to his sedentary lifestyle  and past surgical and medical history.      Relevant Literature: According to the literature  the patient’s age  obesity  history of prior surgery  and sedentary lifestyle all predispose him to deep vein thrombosis. White/European population are also at greater risk as compared to other races. DVT is a common acute medical condition  with an incidence of 1 in 1000/year. Over 60% of all first DVT occur in individuals aged 70 and above. The risk of DVT is 4-6 times higher in overweight and obese individuals.

Patient Representation:  - Identifier: Patient X - Gender: Female - Age: 60-year-old - Ethnicity: Caucasian (53% of patients with DVT are White according to literature) - Occupation: Office worker (sedentary lifestyle)  Medical History: The patient has a personal history of multiple risk factors for deep vein thrombosis including:  1. Obesity: Patient has a body mass index (BMI) of 33 (obese class 1).  2. Previous DVT: Patient had a confirmed DVT episode 5 years prior. 3. Limited mobility: She works from home and does not engage in any physical activities. 4. Hormone replacement therapy (HRT): The patient has been taking hormone replacement therapy for menopause symptoms for the past 6 years. 5. Family History of DVT: Her mother and aunt both had DVT.  Current Presentation:  Patient X presented to the emergency department with complaints of swelling in her right lower limb which has been persisting for a few days. She also mentions experiencing pain in her calf while walking. She has denied any shortness of breath  chest pain  or history of recent trauma/surgery.   Assessment:  Given her previous history of DVT and current symptoms  there is a high suspicion for recurrence of DVT. This is further exacerbated by her risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and HRT use.  Plan:  She would need to undergo diagnostic tests  such as a D-dimer test  followed by an ultrasound for confirmation if needed. Considering the strong suspicion of DVT  anticoagulation initiation should be considered even before the diagnostic results. Difference in the management may occur based on the confirmation of diagnosis and her risk stratification. She would also need lifestyle modification counseling including but not limited to dietary changes  exercise  and possible reassessment of HRT. This includes a detailed discussion about the risks and benefits of HRT continued use.   In the case of a confirmed DVT  long term follow up is recommended to manage and prevent the recurrence as she is at a higher risk for DVT recurrence. This could consist of regular monitoring of her coagulation parameters if she is on anticoagulation  the periodic reassessment of her deep vein thrombosis risk  lifestyle modification  and constant evaluation for the signs of post-thrombotic syndrome.

Patient Representation:  1. Presenting Condition: The patient presents with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Given this representation  a plan for the patient's treatment  including anticoagulation therapy  lifestyle modification and regular follow-ups  might be considered.

Patient Representation:   A 55-year-old white female presents with symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  - Age: Approximately 60 years old (Most DVT cases occur in individuals aged 60 and above) - Gender: Slightly more common in males than females - Occupation: Jobs requiring prolonged sitting or standing  - Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle with low levels of physical activity - Family history: Relevant family history of clotting disorders or DVT  Presenting complaint:   - Sudden onset severe pain in one leg  often calf area  - Swelling in the affected leg - Warm skin over the area of the clot - Red or discolored skin on the leg - A heavy ache in the affected area  Past Medical History:  - History of pelvic or leg trauma/surgery  - Previous episode of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism - Obesity (BMI > 30) - Cardiovascular diseases - Varicose veins - History of cancer  especially of the lung  pancreas  and colon  - Pregnancy or recent childbirth (if female) - Chronic respiratory failure - Renal failure - Inflammatory conditions  Medication History:  - Oral contraceptive pills or hormone replacement therapy (if female) - Anticoagulant therapy - Chemotherapeutic agents  Risk Factors:  - Long periods of immobility such as bed rest or long flights - Smoking - Catheter placed in a large vein - Family history of deep vein thrombosis  Physical Examination/results of investigations:  - Dilated veins noted in the affected leg - Positive Homan's sign (pain in calf on dorsiflexion of patient's foot) - D-dimer blood test might be elevated - Ultrasound will confirm the diagnosis by showing the thrombus in the vein - Sometimes venography  CT scan or MRI may be used for further investigation  This comprehensive representation takes into account both the demographic and clinical parameters that are typically associated with deep vein thrombosis  thus providing a holistic picture of the patient's profile.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Gender: Age: 65 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired BMI: 29  Medical History: 1. Occurrence of a previous episode of deep vein thrombosis. 2. Diagnosis of type 2 diabetes. 3. History of obesity  with a BMI consistent with being overweight. 4. History of prolonged periods of immobility due to an injury that required him to be on bed rest for a month  eight years ago. 5. Diagnosis of high blood pressure. 6. Chronic smoker - 30 pack years. 7. History of heart failure.  Presenting Complaints: 1. Pain  swelling and warmth on the lower limb  specifically the left leg. 2. Redness around the area of pain on the leg. 3. Shortness of breath and chest pain when breathing in deeply.  Assessment: Mr. Doe’s age  family history  personal medical history (obesity  diabetes  heart diseases  hypertension)  along with symptoms he presents (leg pain  swelling  redness; chest pain and shortness of breath) are highly suggestive of the possibility of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His history of tobacco use  along with his age and race  as Caucasian aged individuals have been found to have an increased incidence of DVT  are other relevant risk factors to consider. Further diagnostic evaluations  such as a D-dimer blood test  ultrasound of the leg veins  and in some cases  computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest (due to his presenting symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath  indicating possible pulmonary embolism) should be conducted to confirm diagnosis.

Patient Profile:  Name: Carlos Rodriguez Age: 57 years Sex: Male Marital Status: Married Ethnicity: Hispanic  specifically of Mexican descent Occupation: Office work (mostly sedentary) Home Environment: Lives with wife in a suburban location Body Mass Index (BMI): 33.0 (obesity)  Medical History:  1. Chronic Diseases: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 7 years ago  managed with Metformin. 2. Past Surgical History: Total knee replacement on the right side 3 months ago. Followed with a course of prophylactic anticoagulants for 6 weeks post-surgery. 3. Family History: Father and older brother both died of ischemic heart disease in their early 60s. 4. Smoking History: Smoked a pack a day for 20 years  quit 10 years ago. 5. Alcohol Intake: 2-3 glasses of wine on weekends. 6. Medications: Metformin 1000mg twice a day for diabetes and Aspirin 81mg daily for cardiovascular disease prevention. 7. Allergies: Penicillins  Recent Clinical Presentations: Presented with left calf pain and swelling for two days. The pain is continuous and intense  worsening with walking. There are no fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or hemoptysis. On physical examination  left calf is noticeably swollen  warm  tender  and erythematous.   Homan’s sign is positive. Cardiovascular examination unremarkable.  Findings: Given the unilateral painful leg swelling  recent major surgery  a sedentary lifestyle  obesity and other potential risk factors  Carlos Rodriguez is likely suffering from deep vein thrombosis (DVT). These suspicions should be confirmed with a Doppler ultrasound test and D-dimer blood test. He will likely require anticoagulant treatment in the form of Low Molecular Weight Heparin followed by Warfarin or a Direct Oral Anticoagulant  alongside lifestyle changes and potential thrombectomy if the case is severe. Given his previous history and risk factors  he will also require long-term monitoring for recurrent DVT and potential Pulmonary Embolism.   Please note: Carlos' ethnicity and the fact that men are slightly more likely to develop DVT are based on accurate demographic representation from literature. Other important risk factors include recent surgery  immobilization  his age  obesity  and accompanying type 2 diabetes.

Problem Representation: Patient Profile: Patient is a white male  aged 68  from a suburban community with a history of occasional tobacco and alcohol use.   Presenting Problem: Patient presents with unilateral leg edema  redness  warmth  and pain in the left lower extremity. Patient also reports shortness of breath and occasional chest pain over the last week.  Past Medical History: 1. Occasional smoker and alcohol consumer 2. History of intermittent claudication 3. Long term use of hormonal therapy for prostate cancer 4. Sustained a hip fracture 2 years ago requiring 6 weeks of immobilization 5. Diagnosed with hyperlipidaemia and is on cholesterol lowering therapy 6. Obesity with a BMI of 32. 7. Admitted to hospital 6 months ago for an elective cholecystectomy (gall bladder removal surgery) 8. Had a deep vein thrombosis in the right leg six years ago 9. Mother died of a pulmonary embolism  age 60.  Family History: Mother had a history of venous thromboembolism.   Review of Symptoms: 1. Positive for leg pain  swelling  redness  and warmth 2. Positive for dyspnea and chest pain 3. Negative for cough  fever  headache  abdominal pain  and nocturnal sweating 4. Negative for recent weight loss  change in appetite or diet  Analysis: The patient's risk factors for DVT include age  smoking  alcohol use  history of DVT  family history of VVT  prolonged immobilization  cancer  major surgery  obesity  and hyperlipidaemia. His symptoms of leg pain  swelling  and warmth  along with his dyspnea and chest pain  are all possible indicators of DVT with potential adjacent pulmonary embolism. This patient requires immediate diagnostic testing and treatment to confirm and manage a potential DVT condition.

Patient Problem Representation:  Patient: Jane Doe Age: 60 Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Sedentary office work Home Situation: Lives alone  no children or spouse  Presenting symptoms: Patient presents with unilateral leg swelling  redness  and warmth  accompanied by tenderness over the course of a week. Jane also reports a mild fever and shortness of breath without chest pain.  Past Medical History: 1. Ovarian Cancer: Diagnosed 1 year ago  receives regular chemotherapy treatments 2. Obesity: BMI of 32 3. Hypertension: Controlled with medication for over 10 years 4. Previous DVT: Had a DVT incident 18 months ago on contralateral leg 5. Cardiovascular disease: history of coronary artery disease  Medication:  1: Antihypertensives 2: Oral Contraceptives (estrogen-progestin) 3: Cancer-related medications  including chemotherapy  Additional Information: 1. Patient recently participated in an overseas trip involving a long-haul flight of over 8 hours. 2. Patient reports minimal physical exercise. 3. Patient has a family history of DVT and pulmonary embolism. 4. Patient was a past smoker but quit 10 years ago.  This patient profile reflects typical risk factors associated with DVT. These factors include advanced age  female gender  obesity  hypertension  past occurrence of DVT  cancer diagnosis (increased risk due to malignancy and chemotherapy)  prolonged immobility (long-haul flight  sedentary job)  oral contraceptive use  and a family history of DVT and pulmonary embolism.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Elderly  Diabetic Male: A Case Report   Patient Information:  A 79-year-old African-American male  living in an urban setting  presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of pain and swelling in the right lower extremity. The patient was moderately obese with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. The patient was a retiree and lived alone with home assistance services twice a week.  Past Medical History:  The patient had a significant past medical history  which included type 2 diabetes  well controlled on oral medication  and hypertension  managed with a calcium channel blocker. He had a history of ischemic stroke three years prior and was on antiplatelet therapy. There were no known allergies and he was a former smoker having quit 10 years before. The patient also reported a family history of heart disease and a brother diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his early sixties.  Current Illness:  For the past three days  the patient experienced substantial pain and notable swelling in his right calf that significantly limited his mobility. The pain was acute at the onset and progressively worsened. He denied trauma  recent surgery  or a long period of immobility. The symptoms were associated with mild shortness of breath on exertion but no chest pain.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  he was alert  oriented  and appeared anxious. His blood pressure was 154/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats/min  and respiratory rate 22 breaths/min. His right lower limb was visibly swollen and felt warmer than the left  with tenderness on deep palpation. Homans’ sign was positive. The rest of the examination  including cardiovascular and respiratory systems  was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  Based on presentation and physical examination  the patient was suspected of having deep vein thrombosis. D-dimer levels were elevated at 900 μg FEU/ml (>500 is positive for DVT). A Doppler Ultrasound of the right leg showed an occlusive thrombus in the distal femoral and popliteal veins  confirming the diagnosis. An ECG showed sinus tachycardia but no signs of right heart strain or Ischemia. Additionally  a CT Pulmonary Angiography was performed due to the shortness of breath  which ruled out pulmonary embolism.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  The patient was admitted under the internal medicine department. Anticoagulant therapy was initiated with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) while monitoring the platelet count and renal function. After five days  the anticoagulant was transitioned from LMWH to oral rivaroxaban.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  The patient’s hospital stay was complicated by acute kidney injury  which was managed with intravenous fluids. He reported significant pain improvement and reduced swelling over ten days. He was discharged on rivaroxaban with a follow-up appointment scheduled with his primary physician for coagulation panels.  Patient Perspective:  Although initially anxious  the patient was grateful for the timely diagnosis and management. He shared his intention to engage more actively in managing his diabetes and hypertension.  Informed Consent:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Keywords: deep vein thrombosis  diabetes mellitus  hypertension  elderly  obesity.

Title: Acute Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Woman with No Recognizable Risk Factors  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  married  and retired teacher residing in the suburban area of Tennessee. She presents no history of smoking  alcohol consumption  or drug abuse. She exercises regularly  maintains a healthy diet  and keeps herself adequately hydrated. The patient's weight is within a normal range with a BMI of 24.1 kg/m^2. She has no familial history of hematological disorders or cardiovascular diseases.  Medical History: The patient has a history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She was diagnosed with Type II diabetes five years ago and has it controlled with metformin and lifestyle modifications. The patient is post-menopausal for the past 15 years with no hormonal replacement therapy. She underwent a colectomy due to diverticulitis 10 years ago. The patient is not currently on anticoagulant therapy but takes a daily low-dose aspirin for cardiovascular protection.  Presenting Complaints: She presented with acute onset of left lower limb swelling  localized warmth  and tenderness. She also reported experiencing mild discomfort while walking for the last three days. The patient denied any recent sedentary travel  trauma  surgery  or indication of infection.  Clinical Findings: Upon examination  the patient's left lower limb was visibly swollen and hypersensitive to touch compared to the right limb. However  she did not present with any signs of superficial vein thrombosis. Initial vitals were: Blood Pressure of 145/85 mmHg  heart rate of 78 bpm  respiratory rate of 15 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Her Homan’s sign was positive.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Laboratory findings revealed a hemoglobin of 13.2 gm/dL  platelet count of 275 000/µL  and an INR of 1.0. D-dimer levels were elevated  suggesting the possible presence of thrombus. The patient underwent a Doppler ultrasound which confirmed deep vein thrombosis to the left popliteal vein  with an extended clot observed just below the knee level. The diagnosis was based on her clinical presentation and imaging results.  Management and Follow-Up: Treatment initiated with the parenteral administration of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for immediate anticoagulation  and then switched to oral anticoagulant  rivaroxaban. She was advised to continue medication for three months at least  coupled with regular monitoring of her INR levels. Weight reduction and diabetic control measures were reinforced. She was also educated on the importance of leg elevation  physical activity  and usage of compression stockings.  Conclusion: This case exemplifies that DVT can occur even in patients without prominent identifiable risk factors. It reinforces the need for a high index of suspicion  timely diagnosis  and appropriate management of DVT to prevent fatal complications such as pulmonary embolism.  This case has adhered to CARE guidelines for case reports. The patient gave consent for her demographic and medical information to be used for medical education and research without jeopardizing her identity.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 64-year-old Caucasian Male   Patient Information  Mr. X  a 64-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes  presented to the emergency department complaining of increasing leg pain and swelling over the past four days. He described his symptoms as a cramping sensation in his left calf. Mr. X is a retired accountant and leads a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement three years ago. His medication regime includes Metformin and Lisinopril. Mr. X does not smoke or consume alcohol. His family history is significant for myocardial infarction and stroke in his father and a venous thromboembolism in his older brother. He reported no known allergies.  Clinical Findings  On physical examination  he appeared anxious and his vital signs were stable. Examination of the lower limbs showed left leg swelling with a circumference 3cm greater than the right leg. The left calf was tender to touch. Homan's sign was positive. There was no evidence of ulceration or varicose veins  and peripheral pulses were palpable bilaterally. There was no peripheral edema. His BMI was 32  indicating obesity.  Diagnostic Assessment    The symptoms  signs  and past medical history raised clinical suspicion for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). A D-dimer test was conducted  which turned out to be significantly elevated. Ultrasound Doppler of the left lower limb confirmed the diagnosis by showing a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein with absence of color flow  indicating a thrombus.   Therapeutic Intervention    Mr. X was admitted and immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with a low-molecular-weight heparin (Enoxaparin)  and later transitioned to an oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban). Pain management was achieved with acetaminophen. He was also advised compression stockings to reduce swelling during the day.  Follow-up and Outcomes  Mr. X responded well to the anticoagulation therapy. His symptoms improved significantly  and a repeated ultrasound Doppler after seven days indicated recanalization of the vein. Due to the patient's existing comorbidities and the risk of recurrence  it was decided to continue oral anticoagulation for an extended period. He was also advised to undertake regular exercise  dietary changes and weight management to decrease his BMI.  The patient was educated about signs and symptoms of recurrent DVT and potential complications like pulmonary embolism. He was asked to schedule regular follow-ups to monitor his treatment progress and to manage his Type 2 diabetes and hypertension  thereby reducing the risk of future events.   Patient Perspective Mr. X expressed gratitude for the detailed explanation of his condition  the need for therapeutic lifestyle changes and medication compliance  and the possible complications signaling recurrent events.  This case provides an essential reminder of the significant complications associated with untreated DVT and highlights the importance of early detection  treatment  and modification of risk factors to prevent recurrence. It also emphasizes the need for creating awareness among patients about the signs and symptoms of DVT to promote early reporting and management.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged  Caucasian Female with a History of Prolonged Immobility Due to Hip Arthroplasty  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a medical condition that occurs due to the formation of blood clots in the deep veins of the body  often in the lower extremities. The major risk factors include increased age  obesity  cancer  trauma  surgery  immobility  and inherited blood disorders. This report presents a case of DVT in a 58-year-old Caucasian female with a history of prolonged immobility and hip surgery.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian female  hailing from a suburban community in Northern California. She works as an office manager and leads a moderately active lifestyle. Her past medical history is notable for right hip arthroplasty due to osteoarthritis around two months prior to her presentation. There is no history of smoking  alcohol  or recreational drug use. She has no known allergies  and her only regular medication is a daily multivitamin supplement and occasional over-the-counter analgesics for arthritis pain.  She presented to the emergency room (ER) with a complaint of sudden-onset  non-radiating pain in her left calf of 48 hours duration. The pain was exacerbated on walking and relieved by elevation of the leg. She also reported warmth and swelling in the same leg. She had no complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness. Vital signs on admission were stable.  Physical Examination disclosed a swollen  tender  and erythematous left calf. The rest of her examination was unremarkable. The Wells score for DVT was calculated  yielding a high probability.  Lab investigations revealed a marginally raised D-dimer level. Her Complete Blood Picture  renal  and liver function tests were within normal limits.  A Duplex venous ultrasound was performed  which confirmed the diagnosis of DVT in the left posterior tibial vein.  Management:  The patient was initiated on anticoagulant therapy with enoxaparin  transitioning to oral rivaroxaban. She was advised to elevate the leg and use compression stockings. She was counseled on the symptoms of pulmonary embolism  a serious complication of DVT.  Outcome:  At a one-week outpatient follow-up  the patient reported a significant reduction in pain and swelling. At a four-week follow-up  she had unremarkable physical findings and was continued on rivaroxaban.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing factors predisposing to DVT  such as prolonged immobility following orthopedic surgery. Despite modern prophylactic strategies  DVT remains an important differential in patients with unilateral leg pain/swelling. Prompt recognition and treatment can mitigate the risk of severe complications.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Asian Female with a History of Prolonged Immobility  Introduction:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a significant public health concern due to its high morbidity and mortality potential. This case report introduces a middle-aged Asian female who has developed DVT due to prolonged immobility after hospitalization.   Patient information:  A 52-year-old Asian female presented to the emergency department with complaints of pain and swelling in her left lower leg. The pain was constant and was rated 8 on the 10-point pain scale. She reported that she felt some heat and tightness in her left calf. Her past medical history was significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  which was reasonably well-controlled with Metformin. She had been admitted to the hospital for severe pneumonia three weeks prior and had been discharged three days earlier.  Clinical Findings:   Upon physical examination  her vital signs were stable. Her left lower leg was swollen and palpably warmer than the right. She reported pain when the calf was squeezed (Homan’s sign). There was no superficial venous distention. Her peripheral pulses were palpable.   Timeline:  Doppler ultrasound was immediately performed  which revealed the presence of a clot in the deep vein of her left lower limb confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Blood investigations were remarkable for slight elevations in D-dimer levels.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given her recent history of hospitalization and immobilization  we suspected DVT as a complication. This was corroborated by clinical symptoms and subsequently confirmed with Doppler ultrasound.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Anticoagulant therapy with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) was initiated promptly in the emergency department  with an oral anticoagulant (warfarin) to be started on the following day. Compression stockings were recommended to help reduce swelling and pain.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  The patient was re-evaluated two weeks after the initiation of therapy. Her symptoms had substantially improved. Warfarin was continued at a therapeutic dose aimed at an INR of 2.0-3.0. No bleeding complications were reported.   Patient Perspective:  The patient was appreciative of the medical team’s efforts and satisfied with her treatment process.   Conclusion:  This case underlines the importance of considering DVT in patients with a history of prolonged immobilization or recent hospitalization even in the absence of traditional risk factors such as a genetic predisposition  obesity  or history of smoking. Early recognition and initiation of treatment can significantly affect these patients' prognosis.

Case Report: Male Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Case:  This case involves a patient  Mr. J  a 65-year-old Caucasian male recently retired construction worker. He is married with two adult children  has a family history of cardiovascular disease from his paternal side. He is moderately obese with a Body Mass Index of 30.2. The patient has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for almost 30 years but has recently quit a year ago. The patient comes from a middle-income bracket and has a history of limited physical exercise due to his sedentary lifestyle post-retirement.  Mr. J presented at the clinic complaining of sudden-onset intense pain  warmth  and swelling in his right calf that has been lasting for around three days. His leg was noticeably reddened in the area of swelling. He reported no prior injury to the leg and no recent surgeries.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago. Both conditions were controlled relatively well with medication  including an angiotensin II receptor antagonist for the hypertension  and metformin and insulin for diabetes management.  Upon further questioning  Mr. J mentioned he had recently completed a long-road trip during his vacation where he spent most of his time sitting  with limited mobility. This information coupled with the symptoms he presented  served as a leading clue for the vascular surgeon to suspect deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Following diagnostic assessment including Duplex ultrasonography and D-dimer assay  Mr. J was diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis in his right leg. This fit well with the risk profile of DVT  which can include advancing age  obesity  lack of mobility  smoking history  and chronic illnesses such as diabetes and hypertension.  The patient was then started on systemic anticoagulation therapy and physical measures (like compression stockings) were advised to relieve the edema and pain. Education about modifiable risks and preventive measures with regards to DVT were also given.   This single-case report underscores the importance of comprehensive clinical examination  careful history-taking  and risk assessment in diagnosing potentially dangerous conditions like DVT. In cases with the established pathology  early identification and management can significantly reduce the dangerous potential sequelae  such as pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:  Ms. M is a 72-year-old Caucasian female who resides in an urban nursing home. She is a widow with no children  has undergone high school education and has worked as an administrative assistant before retirement. She has been a nonsmoker and a nondrinker all her life. Her BMI is recorded as 29.6  indicating obesity as per WHO definition.   Presenting Complaint: The patient was admitted with complaints of swelling  pain  and redness in her left leg. She reported that the discomfort had been there for 4 days and was worsening gradually.   Past Medical History: Ms. M has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 10 years  both of which are well-controlled with medication. She has no history of cardiac illnesses or immobilizing conditions. Her surgical history includes a total knee replacement procedure that was performed on her left knee 1 month ago.  Current Medication: She is currently under medication  which includes Metformin 500mg BD for diabetes  Lisinopril 10mg OD for hypertension  and Aspirin 75mg in the morning as an antiplatelet. She finished her course of post-surgical antibiotics and analgesics two weeks ago.  Medical Examination: On physical examination  Ms. M's left leg appeared swollen and erythematous. There was tenderness upon palpation  especially in the calf region. The circumference of the left calf was about 3 cm larger than the right calf  and Homan’s sign was positive.  Diagnostic Assessment: The clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis was confirmed with a Doppler ultrasound which showed the presence of a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein suggestive of a thrombus.   Blood tests revealed HbA1C of 7.4% indicative of fair glycemic control. Fasting blood glucose was recorded as 138 mg/dl; postprandial sugar as 178 mg/dl. Lipid profile showed elevated LDL at 156 mg/dl and reduced HDL at 38 mg/dl. Liver and renal function tests were within normal range. Coagulation profile was within the normal limit.  Diagnosis: Ms. M was diagnosed with left-sided Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) post orthopedic surgery.  Clinical Management: The patient was started on low-molecular-weight heparin and then transitioned to long-term anticoagulant therapy with warfarin. Monitoring of PT/INR levels was initiated to guide dosing. She was also advised to elevate her leg to decrease swelling and was fitted with graduated compression stockings to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome. Weight control and regular exercises were also advised to manage her obesity.  Patient Education: Patient education emphasized the recognition of signs of pulmonary embolism – a severe complication of DVT. She was also counseled on the importance of medication compliance  lifestyle modifications  and regular follow-ups.  Conclusion: In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of early clinical suspicion and prompt diagnosis of DVT in high-risk patients such as elderly  obese postoperative patients. It also underscores the need for patient education about potential complications and medication adherence.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Woman with Previous History of Myocardial Infarction - A Case Report  INTRODUCTION  We report on a case of a 57-year-old African-American woman who presented with deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  further complicated by her medical history of a prior myocardial infarction.  CASE REPORT  The patient  a retired paralegal and non-smoker  has a BMl of 29  lives in urban Atlanta  Georgia  and originally sought medical care due to swelling and discomfort in her right lower limb. The patient's medical history includes hypertension  high cholesterol  and a myocardial infarction two years prior.  Presenting symptoms were progressive swelling  redness  warmth  and pain in the right calf area over two days. The woman initially attributed the discomfort to excessive walking during a recent short vacation. However  when the swelling and pain failed to improve  she sought medical care. She denied chest pain  shortness of breath  or occurrence of similar events in the past.  Physical examination revealed a moderately obese woman in no distress but noticeable swollen  erythematous and warm right lower limb. There was tenderness upon palpation. There were no visible varicose veins.  Hg was 12.9 g/dL  platelets were at 350 000/uL  and WBC count was 7800/uL. Her coagulation profile  as well as kidney and liver function tests  were within normal limits. The patient was placed on low molecular weight heparin and her right leg ultrasonograph reported Deep Vein Thrombosis in the right popliteal and femoral veins.  Treatment included low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)  warfarin  and graduated compression stockings. The patient's care was further managed by an Internist and a Vascular surgeon with considerations for her previous cardiac issues as part of her treatment plan.   The patient had an uneventful recovery and at her six week follow-up  a repeat ultrasound scan showed recanalization of the affected veins.
