CONCLUSION  This case highlights the importance of maintaining a high clinical suspicion for DVT in patients with leg swelling and pain  particularly in those patients with additional risk factors. Awareness of DVT and its potential complications  such as pulmonary embolism  is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment  including in postmenopausal women with a history of myocardial infarction. The treatment approach should be multidisciplinary considering the patient's overall medical condition.   KEYWORDS: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Thrombosis  Veins  Myocardial Infarction  Postmenopausal  Case Report

Title: An Unusual Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): A Case Report  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a serious condition characterized by the formation of blood clots in the deep veins  primarily in the lower extremities. It can be life-threatening if the blood clot dislodges and travels to the lungs  causing a pulmonary embolism. Here  we present the case of a 69-year-old Caucasian female with a non-typical presentation of DVT.  Patient Information:  The patient  Mrs. B  is a 69-year-old Caucasian female from the rural Midwest region of the United States. She is a retired schoolteacher  married  and lives with her husband. Her height and weight at presentation weighed 155 lbs (70.3 kg) and height 63 inches (160 cm)  BMI 27.4  classifying her within the overweight range.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented with a 4-day history of gradually worsening left upper extremity pain and swelling without obvious precipitating incident. The patient reported no recent prolonged travel or surgery  no significant medical history  and is a non-smoker.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a swollen left arm with a positive Homan’s sign. Her lower extremities were unremarkable with good capillary refill and detectable pulses bilaterally. Lower extremity swelling  pain  or tenderness  typically associated with DVT were absent.  Diagnostic Assessment: Lab findings displayed slightly elevated d-dimer levels. Ultrasonography revealed an occlusive thrombus in the left subclavian vein. Given her age  lack of typical risk factors  and unusual presentation  a thorough malignancy work-up process was initiated  which came back negative.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient received intravenous heparin acutely  then was switched to oral anticoagulation (warfarin) accompanied by compression therapy. The patient showed substantial improvement  with a reduction in pain and swelling.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Over three months of follow-up  her symptoms fully resolved. She remained compliant with her anticoagulation therapy and demonstrated no signs of post-thrombotic syndrome. Her case highlights the importance of high clinical suspicion when presented with unexplained unilateral limb swelling  despite the absence of common risk factors.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed surprise by her diagnosis  having no prior knowledge of DVT occurrences outside of the lower extremities. She reported satisfaction with the management provided and pledged to remain compliant with follow-up visits and medication.  Conclusion: This case report adds to the literature on atypical presentations of DVT and draws attention to maintaining a high level of clinical suspicion in older patients presenting with unilateral limb swelling  even without traditional risk factors for DVT.   Keywords: Deep Vein Thrombosis  DVT  Atypical presentation  Upper extremity DVT  Unilateral limb swelling.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a 65-Year-Old Caucasian Female  Case presentation: We present the case of a 65-year-old woman of Caucasian ethnicity who operates a market stand  hence being on her feet for extended periods daily. She is a former smoker and has a significant history of hypertension for the past ten years  but her adherence to prescribed antihypertensive medication (lisinopril) is inconsistent. She abstains from alcohol and denies any history of illicit drug use. There are no known allergies reported.   Clinical narrative:  The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with a two-day history of acute onset  severe pain on her left leg that worsened with walking. Moreover  she noted increased left leg swelling and a mild degree of warmth over the calf. She had no history of recent surgery  immobilization  or previous venous thromboembolism  nor was there a family history of blood clotting disorders. She has been menopausal for 15 years with no history of hormone replacement therapy.  On examination  the left leg was slightly erythematous  warm to the touch  and noticeably swollen  with calf circumferential measurement 3 cm larger than the right. There was mild tenderness on compression testing at the level of the left gastrocnemius muscle  but no superficial venous distension.  Investigations:  Bedside doppler ultrasound performed in the ED confirmed our suspicion of acute DVT  with evidence of occlusive thrombus in the left popliteal vein. Her laboratory results were significant for a D-dimer level of 1100 ng/mL (normal:0-500 ng/mL)  while her complete blood count  plasma electrolytes  liver and renal function tests were within normal limits.  Diagnosis:  Given the patient’s clinical picture  ultrasound findings  and elevated D-dimer level  the diagnosis of acute left lower leg DVT was made.  Management:  The patient was admitted to the hospital for initiation of anticoagulant therapy  beginning with parental unfractionated heparin. Following a cardiology consult  she was transitioned to oral rivaroxaban and educated extensively on medication adherence  leg elevation  and wearing compression stockings. Referrals to a vascular specialist for follow-up and home healthcare services were arranged before discharge.  Discussion: This case underscores the significance of identifying DVT in an outpatient setting without known DVT risk factors such as recent surgery  genetic coagulopathy  or long-term immobilization. Poorly controlled hypertension  old age  prolonged standing  and non-adherence to prescribed medications may all contribute to increased risk. Early detection and prompt management with anticoagulants are crucial to prevent potentially fatal complications such as pulmonary embolism. Furthermore  this stresses the importance of patient education regarding medication compliance.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Female With a Past Medical History of Oral Contraceptive Usage: A Case Report  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of intense  painful swelling in her left leg.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports the swelling started two days prior without any precipitating incident or injury and has become progressively worse. She also mentioned slight shortness of breath and slight chest discomfort  particularly during deep inhalation.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history included hypertension  controlled with angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and long-term use of oral contraceptives in her younger years. She reported occasional alcohol use but denies tobacco or illicit drug use. The patient is post-menopausal with no history of hormone replacement therapy. There was no family history of DVT  malignancies or coagulation disorders.   Physical Examination: Vital signs upon admission were: blood pressure  128/82 mmHg; pulse  85 beats/min; respiration rate  19 breaths/min; temperature  36.7°C; and oxygen saturation  95% on room air. Physical examination revealed an erythematous  edematous  tender left leg. There was no cyanosis  ulceration or evidence of superficial vein varicosities.  Clinical Findings: Diagnostic workup included doppler ultrasonography  which showed occlusive thrombus in her left femoral and popliteal veins indicating DVT. Electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm with no acute ischemic changes. Her D-dimer level was elevated.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was admitted for further management. She was put on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin. Oral anticoagulation with warfarin was initiated a day later with a plan to continue for at least three months. Measures were also taken to control her blood pressure.  Outcome: The treatment was tolerated well. Subsequent examinations and follow-up ultrasounds showed decreasing size of her thrombus  and her symptoms gradually improved. She was discharged with instructions and prescriptions for oral anticoagulants and a recommendation for regular follow-ups.   Teaching Points: This case emphasizes the importance of considering risk factors such as aging  personal history of long-term oral contraceptive use  and present control of hypertension for the development of DVT in the absence of any genetic predisposition or recent immobility.

Title: A Case of Unprovoked Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 45-Year-Old Female   Patient Information:  Mrs. A  a 45-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with complaints of acute onset  unilateral right lower extremity pain and swelling. She is a non-smoker  does not consume alcohol  and had no recent travel or periods of prolonged immobility. Additionally  there was no history suggestive of recent trauma or injury. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is within normal limits. She is gravida 2  para 2 with an unremarkable obstetric history.   Past Medical History:  She was relatively healthy without any significant past medical or surgical history. She has never been on any long-term medication. Mrs. A denied any personal or family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or other clotting disorders.   Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a painful and swollen right calf  measuring 3 cm larger than the left. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.   Investigations:  Venous Doppler ultrasonography was performed  which confirmed thrombosis in the mid and distal segments of the right popliteal vein and calf veins. Her D-dimer levels were markedly elevated. The patient’s complete blood count  electrolytes  renal  and liver function tests were within normal limits. Coagulation profile including Prothrombin Time (PT) and Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (APTT) was also within normal limits.  Screening test for thrombophilic states including Factor V Leiden mutation  Prothrombin gene mutation  and Antithrombin  Protein C and S deficiencies were also carried out to rule out potential hereditary or acquired thrombophilia but all tests came negative.  Diagnosis:  Based on her symptoms  physical examination  and diagnostic results  she was diagnosed with right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Treatment:  The patient was admitted and managed with anticoagulation therapy (Low Molecular Weight Heparin followed by a conversion to a novel oral anticoagulant). She responded well to the treatment and was discharged with advice to continue oral anticoagulant therapy.  Discussion:  This case represents an unprovoked DVT in a middle-aged female with no identifiable high risk factors. Unprovoked venous thromboembolism may indicate presence of an underlying malignancy. However  an extensive malignancy workup was negative in this case.  Follow-up:  On her follow-up appointment 1 month later  she reported alleviation of symptoms and continues to be monitored.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of considering DVT even in patients without identifiable risk factors. Physicians should be aware of the potential for DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling. In cases of unprovoked DVT  it could be imperative to perform thorough investigations in order to rule out other potential pathologies including malignancies.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Female  Introduction:  A 62-year-old African American female presented to the emergency department with acute-onset left lower extremity (LLE) pain and swelling that had worsened over a three-day period. The patient reported no recent travel  injury  or known hypercoagulable state. The patient was post-menopausal and has been on hormone replacement therapy (HRT) since the onset of menopause. She has a previous medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and obesity.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a retired school teacher  lives alone with no children and no prior history of smoking or alcoholism. Her body mass index (BMI) is 34  indicating obesity. She had been on antihypertensives and diabetic medications with poor adherence. On presentation  she was in moderate distress from pain. Vital signs were stable: Blood pressure 142/90 mm Hg  heart rate 86 beats/min  respiratory rate 18 breaths/min  and oral temperature 98.9 °F. The LLE was significantly swollen  erythematous  and warm to touch compared to her other limb. Pedal pulses were diminished but present bilaterally. The rest of her physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigation:  Venous Doppler of the LLE was immediately ordered and demonstrated a non-compressible left femoral vein consistent with deep vein thrombosis. Complete blood count revealed slightly raised white cell count of 12 000/mm3 and hemoglobin of 12.5 g/dL. Her prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time were normal. D-dimer level was significantly elevated at 800 ng/mL (reference value < 500 ng/mL). Fasting glucose level was a bit elevated at 148 mg/dL while her blood urea nitrogen and creatinine were normal.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was started on therapeutic unfractionated heparin and admitted to the general internal medicine ward. Upon further questioning  the patient revealed irregular use of her HRT  so the decision was made to discontinue them due to the significant risk factor they pose for deep venous thrombosis. On hospital day 2  she was transitioned to oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban. Her pain and swelling progressively improved  and she was discharged on hospital day 4 to continue rivaroxaban with outpatient follow-up. Her adherence to antihypertensive and diabetes medication was also reinforced during hospitalization and post-discharge.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing the risk factors for deep vein thrombosis  including HRT  obesity  hypertension  and diabetes. A comprehensive assessment of the demo-social and clinical background of an individual is necessary to optimally manage and prevent the recurrence of DVT.                                                                                                                                                    Conclusion:  Even in the absence of clear hypercoagulable state or physical injury  health care providers should maintain a high degree of suspicion for DVT  especially in patients with multiple risk factors like in our patient. An early diagnosis and intervention can prevent potentially fatal complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Male Patient with Prior Medical History of Metabolic Syndrome  Introduction:  A 55-year-old Hispanic male presented to the Emergency department with pain in the left lower extremity accompanied by swelling  erythema  and warmth. He further described the pain as progressive over three days  which was exacerbated by walking and somewhat relieved with elevation. The patient also reported a recent long-haul flight taken about a week prior to symptom onset.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 55-year-old Hispanic male known to have metabolic syndrome; being a known hypertensive and type 2 diabetic with BMI classified in the obese range. The patient denied any history of smoking  alcohol  or drug abuse. However  sedentary behavior and poor dietary habits were noted. The patient’s family history includes a brother with heart disease and a mother deceased from a cerebrovascular accident.  Clinical Findings:  On presentation  his pulse rate was 96bpm  blood pressure of 142/90 mmHg  and SpO2 of 97%. Physical examination revealed palpable cords  warmth  and tenderness along the course of the left calf muscle  suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. The remainder of the examination was non-significant.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Complete blood counts reported increased platelet counts. Prothrombin time  partial thromboplastin time  and international normalized ratio (INR) were within normal ranges. D-dimer level was significantly elevated. An ultrasound Doppler of the left lower extremity was done which confirmed extensive deep vein thrombosis of the left popliteal vein.  Treatment:  The patient was admitted for management. Anticoagulation was immediately initiated with an intravenous heparin drip with a plan to overlap with oral warfarin until INR was within therapeutic range. Additionally  anti-edema measures such as leg elevation and compression stockings were initiated. The patient was closely monitored for potential complications.  Clinical progress:  The patient responded well to treatment with a noticeable reduction in pain and swelling. At discharge  the patient was advised on the importance of regular follow-up checks  and was educated on lifestyle modifications including regular exercise  healthy diet  and strict control of his hypertension and diabetes.  Discussion:  This case serves as a reminder that DVT can occur in middle-aged patients  particularly those with metabolic syndrome. The presence of metabolic syndrome is a risk factor for DVT due to hypercoagulability related to obesity and hypertension. Sedentary behavior can increase the risk further  as can long-haul flights as seen in this case. Therefore  these patients must be encouraged to manage their metabolic syndrome efficiently and motivated to lead an active lifestyle with proper diet and exercise to prevent DVT and potential life-threatening complications.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged African American Male: A Case Report  Case Presentation:  Our patient  a 50-year-old African American male office worker from Maryland  presented to the emergency department with complaints of increasing left calf pain over the last week. The pain was described as a dull ache  exacerbated by walking and relieved by rest. He also reported mild swelling in the affected limb but denied any shortness of breath  chest pain  fever  or trauma.  Demographics:  The patient is a never smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. He does not use any illicit substances. He has a BMI of 29  indicating overweight  but no previous history of bariatric surgery. He has a history of type II diabetes and hypertension  which are well managed with Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. Patient is non-compliant with regular exercises and has mostly a sedentary lifestyle given his profession. No significant family history for coagulation disorders or DVT was reported. He lives with his wife and two adult children in an urban apartment.   Clinical Findings:  Physical examination demonstrated a mildly swollen  erythematous left lower extremity. The patient’s vitals were stable. No calf tenderness on Homan's sign was noted. Distal pulses were equally palpable bilaterally. There were no signs of superficial venous inflammation or ulcers. Rest of his investigation including routine blood tests were unremarkable apart from a slightly raised D-dimer level.  Diagnosis:  Given the presentation  Virchow’s triad was considered  which suggested a potential high risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The slightly elevated D-dimer level further supported this suspicion. A Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity was performed and confirmed the presence of a non-occlusive thrombus in the popliteal vein suggestive of DVT.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was initiated on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) overlapped with Warfarin as per the standard guidelines for DVT management. He was hospitalized and observed for 48 hours. He had an uneventful hospital course and was discharged home with instructions to continue warfarin for at least three months and attend regular follow-up appointments. He was also educated about the signs of pulmonary embolism (PE) and the need for immediate medical attention if such signs or symptoms occur.   Further instructions given to him included lifestyle modifications like regular exercise  healthy diet  weight optimization  and proper control of his diabetes and hypertension. He was also educated about proper use of compression stockings. The patient has remained asymptomatic at his follow-up visits.   Conclusions:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing DVT in patients presenting with unexplained leg pain and mild swelling  even in the absence of risk factors such as surgery or immobilization. Given the potentially catastrophic complications like PE  clinicians should consider DVT in differential diagnosis  particularly in patients with type II diabetes  hypertension  and in African American populations. Regular monitoring and adherence to anticoagulant therapy are pivotal to the management of DVT.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Female with History of Obesity: A Case Report  Introduction:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is an often underdiagnosed and serious condition involving the formation of a blood clot within a deep vein  typically in the leg.  Case Report:  We report a case of a 62-year-old Hispanic female  Mrs. A  presenting to the emergency department with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Demographics: The patient is a post-menopausal  non-smoking female. She is a retired teacher residing in an urban setting. She is married and has two adult children. The patient is obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 35  and has a history of physical inactivity. She denies any history of alcohol or drug abuse.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  for which she is on medications. Her medications include metformin 500mg twice daily and lisinopril 20mg once daily. She does not report any allergies. She has no previous personal or family history of thrombotic events. She has not undergone any surgeries or been immobilized recently.   Presenting complaints: The patient was admitted with a 2-day history of severe pain and swelling in the left lower limb  without any recognizable triggering event. The patient denied experiencing redness  fever  or other systemic symptoms.   Examination and Investigations: Physical examination showed a swollen  erythematous left lower limb that was warm to touch. Her vital signs were stable. D-Dimer test was positive.  On further evaluation  a lower extremity Doppler ultrasound demonstrated deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal and posterior tibial veins. There was no evidence of pulmonary embolism in a CT pulmonary angiogram. Routine blood investigations showed elevated blood glucose and cholesterol levels.  Discussion: In this case  obesity  diabetes and physical inactivity  likely added to the patient's pro-thrombotic state  leading to the formation of DVT. Obesity and diabetes are independent and modifiable risk factors for DVT. The presence of these risk factors should alert practitioners to a heightened risk and potential need for prophylactic management in appropriate cases.   Management and Outcome: Patient was admitted and started on anticoagulant therapy  with low molecular weight heparin initially  then bridged to oral warfarin. The pain and swelling in her leg improved significantly with treatment. She was counselled regarding weight reduction  physical activity and blood sugar control.  Conclusion: This case highlights the adverse thrombotic risks posed by obesity and diabetes. Healthcare practitioners need to be vigilant about screening for DVT among patients with these comorbidities  even in the absence of other traditional risk factors such as recent immobilization or surgery.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Caucasian Female: A Case Report   Introduction: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a significant public health concern worldwide that  if left untreated  may progress to potentially fatal outcomes like pulmonary embolism. We present a case of a 65-year-old woman diagnosed with DVT with a history of hormone replacement therapy and sedentary lifestyle.  Case Presentation: A 65-year-old Caucasian female presented to our outpatient clinic  complaining of unilateral leg swelling and persistent pain in her left lower limb for five days. The patient  a retired teacher  was a non-smoker and denied any alcohol intake. She had a sedentary lifestyle and had been experiencing an increased body mass index  recorded at 32. Her past medical history included a bilateral total knee replacement two years ago and menopause at the age of 50. Since menopause  she had been on hormone replacement therapy  which she discontinued a year ago due to concerns of breast cancer risk after reading about it online. Her family history was remarkable for hemophilia in a male sibling  now deceased.  Physical examination revealed left calf swelling with tenderness  warmth  and erythema extending from mid-calf to ankle without any signs of superficial vein thrombosis. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable. A clinical suspicion of DVT was made based on the Wells score  and a diagnosis was reached after confirming through Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities which showed an occlusive thrombus in the superficial femoral vein.   Discussions: The patient was managed with standard anticoagulant therapy of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) high-bandage compression followed by oral anticoagulant medications. Follow-up at the end of one month showed significant improvement in her symptoms. The patient was encouraged to maintain an active physical lifestyle  reduce weight  and counseled about the risks and benefits of hormone replacement therapy.  Conclusion:  This case report emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in a patient of post-menopausal age presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially those with risk factors including prolonged periods of inactivity  obesity  and history of hormone therapy. It also highlights the significance of appropriate patient education about medications and the maintenance of a healthy lifestyle.   Keywords: Deep vein thrombosis  Hormone replacement therapy  Post-menopausal women  Sedentary lifestyle.

Title: Acute Lower Limb Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Previously Healthy 55 Year Old Caucasian Female: A Case Report    Introduction:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) represents a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in medicine. It typically occurs in the lower extremities and may lead to pulmonary embolism if untreated. This case report illustrates a straightforward but challenging case of DVT  involving a 55-year-old Caucasian female patient with no previously known medical history.  Case Report: Patient Information:    A 55-year-old Caucasian woman was admitted to the Emergency Department of our hospital complaining of right leg swelling and mild discomfort for the past two days. She denied having any fever  chest pain  shortness of breath or hemoptysis. Her previous medical history was notably empty except for two previous pregnancies without any apparent complications and a cholecystectomy 10 years ago. She had no family history of thromboembolic disease. She does not smoke and rarely drinks alcohol.   Clinical Findings:    The patient appeared uncomfortable  but she was not in acute distress. Physical examination revealed unilateral edema and mild erythema on the right lower limb  starting from mid-thigh to the ankle with a noticeable difference in size compared to the left lower limb. The right lower limb was warm to touch. No signs of superficial vein inflammation were found and peripheral pulses were intact. Her vitals were stable  with a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  a heart rate of 85 bpm  respiratory rate of 16/min and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air.   Diagnostic Assessment:  The D-dimer test was positive and subsequent Doppler ultrasonography of the right lower extremity confirmed the diagnosis of an acute DVT involving the full length of the femoral vein down to the popliteal vein. A Chest CT scan was performed  which did not show any evidence of pulmonary embolism.  Other laboratory data including complete blood counts  coagulation profiles  renal and liver function tests were within normal limits. Testing for antiphospholipid antibodies was negative. Screening for malignancies was also negative.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Anticoagulation was initiated with intravenous low-molecular-weight heparin and transition to oral anticoagulants was done on the second day. Analgesics were administered to relieve the patient's discomfort.  Follow-up and Outcome:  On follow-up after three months  the patient's symptoms were resolved completely. A repeat Doppler showed the complete resolution of the thrombosis. The patient was advised on further preventive measures including staying hydration  regular mobility  and continued anticoagulation therapy.  Discussion:  Despite being a physically healthy  non-obese  non-smoker patient  this case underscores the fact that DVT can occur even in the absence of major risk factors. Regular mobility and hydration  along with awareness of the symptoms  is critical for prevention and early diagnosis of DVT.  Conclusion:  DVT affects individuals of all demographics. Despite an otherwise healthy lifestyle and no prominent risk factors  our patient was diagnosed with DVT which underlines its uncertain nature. This case report strongly advocates for a high degree of clinical suspicion and immediate diagnostic work-up for DVT in patients presenting with unilateral lower limb swelling and pain  irrespective of the presence or absence of known risk factors.

Title: Unprovoked Lower Limb Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 47-Year-Old African American Woman: A Case Report  Patient Profile   Initials: C.D   Age: 47 years   Gender: Female   Ethnicity: African American   Occupation: Office clerk  Presenting Complaint The patient  C.D.  reported to the emergency department complaining of progressive left-sided calf pain and swelling that had started five days prior.  Medical History The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  which is currently managed with metformin and lifestyle modifications. She is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. She has no known allergies  no previous surgeries  and reports no family history of cardiac or hematologic disorders. She denies any preceding trauma  prolonged periods of immobilization  or recent long-haul travel. The patient's last menstrual period was two weeks ago  and she uses oral contraceptives.  Investigations and Findings Physical examination revealed a palpably swollen  warm  erythematous left calf compared to the contralateral side. C.D.'s vitals were within normal limits. D-dimer was significantly elevated. A compression ultrasound of the left lower extremity showed non-compressibility of the left popliteal and calf veins suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Diagnosis The patient's clinical presentation and diagnostic studies confirmed a diagnosis of unprovoked left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis.  Management  The patient was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) in the hospital. Oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban was initiated  with the LMWH being discontinued after two days of overlap. She was counseled on the importance of adherence to anticoagulant therapy  potential bleed risk  the signs of bleeding  and when to seek emergency medical attention. She was discharged on the third hospital day. Arrangements were made for close outpatient follow up with Hematology  under whose care the decision will be made regarding the duration of anticoagulant therapy.  Discussion This case highlights the occurrence of unprovoked DVT in an African American woman under 50 years of age  out of the demographics where DVT is most commonly expected. It is noteworthy considering the absence of commonly associated risk factors such as major surgery  malignancy  or previous history of venous thromboembolism. This unusual presentation underscores the importance of considering DVT even in seemingly low-risk patients if they present with suggestive symptoms.  Conclusion Despite DVT being more prevalent in the elderly and those with specific risk factors  this case emphasizes the indispensability of having a high index of clinical suspicion in young  ethnically diverse patients presenting with symptoms in line with DVT.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged African American Female: A Case Report  Introduction:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a medical condition that occurs when a blood clot forms in one or more of the deep veins typically in the legs. This case report describes the diagnosis  treatment  and management of DVT in a middle-aged African American female with a sedentary lifestyle and medical history of hypertension and obesity.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 52-year-old African American female  residing in an urban setting in New York  New York  United States. She is employed in a sedentary job and does not engage in regular physical exercise. She has a BMI of 35  medically characterized as obese  and is a non-smoker with no addiction behaviors. Her family history reveals that her mother had myocardial infarction at the age of 64  but no history of venous thromboembolism was found.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presented with sudden onset  unilateral leg swelling  with associated warmth and tenderness. Upon examination  she was noted to have a differential limb circumference and positive Homan's Sign. Her vital signs were stable  and she showed no signs of respiratory distress.  Diagnostic Assessment: Venous Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a thrombosis in the right popliteal and femoral veins  leading to the diagnosis of DVT. Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels typical for this condition. Other routine investigations  including CBC and lipid profile  revealed mildly elevated cholesterol levels.  Therapeutic Interventions:  Treatment involved initiation of anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) followed by warfarin. The patient was educated on the importance of compliance with anticoagulant medication  and the need for regular INR monitoring. Compression stockings were recommended for symptom relief.  Follow-Up and Outcome:  On her 6-week follow-up  the patient's symptoms had improved considerably  and INR was within therapeutic range. A repeat ultrasound showed partial recanalization of the femoral and popliteal veins. Long-term management of DVT was discussed  including continuation of anticoagulant  weight management  and increased physical activity. She was referred to a dietitian to design a comprehensive nutritional plan and encouraged to participate in moderate physical activity.  Patient Perspective:  The patient seemed to appreciate the gravity of her condition and expressed motivation to improve her lifestyle habits which she understood were a contributory factor to her condition. She was open to the idea of losing weight and was resolute about making significant diet modifications and engaging in physical activity. She appeared well aware of her follow-up visits and was consistent with her medication.  Conclusion:  Management of DVT involves a multidisciplinary team approach. This case reinforces the need for understanding individual lifestyle and demographic risk factors that may contribute to the person’s overall health. It also emphasizes the need for patient education and motivation to manage a chronic condition.

Title: A Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Female Adult with Hypertension  Patient Information:  A 55-year-old African-American female (Mrs. L) in low socioeconomic status from an urban setting presented to the office with complaints of increasing pain  edema  and warmth located in her right lower leg  which had been ongoing for the past week.  Medical History:  Mrs. L has a ten-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago. She is also obese (BMI 32) and has a 30-pack year history of smoking. There is no history of cancer  surgery  hospitalization  or immobility.   Pharmacological history:  The patient is currently on Metformin for diabetes and Hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. She also takes aspirin irregularly. She has no known allergies to medications.  Family History: The patient's mother had a stroke at the age of 68  her father had heart disease  and her younger brother was recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. There is no family history of coagulation disorders.  Clinical findings: Physical examination of the right leg revealed tender calf muscles  significant edema  and skin discoloration  while the pulse was intact. There were no ulcers or sores. A mild grade 2/6 systolic murmur was appreciated on cardiac auscultation. Both lungs were clear to auscultation.  Diagnostic assessment: Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of deep vein thrombosis in the right lower leg with evidence of non-compressibility of the popliteal and femoral vein. Laboratory investigations revealed a mildly elevated D-Dimer level. The lipid profile was abnormal with an elevated LDL cholesterol level. Hemoglobin A1C was also high  indicating poor control of diabetes.  Therapeutic intervention: Mrs. L was administered low-molecular-weight heparin therapy for anticoagulation  as well as compression therapy. She was counseled about lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation  weight reduction  regular physical activity  and adherence to her antihypertensive and diabetic medications.   Follow-up & Outcomes:  The patient was scheduled for follow-ups to monitor her response to treatment and the status of her DVT. She was also referred to a nutritionist to plan a diabetic and hypertensive-friendly diet.  Patient perspective: Mrs. L was concerned about her current diagnosis but was willing to adhere to medications and lifestyle changes. She was also eager to attend regular follow-up visits to ensure improvements in her health status.  Key Learning points: 1. The risk of developing deep vein thrombosis increases in individuals with hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and a history of smoking. 2. Prompt management with anticoagulation therapy and lifestyle modifications is essential to prevent serious complications such as pulmonary embolism. 3. Regular follow-up and close monitoring of high-risk patients for DVT is crucial.   This case highlights the need for healthcare providers to actively screen  educate  and manage patients with multiple risk factors for deep vein thrombosis. More attention should be given to populations that commonly experience health disparities  such as low socioeconomic groups and racial minorities  to prevent conditions like DVT.

Title: Unilateral Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a Middle-Aged Sedentary Male with a History of Recent Orthopedic Surgery: A Case Report  I. Demographic Information: Patient Initials: T.M. Sex: Male Age: 52 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Software engineer (Semi-Sedentary Lifestyle) Marital Status: Married Socioeconomic Status: Middle Class  II. Case Presentation:  Mr. T.M.  a 52-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the ER with complaints of severe left leg swelling  pain  and redness. These symptoms had progressively worsened over a week. Other than a mild-to-moderate intensity dropping in his leg  there were no other symptoms; he denied any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  fever  or urinary problems. Past medical history revealed recent orthopedic surgery – an essential arthroplasty  III. Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  there was marked edema and warmth in the lower left limb  along with superficial vein distention. There were no significant findings on cardiopulmonary examination. The patient’s vital signs were within the normal range. CBC showed normal cell counts.   IV. Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  Considering the clinical features and the background of recent orthopedic surgery  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was suspected and diagnostic tests ordered. A Doppler ultrasound of the leg showed a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein  confirming the suspicion of DVT. A D-dimer test was also high.  V. Therapeutic Intervention:  Prompt treatment was initiated with subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) and oral Warfarin therapy. The patient was instructed to keep his leg elevated and was fitted with compression stockings to aid venous return. Post-discharge  the patient was advised for a follow-up with the hematologist to monitor INR levels and adjust warfarin dosages as needed.   VI. Follow-up and Outcome:  At the one-month follow-up  the patient showed significant improvement in the leg swelling and pain. The therapeutic warfarin dose had stabilized his INR level within the target range (2.0-3.0). The patient has since remained symptom-free and has returned to his usual routine.   VII. Discussion:  The increased risk of Deep Vein Thrombosis with recent orthopedic surgery is well known. It critically highlights the necessity of prophylactic measures in such patients highlighting the importance of patient education post-surgery about DVT's signs and symptoms. Health practitioners should strongly consider the use of prophylaxis in such high-risk groups.  VIII. Patient Perspective:  Mr. T.M. was appreciative of his care and understood the value of preventative measures. He mentioned that he would have sought medical care far earlier had he known about the connection between his surgery and DVT. He pledged to stick to his follow-ups and medication regimen.  IX. Informed Consent:  The patient provided informed consent for the case to be published  and his identity was anonymized.  Identifying patient details have been changed to protect patient privacy.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Postmenopausal Woman with Comorbidities: A Case Report  Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old African-American female presented to the hospital with a 3-day history of progressive left lower extremity pain and swelling. The patient mentioned a dull aching pain  localized and somewhat worse with walking  and reported no history of trauma or injury. She has no family history of blood clotting disorders.  Demographics and Medical History:   The patient's demographic data revealed her age  ethnicity  and postmenopausal status. She resides in a rural area in Georgia. The patient is overweight (BMI 27) and a smoker with a 20-pack year smoking history. Her medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  for which she was prescribed metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin respectively. She was not on any form of hormone replacement therapy. She denied any history of surgery  bleeding disorders  or prolonged period of immobilization.   Clinical Findings:   Physical examination showed an acutely swollen  tender left lower calf and ankle with a positive Homan's sign (a possible sign of DVT). There were no visible signs of pulmonary embolism such as tachypnea or decreased oxygen saturation.   Investigations:   Lab tests  including complete blood count  coagulation profile  and D-dimer  were ordered. The patient's D-dimer level was markedly elevated (900 ng/mL  normal range ≤500 ng/mL). An ultrasound Doppler of the left lower extremity revealed a non-compressible left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.   Therapeutic Interventions:   The patient was immediately started on subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) as per the hospital protocol for DVT. Following treatment initiation  she was counselled on the need to eliminate smoking and improve her dietary and exercise habits for effective management of her comorbidities.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient responded positively to LMWH therapy with a gradual reduction in pain and swelling over 4 days. Prior to discharge  she was transitioned to oral anticoagulation therapy with rivaroxaban for long-term DVT management. A 6-month follow-up plan was designed for continual assessment and management of her condition.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of a thorough clinical evaluation in patients presenting with unexplained extremity pain and swelling. Moreover  it underscores the need for effective management and lifestyle modification in patients with multiple risk factors to prevent serious conditions like DVT. Race and geography have been shown to increase the risk of DVT  and should be weighed into diagnostic considerations.

Title: Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Male  Introduction:   This case report presents a 52-year-old white male  presenting with symptoms suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Patient Information:  The patient is an accountant from middle socio-economic background  living in an urban area in Oregon  USA. He is a married individual who is moderately active  does not smoke  and drinks alcohol infrequently. He is of average weight  with a BMI of 24.6. He has no known allergies.  Clinical findings:   The patient came to the hospital complaining of pain and swelling in the left calf  which he noticed 3 days prior. He reported the pain intensifying over time  with mild difficulty in walking but no other associated symptoms. On examination  there was tenderness  redness  and warmth over the left lower leg  particularly over the calf.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Taken the patient's age  gender  and symptoms into account  a preliminary diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was considered. The patient was sent for further evaluation  including ultrasonography of the lower limb and D-dimer test. Ultrasonography indicated the presence of an occlusive thrombus in the left lower extremity  confirming the DVT diagnosis. The D-Dimer test also yielded positive results.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was admitted  and anticoagulant therapy initiated with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). After an initial course of LMWH  the patient was transitioned to long-term oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban.  Follow up and Outcome:  The patient's condition improved significantly over the day  with reduced pain and swelling. He was discharged with guidelines for taking oral medication and instructions for leg exercises at home. Frequent clinic visits for repeat investigation and monitoring were scheduled.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension for the past five years and has been on medication.  Discussion:  Male gender  increasing age  and personal history of thrombotic conditions such as hypertension are known risk factors for DVT. In this case  his sedentary job and lack of regular exercise potentially added to the risk.  In conclusion  clinicians should keep a high degree of suspicion for DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg edema and pain  especially in the presence of risk factors  and timely management can lead to excellent patient outcomes.   This case underlines the importance of patient education in maintaining a healthy lifestyle to prevent such conditions  encouraging regular movement and exercises  especially in sedentary jobs. As well  it emphasizes the need for regular screening and control of thrombotic conditions such as hypertension.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-menopausal Female with Obesity  Abstract: We report an unusual case of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a post-menopausal  obese female. Despite having no significant family history or known genetic predisposition  she experienced an extended period of inactivity  which may have contributed to the formation of the thrombus.  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who originally presented with left lower limb pain and swelling. She is a retired school teacher  married  and resides in a suburban region. She denies usage of tobacco and consumes alcohol in moderation.   Medical History: She has a past history of obesity (BMI: 33)  controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) on Metformin and hypertension managed with Telmisartan. She has no history of recent surgery  trauma  or prior similar episodes of leg pain or swelling. There is no known case of cancer or cardiovascular disease. She denies usage of oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy post-menopause.  Clinical Findings: Her vital signs on presentation were stable  with a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg. Physical examination of the left lower extremity showed swelling and warmth without any discoloration. Homans' sign was present.   Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory tests including Complete Blood Count (CBC)  renal and liver function tests were within normal limits. Her A1C was slightly elevated at 7.2%. D-Dimer assay was significantly high  prompting referral for a Doppler ultrasound. The ultrasound confirmed a thrombus in the left femoral vein  confirming DVT.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was diagnosed on an outpatient basis. Therefore  we initiated treatment with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) as an at-home treatment  alongside oral anticoagulation consisting of Rivaroxaban. She was advised to elevate her legs and apply graduated compression stockings.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient was instructed to follow up after 5 days and then every month. On follow-up at two months  she showed significant improvement with reduced leg swelling  no pain  and normalization of D-Dimer levels. No adverse events were reported during her treatment period.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief with the improvement and agreed to continue medication and lifestyle modifications for weight loss  such as regular exercise and a balanced diet  to mitigate the risk of recurrent DVT.  Conclusion: This report emphasizes that DVT can occur even without significant familial or genetic predisposition. Physiological changes post-menopause  long periods of inactivity  and obesity can increase the risk  indicating the importance of regular exercise and weight management among post-menopausal women.

Title: A case report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Male with a History of Smoking and Hypertension  Introduction: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a significant health issue primarily triggered by blood clotting in deep veins  commonly affects the veins in the lower leg and thigh  making it predisposed to embolization and potential severe complications such as pulmonary embolism (PE). On that note  we report a notable case of DVT in a 57-year-old Hispanic male with relevant co-morbid conditions.  Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. J  a 57-year-old Hispanic male  with a history of hypertension and smoking  presented with complaints of increasing pain and swelling in his left lower limb for the past one week. He is a regular smoker with a 30-pack-year history  and also reports an abrupt increase in sedentary lifestyle due to the recent quarantine measures for COVID-19. His medical history includes essential hypertension which is controlled on medication for a decade. He has no previous family history of venous thromboembolism or other blood clotting disorders.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed swelling  warmness  tenderness  and erythema of the left leg  especially in the calf region. A Homan's sign was positive. His vitals recorded mild hypertension with elevated heart rate.  Diagnostic Assessment: A duplex ultrasound of the lower extremities confirmed the diagnosis of DVT  revealing a thrombus within the left popliteal vein. His D-dimer level was significantly elevated  further supporting the diagnosis. Other laboratory findings  including full blood count  platelets  PT  APTT  liver  and renal function tests  were within normal limits except for slightly increased LDL levels.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately administered subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as a part of anticoagulant therapy and placed on strict bed rest with the left leg elevated. Lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation  were encouraged.  Follow-up: Upon his outpatient follow-up after 1 week  he demonstrated significant improvement with reduced swelling and pain in the affected limb. His anticoagulant therapy was switched to oral warfarin  aiming for a target INR of 2-3  with further follow-ups arranged for monitoring.   Conclusion: This case report underscores the significance of considering DVT as a differential in patients with unilateral leg swelling  especially when presenting with risk factors such as advanced age  smoking  hypertension  and recent immobilization. Early detection and prompt anticoagulant therapy are key to reduce morbidity and potential complications of DVT.   Key Learning points: 1. High index of suspicion is needed in symptomatic patients with risk factors for DVT. 2. Timely duplex ultrasound and appropriate laboratory tests assist in confirming DVT diagnosis. 3. Immediate anticoagulant therapy and lifestyle modifications are essential in DVT management.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Male with a Sedentary Lifestyle: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 52-year-old Caucasian male  identified as Mr. X  was presented to the emergency department of our tertiary care center. He is a resident of New York City and works as a software engineer. He reports to be a nonsmoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His daily activity level is sedentary due to his desk job and he has no known drug allergies. The patient has no history of travel in recent months. The family history revealed that his father had coronary heart disease.  Clinical Findings: Mr. X complained of abrupt onset of unilateral lower limb pain and swelling that had been worsening over a period of several hours. He noticed swelling primarily in his left calf with associated discomfort  redness  and localized heat on the same region. His vital signs upon admission were as follows: blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  pulse rate 80/minute  body temperature 98.6°F  and a respiratory rate of 16/minute. The physical examination highlighted a noticeable difference in left calf circumference in comparison to the right one. No superficial venous dilatation was noted.  Clinical History: Mr. X has a history of obesity (BMI 30.7 kg/m2) and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) four years ago  for which he is under oral hypoglycemic medication Metformin. He also has hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin. His daily medication includes Metformin 500mg twice daily and Atorvastatin 10mg once daily. He has no prior documented history of venous thromboembolism (VTE)  heart disease  stroke  or any malignancy.   Diagnostic Assessment:  According to the Wells Criteria for DVT  the patient had a moderate-to-high probability of DVT. Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels  which further suggested the possibility of a clotting disorder. Confirmation of DVT was done via duplex ultrasonography which showed thrombus in the left posterior tibial vein and popliteal vein.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on subcutaneous Enoxaparin immediately upon diagnosis at a dosage of 1mg/kg twice daily as a bridge to warfarin. Outpatient follow-up and treatment plan were arranged for oral anticoagulation therapy.   Outcome:  On outpatient follow-up after a week  the patient showed improvement in symptoms. Warfarin was continued and the patient was advised weight loss  diabetes management  frequent moving especially during work hours  and wearing compression stockings to prevent reoccurrence. Regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor the patient's condition.   Conclusion: Mr. X’s case underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients with a sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and T2DM presenting with unilateral leg swelling. It also stresses the importance of identifying and managing potential risk factors for DVT to mitigate the risk of serious complications like pulmonary embolism. Regular patient education with regard to lifestyle modifications can go a long way in preventing these venous thromboembolic events  thus contributing to better patient outcomes.

Case Report: A 46-Year-Old Female with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Presenting Patient Information: This report discusses Jane Doe (name altered for privacy)  a 46-year-old Caucasian (52% prevalence in the United States) female (two to three times higher probability of developing DVT). Her occupation involves prolonged periods of inactivity  as she is an accountant. She is married with two children  residing in a suburban area of Seattle  Washington  USA.  Medical History: Ms. Doe has a moderately complex past medical history.  She was diagnosed with type II diabetes (common comorbidity with DVT) roughly five years ago  for which she takes metformin. She also has hypertension  managed with Lisinopril. She has no history of surgeries or major injuries. Notably  she has no history or family history of coagulation disorders.   Ms. Doe is a former smoker  having quit ten years ago. She consumes alcohol socially. Her BMI falls into the overweight category  and she has a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity.  Presenting Symptoms and Clinical Findings:  She presented to the emergency department with a two-day history of unilateral swelling  redness  warmth  and moderate pain in her left calf. She denied any recent travel  surgeries  periods of immobilization  chest pain  hemoptysis  or dyspnea. Physical examination revealed an elevated heart rate  slight edema and erythema confessed to her left lower leg. Neurologically  she was intact.   Investigation and Diagnosis: With high suspicion of DVT  a Doppler ultrasound was performed  confirming the presence of a thrombus in the left popliteal vein. D-dimer level was elevated at 929 ng/ml (normal: 0-500 ng/mL). Electrocardiogram (ECG) and routine laboratory tests were within normal limits.  Management and Follow-Up: Ms. Doe was admitted to the hospital for therapeutic anticoagulation. She was started on injectable low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) and oral warfarin. A follow-up Doppler Ultrasound was arranged for one week later to assess the thrombus's resolution. She was also educated on lifestyle modifications  including increasing physical activity  losing weight  and managing her diabetes.  Outpatient follow-up visits with her primary care physician were recommended to monitor her anticoagulation therapy and manage her chronic conditions effectively.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the typical presentation of DVT in a patient with significant risk factors  such as sedentary lifestyle  obesity  type II diabetes  and age  highlighting the importance of early detection and management to prevent complications like pulmonary embolism. Furthermore  it's important to quantify the effectiveness of lifestyle modifications and pharmacological therapy in patients with similar profiles.

Title: Case Report: A 68-Year-Old Female with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  the formation of blood clots in the deep veins  predominantly of the lower extremities  is a serious condition with potential fatal complications  such as pulmonary embolism. Risk factors for DVT include prolonged immobilization  surgery  malignancy  pregnancy  oral contraceptive use  and inherited coagulation disorders  among others.  Case Presentation: Patient X is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency department (ED) with symptoms of severe pain and swelling in her left lower extremity  which had been progressing over a week. The patient revealed that she had recently undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy  a surgical procedure to remove her gallbladder  about two weeks earlier.   Medical History: The patient's medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes mellitus  and she is a non-smoker. There is no personal or family history of venous thromboembolism. Her daily medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. She reported no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination of the involved extremity showed notable erythema  warmth  tender to touch  and a positive Homan's sign. The patient's vital signs were normal  and cardiovascular and pulmonary examinations were unremarkable.  Diagnosis: A D-dimer test was ordered  which came back elevated  suggesting the possibility of DVT. To confirm  an ultrasonography was conducted  which revealed thrombosis of the left lower limb's femoral and popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Management and Outcome: The patient was admitted and initiated on a heparin drip per protocol for acute DVT and bridged to warfarin therapy later. She was also prescribed compression stockings and advised early ambulation as tolerated. The patient was educated about the risk factors and signs and symptoms of DVT and potential complications such as pulmonary embolism  post-thrombotic syndrome  and recurrent DVT. She was discharged home after four days with close outpatient follow-up plans.  Discussion: The case indicates the importance of recognizing the potential risk of thrombogenesis post-surgery despite appropriate prophylactic measures. It stresses the necessity to provide thorough patient education about the signs and symptoms of DVT  especially for patients with multiple risk factors  as they may present later in primary or emergency care. Regular follow-up and long-term anticoagulation plans should be considered in these patients to decrease morbidity and mortality.  Conclusion: While a rather common condition  DVT remains a significant risk due to potential life-threatening complications. Therefore  timely recognition of the signs and symptoms and appropriate management strategies are crucial for better outcomes. This case emphasizes the importance of patient and caregiver education for earlier diagnosis and treatment to prevent potential critical consequences.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Asian Female: A Single Case Study  Introduction: This case report provides an account of a 55-year-old Asian female diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). By reporting this case  we aim to highlight the importance of early detection  the unique risk factors seen in Non-Caucasians  and the robust management of DVT.  Case Presentation: A 55-year-old Asian female with no significant past medical history presented to the emergency unit with severe  non-acute-onset  throbbing pain in her left lower limb  which had been progressive over the past four days. Her family history was unremarkable  with no documented instances of hypercoagulable disorders. She had no history of recent trauma  surgery  or immobilization. The patient was a non-smoker and seldom consumed alcohol.  Upon examination  her left calf was significantly swollen  with notable erythema and localised tenderness. Her body mass index was within acceptable limits  blood pressure was at the upper norm (138/85 mmHg)  and other vitals were stable. Her lower limb pulses were palpable. A venous duplex ultrasound scan revealed deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal vein.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations revealed a significantly raised D-dimer (2650 ng/mL; reference <500 ng/mL). Her complete blood count  including platelet  was within normal limits  as were her baseline renal and hepatic profiles. The lipid profile was normal  and no indications of an infection were present. Thrombophilia screening was also performed  which was negative for Factor V Leiden mutation  prothrombin gene mutation  antiphospholipid antibodies  and deficiencies of antithrombin  protein C  and protein S.  Treatment: The patient was initiated on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) and oral anticoagulant (rivaroxaban). She received LMWH for the first five days alongside rivaroxaban  after which the LMWH was discontinued.  Outcome and Follow-Up: The patient responded well to the treatment regime with a significant reduction in pain and swelling observed during the treatment course. The anticoagulant therapy has been planned for six months with monthly follow-ups and reassessments based on the department protocol. The patient has been advised to maintain mobility and a balanced diet  along with hydration  to mitigate the risk of recurrence.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral lower limb swelling and pain irrespective of ethnic predisposition and past medical history. Prompt diagnosis through comprehensive evaluation and initiation of anticoagulant therapy is vital for successful outcomes. Regular monitoring can also aid in minimizing the risk of long-term complications such as post-thrombotic syndrome and pulmonary embolism.

Title: Case Report: Bilateral Lower Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 62-year-old Caucasian Male with Prior History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by the formation of a blood clot in the deep venous system  commonly affecting the lower extremities. It can occasionally lead to life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism (PE).  Case Presentation: We report a case of Mr. A  a 62-year-old Caucasian male from rural Georgia  who presented with the acute onset of bilateral lower limb edema and tenderness.  History: Mr. A  a retired carpenter  had a history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with Lisinopril 10mg and Atorvastatin 20 mg per day  respectively. He was a non-smoker and consumed alcohol occasionally. He had a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity and did not follow any specific diet plan.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient’s vital signs were within normal limits. However  his bilateral lower extremities were found to be swollen and tender  right more than left. A Homan’s sign was positive on the right. There was no erythema or palpable cord noted. No other significant clinical findings were observed.  Investigations: Doppler ultrasound of both lower extremities was performed  which revealed clot formations in the deep veins of both legs  more extensive in the right. He had slightly elevated D-dimer levels. The thought of a possible malignancy leading to DVT was ruled out after a complete blood count  liver function tests  and computed tomography revealed no abnormalities.  Treatment and Follow-up: Based on the DVT diagnosis  Mr. A was initiated on low-molecular-weight heparin therapy associated with warfarin. His medications were adjusted over time to maintain the target INR. The patient was counseled about the importance of improving lifestyle habits such as regular physical activities and a balanced diet  controlling weight  and being compliant with medications.   At a three-month follow-up  Mr. A reported a significant reduction in swelling and pain. On repeat Doppler ultrasound  there was notable clot resolution. He continued his medication regimen  physical activity  and healthier diet choices  leading to an overall improvement in quality of life.   Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral or bilateral lower limb swelling  especially in individuals with risk factors such as sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  or hyperlipidemia. Early diagnosis and appropriate management of DVT can significantly reduce morbidity and life-threatening complications.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Male   Patient Information:  A middle-aged man  56 years old  of Caucasian ethnic background  presented to the hospital with complaints of pain  swelling  and redness in his left lower leg. He is a non-smoker  consumes alcohol moderately  and works a sedentary job as an accountant with long hours of sitting. He has no known allergies. The patient is married with two adult children and lives in an urban area. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 30.2 Kg/m2  implying he's obese. Family history reveals that his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and his mother was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at age 65.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a prior medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed with these conditions five years ago and has been managed on antihypertensive medication (amlodipine  5 mg daily) and a statin (atorvastatin  20 mg daily). His medication has been fairly consistent over the year with good overall compliance despite occasional adjusted dosage for better management of his condition. His last documented blood pressure reading was 138/85 mmHg and LDL (Low-density lipoprotein) cholesterol level was 115 mg/dL. Aside from these  his medical history is unremarkable  with no previous incidents of thrombosis or similar conditions.  Clinical Findings:  Primary physical examination revealed a noticeably swollen  erythematous left calf that was warm to touch. A positive Homans' sign was observed (pain in the calf upon dorsiflexion of the patient's foot). The patient also reported a low-grade fever  fatigue  and a feeling of heaviness in the affected leg.   Diagnostic Assessment:  A blood test showed an elevated D-dimer level at 800 ng/mL (normal is less than 500 ng/mL)  suggestive of a possible thromboembolic event. To confirm  a Doppler ultrasound was performed and showed evidence of a deep venous thrombosis in the posterior tibial vein. The hypercoagulable workup was negative  reducing the likelihood of a hereditary blood clotting disorder in this case.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was started on anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH; enoxaparin) at a therapeutic dose. Overlapping with the LMWH  warfarin was initiated. Once the patient's international normalized ratio (INR) reached the optimum therapeutic range of 2.0 to 3.0  the LMWH was discontinued.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  The patient was discharged with a prescription for oral anticoagulation (warfarin) with instructions for strict adherence to the regime and regular INR monitoring. Lifestyle modifications were also advised  such as increasing physical activity  losing weight  and maintaining a healthy diet low in saturated fats and sodium. During the outpatient visit 1 week post-discharge  the patient showed improvements in swelling and pain. He did not develop post-thrombotic syndrome at the follow-up visit 6 months later.   In this case  the patient's age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia made him a suitable candidate for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This emphasizes the importance of being cognizant of risk factors and potential indications of DVT in a similar demographic.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Previously Healthy Middle-aged Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by the presence of a blood clot in the deep veins  usually present in the lower extremities. We present the case of a 54-year-old Caucasian male with no previous medical history.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian male  a professional bus driver  non-smoker  and occasional alcohol drinker  with no known drug allergies and no record of any familial diseases. The patient presented with acute  severe lower leg pain  swelling  and discoloration of the right leg which had started approximately three days before presentation. He reported no history of prior similar episodes  prolonged immobility  recent travels  or surgery. He does not take any medication and has no significant medical or surgical history.  Upon admission  the patient had a BP of 130/80 mmHg  a pulse rate of 88 beats/minute  a temperature of 36.5 °C  and was afebrile. Physical examination revealed swelling  erythema  and warmth in the right lower limb  particularly in the calf region. The Homans' sign was positive. Laboratory findings were as follows: D-dimer level was highly elevated at 2 000 ng/mL  platelet count was 400 000/mm3  prothrombin time (PT) was 14s  and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) was 30s.   A Doppler ultrasound of the right leg was performed which demonstrated a non-compressible right popliteal vein suggestive of acute DVT. Other tests such as chest X-ray  electrocardiogram  and urinary analysis were all within normal limits.   He was managed using low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and oral warfarin. The pain and swelling began to reduce on the 3rd day of treatment. The patient was counseled about his condition and the importance of medication compliance. He was advised to stop alcohol  to increase physical activities  and to control his diet.   Discussion:  This case highlights an instance of primary DVT in an otherwise healthy individual with no apparent risk factors except his occupation  which involves long hours of immobility. This emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in the differential diagnosis of leg pain  even in patients without obvious risk factors.  Conclusion: Even though classic symptoms of DVT  such as pain and swelling  are often seen in many other diseases  clinicians should also consider DVT as a possible diagnosis  particularly in patients whose profession involves prolonged periods of immobility. Prompt diagnosis and early initiation of therapy can prevent serious complications  such as pulmonary embolism. Patient education regarding lifestyle modifications and compliance with medication is crucial in disease management.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Female with a History of Obesity and Hypertension   Introduction: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian female presenting with unilateral pain and severe swelling in the left leg. She lives in an urban setting in Chicago  Illinois  is a retired teacher  and lives an overall sedentary lifestyle.  Case Presentation: On examination  the left leg was noted to be visibly swollen  erythematous  warm to the touch  and painful. The patient has a history of obesity  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. She's also being treated for hypertension for over a decade. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Leonoro and can't recall any recent rigorous physical activity or prolonged period of immobility. She had been postmenopausal for 13 years  but refused hormonal replacement therapy due to personal reasons. Moreover  she does not have a personal or family history of thromboembolic diseases.  Investigations: An ultrasound Doppler study of the left leg was performed  revealing acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left popliteal vein extending to the trifurcation of the tibial veins. Her complete blood count (CBC)  liver function test  renal function test  and coagulation profile were normal. However  her lipid profile showed hyperlipidaemia.  Management and Outcome: The patient was admitted to the hospital and started immediately on anticoagulative therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) followed by oral warfarin therapy. She was closely monitored for any signs of pulmonary embolism. After 5 days of hospital treatment  her symptoms were significantly resolved. Follow-up duplex ultrasonography showed recanalization of the popliteal vein. The patient was discharged with warfarin therapy and was advised to maintain lifestyle modifications  including a healthier diet  regular exercise  and weight loss to manage her obesogenic condition and hence preventing the recurrence of DVT.  Discussion: Postmenopausal women  especially those with obesity and hypertension  may have an increased risk of venous thromboembolism  as seen in this case. This case reiterates the importance of considering DVT in patients who present with unilateral leg swelling  particularly in those who possess risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  or hypertension.  Conclusion: Clinicians should be vigilant in recognizing the common signs and symptoms of DVT  especially in patients who are at a higher risk. This early diagnosis  combined with prompt therapeutic intervention  can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality associated with potential complications  such as pulmonary embolism. This case also draws attention to hypertension and hyperlipidaemia  which could contribute to the incidence of DVTs. Desirable control of these variables can help prevent future occurrences.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Hispanic Woman with a History of Oral Contraceptive Use and Prolonged Immobilization   Patient Information:  The patient is a 51-year-old Hispanic female who presents to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of a painful  swollen  and erythematous right lower extremity  which has gradually worsened over a period of seven days. She has a BMI of 32  categorizing her as obese according to the WHO standards. The patient denies any trauma  recent surgery or travel.  Past Medical History:  In her past medical record  she has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she takes Amlodipine and Atorvastatin respectively. She has been post-menopausal for one year and reports having used an oral contraceptive (Ethinyl Estradiol and norgestimate) for 15 years before stopping a couple of years ago. She's also a non-smoker.  Pertinent History:  On further inquiries  she revealed she recently underwent a period of prolonged immobilization due to the advancement of COVID-19 and was primarily bedridden at home for three weeks with minor physical exertion.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  vital signs were in normal range. Her right lower extremity was swollen and warm to the touch  approximately double the size of the contralateral limb. A palpable cord was noted along the medial thigh and calf. The presence of Homan’s sign was not clear. Peripheral pulses were symmetrical.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A Doppler ultrasonography was ordered which revealed a noncompressible femoral and popliteal vein suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Full blood count showed a slight increase in cell counts while D-dimer levels were markedly elevated. Her lipid profile and blood pressure were slightly elevated.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) was initiated immediately alongside oral anticoagulant Rivaroxaban. Additionally  she was advised to wear graded compression stockings and to elevate the affected extremity whenever possible.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient was admitted to the hospital for initial management and monitoring. Repeat ultrasonography after one week showed recanalization of the femoral and popliteal vein. She was discharged with instructions to continue Rivaroxaban and was referred to a vascular specialist for follow up.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief at the reduction of pain and swelling. She stated she understood the seriousness of DVT and pledged adherence to the medications and necessary lifestyle modifications such as increased physical activity  dietary control  and regular follow-up.  Informed Consent:  The patient gave consent for the publication of her case anonymously.  Discussion: This case highlights the interplay of risk factors such as obesity  hormonal contraceptive use  immobility and post-menopausal status in the development of DVT in the absence of any inherited predisposition.
