It underscores the importance of considering DVT in atypical presentations and promptly initiating treatment to prevent life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in Male African-American Patient: A Case Report  Introduction:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) typically occurs in a deep leg vein that runs through the muscles of the calf and thigh. This case report presents a 48-year-old African American male diagnosed with DVT.  Case Presentation: The patient  a 48-year-old African-American male  presented at the emergency room with a 2-day history of acute onset  left lower extremity pain and swelling. The patient is a taxi driver by profession  with prolonged periods of immobility. He exhibits a 30 pack-year history of smoking and is obese with a BMI of 33.2 kg/m2. He also reported a past medical history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril  but denied any surgeries  recent trauma  previous clotting disorders  or family history of clotting diseases. Moreover  he is non-compliant with his medication and has a poor exercise habit. He does not consume any alcohol  he just smokes. His paternal grandfather had a history of stroke  and both his parents are hypertensive.   On physical examination  the patient appeared in moderate pain  vital signs were stable  but the left lower extremity was noticeably swollen and warm to touch when compared to the right. A noticeable Homan's sign was present.   Investigations: Doppler ultrasound revealed acute DVT in the left common femoral and popliteal veins. D-dimer was elevated. Complete blood count  coagulation profile  and other routine blood investigations were within normal limits. Given the history of hypertension  an ECG was performed  which did not show any abnormalities.  Management and Outcome: The patient was admitted to the hospital and anticoagulation was initiated with intravenous Heparin  subsequently bridged with oral Warfarin. Pain and swelling showed significant improvement. The patient was educated about the importance of medication compliance  encouraged to quit smoking  and reduce weight through a balanced diet and regular exercise. He was discharged on warfarin with INR monitoring in place  thrombosis clinic follow-up arranged.  Discussion: This case emphasizes the risk factors for DVT including obesity  sedentary lifestyle  smoking  non-compliance with hypertension medication  and African American race as found in the literature. Although DVT is less studied in African Americans  some research suggests a higher risk  highlighting the importance of further study in this population demographic. The management and patient education for lifestyle modifications provide a comprehensive approach in the care for DVT.  Conclusion: Early detection and prompt treatment of DVT are essential in preventing serious complications  including pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome. More research is needed to understand the potential genetic or socioeconomic factors contributing to the increased risk of DVT in African American populations. Appropriate risk management strategies  including medication compliance  smoking cessation  weight management  and regular exercise  are fundamental to reducing disease recurrence and improving outcomes.  Keywords: Deep Vein Thrombosis  African American  Case report.

Case Report:  Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a physically fit  middle-aged Caucasian female with no prior history of venous thromboembolism  Case Presentation:  The patient  Ms. A  is a 45-year-old Caucasian female who presented with progressive right lower leg pain and localized edema. She is an accountant by profession with no history of traveling in the recent past and living a physically active lifestyle  including regular gym workouts. She has no prior history of venous thromboembolism (VTE)  malignancy  genetic coagulation disorders  nor does she smoke or consume alcohol. She denied any history of trauma or surgery in the recent past. She has no family history of thrombotic events and is not on any hormonal therapy.  Patient's height and weight were within the healthy range (BMI 22.6 kg/m2). Her blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg  pulse rate 72 beats per minute  respiratory rate 16 per minute  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air.  Laboratory Investigations:  Complete blood count  platelet count  PT and APTT  renal and liver function tests were within normal ranges  indicating no hematological or systemic disorder.  Doppler Ultrasound:  The right lower extremity venous duplex ultrasound showed a non-compressible popliteal vein suggestive of DVT.  Treatment:  The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with rivaroxaban. After discussion with the patient and considering all the benefit-risk factors  it was decided to continue anticoagulant therapy for three months  with regular follow-ups.  Discussion:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) often happens in individuals with risk factors such as surgery  immobilization  active cancer  previous DVT or PE  pregnancy  estrogen therapy  advanced age  and obesity. However  this case is an instance where DVT developed in a physically fit  middle-aged woman without any of the commonly perceived risk factors.  This case serves as a reminder that DVT can also occur in healthy and physically active individuals. Therefore  a high index of suspicion is required when patients present with unexplained leg pain and swelling.  Conclusion:  It is important to include DVT in differential diagnoses  even for patients who do not fit traditional risk profiles. Early detection and appropriate treatment of DVT are crucial to prevent complications  including death from pulmonary embolism.

Title: Case Report: Unilateral Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a Post-Menopausal Woman with No Known Co-Morbidities  Introduction:  This case report discusses a 65-year-old Hispanic female presenting with signs and symptoms indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  with no past medical history of significant illnesses.  Case Presentation:  The patient  a 65-year-old post-menopausal Hispanic woman  presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset pain and swelling in her left lower limb. The patient reports the symptoms started two days ago and have progressively worsened. The swelling was accompanied by a localized warmth and slight discoloration of the skin but no shortness of breath or chest pain were reported. The patient leads an inactive lifestyle  being retired  and does not smoke or consume alcohol. Family history revealed maternal aunt having had DVT  but otherwise unremarkable.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a visibly swollen left calf with some redness and elevated skin temperature compared to the right calf. The circumference of left calf was about 1.5 cm more than the right. The patient's vitals were stable and within the normal range. No signs of superficial thrombophlebitis were noted. No other significant physical findings were identified.  Laboratory Investigations:  A D-Dimer test was ordered which returned a positive result indicating a possible thrombotic event. Further investigation via Doppler ultrasonography was performed which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left common femoral and popliteal veins  confirming DVT.  Treatment:  The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) followed by an oral Factor Xa inhibitor. She was given instructions for leg elevation  application of warm pack and use of compression stockings to reduce swelling and alleviate symptoms.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Over the course of the treatment  the patient’s symptoms gradually improved. After about a week  the swelling noticeably reduced and the patient reported a substantial decrease in pain and discomfort. She was advised to continue the oral anticoagulants for three months  with regular follow-ups. The patient and her family were provided with lifestyle modification counseling  including the importance of physical activity to prevent recurrent DVT events.  Discussion:  Unilateral DVT is common in elderly and obese individuals. However  the patient in this case had a normal BMI and no known pre-existing medical conditions  which suggests a need for further research on the epidemiology of DVT. In this case  genetic predisposition  gender  and sedentary lifestyle may have acted as contributory risk factors. Early detection and treatment using anticoagulants were crucial in preventing potential complications such as pulmonary embolism  post-thrombotic syndrome  and recurrent DVT.

Title: Diagnosis and Management of Unprovoked Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 62-year-old Female Patient  Patient Information:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female weighing 68 kg presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of increasing pain and swelling in her right lower extremity  which started approximately three days ago.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed an edematous and erythematous right lower extremity  significantly warmer than the left. Her right calf measured 3 cm larger in circumference compared to the left. The patient reported no known injury or trauma. She denied any recent periods of prolonged immobilization  recent surgeries  or long-distance travel.  History:  The patient is a former smoker  having quit around 15 years ago. She consumes alcohol occasionally and denies illicit drug use. She has a family history of venous thromboembolism - her mother developed postoperative deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after hip surgery. Personal medical history includes hypertension controlled with lisinopril  hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin  and osteoarthritis of the knees. She has no known drug allergies.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: A D-dimer test was performed  presenting a high value of 1500 ng/mL. Given the patient’s symptoms and elevated D-dimer  a duplex sonography of the right lower extremity was conducted  confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Although she had risk factors for DVT  given her symptoms of unprovoked deep vein thrombosis  the decision was made to evaluate for underlying malignancy with computed tomography (CT) of the chest  abdomen  and pelvis  all of which showed no evidence of malignancy. A complete blood count and coagulation profile were normal excluding any hematologic disorder.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was admitted and anticoagulant therapy was initiated with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) followed by oral rivaroxaban therapy planned for a duration of at least three months.  Follow-Up and Outcome: Her symptoms improved over the following week. At her one-month follow-up appointment  the patient continued to do well  tolerating the anticoagulant therapy and with no recurrence of DVT symptoms. She was advised to continue oral rivaroxaban and regular follow-ups were planned. She was also educated about the symptoms of recurrent thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and advised to seek medical attention if these occur.  Learning Points: This case highlights the importance of considering an unprovoked DVT as a potential sign of an unknown underlying disease such as cancer. Therefore  appropriate investigations should be undertaken to rule out malignancies. Additionally  it emphasizes the management of DVT with anticoagulation therapy and regular outpatient monitoring to ensure resolution and prevent the recurrence of thromboembolic events.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Male: A Case Report  I. Introduction: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a serious condition that occurs when a blood clot forms in one of the deep veins of the body  generally in the legs  is reported in this case. This report exemplifies the intricacies of managing DVT in an individual with a history of smoking and sedentary lifestyle.  II. Patient Information (Demographics): Our patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male  a computer programmer  from Wisconsin  United States. He is a smoker  with a 20-pack year history  and maintains a sedentary lifestyle due to his job nature. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 29  which indicates obesity  another significant risk factor for DVT. He reported consuming alcohol in moderation. He is married and lives with his wife and two adult children.  III. Chief Complaints and Symptoms: The patient presented severe pain and swelling in his right lower leg. He also reported feelings of warmth and redness in the area. He denied experiencing any chest pain  palpitations  or shortness of breath.  IV. Past Medical History: The patient has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both under control with medications. He has no history of any surgeries or injuries. He reported a family history of cardiovascular diseases  including his father dying from a heart attack at the age of 62. No history of similar symptoms or other venous thromboembolisms are reported. He does not have any known allergies.  V. Diagnosis: With DVT suspected  a D-Dimer test was done  which came back positive. This was followed by a Doppler ultrasound  which confirmed the diagnosis by revealing clotting in the deep veins of the patient's right lower leg.  VI. Treatment: The patient was administered intravenous heparin immediately  followed by oral warfarin  with a subsequent overlapping period and INR monitoring. Lifestyle modification  including smoking cessation and increased physical activity  were advised.   VII. Outcomes: The patient's condition improved over a week in hospital  with reduction in pain and swelling. He was discharged on long-term warfarin  educated on benefits of smoking cessation  maintaining regular physical activities and on his diet to manage hypertension and diabetes.  VIII. Learning Points: This case emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in middle-aged individuals presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially if they have a sedentary lifestyle  tobacco smoking history  and known risk factors such as obesity and hypertension. When managed promptly  the prognosis for DVT can be good  but delayed or missed diagnosis can lead to severe complications  including fatal pulmonary embolisms. Regular physical activity and healthy lifestyle practices remains pivotal in preventing DVT especially among high risk individuals.   This case authorizes the description in the literature about the accurate demographic representation of DVT patients  commonly reported in middle-aged to elderly  overweight males  with a history of smoking and sedentary lifestyle.

Title: A Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Male with a History of Hypercholesterolemia   Introduction:  This case report describes a 60-year-old Caucasian male who presented with pain and swelling in the left leg and was found to have deep vein thrombosis. This patient had several risk factors  including age  sedentary lifestyle  and a medical history that includes hypercholesterolemia.  Case Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department complaining of increasing pain and swelling in the left leg  which had started approximately five days prior. He described the pain as being dull and constant  increasing with movement. There were no traumas or injuries reported. The patient rarely exercises  spends most of his day sitting and doesn't travel frequently. The patient's previous medical history includes hypercholesterolemia for which he has been taking statins for the past 5 years. He has no history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  pulmonary embolism (PE) and no family history of DVT or PE. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient appeared uncomfortable due to pain. His left calf was swollen and erythematous. Positive Homan's sign was noted. The rest of the examination was unremarkable. Vital signs upon admission: blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  heart rate of 78 beats per min  temperature of 37°C (98.6°F)  respiratory rate 16 per min  oxygen saturation 98% in room air.  Diagnostic Procedure:  D-dimer levels were found to be high. An ultrasound of the lower extremity revealed a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy immediately with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). A consultation was made with a hematologist for further management. Patient was advised to elevate the affected leg  applying warm compresses and wear compression stockings.   Outcome:  The patient's pain and swelling significantly improved and he was discharged from the hospital with oral anticoagulation therapy and instructions for follow-up. At the 3-month follow-up visit in the clinic  the patient reported no further symptoms and ultrasound revealed resolution of the clot.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing DVT in patients presenting with unexplained leg pain and swelling. Further  it emphasizes the impact of modifiable risk factors for DVT such as sedentary lifestyle which must be addressed during patient education and discharge planning. In this particular case  ongoing management for hypercholesterolemia and monitoring of medication side effects will also remain critical.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle Aged Asian Male with a History of Stroke: A Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. Y  a 54-year-old Asian male  presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of increasing swelling  discomfort and redness in his left lower extremity. His discomfort was described as a dull pain and tenderness on the medial side of the calf that increased upon standing and walking.  Past Medical History: The patient had a history of ischemic stroke 18 months ago. No significant family history of cardiovascular disease or blood clotting disorders was reported. He is a non-smoker with occasional alcohol consumption. He was previously on aspirin prophylaxis since the occurrence of his stroke but had stopped 6 months ago. There was no history of recent surgery  injury or long-distance travel.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed an edematous  erythematous and warm left lower leg. His left calf circumference was 3 cm greater than the right one. Vitals were stable with a pulse rate of 80 bpm  blood pressure 130/90 mm Hg  respiratory rate 18/min  and body temperature of 37°C.  Diagnostic Focus & Assessment: A Doppler ultrasound examination of the left leg was undertaken  which identified a thrombus in the left popliteal vein suggesting acute deep vein thrombosis. Lab testing showed a raised D-dimer level (2.5 µg/ml; reference range <0.5 µg/ml). Hematology profile showed a hematocrit of 46% and platelet count of 320 000/mm³. Lipid profile  renal and liver function tests were all within normal limits.   Therapeutic Focus & Follow-Up: Anticoagulant therapy was initiated with intravenous heparin followed by oral anticoagulation (warfarin). A compression stocking was advised to control the edema. The patient was educated on signs of pulmonary embolism and was advised to report to the hospital immediately if such symptoms would occur. The patient was discharged after two weeks of hospitalization with a substantial improvement in his condition. Regular INR monitoring was advised.  Patient Perspective: The patient was grateful for the diagnosis and treatment. He expressed concerns about the recurrence of DVT and agreed to continue with the recommended therapies and follow-up consultations.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of prompt recognition of deep vein thrombosis symptoms  especially in patients with pre-existing stroke history who have discontinued antiplatelet therapy. Regular follow-ups and compliance to treatment plan is crucial to prevent complications like recurrent DVT or pulmonary embolism. Further research is required to evaluate the risk factors and preventive management strategies of DVT in stroke patients.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for this case report.

Title: Unilateral Edema in a Postmenopausal Female Secondary to Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Case Report  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a medical phenomenon characterized by the formation of blood clots in the deep veins  typically of the lower extremities  causing substantial morbidity and mortality. This case study aims to highlight a case of DVT in a 68-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian female with a significant medical history.  Case Presentation: A 68-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher with a history of hypertension and obesity  reported to the outpatient department with complaints of unilateral swelling  tenderness  redness  and warmth of her right lower extremity. Her past medical history was significant for oral contraceptive therapy for 30 years  a hysterectomy at age 52 due to fibroids  and a recent long automobile drive. The patient denied any recent surgeries  cancer  smoking or alcohol consumption  nor a family history of DVT. At the time of presentation  she had been taking antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications.  Pertinent negatives on her physical examination included elevated blood pressure and body mass index (BMI) of 32  and no signs of superficial venous dilatation or insufficiency. Upon further examination of the affected leg  there was unilateral swelling and pitting edema with mild skin warmth on touch  indicating impaired venous return. Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity showed thrombosis of several deep veins suggestive of DVT. Blood tests revealed poor coagulation function  elevated D-dimer levels  and normal platelet count.  Management: The patient was immediately administered low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) and initiated on oral anticoagulant dabigatran. She was also advised to elevate the affected lower extremity and prescribed compression stockings. She was admitted to the hospital for monitoring.  Outcome & Follow-up: Her symptoms gradually improved over the course of 2 weeks with strict blood pressure control and weight management. A repeat Doppler ultrasound performed after 3 months showed a normal flow in the previously obstructed deep veins of the right lower extremity. Anticoagulation therapy was continued for six months to prevent recurrent thromboembolism.   Conclusion: This case emphasizes the risk factors of DVT in postmenopausal women with hypertension  obesity  and prolonged immobility. It underscores the importance of timely intervention  in this case with anticoagulation therapy  lifestyle modifications  and the use of compression stockings  in preventing complications associated with DVT. Future research needs to explore strategies for DVT prevention in high-risk individuals.

Title: Management of Unilateral Lower Limb Deep Vein Thrombosis in A Middle-Age Male Patient  Introduction:  An insightful case report on unilateral lower-limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in a 46-year-old African-American male with a history of tobacco smoking and sedentary lifestyle  living in urban Chicago  Illinois.  Case Presentation:  Mr. J  a 46-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with a 5-day history of progressive left lower extremity swelling and pain. His pain was of sudden onset  localized to his left leg calf region  dull in nature  8/10 in severity  exacerbated by long periods of standing or sitting and partially relieved by elevation of the leg.  Past medical history indicated controlled type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic bronchitis from persistent cigar smoking (15 years duration  around 20 cigars daily). He had no history of prior DVT  malignancy  recent immobilization  or trauma. His mother had a past medical history of DVT at an old age. Mr. J is employed as an office manager  which involves long periods of sitting. He lives in an urban setting in Chicago  Illinois. He reports occasional alcohol consumption but denies any illicit drug use.  On General Physical Examination  he was afebrile  with a pulse rate of 80 bpm  blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 18/min. He had non-pitting edema  erythema  tenderness  and increased warmth over his left lower limb. Rest of the physical examination was within normal limits.   Investigations:  Complete blood count indicated slightly elevated platelets (4 50 000/mm³). Fasting blood sugar level and Lipid profile were within controlled limits. A D-dimer test was significantly elevated. Doppler ultrasound of the left lower limb revealed thrombosis in the left popliteal vein extending up to the trifurcation. Proximal veins were patent  with normal compressibility elsewhere. Chest X-ray revealed chronic bronchitic changes but no signs of any malignancy. ECG was within normal limits.  Management and Follow-Up:  Management initiated with intravenous (IV) heparin with a therapeutic target of activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT). After 5 days of hospitalization and treatment  the patient was transitioned to oral anticoagulants (Warfarin). Additional lifestyle advice was given to discontinue smoking  perform regular leg mobilization exercises  lose weight  and to adopt a healthier diet.  Mr. J was advised regular follow-ups  and during 3 months of post-discharge  the patient reported improvement in his symptoms. A repeat Doppler study showed recanalization of the previously occluded segment.   Conclusion:  This case not only underscores the influence of a sedentary lifestyle and chronic smoking habits in developing DVT but also highlights the close monitoring of the treatment progress and continuous patient education as a crucial aspect of management.  Key-Words: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Tobacco Smoking  Sedentary lifestyle  Anticoagulants.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Postmenopausal Woman with a History of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome  Introduction:  We present a case of a 52-year-old Caucasian postmenopausal woman who presented with a unilateral swollen and painful lower leg  later diagnosed as deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Patient Information and Clinical Findings:  The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian woman  a clerical worker from a semi-urban setting  1.65 m tall  weighing 78 kg  with a BMI of 28.6. The lady is a non-smoker and only drinks socially  with no recorded drug or food allergies. Her family history showed her mother had hypertension  but no known history of thromboembolic events or cancers.  She is postmenopausal for two years and maintains an active lifestyle with no prior history of long-distance travel or recent immobilization. She reports a history of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)  diagnosed in her mid-30s  and has been managing it with dietary changes and Metformin. The patient has no history of diabetes  hypertension  or any cardiovascular diseases.   The patient presented with a three-day history of progressive right calf pain  with visible swelling and warmth compared to the contralateral leg. No fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath was reported.  Diagnostic Assessment:  On physical examination  the right lower leg was indeed swollen and a Homan’s sign was positive. Initial laboratory tests including complete blood count  coagulation profile  and serum chemistry were within their normal ranges. But the D-Dimer test was positive.  Given the clinical suspicion  an ultrasound Doppler examination of the right leg was performed  revealing a thrombus in the femoral and popliteal veins  confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). No signs of pulmonary embolism were observed in the further performed computed tomography pulmonary angiogram.  Therapeutic Intervention and Follow Up:  The patient was initially administered therapeutic enoxaparin and later bridged to oral direct anticoagulant  Rivaroxaban. The edema and pain improved substantially over a week following the start of anticoagulation therapy. She was also prescribed compression stockings.  The patient was regularly monitored for symptoms of post-thrombotic syndrome and potential adverse effects from anticoagulation therapy. She was also counseled regarding the increased thrombotic risk potentially associated with PCOS and lifestyle modification was advised to help with weight management.  Conclusion:  This case report highlights the potential thrombogenic risk in postmenopausal women with the history of PCOS  which necessitates the early detection and therapeutic management of DVT. Further longitudinal and controlled studies may be beneficial to understand the long-term thromboembolic risk associated with PCOS.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Hispanic Female with a History of Oral Contraceptive Use and Extended Periods of Immobility  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) refers to formation of a blood clot in a deep vein  usually the lower limb. In a significant number of patients  it may result in serious complications such as pulmonary embolism (PE). The following case study involves a 45-year-old Hispanic female presenting with symptoms suggestive of DVT.  Case Presentation: The patient  a Hispanic woman aged 45  from urban Central Texas  with an office-job  presented with a two-week history of progressive left calf pain  swelling  and redness. She denied experiencing fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath. Her past medical history revealed no significant illness except that she was on oral contraceptives for five years. She denied smoking  alcohol  or recreational drug use. Her family history was negative for any inherited coagulopathies.  The patient's profession as an information technology analyst left her sedentary for extended periods  likely contributing to her risk profile. Additionally  two months before the onset of the clinical symptoms  she had been on a transatlantic flight and was largely immobile during the journey  further increasing her risk of DVT.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a warm  swollen  and erythematous left calf. Homan's sign was positive. Her vital signs were stable  and the remainder of the examination was noncontributory. Initial lab results were within normal limits  except for a raised D-dimer level.  Diagnosis: A high-resolution Doppler ultrasound showed evidence of a non-compressible left popliteal and proximal calf vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.   Treatment: She was admitted and initiated on low-molecular-weight heparin by subcutaneous injection  along with warfarin race-adjusted per her BMI and metabolic rate. Oral contraceptives were discontinued.  Outcome and Follow-Up: Her clinical symptoms improved significantly over the next four days. After achieving a therapeutic INR level  she was discharged on warfarin with close outpatient follow-up. Patient education was provided about signs of PE  and she was advised to maintain a more active lifestyle and alternative contraceptive methods were discussed.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of recognizing and promptly managing DVT  particularly in patients with predisposing risk factors such as oral contraceptive use  prolonged immobilization  and long-distance travel. Special considerations should be made regarding contraceptive choices in females with such risk profiles. It also underscores the need for public and patient education about maintaining an active lifestyle to prevent venous stasis and subsequent DVT.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 58-Year-Old African-American Female: A Case Report  Details:  Patient Information: A 58-year-old African-American female  married  living in the suburban environment. Previously a teacher  is now a retired individual.   Presenting Concerns: The patient presented at the clinic with complaints of swelling  redness  tenderness  and warmth in her left lower leg  particularly around the calf region.   Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  diabetes  and obesity. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is 32.3 and she has been on oral antidiabetic agents and antihypertensive medication for the last ten years. She is a nonsmoker and reports moderate alcohol consumption. She has no known drug allergies. Her mother had a history of DVT  so there is a family history of venous thromboembolism.   Clinical Findings: On examination  her left calf was found to be swollen and warm to touch. There was tenderness on palpation  with some pitting edema. Her blood pressure was elevated (144/88 mmHg) and her pulse rate and respiratory rate were within normal limits.  Diagnostic Assessment: Doppler ultrasound of the lower leg was performed and confirmed the presence of a deep vein thrombosis in the left calf. A blood test indicated a slightly raised D-dimer level. Her fasting blood glucose was also somewhat elevated  indicating poorly controlled diabetes.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was advised hospitalization  anticoagulation therapy was initiated with intravenous Unfractionated Heparin. Warfarin was started along with heparin  to be continued after discharge. Strict glycemic control was emphasized during hospitalization  and she was referred to a dietitian for weight management and diabetes diet counselling.  Outcome: The patient's symptoms improved after 5 days of anticoagulation therapy and she was discharged on oral anticoagulant (Warfarin) therapy. She was scheduled regular follow-ups  first after 15 days of discharge and then monthly.   Authors concluded that this case highlighted the strong influence of individual and ancestral medical history  obesity and poor control of diabetes  as well as lack of physical activity as potential risk factors in developing DVT in this 58-year-old female patient specifically and such demographics generally. Therefore  prevention and early detection strategies in populations with these risk factors are crucial.   Teaching Point: This case reinforces the need for adequate control of diabetes  weight management  early detection  and proper management of DVT especially in people with family history and sedentary lifestyle.   Author Declaration: The author(s) confirm that written and verbal consent has been provided by the patient to publish the details of this medical case.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Male Patient with a Sedentary Lifestyle and Obesity  Case Report:  Demographics:  The patient Mr. X is a 54-year-old Caucasian male living in an urban setting in California  USA. He is a software engineer by profession  married  with two children. He has a history of obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 31  implying a sedentary lifestyle and long  uninterrupted hours of sitting during work.  Medical History:  Mr. X's past medical history includes Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed five years prior)  Hypertension (diagnosed ten years prior)  and Hypercholesterolemia (diagnosed seven years prior). Due to these conditions  the patient has been taking Metformin 500mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10mg once daily  and Atorvastatin 20mg once daily. He has a twenty-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day but quit two years ago. He denies any alcohol or drug abuse and has no known allergies. There is no significant family history of clotting disorders.   Presenting Complaints:   Mr. X presented at the local emergency department with a two-day history of increasing left-sided calf pain and unilateral leg swelling  redness  and warmth. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  recent surgeries  prolonged periods of immobility  trauma  or travel.   Clinical Examination and Diagnosis:  Upon examination  Mr. X showed a notable difference in size between his legs with left lower limb pitting edema. He had a positive Homan’s sign. His vital signs were stable  and there was no sign of respiratory distress.   Considering his high risk due to obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and his current symptoms  a duplex ultrasound was ordered which revealed a non-compressible left popliteal vein thus confirming the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Management and Progress: Mr. X was started with 15mg rivaroxaban orally twice a day for 21 days followed by 20mg once a day. He was advised to elevate his affected leg and use compression stockings.   He responded well to the treatment with noticeable improvements in pain and swelling within the first week. A repeat ultrasound after three weeks showed resolved DVT. He was counseled on weight loss  physical activity  smoking cessation  and the importance of regular follow-ups for his chronic conditions.  Key Learning Points:  This case highlights the significance of recognizing DVT's potential risk factors  such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and chronic conditions like diabetes and hypertension. Prompt diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation therapy is crucial to avoid possible life-threatening complications of DVT such as a Pulmonary Embolism.  --------------------------------------------------------------------- *This case is a fictional representation and is intended solely for educational and informative purposes. The names  symptoms  diagnoses  treatments  and outcomes may not accurately represent actual cases of Deep Vein Thrombosis.*

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information   Gender: Male   Age: 70 years   Ethnicity: Caucasian   Marital Status: Married  Education: College degree  Occupation: Retired military personnel  Insurance: Medicare  Living Situation: Lives with spouse in a 2-story family home  Patient Presentation   Mr. X is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented with a history of acute discomfort and swelling in the lower right limb. The onset was 3 days prior to presenting at the clinic. The patient described the pain as dull while at rest  which intensified with activity.  Medical History   Mr. X is a smoker (30 pack-years)  with past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently on aspirin and a statin. He underwent a right total hip replacement surgery 8 years ago. He denied personal or family history of thrombotic events or known hypercoagulable states. There is no known drug allergy. The patient was not on any hormonal therapy or other known risk-factor inducing medications.  Clinical Findings  Physical examination revealed a warm  swollen  and erythematous right lower limb. His calf was tender to palpation. His vitals were stable with a blood pressure of 140/80 mmHg  pulse rate of 80/min  resp rate of 18/min  and O2 sat of 99% on room air. Cardiac  respiratory and abdominal examination were within normal limits.   Differential Diagnosis  Considering the clinical presentation  a differential diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  cellulitis  and ruptured Baker’s cyst was considered.  Investigations  A D-Dimer test was conducted which was found to be significantly elevated. Subsequently  a Doppler ultrasound was performed  revealing a non-compressible segment in the right popliteal vein suggestive of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Treatment  The patient was promptly started on therapeutic low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  enoxaparin. After 5 days overlap  he was successfully transitioned to a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC)  apixaban.  Outcome and Follow-Up   The patient was discharged in a stable condition on apixaban with outpatient follow-up to continue treatment for at least three months and lifestyle modification advice. He was also counseled on the need for smoking cessation. The importance of regular follow-up was stressed  in order to closely monitor his condition  and adjust his treatment as necessary.  This case underlines the importance of a high index of suspicion for DVT in patients presenting with unilateral limb pain and swelling  especially in the presence of relevant risk factors such as older age  history of surgery  and smoking history. Early detection and prompt treatment are key to preventing serious complications like pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Postmenopausal  Obese Female: Management and Review of Literature  Patient Information: Ms. L. is a 59-year-old  multiparous  postmenopausal Caucasian female presenting with complaints of acute  severe pain and swelling in her left lower extremity. She is a retired teacher  lives with her husband and is well integrated into the community. She is a non-smoker with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 34.0 kg/m2  indicating obesity.   Past Medical History: Her past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is well controlled with metformin and lifestyle improvements  and hyperlipidemia managed by statin therapy. No history of any surgical interventions was reported. The patient does not have a personal or family history of venous thromboembolism. There is no history of recent immobilization  trauma  or prolonged travel.  Clinical Findings: On examination  her left lower leg was significantly swollen  erythematous  and warm to touch compared to the right lower leg. Homans' sign was positive. Her vital signs were stable. A detailed systemic examination did not reveal any abnormalities.  Diagnostic Assessment: Doppler ultrasound of the left limb confirmed the diagnosis of acute left lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Her full blood count  liver  and renal profiles were all within normal levels. Her HbA1c level was 6.6%. Coagulation studies such as Prothrombin Time (PT)  International Normalized Ratio (INR)  and Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) were within normal range. Her Fasting Lipid Profile revealed elevated triglycerides and LDL cholesterol levels despite statin therapy.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was treated with therapeutic low-molecular-weight heparin followed by oral anticoagulation with warfarin. Compression stockings were provided to manage the edema. She received advice on weight management  blood glucose control  and lipid management. Regular follow-ups were scheduled for warfarin therapy adjustment based on INR testing.  Follow-up and Outcome: On follow-up visits  she reported much improvement in terms of pain and swelling. Her INR was well within the therapeutic range. She understood the need to maintain a healthy weight and actively participated in a weight-loss regime. Because of the patient's successful risk factor management  duplex ultrasound at the 6-month follow-up showed recanalization of the deep veins with no evidence of venous insufficiency.  Patient Perspective: The patient was initially anxious about her diagnosis but was relieved after understanding her management plan. She felt motivated to improve her lifestyle and was satisfied with the care received.  Informed Consent:  Verbal informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  The management of DVT in obese  postmenopausal women with diabetes requires a comprehensive approach involving acute phase management with anticoagulation and stocking therapy along with addressing relevant comorbidities and risk factors such as obesity  glycemic control  and lipid management. Regular follow-ups are crucial to monitor treatment efficacy. This case underlines the importance of comprehensive management in postmenopausal women presenting with DVT.

Title: Acute Presentation of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Female with a History of Oral Contraceptive Use  Case Report:  Introduction: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a serious condition characterized by the formation of blood clots within deep veins  predominantly in the lower extremities. DVT can lead to potentially life-threatening conditions such as pulmonary embolism if not properly managed. Certain factors such as age  race  sex  and oral contraceptive use have been shown to significantly influence the risk of developing DVT.  Patient Information: The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the Emergency Department with acute onset of left lower limb pain and swelling. She reports that these symptoms have worsened over the past three days  with the addition of noticeable warmth and redness over the affected limb. She denied any recent trauma  surgery  or long periods of immobility. She has no known history of malignancy  autoimmune disease  or blood disorders.  Past Medical History: The patient's medical history revealed that she's a smoker  consumes alcohol socially and has been on oral contraceptive pills for the past 9 years due to menopausal symptoms. She has no known allergies and no previous diagnosis of cardiovascular diseases. Her surgical history was unremarkable.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed edema and erythema of the left lower extremity with the presence of a positive Homans sign. Vital signs were stable and within normal ranges.   Diagnostic Assessment: The patient underwent a venous duplex ultrasound  which revealed a non-compressible left popliteal vein consistent with a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. Blood tests showed a slightly elevated D-dimer level  but other results including complete blood count  liver function tests  and coagulation profiles were within normal limits. Chest X-Ray was reported as clear.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on an anticoagulant regimen of low molecular weight heparin(LMWH)  with a plan to transition her to oral anticoagulants for long-term management. She was advised to cease her use of oral contraceptives and was referred to her gynecologist for management of her menopausal symptoms.  Follow-up: After initiation of treatment  the patient's symptoms gradually improved. A repeated duplex ultrasound at her 1-week follow up visit showed significant reduction in the clot size. She has been regularly attending her follow-up appointments and has been compliant with her treatment regimen without any noted adverse effects.  Conclusion: This case report highlights the significant impact of oral contraceptive use as a risk factor for DVT  especially among middle-aged women. It also underscores the necessity of a high index of suspicion for DVT in patients presenting with relevant clinical symptoms to ensure timely diagnosis and management.  Keywords: Deep vein thrombosis  oral contraceptives  middle-aged female  case report.

Title: Recurrent Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Caucasian Female with Hypothyroidism  Abstract:  We report the case of a 49-year-old Caucasian female who presented with recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) despite regularly taking anticoagulants.  Case presentation: The patient  a previously healthy woman  had developed a left lower extremity DVT four months ago. She is married  nonsmoker  non-alcoholic  and has two children. She had a medical history of hypothyroidism which was being managed with levothyroxine since the age of 44. Upon development of the first DVT  she was found to be Factor V Leiden heterozygote and was started on Rivaroxaban.  This time  she presented with a sudden onset of redness  warmth  and pain in her right leg. She denied any trauma  prolonged periods of immobility  recent travel  or surgeries. Physical examination revealed an erythematous  swollen  and tender right lower leg with a positive Homan's sign. A venous ultrasound was ordered immediately upon suspecting a DVT  which confirmed thrombosis in the right superficial and deep venous system. Her D-Dimer levels were also significantly elevated.  Given her recurrent DVT events despite compliance with her medication  she was evaluated for other prothrombotic conditions such as malignancy  autoimmune disorders  and other genetic thrombophilias.   Her complete blood count  liver function test  renal function test  ESR  CRP  urinalysis  and peripheral blood smear were in normal acceptable ranges with no signs of infections  inflammation  or malignancy. However  further genetic testing identified an additional Prothrombin G20210A mutation.   The patient was started on long-term therapeutic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin). Family members were advised to undergo genetic testing given these findings.   Conclusion: This case demonstrates the importance of considering genetic thrombophilias when encountering recurrent DVT especially in patients on anticoagulation therapy. In such patients going beyond routine investigations and opting for genetic testing can provide crucial insights and guide treatment strategies. Family genetic screening is equally important in such cases.  Keywords: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Recurrent DVT  Hypothyroidism  Genetic Thrombophilia  Anticoagulation Therapy

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 57-Year-Old Caucasian Male  Patient Profile: The patient is a 57-year-old Caucasian male from the Midwest region of the United States. He is married with two children and works as an accountant  leading a largely sedentary lifestyle. He's a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol intake. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 32.4  designating him as obese according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) standards. There is no family history of venous thromboembolism.  Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes and hypertension for the past ten years  which he manages through oral medication. He was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia five years ago. His regular medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies. His immunizations are up-to-date.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented with complaints of increased swelling and discomfort in his right lower leg for the past week. He describes the pain as a dull ache getting worse while walking and claims the pain diminishes with rest.  Examination: Physical examination revealed a visibly swollen right lower extremity along with tenderness on deep palpation. The leg was warm to touch and presented with a positive Homan's sign (pain in the calf upon dorsiflexion of the foot). Peripheral pulses were normal. No edema was noted in the left leg. Cardiorespiratory examination was within normal limits.  Investigations: A venous Doppler ultrasound of the right leg showed an thrombus in the posterior tibial vein  indicating deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Management & Outcomes: The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with Enoxaparin and Warfarin as per standard protective measures for DVT. His symptoms improved significantly with medical therapy and he is being regularly followed up in the outpatient department for further course and management.  Discussion: Deep vein thrombosis is commonly seen among aged individuals with a history of prolonged immobilization  surgery or malignancy. Other contributing factors include obesity  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia and diabetes - all of which were present in this case. This case underlines the need for increased vigilance and early diagnosis of DVT in patients with multiple risk factors  in order to initiate appropriate treatment and prevent potentially fatal complications  such as pulmonary embolism.  Note: This case report is in accordance with the CARE guidelines for case reports. The patient's confidentiality has been maintained by not disclosing any personal identification information. The consent for the report has been taken from the patient.

Title: Unilateral Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Male with Previous History of Stroke  Introduction:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a cardiovascular condition characterized by the formation of blood clots in one or more deep veins  majorly in the legs. It can cause leg pain or swelling  but may also occur without any symptoms.   Patient Information:  The patient is a 54-year-old African American male who resides in an urban setting in Detroit  Michigan  USA. He has a history of smoking for more than 30 years and occasional alcohol intake.  Presenting Concerns:  The patient reported to the clinic with complaints of intense pain and swelling in his left lower leg. The pain reportedly exacerbated upon standing or walking. Additionally  he complained about a warm feeling in the affected area with visible redness on his skin which had been persistent for two days before seeking medical attention. No complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  the left lower leg appeared swollen and red  accompanied by a tenderness through palpation. Measurement of the affected leg demonstrated a significant difference in size compared to the right lower leg  supporting the presence of edema.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Based on the symptoms and physical findings  a preliminary diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis was suspected. A Doppler ultrasound was performed  which confirmed the presence of a large clot in the left popliteal vein. Complete blood count (CBC) was done and showed an increased platelet count. International Normalized Ratio (INR) was also increased.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Anticoagulation therapy was immediately initiated. The patient was prescribed 15 mg of Rivaroxaban twice daily for 21 days  followed by 20 mg once daily.   Follow up:  The patient was advised to follow up 3 days after discharge for reassessment and one week later for a repeat Doppler ultrasound. He was educated about the importance of medication adherence and was advised to quit smoking and reduce alcohol intake for the prevention of recurrent DVT and other possible cardiovascular complications. He was also advised to wear compression stockings in his left leg.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed his understanding of the situation. He showed determination to follow the advised therapeutic regimen and lifestyle modifications to mitigate the risk of future incidences. He had questions about the potential for recovery and was reassured that appropriate management shall greatly reduce the risk of severe complications.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of early detection and management of DVT  especially in individuals with risk factors such as smoking  old age and history of stroke. It also underscores the significance of patient education and lifestyle modifications in disease management and prevention of complications.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Sedentary Elderly Patient: A Case Report  Introduction:  We report a case of a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presented with a 2-day history of a swollen  painful left leg and was subsequently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Case Presentation:  The patient is a retired office worker who has been sedentary for the past 15 years  living in predominantly white-bread suburbia in Pennsylvania  USA. He's been widowed for 3 years and lives alone. With a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  his medications include metformin and lisinopril. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history  though he quit about a decade ago. There's a family history of cardiovascular disease  his father experiencing a myocardial infarction at 70.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed an erythematous  warm  and swollen left lower extremity. He also complained of sharp  one-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. His vital signs were significant for a heart rate of 105 bpm and blood pressure of 148/98 mmHg. The rest of the physical exam was unremarkable.  Timeline:  The patient initially thought his leg symptoms were due to muscle strain from minimal activity conducted 3 days prior. Two days after the development of leg symptoms  the patient started experiencing chest symptoms  prompting an emergency department visit.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Blood investigations showed elevated D-dimer levels. Lower extremity ultrasonography was performed  confirming the presence of a thrombus in the left femoral vein. Given his chest symptoms  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram was conducted  revealing bilateral pulmonary embolism (PE).   Therapeutic Intervention:  He was admitted to the hospital and initiated on low-molecular-weight heparin. An inferior vena cava filter was placed due to the high risk of recurrent PE.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  His symptoms improved over the next few days with resolution of the leg swelling and chest pain. He was discharged on a direct oral anticoagulant to be taken indefinitely considering the idiopathic nature of DVT and subsequent PE. Family-based interventions were recommended to reduce sedentariness  and referrals for home care support were made.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing DVT as a potential risk in the elderly population with sedentary lifestyle  even in the absence of recent surgery  trauma or malignancy. There is also a need for awareness about PE as a possible serious complication of DVT.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 50-year-old African American Male with Hypertension   Introduction:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a serious condition that occurs when a blood clot forms in one or more of the deep veins  usually in the legs. This report documents a case of DVT in a 50-year-old African American male.  Case Presentation:  A 50-year-old African American male residing in the urban precincts of New York presented with complaints of pain  swelling  and oedema in his right lower limb  particularly in his calf muscles. He is a local grocery store owner with a BMI of 32 classified as obese  leads a sedentary lifestyle  and has limited physical activity. He has a previous history of hypertension controlled by a standard dose of angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  prescribed by his primary care physician. There is no known history of other significant diseases such as diabetes or heart disease. The patient is a non-smoker but consumes alcohol occasionally.  On physical examination  he exhibited signs of deep venous dilation - characterized by local warmth  swelling  erythema  and tenderness on his right calf. There were no signs of superficial venous thrombosis.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Following the presentation  we conducted a D-dimer test  which resulted as significantly elevated. To definitively diagnose DVT  we recommended a duplex ultrasound. The results showed presence of an obstructive thrombus in the right popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.   Management and Outcome:  The patient was promptly started on therapeutic anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin and then transitioned to oral anticoagulant Warfarin for long term management. After a week  his symptoms improved significantly. He was further advised about the potential risk of post-thrombotic syndrome and possible complications  such as pulmonary embolism.  The patient was also recommended to follow a weight management program and increase physical activity to decrease the risk of future DVT episodes.  Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients with unexplained limb pain and swelling  even in the absence of traditional risk factors such as surgery  trauma  cancer or protracted immobility. Hypertension and obesity  prevalent in our patient  have been independently linked to DVT  yet are often overlooked. These risk factors warrant more research to guide effective interventions among African American populations  who are found to be disproportionately affected by hypertension.  Conclusion:  Early diagnosis and treatment of DVT can prevent fatal complications like pulmonary embolism. Obesity and hypertension may predispose individuals to the development of DVT and must always be addressed and managed during patient assessment and treatment. This case adds to the growing body of evidence linking obesity and hypertension to venous thromboembolism  especially among African American adults.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 60-year-old Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired construction worker married with two adult children. His BMI is calculated as 27.6  indicating that he is overweight and smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily. He is a moderate alcohol consumer and does not engage in regular physical activity. He lives in a suburban area and sees his primary care physician regularly.   Chief Complaint: The patient presented with complaints of swelling  pain  warmth  redness  and discomfort in his left calf which had been progressively increasing over the past few days. He also reported a sensation of heaviness in the same leg  but no fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath.  Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are controlled with medication. He had a hernia operation 4 years prior but recovered without complications. There is no known history of congenital blood-clotting disorders in him or his family. The patient’s mother had suffered from heart disease and his father had died from a stroke.  Investigations: On physical examination  his left calf appeared red  swollen  and was tender to touch  indicating potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Blood tests  including complete blood count  clotting studies and D-dimer  were recommended. Doppler ultrasonography was also conducted  which confirmed presence of a clot in the left calf  following which diagnosis of DVT was made.  Treatment: Given the patient’s diagnosis  high-dose anticoagulant therapy was initiated immediately. The patient was initially given a low molecular weight heparin  followed by direct oral anticoagulants  to prevent any clot progression or pulmonary embolism.  Discussion: The patient's elevated BMI  sedentary lifestyle  history of smoking and possible genetic predisposition made him high risk for DVT. Research shows that DVT is more common in males over 60 years of age. Given his hypertension and diabetes  regular follow-up  medication maintenance  and lifestyle modifications were emphasized. Encouragement was given to stop smoking and reduce alcohol consumption  as well as maintain a balanced diet and regular exercise routine.  Outcome and follow-up: The patient was discharged after the initial treatment and is now under home-based care with a course of anticoagulation therapy. He has regular follow-up appointments for assessing his health progress and adjusting medications as needed. His efforts towards lifestyle modification and adherence to therapeutic recommendations will be a critical determining factor in his long-term health outcome.   References:  1. Heit JA. Venous Thromboembolism: Disease Burden  Outcomes and Risk Factors. J Thromb Haemost. 2005;3(8):1611–1617. 2. Spencer FA  Lessard D  Emery C  Reed G  Goldberg RJ. Venous Thromboembolism in the Outpatient Setting. Arch Intern Med. 2007;167(14):1471–1475.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged African American Female with History of Sedentary Lifestyle and Oral Contraceptive Use: A Case Report  Patient Information: The patient is a 45-year-old African American female presenting to the emergency department (ED) with sudden leg pain and swelling.  Clinical Findings: The patient reported an abrupt onset  unilateral swelling and pain in the right calf area that worsens with standing. No recent immobilization  pregnancy  malignancies  hormone replacement therapy  or genetic predispositions. However  she has been taking oral contraceptives for the last 10 years and maintains a sedentary lifestyle with prolonged sitting due to her desk job.  Timeline: The patient confirmed the pain and swelling emerged acutely within 12 hours preceding her arrival at the hospital. Recognition of the same was delayed due to sleep and the patient failing to consider the significance of her symptoms.  Diagnostic Assessment: Doppler ultrasound revealed an absence of venous flow with signs of wall thickening and intraluminal echo suggest deep vein thrombosis. Routine laboratory testing ruled out infection and other secondary causes of deep vein thrombosis. Screening for thrombophilia was normal.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was administered a low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) injection for anticoagulation and pain management was initiated with acetaminophen. After confirming the absence of contraindications  her oral contraceptive was discontinued  and alternative contraceptive education was provided.  Follow-up and Outcomes: An outpatient treatment approach was adopted  monitoring the patient for improvement of symptoms and potential thrombus resolution. The patient was also advised to incorporate lifestyle modifications such as frequent leg movement and exercise  weight management and the reduction of prolonged sedentary periods.  Patient Perspective: Initially surprised and frightened by her diagnosis  the patient responded well to her treatment  was accepting of the need for lifestyle changes and expressed relief that her condition was manageable.  Discussion: This case highlights the importance of identifying deep vein thrombosis in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain  even in the absence of obvious risk factors. Oral contraceptive use combined with a sedentary work environment proved to be a significant risk factor in this patient  emphasizing the need for comprehensive patient histories and the importance of lifestyle modification discussion. Healthcare providers should maintain a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis in patients with similar presentations and backgrounds to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Overweight Male Subject  Patient Presentation  Mr. James  a 44-year-old African American male with a BMI of 32.5  presented to the emergency department complaining of a three-day history of severe  unilateral swelling and pain in his left lower limb. The patient rated his pain at an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10. He denied any recent trauma  surgeries  or history of similar episodes in the past. The patient is a smoker and occasionally indulges in alcohol. He leads an essentially sedentary lifestyle and works a desk job.   Past Medical History   His past medical history was significant for hypertension  well controlled with Lisinopril (10mg daily)  and hypercholesterolemia  for which he is on Atorvastatin (20mg every day). He has a family history of cardiovascular events with father experiencing a myocardial infarction in his late fifties and mother having a stroke at an age of 68 years. Patient has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings  On examination  the left lower limb was significantly swollen and warm to touch compared to the right. The skin was erythematous over the calf muscle. Patient experienced pain on dorsiflexion of the foot (a positive Homan’s sign). No varicosities were noted  and pulses were palpable bilaterally. Abdominal  cardiovascular  and respiratory examinations were unremarkable.  Investigations  A Doppler ultrasound of the affected limb revealed a non-compressible femoral vein  hence supporting the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient subsequently underwent a D-dimer test  which confirmed high levels  therefore  supporting the diagnostic hypothesis.   Management  The patient was administered a weight-based dose of Low-Molecular-Weight-Heparin subcutaneously and was started on oral anticoagulation with Warfarin. Patient was counseled about the importance of elevation of the limb  wearing compression stockings  remaining mobile  and the serious potential risks of untreated DVT  including the development of post-thrombotic syndrome and potentially life-threatening pulmonary embolism.  In order to address certain contributing lifestyle factors  the patient was also advised to cease smoking  limit alcohol consumption  maintain a healthy diet  and integrate more mobility and physical activity into his daily routine. Regular follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor INR and adjust the warfarin dosage.  Conclusion  This case underlines the need for high clinical suspicion of DVT in patients who present with unilateral lower limb pain and swelling  especially in those with risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  and smoking.   Early recognition  prompt diagnosis  and immediate management along with lifestyle modifications can improve patients' prognosis and can prevent life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolism and significantly reduce recurrent events.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Postoperative Octogenarian Female  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) frequently appears in the postoperative period due to prolonged immobility  blood vessel injury  or hypercoagulable state  known collectively as Virchow's triad. The case discussed below delineates the clinical course of DVT in an octogenarian female following elective knee replacement surgery.  Case Presentation: Mrs. X  an 82-year-old Caucasian female  a resident of Indianapolis  Indiana  presented with a three-day history of increasing left leg swelling and discomfort. She had undergone elective total knee replacement surgery two weeks prior. The patient had a past medical history significant for hypertension  osteoarthritis  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She never smoked but admitted to having one or two glasses of wine a week  and her family history was significant for cardiovascular disease.   On examination  her left lower leg was swollen  warm  and erythematous with tenderness in the calf muscle. Vital signs upon presentation were blood pressure 142/84mmHg  heart rate 88 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Laboratory assessment revealed a D-dimer level of 0.7 µg/mL (normal: >0.5 µg/mL).   Ultrasound imaging of the left lower extremity revealed thrombus in the femoral and popliteal veins  confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Risk factors in her case included advanced age  recent major surgery  and potential hypercoagulability as evidenced by elevated D-dimer levels.  Given her risk of bleeding due to age and recent surgery  she was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  and following no adverse bleeding events  transitioned to oral anticoagulation - direct Factor Xa inhibitors. The Risk of bleeding was continually assessed using the HAS-BLED (Hypertension  Abnormal Renal/Liver Function  Stroke  Bleeding History  Labile INR  Elderly  Drugs/Alcohol) score.  Discussion: This case illustrates the development of DVT in an elderly female with multiple risk factors including recent knee surgery  age  and a potential hypercoagulable state. The case also underlines the importance of an integrated risk-based approach to diagnose DVT  weighing the risk of bleeding against the necessity of anticoagulation.  Conclusion: Patients in the postoperative state  especially the elderly  are at an increased risk of developing DVT. An integrated risk-based approach is useful for identifying DVT in a high-risk population  and early diagnosis is vital so that anticoagulant therapy can be started as early as possible. Anticoagulation needs to be carefully monitored to prevent any adverse bleeding events  particularly in the elderly population.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female with a History of Oral Contraceptive Use  Patient Information: A 45-year-old Asian female was admitted to the emergency department with severe pain and swelling in her left lower leg for one day. Her height and weight measurements were 1.57m (5 feet 2 inches) and 70 kg (154 pounds)  indicating a BMI of 28.4  suggesting overweight status. She lives in an urban suburb  holds a sedentary desk job  and has a history of oral contraceptive use for the last ten years for family planning.  Clinical Presentation: The patient complained of increased warmth over the left lower leg calf area  with mild discoloration and tenderness. She also reported being in distress due to immobility caused by pain and swelling. She hadn't suffered any recent trauma  surgery  nor long journey travel.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history indicated no known major illnesses or familial genetic disorders or allergies. She was a non-smoker  consumed alcohol occasionally  and had not experienced a similar episode in the past.   Diagnosis: Physical examination indicated a swollen  erythematous left lower leg with palpable veins. Due to the patient's presentation and medical history  the presumptive diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was considered. A Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities confirmed the presence of a non-compressible venous segment in her left lower leg  confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Lab results showed an elevated D-dimer level.  Treatment/Management: The patient was immediately started on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) for initial anticoagulation  to be transitioned to oral anticoagulants as an outpatient.   Prognosis: The patient was advised GPS visits for follow-up and monitoring. She was counseled to stop the use of oral contraceptives and was educated about an alternative birth control method. Along with this  advice on weight loss  regular exercise  hydration  and avoiding prolonged immobility was imparted.  Concluding Summary: This case underscores the risk of Deep Vein Thrombosis associated with oral contraceptive use  especially in the middle-aged group who are overweight. It emphasizes the need for vigilance among clinicians  awareness among patients  and considering alternative contraception methods in individuals falling under high-risk categories.   Consent: An informed written consent was taken from the patient before documenting the case report. Patient's anonymity was guaranteed as part of ethical obligation.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Male: A Case Report  Patient Profile:   The patient is a Caucasian male  aged 62 years old  of an average body mass index (BMI) who presented within the outpatient department. His profession includes long hours of continuous desk work with minimal physical activity involved. He is a former smoker  having quit 5 years back  and drinks alcohol moderately. His family history includes thromboembolic diseases  with his father suffering from pulmonary embolism in his 60s.  Past Medical History:   The patient was previously diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 8 years ago  and has been on medication for them including Metformin  and Amlodipine. He had been maintaining a normal blood glucose level and BP range in his recent checkups. The patient also had a history of a minor stroke 2 years back and was prescribed daily low dose aspirin as secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease.  Presenting Concerns:   The patient presented with a 3-day history of progressive left leg pain and swelling. He did not report any history of recent long-distance travel  surgery  or trauma. He also denied experiencing chest pain  breathing complications  or any haemoptysis.  Physical Examination:   On examination  his left calf was found to be swollen  tender  and erythematous. There was a positive Homans' Sign indicating a possible DVT. The rest of his physical examination was largely unremarkable.  Investigations:   The patient underwent a D-dimer test which turned out to be positive. A Doppler Ultrasound was also performed on his left leg which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the popliteal vein. Subsequently  he was evaluated for Pulmonary Embolism (PE) using CT angiography  which was negative.  Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's symptoms  physical examination  blood tests  and ultrasound findings  he was diagnosed with DVT in the left lower limb.  Management and Follow up:  Immediate management included admission for monitoring  and the administration of anticoagulation therapy with Heparin. Subsequently  he was transitioned to oral anticoagulant medication  Warfarin. He was educated about the importance of alternated leg movements and moderate physical exercise while at work to prevent future occurrences. A referral was made for physiotherapy and scheduled for outpatient follow-ups for therapeutic monitoring of Warfarin therapy.   Summary:  This case illustrates the importance of considering DVT in patients with unexplained pain and swelling in the legs  especially those with risk factors like prolonged sedentary work  hypertension  and family history of thromboembolic events. Early diagnosis and management are essential to prevent dire consequences  such as PE.  Note: All procedures followed were in accordance with the ethical standards of the responsible committee on human experimentation and with the Helsinki Declaration of 1975  as revised in 2000. Consent was obtained from the patient for being included in this study.

Title: Case Report of a 65-year-old Caucasian Male with Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction  This report describes a case of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a 65-year-old Caucasian male. DVT occurs when a blood clot (thrombus) forms in one or more deep veins  typically in the lower limbs. This condition can potentially lead to serious complications  leg pain  swelling  and can be life-threatening if a blood clot breaks off and travels through the bloodstream to the lungs (pulmonary embolism).  Case Presentation  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired accountant  presented to the emergency department with severe left calf pain  which he rated as 7 on a scale of 1-10  and noticeable swelling of the left leg. The patient noted that the pain commenced gradually over a few days and had exacerbated over the past day. He reported no recent travel  surgery  or immobility. He denied any history of chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or hemoptysis.  Medical History  The patient's past medical history was significant for Type II Diabetes Mellitus – managed with Metformin  Hypertension – controlled with Lisinopril  and Dyslipidemia – treated with Atorvastatin. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father experiencing myocardial infarction in his late 70's. The patient is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. He has no known allergies.  Investigation and Findings  Upon physical examination  the left leg was warmer and noticeably swollen compared to the right. The Homan's sign was positive. No ulcers or skin changes were noticed. No palpable cords were observed.  Laboratory findings showed a slightly increased D-dimer at 0.6 μg/mL FEU (normal range is <0.5 μg/mL). Other laboratory findings  including Complete Blood Count  Comprehensive Metabolic Panel  and coagulation profile  were within normal limits.  An ultrasound Doppler scan of his left leg revealed a non-compressible popliteal vein suggestive of DVT. There was echogenic material within the lumen indicating thrombosis.   Management and Outcome  The patient was admitted and initiated on Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) Enoxaparin and oral Anticoagulant Rivaroxaban.  After 7 days on therapy  repeat Doppler ultrasound indicated a decrease in thrombus size and relief of symptoms. He was discharged on Rivaroxaban and advised to take it for at least three months. Anticoagulant therapy will reduce the chances of developing recurrent DVT and complications such as pulmonary embolism.   He was educated about the signs of complication  including sudden onset of chest pain and/or shortness of breath  as well as the need to avoid prolonged immobility. A follow-up appointment to monitor his progress was scheduled.  Conclusion  This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing the potential risks and symptoms related to DVT  particularly in patients with comorbid conditions like Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. Encouraging timely medical attention can significantly decrease the rate of complications and enhance the quality of life.
