Patient Initial: MJ Age: 68 years Gender: Female Ethnicity: White Country: United States  Presenting Concerns: Patient MJ presented with a 5-day history of progressive swelling and mild pain in her right lower leg. The patient reported no injury or trauma to the area. The patient is not an athlete and her occupation doesn't require prolonged immobility. Her pain and swelling were not associated with redness  fever or any systemic symptoms.   Medical History: MJ is a postmenopausal woman with a history of hormonal replacement therapy 5 years back. She is also hypertensive and obese with BMI of 30. She has been on medication for hypertension for the last 10 years. There is no known family history of thromboembolic disease. She is non-diabetic and she does not smoke or consume alcohol. The patient underwent hip replacement surgery a year ago.  Examination and Findings: On examination  MJ's blood pressure was found to be 140/90 mm Hg. No significant findings on chest and heart examination. Lower extremity examination revealed unilateral non-pitting edema and slight warmth in the calf of her right leg. No visible skin discoloration or venous varicosities were noted.  Diagnostic Assessment: Doppler Ultrasound of the right lower extremity revealed a non-compressible segment suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower calf vein (Distal DVT). Laboratory investigations including complete blood count  liver function tests  kidney function tests were within normal threshold  but D-dimer values were elevated.   Treatment and Follow-Up: MJ was started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin. Later  she was switched to oral anticoagulants. She was advised to wear compression stockings and to elevate her leg when possible to help reduce swelling and pain. She was also informed to keep mobile when possible to improve her blood circulation.   On follow-up after 1 month and 3 months  she reported much improved symptoms and was advised to continue her treatment as per the initial plan. A repeat ultrasound examination revealed the resolution of the thrombus. The anticoagulants were planned to be continued for a total of 6 months.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering DVT in post-menopausal patients  with history of hormonal replacement therapy or major surgery  even in the absence of familial thrombotic history. The patient responded well to the anticoagulant therapy and lifestyle changes  contributing to a positive prognosis. Regular follow-ups and repeated imaging helped ensure the timely resolution of the thrombus.

Case Report: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 67-Year-Old Caucasian Female  Abstract:  We report a rare case of an elderly Caucasian woman who presented with acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She suffers from a history of hypertension and has long periods of immobilization due to her job as a receptionist. The mainstay therapy of anticoagulant medications was initiated to treat her condition.  Case Presentation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressive pain and swelling in her right lower extremity. The patient also reported a sense of heaviness in the affected leg. She is a non-smoker  non-alcoholic  and has a medical history of hypertension for the past ten years. She lives alone and is currently working as a receptionist where she spends many hours a day sitting  contributing to her sedentary lifestyle. The patient denied any history of surgery  trauma  malignancy  or genetic coagulation disorders. There is no known family history of DVT or pulmonary embolism.   On examination  her right calf was tender  edematous  and warm to touch compared to the left. The circumference of the right calf was also noticeably larger than the left one. Her vital signs were stable  with a blood pressure of 142/85 mmHg and a pulse rate of 85 beats per minute.   Investigations:  Laboratory tests revealed D-Dimer levels significantly raised to 1300 ng/ml (normal <500 ng/ml). Her renal function test  liver function test  and complete blood counts were within normal limits. Ultrasound Doppler of the right lower limb revealed thrombosis in the femoral and popliteal veins consistent with acute deep vein thrombosis.   Treatment/Outcome:  The patient was immediately started on a therapeutic dose of low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) and was hospitalized for close monitoring. Subsequent oral anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin) was initiated with an INR target of 2.5 (range 2.0 to 3.0). On follow-up after 3 months  the patient reported a significant reduction in the symptoms  and an ultrasound confirmed the resolution of the thrombus.   Discussion:  The presented case reiterates that advanced age  hypertension  and prolonged immobilization constitute significant risk factors for developing deep vein thrombosis. It underscores the importance of early recognition and management of this potentially life-threatening condition. Early initiation of anticoagulant therapy plays a pivotal role in preventing fatal complications including pulmonary embolism.  Conclusion:  This case report serves as a reminder to clinicians of the risk factors associated with DVT and the importance of early diagnosis and prompt treatment. Healthcare practitioners should encourage elderly and sedentary individuals to incorporate routine physical activity into their lifestyle to reduce their risk of DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 62-year-old Caucasian Male  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a serious medical condition characterized by the formation of a thrombus or blood clot in the deep veins  typically in the legs. The pathophysiology of DVT is based on Virchow’s triad of venous stasis  hypercoagulability  and vessel wall injury.  Patient Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presently residing in Florida  USA. He is a retired construction laborer  living independently. He is a former smoker  with a 40 pack-year smoking history but had quit two years ago. His lifestyle was moderately active till recently.  Past Medical History: The patient presents with a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He was diagnosed 15 years ago and has been on Metformin (500mg twice daily) and Losartan (50mg every morning). He also has a family history of early cardiac disease; his father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 64. He had an open hernia repair ten years ago. There is no history of cancer  Hashimoto's disease  or autoimmune illnesses.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency room with a three-day history of increasing left calf pain  redness  swelling  and warmth. There was no history of trauma or recent prolonged immobility. He also denied any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis.   He denied experiencing any loss of consciousness  headache or recent sick contacts. His BMI on examination was 30 kg/m2  and his blood pressure was elevated at 170/90 mmHg  but was otherwise clinically stable.  Diagnostic Assessment: Diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was made based on clinical signs and symptoms  confirmed through Duplex ultrasonography  which revealed an incompressible segment in the left popliteal vein. D-dimer levels were also elevated at 700 ng/mL (normal up to 500 ng/mL).  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was admitted to the medical ward. He was started on subcutaneous Enoxaparin (a low molecular weight heparin) along with his usual medication  and hypertension was managed with increased Losartan dosage. Compression stockings were prescribed  and he was advised to elevate the affected limb to help reduce swelling.  Follow-up and Outcomes: On a follow-up consultation after two weeks  the patient has reported relief from pain. Swelling and redness of left calf had significantly reduced. He is continued on his oral anticoagulant Rivaroxaban. Hyperglycemia and Hypertension is managed with medication.  Key Learning Points: This case emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in the differential diagnosis  especially in patients presenting with calf pain  swelling  and changes in skin color. Risk factors in this case include advanced age  history of hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and a sedentary lifestyle due to retirement.

Title: A Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Female Patient   Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a significant healthcare issue worldwide. It pertains to the formation of blood clots  typically in deep veins found in lower limbs. If inadequately addressed  the disease can become life-threatening due to complications like pulmonary embolism (PE). Despite the high prevalence of this disease  it often remains under-diagnosed. This report presents a case of DVT in a 68-year-old post-menopausal Caucasian female.  Case Presentation: The patient  a retired social worker  came with complaints of excessive swelling and sustained pain in her left calf for a week. She had a history of varicose veins and had been inactive due to recent hip surgery. Additionally  she had obesity (BMI 33)  non-insulin-dependent diabetes  and managed her hypertension with medication. She had quit smoking 10 years ago and consumed alcohol moderately. There was no familial history of blood clot disorders.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed warmth and reddish discoloration in the affected leg  indicative of superficial thrombophlebitis. But the patient's pain intensity and progression  along with her medical conditions  raised suspicions of DVT. The patient also had mild shortness of breath but no chest pain or other symptoms of PE.   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Laboratory examination showed elevated D-dimer levels. Doppler Ultrasound confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left posterior tibial vein  validating the diagnosis of DVT. The patient's Wells score was 3 points  indicating moderate risk.  Therapeutic Focus and Results: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Upon stabilization  she was switched to oral Rivaroxaban for at least three months. Her symptoms improved significantly over the course of a week  and follow-ups were planned to check for comorbidities and bleeding complications. The patient was also advised on lifestyle modifications  including weight loss  activity enhancement along with the use of graduated compression stockings.  Conclusion: This report shines a light on a woman at moderate risk of DVT due to several individual risk factors including obesity  surgery  and varicose veins. Physicians should maintain a high index of suspicion in such cases  with prompt and suitable management hugely impacting patient outcomes. Despite the ubiquitous use of risk assessment tools like the Wells score  diagnosis of DVT based solely on clinical suspicion can significantly prevent morbidity and mortality.   Keywords: Deep Vein Thrombosis; post-menopausal; Doppler Ultrasound; low molecular weight heparin; Rivaroxaban.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Female with No Previous Medical History  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a condition that involves the formation of a blood clot in the deep veins  typically in the legs. This case report will focus on a patient who was diagnosed with DVT despite having no significant past medical history pointing to a risk of DVT.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 55-year-old Hispanic female who presented to the emergency room with complaints of sudden-onset acute pain and swelling in her left lower extremity. The patient disclosed that there’s no history of injury  recent travel  bed rest  surgery  or immobilization in the past month. She denied any history of smoking or alcoholism. The patient had a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30.1 kg/m2  suggesting obesity. Her family history was significant for heart disease in her father.   The patient was afebrile and vital signs were within normal limits. On examination  the left lower extremity was markedly swollen  warm to touch  and tender  suggesting inflammation and edema. No signs of superficial venous inflammation were seen. The rest of her physical exam  including her cardiovascular and respiratory examination  was unremarkable.  Investigations: A venous Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity was performed  which identified a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.  Over the course of the hospital stay  she underwent a series of laboratory investigations  including D-Dimer  complete blood count (CBC)  coagulation profile  lipid profile  and a thrombophilia screen  including tests for Factor V Leiden and Prothrombin gene mutation. The results only highlighted a high D-Dimer value and a slightly elevated LDL cholesterol level. Genetic testing did not point to any hereditary thrombophilia.  Management and Outcome: The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with rivaroxaban  and analgesia was provided for pain relief. Swelling and pain in the left leg gradually subsided over a week. She was counseled about the lifestyle modifications necessary in obesity and discharged with the advice to follow up in an outpatient department. On subsequent follow-up visits  the patient adhered to medication  and there was no extension or recurrence of DVT.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes that DVT can occur even in patients with no previous medical history suggestive of a risk for DVT. It also highlights the importance of considering DVT as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with acute onset lower limb swelling and pain and the role of obesity as a risk factor.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Female With Past Medical History of Obesity and Prolonged Immobility: A Case Report  Introduction:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a serious condition characterized by the formation of a blood clot in the deep veins  predominantly in the lower limbs. Risk factors for the development of DVT include prolonged immobility  surgery  obesity  history of venous thromboembolism  among others. We present an interesting case of DVT in a 56-year-old woman with a history of obesity and prolonged bedrest.  Case Description:  Patient Information: The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian woman residing in Midwest USA  who works as an office-manager  a mostly sedentary occupation. No known allergies were reported. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Clinical Findings: She presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of painful swelling in her left lower limb. Physical examination revealed a swollen  erythematous left calf  which was warm to touch and tender on deep palpation. There were no signs of superficial vein inflammation.   Diagnostic Assessment: A spectrum of tests were performed  including complete blood count  coagulation profile  and D-dimer test  which came back elevated  raising suspicion for DVT. Confirmatory diagnosis was established with a lower extremity Doppler ultrasound  which showed a non-compressible left popliteal vein.  Therapeutic Intervention: Anticoagulant therapy with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) was promptly introduced. After initial treatment  oral anticoagulation with Warfarin was started alongside LMWH  and the latter was discontinued once a stable international normalized ratio (INR) of 2-3 was achieved.  Follow-Up: The patient was advised to lose weight  encouraged to mobilize  and increase physical activity. Elastic compression stockings were recommended for leg edema. Follow-ups at the anticoagulation clinic are ongoing for INR monitoring and warfarin dose adjustment.  Past Medical History: Notably  the patient has a past medical history of obesity with a body mass index of 35 kg/m2 and had been immobile for several weeks due to a fractured ankle. She has no known history of thrombophilic disorders or previous venous thromboembolism.   Discussion:  This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing DVT as a possible diagnosis in patients with calf pain and swelling  particularly in the presence of risk factors like obesity and prolonged immobility as seen in our patient. Prompt diagnosis using a combination of D-dimer testing and Doppler imaging  followed by immediate initiation of anticoagulation therapy  is crucial to prevent fatal complications.  The patient’s occupation as an office manager  which involves prolonged sitting periods  also might have contributed to her risk of developing DVT. Highlighting the need for preventive strategies like regular movement and lifestyle modifications in a similar at-risk population.  Conclusion:  The case serves as a reminder for physicians to consider deep vein thrombosis in differential diagnosis in patients with unremitting leg pain and swelling  especially when they have significant predisposing risk factors. Early detection and initiation of appropriate treatment are vital in reducing the morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Presenting a case of a 52-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) but with no significant medical history. The purpose of this report is to highlight the importance of prompt diagnosis and management even in individuals with low risk factors.  Patient Information: Mr. X  a 52-year-old Caucasian male  presented with a three-day history of increasing right calf pain and leg swelling. He denied any recent periods of immobility  surgery  or trauma. He does not smoke or consume alcohol.   Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient's right calf was noticeably swollen in comparison to the left. He had a positive Homan's sign and the area was tender to touch. His vital signs were stable: blood pressure 135/80 mmHg  heart rate 78 beats/min  respiratory rate 18 breaths/min  temperature 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air.   His body mass index was 27.1 kg/m2  rendering him slightly overweight. His breathing was regular with no abnormal sounds  heart sounds were dual and rhythmic  and abdomen was soft with no organomegaly.   Diagnostic Assessment: The patient underwent a D-dimer test which came back significantly high at 700 ng/mL (normal range: 0-500 ng/mL)  prompting a suspicion of DVT. This diagnosis was definitively confirmed by a Duplex ultrasonography that demonstrated a non-compressible femoral and popliteal vein in the right leg  indicating a significant clot.   Standard coagulation test results were all within normal range and thrombophilia screen was negative. A basic metabolic panel and lipid profile were recorded showing slight deviation in LDL and HDL ratios.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  Enoxaparin 1mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 hours along with a Rivaroxaban 15mg orally twice daily. His symptoms started to alleviate after three days of therapy.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Two weeks later  the patient reported a significant reduction in swelling and pain. Subsequent ultrasound showed a reduced clot burden  indicating positive response to treatment. After one month  the patient was switched to Rivaroxaban monotherapy  20mg orally once daily for long term therapy.  Conclusions: This case emphasizes that DVT should be considered in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling  even in those without traditional risk factors. Early diagnosis and prompt initiation of anticoagulation therapy are crucial in preventing further complications including pulmonary embolism. Patients presenting with similar symptoms should be thoroughly investigated for DVT to improve the outcome of this potentially lethal condition.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Elderly Caucasian Male  Patient Profile  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who resides in a suburban community in Connecticut  USA. He is a retired car mechanic  married  with 3 adult children and 5 grandchildren. He has never used tobacco products  drinks alcohol socially  and is generally active  often enjoying gardening  woodworking  and fishing. He has a weight of 195 pounds  with a height of 5'10"".  Medical History  He has a documented medical history of hypertension controlled by medication (Benazepril 20mg daily)  and hyperlipidemia managed with diet and statins (Atorvastatin 40mg daily). He also has osteoarthritis for which he takes NSAIDs but avoids opioids. He has had one instance of a TIA (transient ischemic attack) about 4 years ago from which he recovered without any aftermath of neurological deficit. His family history includes a paternal history of myocardial infarction and a maternal history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stroke.  Presenting Complaint  The patient presented to the emergency room complaining of a painful  warm  swollen left leg  which has caused him difficulty walking for the past two days. He denies any history of trauma or injury to the leg. Of note  he reports returning from a fishing trip in Alaska two days ago  during which he had prolonged periods of immobility during the flight that lasted about 7 hours.  Clinical Findings  Physical examination revealed a swollen left calf and foot with erythema over the posterior calf. His left calf was tender on deep palpation. His body temperature  blood pressure and heart rate were all within normal ranges. Pitting edema was present in the left leg with a positive Homans' sign.  Laboratory tests results showed elevated D-dimer. Duplex ultrasonography of the patient's left leg demonstrated a thrombus in the posterior tibial vein.  Diagnosis  Based on the clinical picture  laboratory findings  and imaging results  the patient was diagnosed with acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the left lower extremity.  Discussion  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a common but under-diagnosed medical condition that can cause significant morbidity and mortality. This patient's extended period of immobility during his fishing trip coupled with his genetic predisposition (mother's history) may have contributed to the formation of DVT.  As per the American Society of Hematology  he was managed with low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) followed by oral anticoagulation. He was also educated about the importance of regular movement and exercises especially during long travels.  In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of understanding risk factors for DVT and how early diagnosis and immediate treatment can prevent subsequent complications like pulmonary embolisms. It also emphasizes on the significance of patient education in prevention of this disease.  Keywords: DVT  risk factors  anticoagulation  thrombus  prolonged immobility.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Sedentary Adult Male: A Case Report  INTRODUCTION:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by a blood clot that forms in the deep veins  most commonly in the lower leg  thigh  or pelvis. This case report highlights a detailed examination of a 54-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with DVT.  PATIENT INFORMATION:  The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian male with a BMI of 28  working in a sedentary job and living in Northern Texas. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history  having quit 5 years ago. He is married with two children. His family history reveals that his father had a stroke at the age of 67  his mother has hypertension  and a paternal uncle had an unproven venous thromboembolism (VTE).  CLINICAL FINDINGS:  The patient complained of a sudden onset of left leg pain and swelling with slight redness. He also reported increased warmth over the affected area over the last three days. The patient did not mention any chest pain  shortness of breath  or episodes of fainting. He suffered noticeable limping but managed to perform daily routine work with considerable discomfort.  DIAGNOSTIC ASSESSMENT:  On physical examination  there was a visible swelling on the left leg compared to the right. Homan's sign was negative. Blood tests indicated a slightly elevated D-dimer level. Doppler ultrasound confirmed a clot in the left femoral vein  thus confirmed Deep Vein Thrombosis. No diagnostic tools identified potential pulmonary embolism (PE).  THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTION:  He was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  followed by warfarin for long-term anticoagulation. He was also advised to wear compression stockings during the day and encouraged to walk as much as possible without causing pain.  FOLLOW-UP AND OUTCOMES:  On follow-up visits  the patient showed signs of improvement. The swelling was considerably reduced; pain was reported as more manageable. The INR value was in the therapeutic range at the subsequent visit  indicating warfarin was effectively thinning his blood. He was advised to continue with the anticoagulation therapy and periodic check-ups.  CONCLUSION:  Sedentary lifestyle and family history were significant risk factors for DVT in this patient's case. Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial in managing DVT cases successfully. Besides medical treatment  educating patients about lifestyle changes and the importance of regular exercise may help prevent the recurrence of DVT.    Learning Point: Among adults  especially those with a sedentary lifestyle  the possibility of DVT should be considered when they present with unilateral leg swelling and pain. Early investigation  diagnosis  and management are crucial to prevent possible severe complications like pulmonary embolism.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Obese Male Patient with a Sedentary Lifestyle  Patient Information: The patient is an African-American male  aged 54  hailing from an urban area in the Midwestern part of the United States. He is a non-smoker. He is married and has two children. The patient is employed as an office worker and leads a sedentary lifestyle. His medical record suggests he is obese (BMI 32) and has a history of hypertension.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of acute severe pain and swelling in his left calf  which started a day ago.  History of Present Illness: The patient started experiencing a dull ache in his left calf about two weeks ago  which later developed into severe pain and perceptible swelling a day ago. The patient denied any recent traumatic injury but admitted to prolonged periods of immobility due to his office job.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  for which he has been receiving treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors for a period of 5 years. There is no history of any other known medical or surgical diseases. He takes no other medications. His family history is unremarkable.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient had a raised temperature (37.8 degrees Celsius)  with an elevated heart rate of 102 bpm but a normal respiratory rate. His BP was moderately high at 156/96 mm Hg. Physical examination revealed an edematous  erythematous left calf which was warm to touch and tender on deep palpation. There was no other remarkable finding on cardiovascular or respiratory examinations.  Diagnostic Assessment: A venous Doppler ultrasound revealed evidence of a deep vein thrombosis in the left proximal femoral and popliteal veins. The patient's D-dimer values were significantly raised  and his blood work showed a normal total blood count  except for a slightly raised platelet count. Liver and renal function tests were within normal limits.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately treated with subcutaneous low molecular weight Heparin (LMWH)  and oral anticoagulant (Warfarin) was also started. The patient is recommended for a weight loss program and moderate physical activates.  Follow Up and Outcomes: The patient responded well to anticoagulation therapy. Swelling and pain have been reduced significantly after 10 days of treatment. He will continue on anticoagulant therapy and will be frequently monitored for complications and improvement.  Patient Perspective: Although initially frightened by the severity of the symptoms  the patient expressed relief following the rapid reduction in his symptoms. He recognized the need for lifestyle changes and had expressed motivation towards improving his health.  Informed Consent: The patient provided informed consent for this case report.   Key Learnings: It is critical to consider DVT in differential diagnosis for patients presenting with calf pain and swelling  particularly in those with risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and hypertension. Early intervention with anticoagulation therapy can rapidly alleviate symptoms and reduce the risk of further complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 57-year-old Male with Previous Cardiovascular Conditions: A Case Report  Introduction: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a medical condition that arises due to blood clot formation in one of the large veins  particularly in the lower limbs. It may result in life-threatening complications like pulmonary embolism if left untreated. The risk factors include increasing age  sedentary lifestyle  certain genetic and acquired conditions  and a previous history of DVT.  Patient Information: We present the case of a 57-year-old Caucasian male  diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis burdened with previous cardiovascular conditions.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented with a 5-day history of pain and swelling in the left leg  which he described as ""cramp-like."" He denied any recent trauma or history of prolonged immobility. He had no known hereditary clotting disorders in his family  no history of malignancy  and did not smoke or consume alcohol.  Past Medical History: He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease for which he has been on amlodipine  simvastatin  and aspirin  respectively. Additionally  he had an inferior wall myocardial infarction three years ago  managed medically with no surgical intervention.  Diagnostic Assessment: A venous duplex ultrasound of the left leg showed non-compressibility of the popliteal and femoral veins consistent with deep vein thrombosis. His D-dimer level was elevated at 2.34 mg/L (normal: < 0.5 mg/L)  blood counts remained within normal range  and renal function was adequate.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on anticoagulants with low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) initially and then switched to a direct oral anticoagulant  apixaban  as per the patient's preference towards oral drug and compliance-friendly regimen.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient reported a gradual reduction of pain and swelling in his left leg over the next few days. He was counseled on the need for long-term anticoagulant therapy  signs of potential complication  and lifestyle modifications like regular physical activity within tolerance  low salt diet and maintaining a healthy weight.  Conclusion: This case of DVT in a 57-year-old male with a high cardiovascular risk profile underscores the importance of considering DVT in the differential diagnosis for unexplained leg pain/swelling  especially in individuals with cardiovascular conditions. Effective management involving an individualized  patient-preferred anticoagulation regimen can result in favourable outcomes. Further research is needed to effectively stratify DVT risks in patients with cardiovascular diseases and individualize their treatment plans.

Title: A Case Report of Unilateral Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 67-year-old Hispanic Female  Introduction This case report spotlights a prevailing health condition  DVT  in an ethnicity disproportionately affected in the United States population. Its purpose is to stimulate discussion around critical diagnostic considerations in this population.  Case Presentation The patient was a 67-year-old Hispanic female who presented to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of unilateral right leg pain and swelling  which had persisted for two days without trauma. The patient described the pain as ""severe  dull and aching"" adding that it was somewhat relieved when she elevated her leg. She rated her pain intensity as an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10. She reported no fever  chest pain  dyspnea  cough  or hemoptysis but divulged that she had been sedentary for a few weeks due to Covid-19 confinement measures.  The patient lived with her husband and two children. She was retired but had previously worked as a school teacher. She had a known history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension - both were treated with medications for over ten years. She has no known allergies. There was no known family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  pulmonary embolism (PE)  or inherited thrombophilias. The patient did not smoke and consumed alcohol moderately.  Assessment Physical examination revealed that the affected right leg was edematous extending from the calf to the ankle  warmer compared to the left leg  and slightly erythematous. Pulses were palpable bilaterally and symmetric  without noticeable temperature difference between legs. No visible superficial veins were noted.  Investigation The d-dimer test was significantly elevated. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the right femoral vein. Chest X-ray was unremarkable. Hematologic tests showed elevated hemoglobin A1C and Coagulation tests were within normal limits.  Management After diagnosis  the patient was started on Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) and switched to oral Rivaroxaban after 5 days. Concomitant use of Aspirin was ceased. The patient was educated about the importance of ambulation  leg elevation  regular monitoring  diet control for diabetes  and her newly started medication.  Outcome and Follow-up Two weeks post-discharge  a follow-up visit revealed substantial improvement in her symptoms. The patient was regularly compliant with medications and showed increased physical activity. The monitoring test revealed the prothrombin time within the normal range.  Discussion In this case  the patient's sedentary lifestyle due to pandemic restrictions  age  diabetes  and hypertension are potential risk factors for DVT. This case emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain  even in populations where DVT is less common.  Learning points - Abnormal leg swelling should trigger the suspicion of DVT in older patients with underlying risk factors. - Diversified management of the condition is crucial  encompassing pharmacotherapy  patient education  and adoption of a healthier lifestyle. - Hispanic patient populations may underreport conditions such as DVT; therefore  a high index of suspicion and detailed investigation is central.  Acknowledgment: The patient and family gave informed consent for this case to be published.

Title: A Case Report on a 65-year-old Caucasian Female with Deep Vein Thrombosis   Demographic Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian woman presently residing in a rural part of Alabama. She is a retired school teacher  a widow with four grown-up children. The patient lives on her own  though her children visit her frequently. She has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is 27.3 kg/m2  indicating overweight.  Medical History: The patient's past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are currently controlled under medical management (Lisinopril 20 mg/daily and Simvastatin 40 mg/daily respectively). She does not have a history of diabetes  lung  or heart disease. She had a remote history of left total knee arthroplasty performed five years ago.  Presenting complains: The patient presented to the emergency department with an acute onset of left calf pain and noticeable swelling  which has progressively worsened over the last 48 hours. The pain is constant  severe  and increases with ambulation. There is no history of trauma or injury. The patient has been sedentary recently due to a broken arm  which required casting four weeks prior.   Clinical Examination and Investigation: Upon examination  her left calf was tender  erythematous  and showed pitting edema. Her vital signs were stable. No palpable cords or noticeable skin changes were present.   The patient was subjected to compression ultrasonography and a D-dimer test  which confirmed the presence of a thrombus in her left popliteal vein indicative of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Her Simplified Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (sPESI) score was zero  reflecting a low risk for early mortality from Pulmonary Embolism (PE). However  the patient was further evaluated to rule out PE given her recent history of immobility.  Treatment: The patient was administered low molecular weight heparin for immediate anticoagulation. She was prescribed Rivaroxaban [a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC)]  for long-term management. She was also advised to buy graduated compression stockings.   Follow up: Follow-ups were scheduled for review and to monitor for any adverse events related to the therapy. Necessary lifestyle modifications like low-fat diet  moderate exercise  and avoidance of prolonged immobility were reinforced.   This case emphasizes the importance of a high index of suspicion for DVT in patients presenting with unilateral lower extremity swelling and recent history of immobilization  even in the absence of major risk factors. Early detection and appropriate anticoagulation are pivotal in preventing life-threatening sequelae such as PE.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Hispanic Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a cardiovascular disorder characterized by the formation of blood clots in one or more deep veins  typically in the legs. It often results from long periods of inactivity and could lead to severe conditions like pulmonary embolism if not diagnosed and treated promptly. Demographic factors such as age  gender  and ethnicity have been identified as significant risk factors for DVT.  Patient Information: A 54-year-old Hispanic female  teacher by profession  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with complaints of swelling and tenderness in her left lower leg  a month after undergoing an abdominal hysterectomy. The patient had a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. The patient reported no known allergies. She does not smoke nor drink alcohol. She is married and has two children.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed that the patient's left leg was warm  reddish  and visibly swollen in comparison to the right leg. Pain was exacerbated upon palpation or flexion of the foot. Vital signs were stable  and no discernible shortness of breath or chest pain was observed.   Diagnostic Assessment: The possibility of DVT was considered based on clinical manifestations. Patient underwent Doppler ultrasonography which revealed a non-compressible left popliteal vein consistent with a deep vein thrombus. CBC showed slight elevation in WBC count. D-dimer levels were elevated to 950ng/mL.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initiated on low molecular weight heparin therapy with close monitoring of her CBC and coagulation profile. After demonstrating therapeutic range and achieving clinical stability  she was transitioned onto oral anticoagulant therapy with Warfarin for a planned duration of three months. The patient was also fitted with compression socks and advised on physical activity to promote blood circulation.  Follow Up and Outcomes: At the one-month and three-month follow-up  the patient reported decreased pain and reduction in swelling. Repeat Doppler ultrasound at three months revealed resolution of the DVT. Blood work at monthly intervals were within normal limits  including INR under anticoagulant therapy.   Conclusion: This case illustrates that post-operative states and underlying medical conditions heighten the risk for DVT. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial. Hispanic ethnicity is presently under recognized and under researched in terms of the prevalence of DVT  thus necessitating a need for further studies. This case should be beneficial in promoting awareness about the potential for DVT in Hispanic populations.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Hispanic Female: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 57-year-old Hispanic female  residing in South Texas  presented to the out-patient department of our hospital with complaints of swelling and pain in her left lower leg. The patient was a non-smoker and occasional alcohol user. She was post-menopausal  5 feet tall  and overweight with a body mass index of 29 kg/m2. She held an office-based job  indicating a sedentary lifestyle.  Past medical history: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 diabetes five years ago  treated with Amlodipine and Metformin  respectively. The patient reportedly adhered to her medications. The patient's mother had a history of stroke at the age of 62  suggesting a familial risk. The patient had no prior history of thromboembolic diseases  pregnancies  surgeries  or prolonged immobilization.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  her left lower leg was swollen  warm  and erythrodermic with visible surface veins  while pulses were intact on palpation. Pain increased on dorsiflexion of her left foot (Homan’s sign). Her systemic vital signs were stable with blood pressure at 147/92 mmHg.  Diagnostic Assessment: Complete blood count  liver  and renal function tests were within normal limits. The D-dimer test result was 1100 ng/mL  which is significantly high. Doppler ultrasound showed a lack of compressibility in the popliteal vein and lower superficial femoral vein  demonstrating the presence of a thrombus in the left lower extremity. Further CT scan ruled out any pulmonary embolism.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Initial management included subcutaneous Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)  followed by long-term oral anticoagulation therapy with Warfarin. The patient was advised to elevate her limb  wear graded compression stockings for symptom relief  and increase mobility to improve blood circulation.   Follow-up and Outcome: There was noticeable improvement in her symptoms during a two-week follow-up visit. She was advised regular follow-ups and monitoring of international normalization ratio (INR) to adjust Warfarin dosage. Patient education emphasized maintaining a healthy weight  increasing physical activity  and controlling hypertension and diabetes to prevent DVT recurrence.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in patients with unexplained leg swelling  even in the absence of prominent risk factors. A high index of suspicion  early diagnosis  and appropriate management can significantly reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Female: A Case Report  Introduction: This report presents a case of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of cigarette smoking and obesity.  Case Description:  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman presenting from a suburban region. She is a non-disabled retiree who lives with her spouse.  Medical History: The patient has a recorded history of obesity (BMI 31.2)  hypertension  and a 15 pack-a-year history of cigarette smoking. She has been treated for hypertension with ramipril. Early menopause (at age 46) and Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) history for a period of 2 years  post-menopause  are major health factors reported. Her parent’s medical history includes coronary artery disease for father and mother’s death related to a stroke.  Present Complaint: The patient complained of persistent pain and swelling in her right calf over the last three days  without any known history of trauma  new medication  or immobilization. The swelling was associated with a mild degree of redness and warm sensation. There were no associated symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain at the time of consultation.  Clinical Findings: Physical Examination revealed a swollen  warm  erythematous  and tender right calf without any palpable cords  rash  or ulcers. Vital signs were stable along with a slightly elevated heart rate (100 bpm). There was no evidence of superficial venous varicosities.  Diagnostic Assessment: Doppler Ultrasonography confirmed the presence of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right popliteal vein. D-Dimer levels were significantly elevated. Renal  liver  and thyroid function tests were within normal ranges. Given her history  EKG and Chest X-ray were done which showed no immediate concern.  Therapeutic Intervention: Patient was managed acutely with subcutaneous Low-Molecular-Weight-Heparin (LMWH) and later transitioned to oral anticoagulation with Apixaban. Lifestyle and diet modifications were advocated.  Outcomes: The patient showed marked improvement with resolution of pain and swelling over a period of one week. She was advised to continue the oral anticoagulation therapy for 3 months and seek medical assistance if symptoms reappear or get worse.  Discussion: This case highlights the increased risk of DVT in elderly  obese women paired with history of smoking and early menopause. DVT risk remains elevated in post-menopausal women  especially those taking hormone replacement therapy. While the patient’s known history of hypertension wasn't a direct factor for DVT  it could have contributed to overall cardiovascular risk.   Patient Consent: Obtained  This single case report represents a typical scenario for deep vein thrombosis in an elderly woman  with co-morbid conditions being contributing factors. Further research into preventative measures for such high-risk individuals is advised.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 50-Year-Old Caucasian Female Patient with No Prior Cardiac Disease: A Case Report  Introduction: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a severe condition characterized by blood clot formation in the deep veins  often in the lower extremities. It may lead to serious repercussions like pulmonary embolism if left untreated. This report presents a case of a 50-year-old Caucasian female diagnosed with DVT in the absence of any prior cardiovascular diseases.  Case Presentation:   The patient  a 50-year-old Caucasian female with body mass index (BMI) of 28 kg/m² (overweight)  presented to the emergency department  reporting progressive swelling and tenderness in her left lower limb for the past three days. She complained of accompanying pain  warmth  and a mild discoloration of the affected area. The patient led a sedentary lifestyle and was a social drinker  consuming an average of two alcoholic drinks per day. She had tried over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications with no relief prior to her visit. Her medical history was significant for type 2 diabetes and borderline hypertension  managed with oral antidiabetic drugs and lifestyle modifications.  Physical examination revealed unilateral edema  erythema  and localized tenderness in the left lower limb  suspicious of DVT. There were no palpable cord signs or superficial venous patterns observed. Cardiovascular examination was unremarkable  with a normal heart rhythm.   On further investigation  the patient's D-dimer levels were significantly raised (680 ng/ML). Color Doppler ultrasonography of the left lower limb showed obstructive thrombosis in the left femoral and popliteal veins  indicative of DVT. The patient’s renal function test  liver function test  and lipid profile were within normal limits  excluding other thrombogenic factors.   Management and Follow Up:   The patient was immediately started on therapeutic heparin bridged to long-term oral anticoagulation therapy with in-house monitoring of her prothrombin time (PT) and International Normalized Ratio (INR) to adjust the dosage. She was educated about DVT  physical activity  leg elevation  and consistent use of compression stockings were advised.   On the 3-month follow-up visit  the patient reported complete resolution of her symptoms. The Doppler ultrasonography revealed partial recanalization of the involved veins with residual clot.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the necessity of considering DVT in patients presenting with unexplained lower limb pain and swelling  even in the absence of pre-existing cardiovascular diseases. Immediate diagnosis and treatment are critical in preventing complications like pulmonary embolism or post-thrombotic syndrome.

Title: A Case Report of Idiopathic Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Young Male Patient  Patient Information:   The patient is a 34-year-old Caucasian male with no significant past medical history or familial predisposition known for thromboembolic afflictions. His body mass index (BMI) falls within the normal range  at 22.3  and he leads an active lifestyle with regular exercise and a balanced diet. The patient does not smoke and has minimal alcohol intake. He is active in the professional field and spends about 6-8 hours daily in a sedentary position due to his job.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented with sudden onset of pain  swelling  and redness in his left leg  more noticeably in the calf region  for two days. He denied any recent trauma  prolonged immobility  recent surgery  medication use  or travel history which could have predisposed him to deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient was vitally stable. His left lower leg appeared visibly swollen and was warm to touch with mild tenderness on deep palpation. Homans' sign was positive  increasing the suspicion for deep vein thrombosis.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Duplex ultrasonography showed a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal vein suggestive of a thrombus  confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Coagulation screen including prothrombin time  activated partial thromboplastin time  thrombin time  and fibrinogen were within the normal range. Factor V Leiden mutation and Prothrombin gene mutation tests were negative. Tests for antiphospholipid antibodies were also negative.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on daily low molecular weight heparin and oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban. Over the course of a week  the swelling and pain in the patient's leg began to reduce significantly.  Follow Up:  The patient was advised to follow-up after two weeks for a re-assessment. On the follow-up consultation  ultrasonography showed a reduction in thrombus size. He continued the oral rivaroxaban therapy.  Discussion:  This case is presented because of its nature as idiopathic DVT in a young male  which is relatively rare and is often associated with known risk factors such as immobilization  recent surgery  trauma  malignancy  and genetic predisposition. The absence of such risk factors in the present case is intriguing. The possibility of an undiagnosed underlying malignancy or hematological disorder was considered  but investigations did not reveal any hidden conditions. This suggests that DVT may occur without recognizable predisposing risk factors in the young.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Postmenopausal Female: A Case Report  Introduction  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a vascular disorder characterized by the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) in a deep vein  predominantly in the leg veins. This condition can lead to serious complications if left untreated  potentially resulting in a pulmonary embolism (PE).  Case Presentation  Patient Information  A 65-year-old Caucasian woman was admitted to the emergency department with a 2-day history of progressive left lower leg pain and swelling. The patient lives in urban Minnesota  is a widow  retired from teaching  and lives alone. She is a nonsmoker and bisectual  and she reported no alcohol or illicit drug use.  Clinical Findings  Physical examination of the swollen leg revealed it was warm to touch and bluish-red in color. Palpation caused severe pain. She had a body mass index (BMI) of 28.2 kg/m2  heart rate 90 bpm  blood pressure 135/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and normal body temperature.  Medical history  The patient had no history of DVT or PE. She was postmenopausal and had last taken Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) 5 years ago. Her medical history also included hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia  all of which were well-controlled with medication. She additionally had a long-standing history of varicose veins.   Laboratory Findings  Blood tests revealed elevated D-dimer levels. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT scan) confirmed left leg DVT. Her hypercoagulability workup was positive. All cultures were negative excluding sepsis  and her kidney and liver functions were within normal range.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was treated with intravenous heparin for five days and oral anticoagulant (warfarin) therapy was initiated. She was kept under watch for signs of PE and provided with compression stockings for the affected leg.  Outcome and Follow-Up  Her leg swelling gradually reduced over a week  and she responded positively to the treatment. She was discharged with oral anticoagulant therapy and was advised to regularly follow-up in the outpatient clinic to monitor her INR.   Discussion  This case report emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in postmenopause female patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially with various risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  hypercholesterolemia  and varicose veins. Early diagnosis and prompt treatment can effectively reduce complications  emphasizing the importance of patient vigilance and regular follow-ups.  Conclusions  This case reinforces the fact that DVT can occur in individuals with multiple risk factors even in the absence of a history of venous thromboembolism. Healthcare providers must consider a systemic approach and detailed investigations in at-risk populations to forestall complications.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Female with a History of Mandatory Immobility: A Case Report   Introduction:  This case report details the presentation  diagnosis  management  and outcome of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in a 50-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for prolonged immobilization.  Case presentation:  A 50-year-old Caucasian female  recently immobilized due to a fractured right femur presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of right calf pain and swelling. She is a non-smoker  does not drink alcohol has  no family history of venous thromboembolism  and is socioeconomic middle-class. Her BMI recorded as 26.  The patient had undergone intramedullary nailing for her femur fracture four weeks prior. Postoperatively she was prescribed low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as DVT prophylaxis which she took for 10 days. According to patient's statement  for the last three weeks  she was mostly confined to a wheelchair with limited physical activity and did not continue any anticoagulant therapy.   Clinical findings:  Physical examinations revealed that her right lower leg was erythematous  swollen  and slightly warmer compared with the left leg. There was mild pain during palpation and dorsiflexion of her right foot (positive Homan's sign).  Diagnostic assessment:  A color Doppler ultrasound of the right leg was performed  revealing acute thrombus in the femoral and popliteal veins  indicative of DVT. Her D-dimer levels were significantly elevated at 1.2 μg/ml (normal range <0.5 μg/ml).   Therapeutic intervention:  She was initiated on intravenous unfractionated heparin and subsequent oral anticoagulation with warfarin for long-term anticoagulation therapy. Demobilization of the leg was advised except for the physiotherapy sessions.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  During follow-up appointments over the next three months  her pain and swelling gradually receded. An ultrasound scan after three months showed recanalization of the femoral and popliteal veins.  Discussion:  Distinct factors in this case include a fracture of the right femur leading to post-operative immobilization and discontinuation of anticoagulant therapy. These events converged to enhance the risk of DVT. This patient's history underscores the importance of proper DVT prophylaxis following orthopedic surgeries and during prolonged immobility.  Conclusion:  While DVT is more frequently observed in hospitalized and bedridden patients  instances in the general population like in this case underline the danger it poses to even those outside of immediate hospital care. Extended anticoagulation prophylaxis and increased physical activity post femur fracture surgery are crucial for reducing DVT risk.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Obese  Sedentary Male: A Case Report   Introduction:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is an exceedingly prevalent condition which if left undiagnosed  can have serious health implications  such as Pulmonary Embolism (PE). DVT is said to be common amongst patients with certain risk factors including obesity  sedentarism  certain genetic clotting disorders  pregnancy  and prolonged bed rest or inactivity.   Patient Information:   Mr. Jones  a 57-year-old African American male  presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of progressive left leg pain and swelling for the last week. He works as a computer programmer and often sits at his desk for hours at a stretch  leading to his sedentary lifestyle. He is significantly overweight (height: 173cm  weight: 106kg  BMI: 35.4kg/m2) but denies any history of smoking  alcohol or recreational drug usage. There were no significant family medical history reported  particularly no known genetic clotting disorders.   Clinical Findings:  The patient's left leg appeared visibly swollen and erythematous. His calf measured 3 cm larger than his non-affected right limb on tape measure examination  and demonstrated a positive Homan's sign  inducing further suspicion for DVT. Both Peripheral pulses were palpable and equal in the lower extremities.   Diagnostic Assessment   Given the high index of suspicion for DVT  a Doppler ultrasound was ordered  which demonstrated evidence of a non-compressible left popliteal vein consistent with the formation of a thrombus. Blood tests revealed no significant abnormalities apart from raised D-Dimer levels.   Therapeutic Intervention   A course of anticoagulation using Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) was initiated immediately  and the patient was referred to a Hematologist for continuous care and monitoring. Education about weight management  increasing physical activity  and the importance of regular follow-ups were also provided. The patient received a prescription for a Grade II compression stocking for use during the day.  Follow-up and Outcome   The patient showed significant improvement with reduced pain and swelling at the one-week review and has been adherent to lifestyle modification recommendations and medication regimen. Further follow-ups and general health surveillance have been scheduled.  Conclusion:   This case emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and intervention in DVT  in the presence of risk factors such as obesity  sedentarism and older age. It is vital for healthcare professionals to consider DVT in the differential when patients present with unilateral limb pain and swelling.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in Middle-Aged African American Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a vascular disorder characterized by the formation of a blood clot  also known as a thrombus  within a deep vein - typically in the leg. While DVT can occur in individuals of all races and ethnicities  it has been found to be more prevalent in African American populations in certain studies.  Patient Information: The patient is a 53-year-old African American woman with a BMI of 32  calculated as obese according to CDC guidelines. She is a resident of the southwestern United States and is employed as a paralegal. She has a previous medical history of type II diabetes and hypertension.  Clinical Findings: On her first visit  the patient complained of increased pain and swelling in her left leg which had been worsening over the past week. She also mentioned occasional shortness of breath. She was not previously on any medications for her hypertension and diabetes.  Diagnostic Assessment: Physical examination revealed a swollen and tender left calf. An ultrasound was promptly ordered and revealed a deep vein thrombosis in her left leg. A D-dimer blood test was also performed which showed elevated levels  further confirming the diagnosis of DVT. A subsequent ECG revealed signs of strain on the right side of the heart  suggesting possible pulmonary embolism.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on an anticoagulant (low-molecular-weight heparin) immediately to stop the clot from growing  and later transitioned to an oral anticoagulant (warfarin). Her diabetes and hypertension were managed with metformin and lisinopril  respectively. She was given lifestyle modification advice to lose weight  increase physical activity  and adhere to her medications.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: On a follow-up visit at 4 weeks  the patient reported a significant reduction in pain and swelling. Her blood pressure read 130/85 mmHg  and her blood glucose levels had improved. An ultrasound reassessment showed a decrease in size of the clot  indicating a positive response to the anticoagulant medication.   Discussion: This case emphasizes the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in middle-aged patients  particularly in those presenting with unexplained extremity pain and swelling. The patient's obesity  type II diabetes  and hypertension may have contributed to the development of DVT. Intervention was aimed at managing these risk factors and treating DVT  with anticoagulant therapy demonstrating success in this case.   Conclusion: Regular monitoring and strict adherence to medication and lifestyle changes played a key role in managing this patient's condition and improving her overall health status. This case report emphasizes the importance of timely diagnosis and management of DVT  especially in patients with multiple risk factors like obesity  diabetes  and hypertension.  Patient's Perspective: The patient expressed relief in the decrease in her pain levels  and commitment to adhering to her medications and maintaining a healthier lifestyle to manage her diabetes  hypertension  and DVT. She plans to use this experience to raise awareness about DVT in her community.   Informed Consent:  The patient gave her informed consent for this case report to be published.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Woman  Introduction: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by the formation of a blood clot in the deep veins  most often in the legs. Complications include pulmonary embolism when the clot breaks loose and travels to the lungs. The risk factors include advanced age  obesity  surgery  immobility  smoking  and a history of venous thromboembolism or cancer.  Patient Information: A 67-year-old Caucasian female presented to the clinic with a one-week history of swelling  discomfort  and redness in her left lower limb. She is a widow  a retired schoolteacher  residing in a suburban neighborhood. She denies any use of tobacco or alcohol  but has a body mass index (BMI) of 29 signifying borderline obesity.   Clinical Findings: The patient reported a pulling sensation in the swollen limb making movement arduous. The leg did not have any visible injuries but did feel warm to touch. She reported no recent injuries or traumas. Ultrasonography confirmed a clot in the left lower leg's deep vein  leading to a diagnosis of DVT.  Timeline: Her symptoms gradually worsened for about a week before seeking medical attention. Prior to this encounter  her last medical consultation was 6 months ago for routine check-ups as a diabetic patient.  Diagnostic Assessment: Complete blood counts were generally within normal ranges. The D-dimer test was positive  a finding common in patients with DVT. Ultrasonography showed a thrombus in the left popliteal vein. Given her history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM)  an HbA1c test was also conducted revealing relatively controlled levels at 7.0%.  Therapeutic Intervention: In mild cases  medication such as anticoagulants is suggested. However  given her advanced age  comorbidity  and obesity  in addition to medication  she was also advised for a brief hospital stay for close clinical monitoring. Low molecular weight Heparin  followed by oral anticoagulants for an extended period  was prescribed.  Follow Up and Outcome: After a week  the patient noticed significant reduction in swelling and discomfort in her leg. Upon evaluation after two weeks  the clot showed substantial resolution on repeat ultrasonography. She is still under observation and continuing her medication regimen.  Patient Perspective: She expressed gratitude for the swift diagnosis and effective treatment. The patient was initially worried about possible complications  however  frequent consultation and thorough explanation by her healthcare provider gave her confidence.  Conclusion: DVT  while a common clinical problem  can have varying risk factors including obesity and T2DM  both present in this case. Prompt diagnosis and treatment can help in successful management of DVT to prevent serious complications like pulmonary embolism  which can be potentially life-threatening.   This case highlights the need for healthcare providers to have a high index of suspicion for DVT in patients who present with limb pain  particularly in those with risk factors and/or comorbid conditions. Patients should be educated about the symptoms of DVT and the importance of early presentation. Regular follow-up is crucial to monitor the clot's resolution and identify any potential complications early.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 60-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction:   Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a severe medical condition defined by the formation of blood clots within the deep veins  usually in the lower limbs. This case report describes a patient presenting with DVT and reviews diagnostic and treatment strategies pursued.   Patient Information:   The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the clinic with symptoms of swelling  pain  warmth  and redness in the right lower extremity. These symptoms started five days prior to his hospital visit. The patient is a retired engineer  a smoker for 25 years  was physically active until recently  and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and history of long-haul flights due to work engagements.   Clinical Findings:  The clinical examination of the patient revealed swelling and inflammation in the right lower limb  approximately 3 cm greater in circumference than the left limb. Homan's sign was positive which signifies the presence of a possible DVT. Further  upon palpation  the patient experienced pain and discomfort.   Diagnostic Assessment:  On suspicion of DVT  Duplex ultrasonography was carried out to visualise the deep veins and detect any blood clot. A positive result was attained and it confirmed a thrombus in the right popliteal vein extending to the femoral vein. The patient's D-dimer levels were elevated which is often seen in patients with DVT  further confirming the diagnosis.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Following the diagnosis  the patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy as per standard guidelines. Rivaroxaban  an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor was started at a dose of 15 mg twice daily for 21 days  followed by 20 mg daily. A patient's warfarin dosage was adjusted based on prothrombin time and international normalised ratio (INR) measurements.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient's symptoms resolved over the subsequent weeks  with a decrease in swelling and pain. He remained on anticoagulants for a total of six months  as per standard DVT treatment guidelines. The patient was also educated regarding lifestyle modification such as regular exercise  quitting smoking  maintaining a balanced diet  and to avoid long periods of immobilisation. He was asked to return for regular follow-ups to monitor his progress.  Conclusions:  In conclusion  this case highlights the need for prompt recognition of DVT signs and symptoms  risk factors  and the importance of early diagnostic interventions  as DVT can lead to serious complications such as pulmonary embolism. Careful follow-up and adherence to anticoagulant therapy are vital for successful DVT management.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Sedentary  Obese Woman with a History of Hypertension and Tobacco Use  Patient Presentation:  Ms. X is a 56-year-old Caucasian female presenting with pain and swelling in her left calf that has persisted for 72 hours. The patient described the pain as dull  continuous  and exacerbates with movement. On examination  the leg was warm to the touch and demonstrated significant edema. Her body mass index (BMI) was calculated to be 35.4  classified as obese. The patient lives alone and her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease.  Past Medical History:  Ms. X has a known history of hypertension for 10 years  for which she has been maintained on Lisinopril 20mg daily. She reports a smoking history of 25 years with an average of a pack per day but had quit 5 years ago. She had been sedentary in nature due to her work commitments involving prolonged hours of sitting continuously. She denied history of any surgeries  diabetes  or hyperlipidemia. She is post-menopausal and has never taken any form of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) or contraception.  Current Investigation and Findings:  Doppler ultrasound of the left lower limb demonstrated an absence of compressibility of the left posterior tibial vein and a lack of color flow  indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Lab investigations showed elevated levels of D-dimer. Full blood count  liver function  kidney function  and lipid profile were within normal limits. Electrocardiograph findings and chest X-ray were also normal.  Final Diagnosis and Plan:  The patient was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis of the left leg. Factors contributing to her medical condition include sedentary lifestyle  obesity  hypertension  and history of smoking. She was started on low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) along with oral anticoagulant (warfarin) therapy which will be continued for 3-6 months. She was advised to elevate her leg and to use graduated compression stockings. Given her risk factors  she was recommended a weight loss program  a healthier diet  and supervised exercise regimen to reduce her risk. She was also educated about the signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism and was advised to seek immediate medical help if she developed chest pain or shortness of breath.  The case of Ms. X highlights the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in patients who present with unilateral leg pain and swelling  especially in the presence of risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  and history of smoking. Early diagnosis and prompt management can prevent potentially life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism. Moreover  patient education and lifestyle modification can significantly reduce the risk of recurrence.   COVID-19 implications: Considering the pandemic  virtual follow-up appointments were scheduled to minimize her exposure to COVID-19. She was educated about the increased risk factors for DVT in COVID-19 patients due to immobilization and critical illness thrombotic microangiopathy.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Caucasian Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a severe condition characterized by the formation of a thrombus  typically in the deep leg or pelvic veins. It poses substantial morbidity and can potentially lead to fatal pulmonary embolism.   Case Presentation: Our patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian female  working as a high school teacher  non-smoker  and non-alcoholic  residing in the suburban areas of Virginia. She is average-built with a body mass index (BMI) of 24.1. Prior to her current condition  she reported no significant past medical history except mild hypertension controlled on anti-hypertensive medications for the past eight years. Her family history unveils no known genetic disorders  cancers  or coagulation dysfunction.  The patient presented with a one-week history of progressive swelling  discomfort and redness located in her left lower extremity. She reported no recent injury  surgery  prolonged travel  or immobilization. There was no history of oral contraceptive use or hormone replacement therapy. She denied any complaints of chest pain  difficulty breathing  or hemoptysis.  On examination  her left calf was significantly swollen and tender  hot to touch  compared to the right. Her vitals were stable with a blood pressure of 135/82 mmHg and a resting heart rate of 78 bpm.   Investigations & Diagnosis: A venous duplex ultrasound of her left leg confirmed the presence of a non-compressible segment in the left femoral and popliteal veins indicative of a DVT. Her D-dimer levels were markedly elevated.   Treatment: She was immediately initiated on therapeutic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) and was transitioned to a direct oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban) after a stabilizing period.  Outcome and Follow-up: She was discharged home after five days of hospitalization. At the one-month follow-up appointment  the patient reported significant symptom relief and repeat ultrasound showed significant reduction in the size of the thrombus.   Discussion: This case adds to the existing literature as it broadly represents DVT patients - middle-aged individuals with potential risk factors (hypertension and sedentary profession). No typical risk factors like recent surgery  pregnancy  malignancy  or genetic predisposition were found. This case emphasizes the importance of considering DVT in any patient presenting with unexplained leg pain and swelling despite a lack of typical risk factors.

Title: A Case Report of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Caucasian Woman With No Significant Previous Medical History  Introduction:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) refers to the formation of one or more blood clots in the deep veins of the body  usually in the legs. While the condition can affect anyone  DVT is more commonly found in adults over the age of 60. However  DVT cases have been increasingly diagnosed in younger adults as well.   Case Report:  The patient  Mrs. E.O.  is a 56-year-old Caucasian woman with no significant past medical history. She resides in rural Kentucky and is a lifelong non-smoker. Her BMI falls within the normal range (22.3 kg/m2). The patient is physically active  with no history of recreational drug use or regular alcohol consumption.  Mrs. E.O. presented to the emergency department with complaints of progressive left lower leg pain and swelling that started suddenly over the course of a day. Her symptoms were associated with mild redness but no skin temperature elevation  wound  recent injury  or prolonged immobilization.   Physical examination revealed mild erythema and swelling predominantly in the left leg compared to the right. The patient yielded positive results on the Homan's sign.   Investigation:  Considering her symptoms and physical findings  a venous Doppler ultrasound was requested immediately. It confirmed the presence of an acute deep vein thrombosis involving the left popliteal and femoral veins. Her D-dimer levels were significantly elevated.   No significant abnormalities were found in complete blood count  liver and renal function tests. Testing for inherited thrombophilia came back as negative. ECG and chest X-ray were within normal limits.  Management:  Mrs. E.O. was hospitalized and started on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin (Enoxaparin) and oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban). There was a noticeable improvement in her symptoms over the course of her hospital stay.  Discussion:  Surprisingly  our patient did not possess any traditional risk factors of DVT such as advanced age  obesity  smoking  or thrombophilia. She was physically active and her medical history was unremarkable. However  her case highlights the reality that DVT can occur in individuals outside of the traditionally perceived high-risk demographics.  Conclusion:  In conclusion  our patient's case emphasizes the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for deep vein thrombosis  even in patients who don't fit within the traditional risk factor framework. Early diagnosis and prompt treatment can significantly reduce morbidity associated with this condition. Further research is needed to better understand these ""outlier"" cases of DVT.

Title: A Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Woman   Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is the formation of a blood clot in a deep vein  primarily the legs. Approximately 900 000 people could be affected each year in the United States. DVT is quite important because it can lead to life-threatening complications  such as a pulmonary embolism.   Case Report: - Patient Information: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian woman with a medical history of obesity  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia who presented with a three-day history of progressive  non-radiating pain and swelling in her left lower leg. She is a non-smoker  non-alcoholic  and post-menopausal. She is a cashier by occupation and therefore remains standing for the majority of the day  which could significantly contribute to her presenting condition.   - Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient’s left calf was significantly swollen  tender to the touch  and warm compared to the other leg. A notable difference in calf diameter by 3 cm was seen on measurement. There was no discoloration  ulcers  or varicose veins. No lymphadenopathy was observed.   - Diagnostic Assessments: She had a positive D-Dimer test and an Ultrasound-Doppler study showed a non-compressible left posterior tibial vein with absent venous flow  confirming the suspicion of DVT. The full blood count  kidney function tests  and liver function tests were normal. Electrocardiogram and chest x-rays were unremarkable.  - Therapeutic Interventions: The patient was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin as a bridge to warfarin  with a goal INR of 2-3. Additionally  she was advised to elevate her leg at home and use compression stockings.  - Follow-up and Outcomes: She responded well to the initial treatment. On an outpatient basis  over the course of six months of therapy  repeat ultrasounds showed progressive resolution of the thrombus.   - Patient Perspective: The patient was initially distressed by the diagnosis but was reassured after a thorough explanation of her condition and management plan. She complied with medication and lifestyle modification advice  resulting in significant relief from her symptoms.
