Conclusion: This case exemplifies the associations between prolonged standing occupations  obesity  hypertension  and post-menopausal status as several independent risk factors for DVT. A high degree of clinical suspicion  timely diagnosis  and early treatment initiation is crucial in managing DVT cases.   Keywords: Deep Vein Thrombosis; Case Report; Post-menopausal.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Elderly Caucasian Man  Patient Information  Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired  non-smoker with BMI of 24.0. He lives in a semi-rural area in the Midwestern United States with his wife. His primary language is English  and he completed high school education. The patient is fairly sedentary with occasional walks in the neighborhood. He is regularly followed-up for his chronic conditions and maintains good compliance with his medication regimen.  Clinical Findings   The patient presented to the emergency department with pain and swelling in his left lower leg that began approximately 24 hours ago. He reported that he felt a small cramp but did not have any visible injuries. Later  the leg became painful  swollen  and noticeably warmer. There was no complaint of chest pain or breathlessness.   Medical History  The patient has a previous medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes diagnosed 10 years ago. He suffered a stroke two years ago with minimal residual deficit. He is currently taking Losartan for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  and Aspirin and Atorvastatin as secondary stroke prophylaxis. He has no known drug allergies.  Physical Examination  The patient’s vital signs were stable. On examination  the left leg appeared swollen  red  and warm compared to the right leg. Distinctive discoloration below the knee was observed. Peripheral pulses were palpable but diminished in the left leg.  Differential Diagnosis  The patient's symptoms suggested deep vein thrombosis (DVT). However  the differential diagnoses also included cellulitis  acute compartment syndrome  superficial thrombophlebitis  and Baker's cyst.  Investigations  A Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity revealed a lack of compressibility of the femoral and popliteal veins  supporting the diagnosis of DVT. Routine laboratory investigations showed slightly elevated inflammatory markers. D-dimer concentration was significantly elevated.  Treatment  The patient was admitted and started on therapeutic dose low-molecular-weight Heparin (LMWH) promptly. He had no complications from anticoagulation. Further management involved transitioning the patient to oral anticoagulants for long-term treatment. We also initiated compression therapy and leg elevation to reduce swelling and pain in the affected leg.  Outcome and follow-up  Over the following week  the patient’s leg swelling and pain decreased significantly. He was educated about the signs of pulmonary embolism and was instructed to return promptly if he noticed symptoms such as sudden shortness of breath or chest pain.   His condition will be reviewed in the outpatient clinic after 1 month and then every 3 months or earlier if necessary. If re-thrombosis or recurrent symptoms occur earlier or bleeding due to anticoagulant therapy  he would be re-evaluated for other potential risk factors for thrombosis  and treatment would be adjusted accordingly.  Informed Consent  Informed written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Patient Perspective  The patient reported being satisfied with the care provided and felt comfortable in his follow-up plan.

Title: 'A Case Report of a Recurrent Unilateral Deep Vein Thrombosis in a 52-year-old African American Female with a History of Smoking and Obesity’  Introduction:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a common yet serious medical condition characterized by the formation of a blood clot within a deep vein  typically in the lower legs  thigh  or pelvis. We report a case of a recurrent unilateral DVT in a 52-year-old African American female with a history of obesity and smoking.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 52-year-old African American woman working as an office manager living in the urban area of Philadelphia  Pennsylvania. She is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history but had quit 10 years prior. She has a high BMI (Body Mass Index) at 35 kg/m2  indicating class II obesity. She also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  with inconsistent medication adherence due to medical cost concerns.  The patient initially presented with symptoms of swelling  intense pain  and warmth in her left leg. She reported a previous incident of DVT in the same leg approximately five years ago  after a prolonged period of immobilization following a minor car accident. At that time  the patient was managed with therapeutic anticoagulation for six months. Family medical history was significant only for type-2 diabetes mellitus in her mother  and no history of blood clotting disorders or malignancies.  On physical examination  the patient showed pitting edema in her left lower leg  calf tenderness  and erythema. No specific findings were spotted upon cardiovascular and respiratory examinations. Vital signs were within normal ranges except for slightly elevated blood pressure at 145/95 mmHg. Laboratory data showed a marginally raised D-dimer at 0.65 mg/L (normal <0.5 mg/ L).  Due to the patient's presentation and positive D-dimer test  a Doppler Ultrasound was performed confirming the presence of a thrombus in the left popliteal vein  leading to the diagnosis of recurrent DVT.  Discussion:  This case illustrates the higher risk of DVT recurrence in individuals with obesity and a previous history of DVT. Further studies are required to better understand and manage the complexities of treating recurrent DVT in patients with these risk factors  as well as challenges in ensuring medication adherence due to economic concerns.  The clinical management for this patient centered around re-initiation of therapeutic anticoagulation therapy and close follow-ups to ensure adherence. Lifestyle changes such as regular exercise  a healthier diet  and weight loss were advised to cope with obesity and consequent cardiovascular risks.  Conclusion:  Recurrent DVT is a serious health condition that requires timely diagnosis and appropriate therapeutic interventions to prevent severe complications like pulmonary embolism. Greater attention and resources should be focused on preventive measures  particularly in high-risk populations  and addressing the barriers to consistent medical adherence in socioeconomically disadvantaged patients.

Title: A Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Hispanic Male  Abstract:   This report describes the case of a 55-year-old Hispanic male who presented with a two-week history of pain and swelling in the left lower limb  indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Highlighted in this report is the importance of considering this diagnosis even in patients without a relevant medical history  or the presence of traditional risk factors such as a sedentary lifestyle.   Case Presentation:  The patient  a 55-year-old Hispanic male  employed as an office clerk  with no significant past medical history  presented with progressive pain and swelling in the left lower limb over a span of two weeks. The patient had no history of surgeries  recent long-duration travel  immobility  or family history of thrombotic disorders. The patient was mildly obese with a BMI of 30.2; he had a sedentary lifestyle and a two pack-year history of smoking  but no record of alcohol or illicit drug abuse.  Physical examination revealed warmth  redness  and tenderness in the calf and ankle area of the left leg. The calf circumference was significantly greater compared to the right leg.   Investigation and Management:  An ultrasound Doppler was performed on the symptomatic leg. It revealed a non-compressible segment in the left popliteal and posterior tibial veins  confirming a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. D-dimer levels were also significantly elevated. The patient's blood work showed normal levels of white blood cells  platelets  and hemoglobin.  He was initiated on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for immediate anticoagulation and began oral anticoagulant therapy with Rivaroxaban. The patient was advised to elevate the left leg  wear compression stockings  and was educated about the signs of pulmonary embolism.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  After a week of treatment  the patient reported significant relief of pain and reduction in swelling. On assessment  LMWH was discontinued  and Rivaroxaban was continued as per guideline-directed therapy.  This case underscores the importance of considering DVT in differential diagnoses  even in patients without apparent risk factors or prior medical history. It further emphasizes the role of appropriate investigation  risk factor management  and the provision of patient education in managing this condition.  Conclusion:  Despite a lack of significant past medical history  this case of a middle-aged Hispanic male with deep vein thrombosis further supports the need to maintain a high index of suspicion for the condition  given its potential for severe complications. Prompt diagnosis and treatment  along with education about symptom recognition and lifestyle modification  can substantially improve patient outcomes.

Title: Diagnosis and Management of Unprovoked Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in a Previously Healthy Individual  Patient Demographic:  A 68-year-old non-Hispanic Caucasian male  retired construction worker  resident of Boston  Massachusetts  non-smoker  moderate weekly alcohol consumption.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with a 4-day history of increasing pain and swelling in his right leg  particularly the calf area. He denied any recent trauma  prolonged periods of immobility  or long-haul flights. He also reported unexplained fatigue  but no respiratory symptoms or chest pain were reported.  Past Medical History: The patient has hypertension managed with amlodipine. He has had no prior history of venous thromboembolism (VTE) or any hereditary coagulation abnormalities. His family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus but no known history of familial clotting disorders. He is not on any anticoagulant medication or taking any form of hormone treatment. He has no known drug allergies.  Physical Examination: Physical examination found the patient to be comfortable at rest  with normal blood pressure and pulse rate. The right leg was warm  erythematous  edematous  and tender on palpation  consistent with the symptoms of DVT. There was no pitting edema  and Homans’ sign was positive. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations showed a mildly raised D-dimer level. A lower extremity venous duplex ultrasound was carried out  which evidenced extensive thrombosis in the right popliteal vein extending into the trifurcation. A CT pulmonary angiogram was also performed due to the high risk of Pulmonary Embolism (PE) associated with DVT but found no evidence of PE.  Diagnosis:  This patient was diagnosed with unprovoked deep vein thrombosis.  Management and Follow-Up: The patient was admitted for observation and anticoagulation therapy was initiated with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). The patient was further transitioned to a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC)  apixaban  given his risk profile and absence of PE. The patient also wore a graduated compression stocking on the affected leg. Education was provided on the need for continuous treatment and signs of potential complications such as PE.  The patient was scheduled for close outpatient follow-up including monitoring for potential post-thrombotic syndrome. There was a discussion on the need for risk factor modification including lifestyle changes. Also  further testing for thrombophilia was considered due to the unprovoked nature of the DVT.  This case highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain even without known provocative factors. Unprovoked DVT could potentially signify an underlying thrombophilia which mandates additional investigations and a different level of clinical management.

Title: Management of Deep Vein Thrombosis in an elderly male patient with previous Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus: A Case Report  Case Presentation  A male patient  aged 70  Caucasian  retired mathematician  non-smoker  presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of progressive swelling  redness  and pain of his right lower leg. On initial sighting  it was noted the patient was overweight with a BMI of 28.  Medical History  The patient had a history of type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years previously  controlled with metformin and a well-managed lifestyle modification program.He also had a history of hypertension managed with a calcium channel blocker  Amlodipine 10mg daily  for the past 5 years. There was no history of malignancy  recent hospitalizations or immobilization  trauma  surgeries  or known coagulation disorders. There was no reported family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism. The patient had undergone a complete medical review 6 months earlier  with no significant findings.  Clinical Findings and Diagnostic Assessment  Physical examination revealed an erythematous  swollen  warm  and painful lower right extremity. The Homans sign was positive. The patient's blood pressure was 140/85 mmHg  pulse rate 88 bpm  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  fever was absent  and oxygen saturation was 97% on room air. Laboratory tests  including complete blood count  coagulation profile  and metabolic panel were within normal ranges  except for an elevated D-dimer level at 750 ng/mL FEU(normal is 0-500 ng/mL FEU).  A lower extremity venous Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the right popliteal vein  diagnostic of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) and oral anticoagulant therapy with warfarin. The dosage of enoxaparin was 1mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 hours and warfarin was initiated at a dose of 5mg daily.   Follow-Up and Outcomes   Upon 48 hours  the patient showed substantial improvement with a decrease in limb swelling and pain. Serial monitoring of the International Normalised Ratio(INR) was started to maintain a therapeutic range between 2-3. The patient was counseled regarding the importance of adherence to medication  risks and signs of bleeding. A follow-up Doppler was planned at one  three  and six months.   Conclusion  This case illustrates the need for high clinical suspicion for DVT in patients presenting with unilateral lower limb swelling and pain  especially in those with previous comorbidities. Early diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation therapy are crucial in preventing serious complications such as Pulmonary Embolism.

Title: Management of Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Obese Female: A Case Report   Introduction: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a potentially life-threatening acute vascular disease characterized by formation of blood clots in the deep veins of the body  typically in the legs. This case describes the management of DVT in a 55-year-old  Caucasian female.  Patient Information: The patient  a 55-year-old  Caucasian female presented to the outpatient vascular clinic with a history of severe pain and swelling in her right lower extremity for two weeks. The patient's demographic information includes a residential address in rural northern Michigan and employment as a cashier. The patient mentioned recent prolonged immobilization due to a fractured left ankle 3 months ago. She denied any history of recent long travel  surgery  or malignancy.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient's right lower leg was found to be warmer  swollen  and erythematous  with significant tenderness on deep palpation. She had a body mass index (BMI) of 32  categorizing her as obese.  Medical History: The patient had a past medical history significant for hypertension and osteoarthritis. The family history was notable for her father having a pulmonary embolism at the age of 60. She reported a 30 pack-year smoking history and admitted to a sedentary lifestyle without regular exercises.  Diagnostic Assessment: A venous Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a deep vein thrombus in the popliteal and femoral veins of the patient's right leg. Complete blood count  metabolic panel  and coagulation profile were within the normal range except for an elevated D-Dimer level. No genetic mutation associated with hypercoagulability was identified.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initiated on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as an initial treatment. After five days  Oral direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC)  Rivaroxaban  was initiated and planned to be continued for at least 3 months.  Follow-up and Outcomes: At a one-month follow-up visit  the patient reported a significant reduction in leg swelling  pain  and was able to ambulate without discomfort. Repeat venous Doppler showed recanalization of the affected veins  indicating successful treatment.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain  especially in patients with predisposing factors like obesity  immobilization  and a history of smoking. Anticoagulation remains the mainstay of treatment for DVT and can lead to successful recanalization and symptom relief. Regular follow-up is crucial to monitor for potential complications of anticoagulation therapy and the recurrence of thrombosis.  Keywords: Deep vein thrombosis  obesity  anticoagulation  case report  vascular disease  immobilization.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Woman with a History of Oral Contraceptive Use  Patient Profile: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female  presented with a 3-day history of pain and swelling in her left lower extremity. She was generally in good health apart from being post-menopausal  however  she reported a history of prolonged oral contraceptive use during her reproductive years. The patient lives in a rural community in Wisconsin  United States.  Past Medical History: The patient reported no previous significant illness or hospitalization until the present condition. Do not have any allergies or had operations in the past.   Family History: The patient's mother reportedly had deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) at the age of 65. Her father died at the age of 82 from a myocardial infarction  and her two older brothers are alive and well with no significant medical history.  Social History: The patient is a non-smoker  rarely drinks alcohol  and has not been engaged in drug use. She lives with her husband and works as a high school teacher. She reports an overall sedentary lifestyle due to her job nature and lacks regular physical activity. The patient reports no recent travels or other potential risk factors for thromboembolic disease apart from her inherited risks and lifestyle.  Presenting Complaint: The patient first noted mild discomfort  redness  and swelling on her left calf that progressively worsened over a few days. The pain elevated and described it as a deep  throbbing ache exacerbated by standing or walking.   Clinical Examination: Physical examination revealed a slightly elevated body temperature at 38.2 degrees Celsius. Her left calf was swollen  warm  erythematous  and tender to touch. There were no signs of superficial vein thrombosis or varicosities. Pedal pulses were intact.   Investigations: A complete blood count and biochemistry tests were conducted  which were within normal ranges. A D-dimer test was positive and a Lower Limb Doppler Ultrasound confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.  Management: Upon diagnosis confirmation  the patient was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)  followed by transitioning to oral anticoagulant - Warfarin. She was advised to elevate her lower limb and wear compression stockings. Education was provided about signs and symptoms of possible complications  notably pulmonary embolism.   Follow Up: The patient has been scheduled for regular follow-ups to monitor her response to therapy and any potential complications.  Conclusion: Given the patient’s family history  prolonged use of oral contraceptives  and sedentary lifestyle  it is a lesson for clinicians to take a comprehensive history and consider DVT in a differential diagnosis when relevant symptoms are present  despite the absence of recent triggering factors such as surgery  injury  or travel. The patient’s case underscores the importance of primary prevention strategies in patients with risk factors for deep vein thrombosis.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Menopausal Female: A Case Report  Patient Information: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female residing in rural Colorado  USA. She is retired and lives predominantly sedentary lifestyle. The patient reported a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31  classified as obese. She is nonsmoker and denies alcohol or illicit drug abuse. Her primary language is English  and she lives with her husband who is her current caregiver.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented in the clinic with several days of progressive level 6 to 7/10 pain (on the pain scale) in her left lower leg characterized as a dull ache and moderate swelling. On physical examination  her left calf appeared slightly red  warm  and swollen. There was tenderness along the calf veins upon palpation. Her right lower extremity appeared normal. She did not present fever or other systemic symptoms. She also complained of mild shortness of breath on exertion but no chest pain or dizziness.  Diagnostic Assessment: Baseline laboratory testing was performed and was largely unremarkable. D-dimer levels were clearly elevated. Venous duplex ultrasound revealed acute deep vein thrombosis in her left popliteal and posterior tibial veins. She was referred for chest computed tomography which ruled out the presence of pulmonary embolism.   Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  controlled through diet and oral hypoglycemic agents and a stable dose of ACE inhibitor  respectively. She had gone through menopause at 51 years old and was not on any hormone replacement therapy. She had no known personal or family history of coagulopathy or venous thromboembolism. She reported no recent hospitalization  surgery  pregnancy  or long-term immobilization.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis and anticoagulant therapy was initiated immediately with intravenous heparin followed by oral warfarin for long-term use. Lifestyle modifications and the use of compressional stockings were recommended. Frequent monitoring of INR level was advised during her course of warfarin therapy.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient was observed for other potential complications and improvement in her symptoms. One month after initiation of therapy  the patient reported a significant reduction in her leg pain and swelling. Her warfarin dosage was adjusted to maintain an INR of 2 to 3.   Patient Perspective: The patient acknowledged her lack of physical activity and unhealthy diet as contributors to her risk factors. She expressed a commitment to follow the new lifestyle modifications and her warfarin regime to prevent the recurrence of deep vein thrombosis.   Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Conclusion: This case sheds light on the occurrence of deep vein thrombosis in post-menopausal  sedentary women  particularly those with a high BMI and controlled chronic conditions such as Hypertension and Diabetes. More research is needed to understand the complex interplay between these factors.

Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-Aged Physically Active Male: A Case Report   Introduction: This case details a 52-year-old Caucasian man with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Patient Information: The patient is a physically active  non-smoking  non-alcoholic individual with no known history of drug abuse. He works as a software engineer and leads a moderately sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of his work.   Chief Complaint: The patient initially presented to the hospital with persistent pain in his left calf  which had been present for one week. The pain reportedly increased on standing and walking. There was also mild swelling  warmth  and redness over the area.  Medical History: Past medical history was significant for Hypertension  managed with angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs)  and occasional migraines. His family history was notable for thromboembolic diseases; his mother had a history of Pulmonary Embolism (PE) and an aunt had DVT. His medications included his antihypertensive medication and ibuprofen as needed for his migraines.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient's vitals were stable. The left calf was mildly swollen in comparison to the right  with venous distension. Homan's sign was positive. The rest of the physical examination was within normal limits.  Diagnostic Assessment: Based on his clinical presentation  a tentative diagnosis of DVT was made. Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the left popliteal vein. Blood tests showed mild anemia and raised D-Dimer levels.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) followed by oral anticoagulation therapy with an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor (Rivaroxaban). He was advised to wear graduated compression stockings and was educated on DVT  its complications  and the importance of compliance to medication.  Follow-up and Outcomes: During follow-up at one and three months  the patient reported a significant reduction in calf pain and swelling. Repeated Doppler ultrasound at three months showed marked thrombus resolution.  Patient's Perspective: The patient expressed relief at his prompt diagnosis and effectual treatment. He was initially worried about the diagnosis due to his family history but felt reassured and well-handled with the comprehensive care he received.  Conclusion: This case serves as an important reminder that DVT can occur in patients who lead healthy  active lifestyles and have no classic risk factors besides a genetic predisposition. It underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg pain and swelling  irrespective of their lifestyle habits or demographic profile. Prompt diagnosis and management can lead to good outcomes and prevent potentially life-threatening sequelae like pulmonary embolism.   Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient to publish this case report.

Patient Presentation  Patient Profile Name: Mr. James Allen Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired textile mill worker Residence: Rural North Carolina   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Allen presented with a 3-day history of pain and swelling in his left calf which heightened when standing or walking. He also reported a slight fever and malaise.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Allen has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. He suffered a stroke 2 years ago with no significant residual deficits.  Social History: He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He reports limited physical activity and is overweight with a BMI of 30. His diet mainly consists of Southern cuisine  high in fats and sugars.   Family History: His father suffered a myocardial infarction at 70 and his mother had diabetes and hypertension.   Investigations and Diagnosis: A venous Doppler ultrasound of his left leg was conducted which confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep veins  thus confirming a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The D-dimer levels in his blood samples were also elevated.   Treatment: The patient was promptly started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin and transitioned to oral warfarin for long-term management. He was also advised on lifestyle modifications including dietary changes  increase in physical activity  and the importance of regular follow-ups.  Discussion: Mr. Allen's case is typical  given that he possesses several risk factors for DVT such as advanced age  history of stroke  and obesity. The rural setting may contribute to a lack of physical activity and access to healthcare facilities for routine checkups. His choice of high fat and sugar diet may have led to his condition of obesity and hypertension  which further increases the risk of DVT. This case underscores the importance of early detection  lifestyle modifications  and long-term anticoagulant therapy in the management of DVT. Regular follow-ups and monitoring of INR levels are crucial in managing the disease and preventing complications such as pulmonary embolism. The patient's family history of cardiovascular diseases points to a possible genetic predisposition  stressing the need for family screening procedures.

Patient Presentation  Name: Mr. Johnson   Age: 64   Gender: Male   Ethnicity: Caucasian   Occupation: Retired school teacher   Location: Rural Illinois    Presenting Condition: Mr. Johnson is experiencing progressive swelling and pain in his right lower leg over the past four days. He states it feels quite heavy and the skin over the calf has become warm and reddish. He hasn't sustained any injuries or engaged in strenuous physical activity.  Medical History: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes twelve years ago and also has a history of hypertension. His diabetes is managed through oral medications and lifestyle modifications  and his hypertension is controlled with ACE inhibitors. He has been fairly compliant with his treatment but occasionally has difficulty managing his blood glucose levels. Moreover  he was a smoker for 30 years but has quit 10 years back. He rarely drinks alcohol and has no history of drug abuse.  Family History:  His father passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 70  and his mother died at 85 due to a stroke. There is no known history of clotting disorders or deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the family.  Physical Examination: On examination  his right calf is significantly larger than his left. There is localized warmth  erythema  and tenderness. The patient shows symptoms consistent with Homan's sign  a clinical sign for deep vein thrombosis. His BMI is recorded as 30  indicating obesity. No other abnormalities were found on physical examination.  Investigations: Preliminary blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels. A Doppler ultrasound was ordered which confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep veins of right lower leg  diagnosing DVT.  Treatment Plan: The patient was admitted for treatment and started on low-molecular-weight heparin and oral anticoagulants as per standard guidelines for managing DVT. He will be monitored regularly for improvements and potential complications. Education is provided about the importance of early mobilization  leg exercises and maintaining a healthy weight. He will be recommended to a nutritionist for dietary counseling and advice regarding diabetic and weight management.  Review and Follow up: A follow-up is scheduled in two weeks to monitor the effect of anticoagulation therapy  check for side effects  and reassess risk factors. If the therapy is effective and there are no complications  Mr. Johnson's oral anticoagulant therapy will be continued for at least three months  as per current guidelines.  Conclusion: Mr. Johnson's case presents a typical manifestation of DVT. His case underlines the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment initiation to prevent complications  especially pulmonary embolism. It also emphasizes the importance of managing modifiable risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  and obesity to reduce overall morbidity.

Patient Case Presentation: DVT   Patient Overview The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  identified as John Doe  from an urban setting in the northwest region of the United States.   Presenting Issue Mr. Doe came to the emergency department with complaints of swelling  pain  warm sensation  and tenderness over the skin  predominantly in his right lower leg  which has been worsening over the past three days. He denies trauma but states the pain appears to increase with walking.   Past Medical History Mr. Doe has a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he is on Metformin. He is also known to have hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril. He previously suffered a minor ischemic stroke two years ago but has since recovered with minor long-term effects. He is a former smoker  has a BMI of 29  indicative of obesity  and does not report routine physical activity.   Family History His mother had deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at the age of 70  and his brother  65 years old  was also recently diagnosed with DVT. His father died at the age of 68 due to a myocardial infarction.   Imaging & Laboratory Findings Upon evaluation  a venous duplex ultrasound was conducted  which showed venous thrombosis in the right popliteal and femoral veins  confirming a diagnosis of DVT.  Treatment He was admitted for further evaluation and treatment  started on low-molecular-weight heparin  and transitioned to Warfarin with a goal INR of 2-3. Patient education was provided on the lifestyle modifications necessary for DVT management  including regular physical activity  leg elevation  wearing graduated compression stockings  and maintaining an appropriate diet.  He was also referred to a dietitian to help control his diabetes and to provide weight management guidance to reduce his BMI. He is scheduled for a follow-up in the outpatient clinic next week  and a referral for home health nursing has been arranged to monitor his Warfarin compliance and home safety.  Considerations Given the patient's medical history  family history  and lifestyle  there are several risk factors for DVT  including diabetes  hypertension  obesity  and family history of DVT. Strict management of these medical conditions and lifestyle modifications will be crucial in preventing recurrence and managing long-term health risks.

Patient Presentation:  Patient: Ms. Alice Brown Sex: Female Age: 68 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Marital Status: Widowed  Presenting Problem: Ms. Brown presented at a local walk-in clinic with complaints of swelling  redness  and aching pain in her left lower leg. She had a noticeable limp.  Past Medical History: She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. She has a documented history of hypertension  controlled with medication (Lisinopril  10mg). She has had two uneventful pregnancies and underwent an appendectomy at age 24.   Recent History: Ms. Brown recently returned from a transatlantic flight to visit her daughter in England. She remembers her left leg feeling ""uncomfortable"" during the journey but hasn't given much thought about it until the continual swelling and aching started.   Family History: Both her parents had cardiomyopathies and her sister has a history of stroke. Her father had deep vein thrombosis diagnosed at the age of 72.  Physical Examination: Patient vitals were stable. Cardiovascular exam was unremarkable other than a slight elevation in her blood pressure (145/86 mmHg). The left lower extremity was noticeably swollen with local heat and redness compared to the right lower leg. There was extreme tenderness upon palpation.  Additional Investigations: D-dimer levels were elevated (0.78 mg/L FEU) hinting at some form of clot. A confirmatory Duplex ultrasonography was done  which reported a non-compressible left popliteal vein  confirming a deep vein thrombosis.  Given her symptoms upon presentation  the recent history of a long-haul flight  hypertension  and family history of vascular issues  the patient's diagnosis was confirmed as Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Management: Ms. Brown was hospitalized and started on anticoagulant therapy with an initial dose of LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin)  followed by oral anticoagulants. Plans were made to monitor her regularly for symptomatic improvement and to prevent side effects and complications.  In conclusion  Ms. Brown's case emphasizes the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in the differential diagnosis of any patient experiencing swelling  redness  or pain in the leg  particularly if risk factors such as recent immobilization  hypertension  relevant family history  or recent long-distance travel are present. Patient Presentation:  Patient's Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old African American female  named Mrs. Helen Jackson  who lives alone in a small apartment. She is a retired teacher  has been widowed for 5 years  and is of lower socioeconomic status.  Past Medical History:  In her past medical history  she has been treated for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 for the last ten years. She also has a history of varicose veins but has not sought any specific treatment for it. She has a history of smoking but quit 15 years ago. Mrs. Jackson is generally compliant with her medication and tends to use diet and lifestyle changes to manage her conditions (vegetarian diet  moderation in alcohol intake  mild-moderate exercise).   Presenting Chief Complaint: Mrs. Jackson has approached the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset  painful  and swollen right calf that started 24 hours ago. The pain is persistent and increases when she tries to stand or walk. There is no history of recent injury or trauma.   Family History: Her mother had diabetes  and her father died of stroke. She had a sister who died due to metastatic breast cancer. No known family history of clotting disorders exists.  Clinical Observation and Diagnostic Tests:  On physical examination  her right calf was noted to be warm  erythematous  swollen  and tender  with pain on palpation. Labs revealed D-Dimer levels to be elevated. A subsequent Doppler ultrasound test confirmed the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis in her right lower leg.  Treatment and Recommendations:  The treatment was initiated with anticoagulation therapy (Low Molecular Weight Heparin followed by Warfarin). She was further advised to increase her ambulation  use elastic compression stockings and to elevate the leg whenever seated or in bed. She was advised to promptly report any symptoms like chest pain or breathlessness  which could imply a pulmonary embolism. Due to her elevated risk for recurrent DVT  consideration was given for a longer-term anticoagulant therapy. Comprehensive patient education was also provided regarding her conditions  as well as steps to take to mitigate risks for recurrent DVT  like regular exercise  hydration  and avoiding long periods of immobility.  Discussions on the role of aspirin or newer oral anticoagulants for primary or secondary DVT prevention  as well as a referral to a hematologist to discuss possible genetic testing for clotting disorders  were done.

Patient's Profile:  The patient in question is a 52-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith  currently residing in an urban area. He is a non-smoker and moderate consumer of alcohol  and his occupation involves extensive sitting hours as a software engineer.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presented with complaints of swelling  warmth  and pain in his left calf for the past week. He reports no recent injuries to his leg and no history of similar complaints.   Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medications. He underwent a right hip replacement surgery two years ago. The patient is on anti-hypertensive  oral hypoglycemic  and statin medication. Smith's body mass index is 31  indicating his overweight status. He sustained a myocardial infarction five years ago  for which he received appropriate treatment.  Family History:  The family history reveals that both of Mr. Smith's parents had type 2 diabetes and his father died from a stroke at the age of 65.  Clinical Findings and Investigations:  On examination  the left calf was swollen and tender with deep red discoloration. The patient’s vital signs are stable. He was sent for an urgent doppler ultrasonography of the lower limbs  which showed the absence of venous flow in the left popliteal and posterior tibial veins  suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. His D-dimer level was also elevated.  Diagnosis:  Given the patient’s clinical presentation and investigation findings  a diagnosis of left lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was made.  Treatment and Progress:  Mr. Smith was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin and later bridged to warfarin therapy. He was instructed to elevate his leg and to wear compression stockings. Exercise and weight reduction were also recommended. Regression of swelling and pain reported in follow-up after two weeks.   Considering Mr. Smith's personal and family history  he was considered for a hereditary thrombophilia screening. Genetic counseling was discussed based on the outcome of this screening.   Conclusion:  Mr. Smith's case demonstrates that deep vein thrombosis can occur in individuals with risk factors such as immobility  co-morbid conditions like hypertension and diabetes  family history of thrombotic events  and being overweight. Appropriate and prompt management is crucial to prevent life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. M is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who presented with pain and swelling in his right calf. The pain was described as aching  rated at an intensity of 7 on a scale of 1 to 10  and was reported to be progressively increasing over a week. There have been no cases of similar symptoms in the past. Notably  the patient flew in from Australia three weeks prior to his presentation  a journey lasting about 23 hours.   Past Medical History:  Mr. M reports a history of hypercholesterolemia  controlled with statins for the past five years. Progress notes also indicate a 35-year history of smoking a pack per day. Mr. M quit ten years ago  but the damage to his vascular system remains significant. He was previously diagnosed with early-stage Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) but has not required much intervention till date. He doesn't have any history of cancer or hematological disorders. His routine medication includes atorvastatin  and an inhaler (tiotropium bromide) as required for his COPD.  Family History:  His father had an unprovoked deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at the age of 50  indicating a possible familial predisposition. His mother passed away at an early age from breast cancer.  Social History:  The patient is a retired high school woodwork teacher. He lives with his wife in New York. Drinks alcohol socially and  as mentioned before  has a history of smoking. He also leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle with little exercise.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A Doppler ultrasound was performed and confirmed the presence of extensive DVT in his right leg. Blood tests revealed elevated D-dimer levels. Coupled with the patient's extended recent air travel  a diagnosis of provoked DVT was made. His hematologist is conducting additional genetic testing to establish if there is an inherited thrombophilia  given the family history of DVT.  Conclusion:  Mr. M's presentation of leg pain and swelling  together with an elevated D-dimer level and a positive ultrasound  led to a diagnosis of provoked deep vein thrombosis. Factors contributing to his heightened risk for this condition include his advanced age  a history of prolonged sedentary travel  and a history of smoking. Further testing is required to determine if there is inherited thrombophilia. The patient has been initiated on anticoagulant therapy as is standard for the management of DVT.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mrs. Smith Age: 65 Ethnicity: African-American Job: Retired Teacher  Mrs. Smith is a 65-year-old African-American female patient  a retired teacher of middle school history. She is married and has four adult children. The patient presents with a chief complaint of pain and swelling in her right lower leg for the past five days. She characterizes the pain as constant and moderately severe (7/10). She denies any trauma  recent surgery  or prolonged periods of immobility.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  both of which are well-controlled with Amlodipine and Metformin respectively. She had a hysterectomy at age 52 due to fibroids and has been on Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) since.  Family History: Her father died at the age of 72  from a stroke  and her mother had breast cancer diagnosed in her late sixties but is currently in remission. She has a sibling with coronary artery disease  and a family history of deep vein thrombosis is unclear.  Social History: Mrs. Smith has never smoked or drank alcohol. She lives with her husband in the city and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to arthritis. She travels periodically  most recently a long flight 2 weeks ago to visit her daughter out of state.  Physical Examination: Her right lower extremity is visibly swollen and red  with palpable warmth over the affected area. She has a positive Homan’s sign. There is no noticeable deformity or skin changes except for discoloration at the swollen site.  Investigations: Doppler ultrasound revealed the presence of a thrombus obstructing blood flow in the Calf Vein  confirming the diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Comments: Given Mrs. Smith's sedentary lifestyle  her recent long-distance flight  her age  and her use of HRT  she has multiple risk factors for the development of deep vein thrombosis. If left untreated  this could lead to serious complications such as a pulmonary embolism. The American Heart Association estimates that 60 000-100 000 Americans die of deep vein thrombosis/PE each year.  Plan: Mrs. Smith has been immediately started on low molecular weight heparin  concomitantly started on Warfarin and will be discharged once her INR reaches therapeutic range. She has been counselled about the importance of mobility and elevating her leg. She is also advised to think about a potential change to her HRT considering her now two major risk factors - HRT use and the confirmed DVT. She is scheduled to follow up in clinic in 1 week to recheck her INR and adjust her Warfarin dosing as necessary.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Anthony  presented to the emergency department with complaints suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). He was a retired construction worker  living with his wife in suburban Los Angeles  California. The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes and is on Metformin of 500mg daily. The patient also reportedly has mild obesity with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30.5.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Anthony reported persistent heaviness and pain in his right lower limb for the past couple of days  accompanied by mild swelling and redness. He had no history of trauma or injury to the leg. He also reported shortness of breath which worsened on mild exertion.  Family History: No significant family history of cardiovascular disease  thrombotic disorders  or chronic illnesses could be traced  except for an elder brother who had passed away due to lung cancer. This family history is substantial as it can indicate whether there might be any inherited disorders that increase the risk of DVT.  Physical Assessment: Upon examination  the patient’s right calf was warm  swollen  and tender  raising suspicion of DVT. However  other systemic examinations were within normal limits.  Investigation: His vital signs showed elevated blood pressure (BP - 140/90mmHg). A Doppler Ultrasonography confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep veins of his right lower leg. His blood tests showed a slightly elevated blood sugar level (HbA1c - 7.2%)  high D-Dimer levels (1000ng/ml)  and increased Clotting time (PT - 16 sec  APTT - 35 sec). A chest X-ray was normal.  Diagnosis: Based on the history  clinical presentation  and investigation results  a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis was established.  Management: The patient was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for immediate anticoagulation and was recommended for oral Warfarin thereafter. Specific instructions on lifestyle modifications  including weight management  were given to reduce the risk of DVT recurrence. The patient was also advised to wear compression stockings and mobilize frequently since prolonged immobilization can increase the risk for DVT.   The patient's diabetes was considered in his management. His metformin dose was readjusted  his diet was reviewed with him  he was advised to regular exercise  and regular follow-up appointments were scheduled to ensure his sugar levels were well controlled.  This presentation aims to represent a typical patient diagnosed with DVT in a western society. However  it's important to note that DVT can affect any age  gender  and population group.

Patient Presentation  Patient Details:  Our patient  Mr. Johnson is a 52-year-old African-American male presenting with a recent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He's a non-smoker but is overweight and has a sedentary job as an office worker. Mr. Johnson has no known allergies.  Past Medical History:  He has a documented medical history of Type II diabetes and hypertension. Both are managed by medication (metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension). He has no previous history of any vascular disorders or clotting abnormalities. He admits non-compliance to the recommended lifestyle changes such as diet modification and regular physical exercises.  Family history:  Upon questioning  Mr. Johnson revealed that his father had a stroke at the age of 58. He also stated that his brother was recently diagnosed with peripheral artery disease. No family history of clotting disorders or cancer was reported.  Recent Events Relevant to Condition:  Mr. Johnson recently experienced left calf pain which is unusual for him. The discomfort started suddenly while he was on a long distance flight returning from a business trip. The pain has been progressively worsening  associated with noticeable calf swelling and mild skin discoloration. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or any other respiratory symptoms.   Initial Findings:  Physical examination revealed left calf tenderness  warmth  swelling  and erythema suggestive of DVT which was confirmed by Doppler ultrasound. The patient’s blood pressure was mildly elevated at the clinic visit (145/95mmHg)  and his random blood sugar reading was not well-controlled (176 mg/dl).   Given his history of diabetes  hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  recent long plane flight and subsequent presentation of symptoms  Mr. Johnson falls under a high-risk category for developing DVT. His family’s history of vascular disorders also lends support to the diagnosis.  Management:  Hypercoagulable workup was done which was unremarkable. He was started on therapeutic low molecular weight Heparin in hospital and discharged on oral anticoagulation with instructions to follow up in a week. He was advised regarding the importance of medication compliance  weight loss  diet modification  and physical exercise.   The patient was counseled about signs of pulmonary embolism  a serious complication of DVT  and instructed to return immediately if any of these symptoms were to develop.  This case represents a common presentation of DVT  emphasizing the critical role numerous risk factors including long-term immobility  increased age  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and certain genetic predispositions can play in its development.

Patient Presentation:   Our patient  Mr. John McKenzie  is a 67-year-old African-American male diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). He is a retired construction worker and is presently residing in Orlando  Florida  with his wife.   Demographics:   Mr. McKenzie  who belongs to one of the most vulnerable demographic groups  represents the estimated 1-2 cases per 1000 adults diagnosed with DVT in the United States every year. The incidence of DVT is higher among African-Americans compared to other racial groups.   Presenting Issues and Symptoms:  Around a week ago  Mr. McKenzie started complaining of discomfort in his left leg. A few days later  he noticed swelling and warmth along with a dull ache in the calf region. He also reported an intense cramping pain in his calf upon standing or walking.   Medical History:  Mr. McKenzie has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension which he manages through medication and a controlled diet. He has had a prior surgery for cataracts in both eyes two years back. Mr. McKenzie is a former smoker  having quit 15 years back and is occasionally consuming alcohol socially. He is also overweight which places him at additional risk for DVT.   Family History:  His father had suffered from stroke at an old age and his mother was diagnosed with diabetes and suffered from varicose veins. His only sibling  a brother  was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease in his early sixties. This family history may have predisposed Mr. McKenzie to his current DVT diagnosis.   Current Diagnosis:  After thorough examination by a physician  Mr. McKenzie's discomfort was not deemed to be a simple cramp. Ultrasonographic venography confirmed the presence of a blood clot in the deep veins of his left calf  confirming the diagnosis of DVT.   Plan of action:  Mr. McKenzie was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy. A Rivaroxaban regimen has been initiated for rapid and targeted anticoagulation. His dosage will be adjusted after a period of 3 weeks. Lifestyle changes such as reduced salt intake  a balanced diet  regular physical activity  and compression stockings were suggested to manage his current health situation better.  This case emphasizes the importance of early detection and management of Deep Vein Thrombosis  particularly in patients who have multiple risk factors like in the case of Mr. McKenzie.

Presentation:  The patient  Mrs. Alice Johnson  is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presented with complaints of acute onset  unilateral calf pain and mild swelling in her right leg over the past two days. Prior to her presentation  she had been observing a sedentary lifestyle due to a recent right hip fracture which she sustained after a minor fall at home about two weeks ago. She was discharged at home after a successful hip pinning surgery  and she has been less mobile since then.  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is currently on regular medication for these conditions  which include Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. There is no known drug allergy. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. Her women's health history indicates she is post-menopausal with no history of hormone replacement therapy.  Regarding her family history  her father had Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  which led to his death at the age of 74. Her mother is alive and well. Alice has two siblings  one brother diagnosed with high blood pressure  just like Alice  and a sister with no known health issues.  On examination  there is mild edema in her right leg  with mild erythema. There is tenderness in the calf muscle  but there is no palpable cord. Pulses are palpable and equal bilaterally. Bilateral lower limbs are warm with no heating.  D-dimer test was ordered  the result of which came back as high  indicating likely thrombosis. An Ultrasound Doppler was then performed which confirmed our suspicion and showed a thrombus in the right calf vein.   She was diagnosed with the right lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  categorized as a provoked DVT due to recent hip surgery and immobility. Alice was started on anticoagulants and was educated on the importance of mobilization and leg elevation.  This case highlights the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in patients with recent surgery or immobilization who present with unilateral leg pain  especially when associated with risk factors such as age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history of cardiac diseases. Active measures for venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis are crucial in the management of such patients.

Patient Profile:  Ms. Jane Doe  a 45-year-old Caucasian woman  is a sedentary office worker with a body mass index (BMI) of 30. She lives alone and does not have children. She was recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  which was confirmed through a venography procedure.  Medical History:  Ms. Doe has a history of hypertension  which has been managed with medication for the past 10 years. She is also pre-diabetic  with a diagnosis for the last two years  and has been managing her glucose levels via diet and exercise. Four years ago  the patient underwent an abdominal hysterectomy due to excessive uterine bleeding and the development of uterine fibroids.  Current Health Status:  Currently  Ms. Doe has reported persistent pain and swelling in her left lower leg for several days  which led to her seeking medical attention. Upon physical examination  the calf was warm to touch and there was a pronounced venous dilation. With the aid of a venogram  a DVT diagnosis was confirmed  and it was localized in the left popliteal and femoral veins. Aside from the leg symptoms  she also complained of occasional dizziness.  Family History:  A significant family history was revealed during the consultation. Her father had a heart attack at age 60  while her mother suffered a stroke at 67. An older sibling has Type 2 diabetes  and her younger sister has obesity-related complications. No instances of DVT or other blood clotting disorders were reported in the family.  Social History:  Ms. Doe is a life-long nonsmoker and does not take alcohol frequently. Her sedentary lifestyle involves long hours of sitting at her desk due to her job as an accounts officer at a local company. She does not engage in any form of regular physical activity.  Treatment Plan:  Ms. Doe was started on anticoagulant (warfarin) therapy and has been advised to limit her immobility. Activities such as short walks with compression stockings have been recommended. She has been assigned a dietitian to work on her meal plans alongside her pre-diabetic care  and a wellness coach to improve her physical activity. Regular follow-up appointments were scheduled  and she was advised to seek immediate medical care if she experienced symptoms like chest pain  shortness of breath  or hemoptysis  due to possible anticoagulation-related complications and/or pulmonary embolism.  This case illustrates the potential consequences of a sedentary lifestyle  particularly in individuals with existing risk factors such as hypertension  obesity  and a history of surgery; all of which are known risk factors for deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Gray  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  came into the clinic presenting symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Mr. Gray works as an accountant and leads a predominantly sedentary lifestyle. Apart from his work  he enjoys watching television and admits that he does not engage in any significant physical activities.  Past Medical History:  Previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  Mr. Gray has been under antihypertensive medication and statin therapy for the last 8 years. His regular medications include Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. His last annual check-up  six months ago  showed controlled blood pressure and cholesterol levels. There was no history of any surgery or blood clot related issues.  Family history:  Mr. Gray’s father passed away at the age of 70 from a stroke and his mother  now 85  is currently living with type 2 diabetes. Given his family history  Mr. Gray has an elevated genetic predisposition towards cardiovascular diseases.  Present Illness:  Recently  Mr. Gray noted persistent discomfort  swelling  and redness in his right lower leg. These symptoms were initially dismissed as the result of a cramp but later  the calf pain intensified  especially when walking which brought him in for the check-up.  Clinical observations:  Upon clinical evaluation  there is significant edema in his right calf and ankle. His right calf circumference is 3 cm larger than the left. There is mild erythema and the area is locally warm  suggesting local inflammation.  Plan:  The clinical findings and his lifestyle factors indicate a high probability of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Doctors have recommended the D-dimer blood test and duplex ultrasound for definitive diagnosis. If confirmed  anticoagulation therapy will be initiated.  Discussion:  DVT is a common condition  particularly in patients with limited mobility and those with a family history of clotting disorders. Physical examination  coupled with the patient’s history  can often provide a high degree of suspicion. In Mr. Gray’s case  his sedentary lifestyle  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension are major risk factors. His family history suggests a higher genetic risk for clotting disorders. Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment can decrease the risk of serious complications like pulmonary embolism. It also will be important to discuss with Mr. Gray lifestyle changes including increased physical activity that could decrease his risk for future DVT.  Conclusion:  A balance of clinical observations  patient history  and the diagnostic test will guide the effective management of Mr. Gray's condition  potentially mitigating the adverse outcomes associated with DVT and significantly improving his quality of life.

Patient Presentation:  Name: David Fisher Age: 68 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Teacher  Past Medical History:  David has a history of hypertension managed with lifestyle modifications and monthly follow-ups. He has also been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for ten years  for which he is on Metformin. He is an ex-smoker  having quit tobacco 7 years ago after a 25-year habit. He holds an occasional glass of wine over the weekend. There's no record of any previous surgical interventions.  Presenting Complaint: David presents with symptoms of left leg swelling and pain  which started gradually about a week ago. The pain is worse on standing for prolonged durations and has spontaneous bouts that linger throughout the day. He denies any recent travel  surgical procedures or previous similar episodes. He describes experiencing mild shortness of breath recently  but no chest pain.  Family History: David's father succumbed to a heart attack at the age of 72. His mother is 90 years old and has Alzheimer's disease. He has one sibling  a brother  who is 65 and is in general good health.   Examination & Evaluation: David is overweight with a BMI of 29. Upon physical examination  his left lower leg was noted to be moderately swollen  erythematous  and warm to touch compared with the right  and he demonstrated a positive Homan's sign. Vitals – BP 140/90 mmHg  heart rate 82/min  respiratory rate 16/min  temperature 98.6°F.  Serum D-Dimer levels were found significantly elevated. Doppler ultrasound of the left leg revealed a deep vein thrombosis in the posterior tibial vein.  Assessment & Plan: David was started on treatment with therapeutic dose low-molecular-weight heparin (Enoxaparin). The necessity for early mobilization  postural maneuvers and wearing compression stockings was explained. He was counseled about the possible risk of pulmonary embolism and advised to report immediately if symptoms such as chest pain or sudden shortness of breath develop. Instruction on the lifestyle modifications to control Type 2 Diabetes and hypertension was reinforced.   The social services team is involved to assess his home environment and provide necessary assistance for his medical condition. Outpatient follow-up in one week for monitoring his response to treatment has been scheduled.  Discussion: In summary  David is a 68-year-old male with a notable history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  who presented with symptoms consistent with DVT. The management plan prioritizes the immediate control of DVT and monitoring for potential complications. Due to his lifestyle and underlying conditions  David is at an increased risk; thus  a multidisciplinary approach has been adopted to ensure effective treatment and follow-up.   Informed by demographics  his age  sex  and race place him in a high-risk category for DVT. According to the literature  post-menopausal women have a slightly lower risk of DVT compared to men of the same age (White  R.). This patient's co-morbidity with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension further increases the risk  warranting careful management and follow-up.

Patient Information:  Mr. Richard Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a sedentary desk job  living in a suburban environment in California. He is widowed with two adult children living out of state. Mr. Smith is an occasional drinker and smoker. He has been independent in daily activities until recently when he started experiencing symptoms related to deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Presenting Issue:  Mr. Smith visited his primary care physician with the complaint of persistent swelling and a painful  tender sensation in his left leg. He mentioned intermittent periods of warmth in the region. No redness or discoloration was observed. Initially  these symptoms were less noticeable and intermittent but have become more pronounced over the last week.  Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension controlled with medication. He has been previously diagnosed with obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both managed with a combination of lifestyle interventions and medication. He underwent right hip replacement surgery six months ago.  Family History:  There is a notable family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father passing away from a myocardial infarction at 72 years old and a paternal uncle who suffered from recurring DVT. His two siblings have hypertension  and his mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed edema in the left calf with significant tenderness but without marked erythema or cyanosis. The measuring tape left an imprint when lifted away from his calf. His vital signs  including blood pressure  were within normal range due to his compliant approach to hypertension management. Blood investigation showed an increased D-dimer level.  Diagnosis:  Upon examination  the treating physician suspected deep vein thrombosis. Doppler ultrasonography of the left leg veins further confirmed the diagnosis  revealing a non-compressible sector in the left posterior tibial vein indicative of DVT.  Treatment:  Mr. Smith was immediately started on anticoagulation treatment with low-molecular-weight heparin. He was also prescribed compression stockings and advised to elevate his leg regularly. Lifestyle modifications  such as increasing physical activity and reducing salt and fat in his diet  were recommended.  Summary:  Deep vein thrombosis is a common yet serious condition. This case highlights the importance of considering a DVT diagnosis in a patient with unexplained leg swelling  especially with a history of recent surgery (hip replacement  in this case) and known risk factors (obesity  hypertension  family history). Crucially  it also demonstrates that immediate treatment is necessary to prevent more serious complications  such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Demographics: Mr. J.B. is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  residing in a suburban community in Colorado. He is married with three adult children. His mother had a history of stroke at the age of 75 and his paternal history is unknown. He has two brothers; the older one suffered myocardial infarction at the age of 64 and the younger one is healthy.  Presenting Problem: The patient primarily reports progressive swelling and pain in the left calf that started five days ago. The symptoms have been worsening  and he also reports slight shortness of breath on exertion.   Past Medical History: Mr. J.B. has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at the age of 50 and has been on Metformin since. He also has hyperlipidemia and hypertension controlled with a low-sodium diet  regular exercise  and medication (Lisinopril and Simvastatin). He underwent a hernia repair operation two years ago.  Social History: Mr. J.B. is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol during social events. He has been leading a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement two years ago.   Physical Examination: On examination  his left calf was swollen  warm  and red. His vital signs: BP 130/85 mmHg  HR 92 bpm  RR 18 breaths per minute  SpO2 97% on room air  and temperature 98.4°F. Cardiac and respiratory examination was within normal limits. Pedal pulses were equal and present bilaterally.   Investigations: Laboratory investigations were overall normal. However  the D-dimer test came back positive. An ultrasound of the lower extremity revealed a non-compressible left common femoral vein suggestive of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Plan and Diagnosis: Mr. J.B.'s signs  symptoms  positive D-dimer test  and ultrasound findings confirm the diagnosis of DVT. The treatment plan includes immediate anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and transitioning to oral anticoagulant such as warfarin.   Discussion: Mr. J.B.'s history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle puts him at higher risk for DVT. His current symptoms and findings add to the urgent need for intervention. The primary concern is to prevent a pulmonary embolism  which could potentially be life-threatening. It's advised that Mr. J.B. should be educated about the importance of regular exercise and maintaining his medications to manage his underlying conditions and reduce the risk of DVT's recurrence in the future.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old African-American male who works as a long-haul truck driver. He presents with unilateral leg swelling and pain for the past few weeks. He denies any history of trauma. He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  all of which are poorly controlled due to noncompliance with medication. He admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and has a BMI of 32. He has a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  with both his father and oldest brother having been diagnosed and treated.  Physical Exam and Findings: On physical examination  his right calf is swollen and erythematous  with warmth on touch. He has a positive Homans’ sign. His peripheral pulses are equal and intact bilaterally. His blood pressure is elevated at 158/95 mmHg and he has an irregular heart rate of 88 beats per minute.   Diagnostic Evaluation: Due to suspicion of DVT  he undergoes a Doppler Ultrasound which confirms the presence of a thrombus in his right popliteal vein. His complete blood count  liver function tests  and kidney function tests return within normal limits. However  his HbA1c is found to be 9.2% and his lipid profile is abnormal with elevated total cholesterol of 240mg/dL and LDL of 160mg/dL. A lower than average HDL of 35mg/dl was also observed.   Plan of Management:  The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy starting with parental anticoagulants (low molecular weight heparin) followed by oral anticoagulant (warfarin). Patient education was emphasized  particularly on the importance of medication compliance to manage his other chronic conditions. He was also advised for immediate lifestyle modifications including cessation of smoking  maintaining an active lifestyle and adopting a healthier diet to manage his co-morbidities.  Summary: A 68-year-old African-American male with medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with deep vein thrombosis. The patient's profession as a truck driver  sedentary lifestyle  history of smoking  and family history of DVT placed him at a higher risk. His diagnosis was made based on his symptoms  physical examination  and confirmed by a Doppler Ultrasound. His Management plan involves immediate anticoagulation therapy  better management of his chronic conditions  and lifestyle modifications.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Smith is a 58-year-old Caucasian male office worker living in San Francisco  California. He lives with his wife and has two adult children. He reports having smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 20 years  but has quit smoking 5 years ago. He consumes alcohol moderately and has a sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of his work.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 50 and Type II diabetes mellitus at 52. He is currently on Losartan 50mg daily for hypertension and Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes. Both conditions are well-managed  but he struggles with disciplining his diet and engaging in regular physical activities.  Recently  he underwent a full knee replacement surgery on his right leg due to severe osteoarthritis. He has been compliant with his medication regimen and physiotherapy sessions since the operation.  Family History:  His father died at the age of 65 due to myocardial infarction and his mother succumbed to colon cancer at the age of 70. His only sibling  a brother  is 60 years old and has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presented with pain and swelling in his right leg  which worsened over the past week. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath and occasional dizziness which he initially ignored but the symptoms persisted. He denies any history of trauma or injury to the leg.  Investigations & Diagnosis:  Physical examination revealed redness and warmth over the right calf muscle  along with tenderness on palpation. An ultrasound Doppler of the right leg showed a clot in the deep veins  confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). D-dimer levels were also elevated.  A Computerized Tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram showed small multiple blood clots in both lungs  consistent with pulmonary embolism.  Treatment:  Mr. Smith was admitted to the medical ward and anticoagulant therapy was started initially with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Later he was switched to oral anticoagulants (apixaban). His symptoms improved steadily with treatment.  Next Steps:  He was educated about the importance of medication compliance  the signs and symptoms of DVT and pulmonary embolism  and the need to seek immediate medical attention if they occur. He was also counselled on the importance of mobility and exercises and maintaining a healthy lifestyle to manage his other chronic conditions.  Risk factor modification strategies like weight management  regular exercise  limited alcohol consumption  and maintaining a diabetic-friendly diet were also discussed.   A follow-up appointment was scheduled for two weeks to monitor his progress and adjust therapy accordingly.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: Mr. Jenkins  a 68-year-old African-American male  was referred to the vascular clinic following an incidental finding of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Past Medical History: His past medical history was significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  stage 3 chronic kidney disease from hypertension  and a splenectomy following a road traffic accident 15 years ago. He had a 30-pack year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He has been on antihypertensive medications (calcium channel blockers and ACE inhibitors) and a bronchodilator for his COPD.  Complete Demographics: Mr. Jenkins is retired  lives alone in suburban Atlanta  Georgia. He held a job as a school bus driver before his retirement. He is widowed and has two adult children living out of state. Mr. Jenkins has Medicare and supplementary insurance through a retiree union benefit.  Presenting Complaint: He presented with no acute complaints and said he felt “just fine.” A recent abdominal ultrasound for an unrelated concern (unexplained weight loss) incidentally discovered an uncharacterized deep venous thrombosis in the lower abdomen.  Family History: His father died at 72 from a heart attack  and his mother died at 76 from stroke complications. He has a younger brother diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.  Physical Examination and Laboratory Results: Vital signs revealed blood pressure to be 139/85 mmHg with all other vital signs within normal rates. His BMI is 27. The physical examination was unremarkable except for reduced breath sounds bilaterally  consistent with his COPD. Labs showed mildly impaired kidney function  slightly raised D-dimer levels  and a Hemoglobin level of 12 g/dl.   Impression: Given his presentation and unprovoked  asymptomatic DVT on ultrasound  Mr. Jenkins was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Unprovoked DVT might indicate an underlying disorder such as a malignancy  especially since he recently experienced unexplained weight loss. We decided on a multidisciplinary approach with consultation from the oncology team and ordered further scans and blood tests to identify the possible causes. Besides  he is at high risk of pulmonary embolism due to his DVT and COPD  warranting a decision to initiate therapeutic anticoagulation.   Plan: Mr. Jenkins is scheduled for a CT scan and blood tests. We plan to begin anticoagulation therapy and are discussing various options  such as warfarin or direct oral anticoagulants. We also plan for monitoring  regular follow-ups  lifestyle changes  and potential referral to a nephrologist for his kidney disease.  This case demonstrates the need for vigilance and thorough investigation when dealing with unprovoked deep vein thrombosis  considering the significant comorbidities and risk factors present in this patient  including age  race  chronic kidney disease  and history of smoking.

Patient Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Demographic Details: John Brown is a 68-year-old  Caucasian male retired construction worker  who lives in the midwestern region of the United States. He is married with three adult children and five grandchildren  has adequate family support  and resides in a suburban neighborhood.   Presenting Complaint and History of Present Illness: Mr. Brown presented with rubor and edema in his left lower leg  which he noticed upon waking up. The onset was sudden  and he experienced a dull ache and a feeling of warmth in the area. He denies any injury or trauma to the area but admits to a recent 6-hour car ride. He denies any chest pain or shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Mr. Brown has a history of Type II Diabetes  controlled with metformin  and obesity (BMI of 30).
