Conclusion: The risk factor in Mr. J's case is his recent surgery  his age  race  family history of heart disease  and his chronic hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He falls into the high-risk category for DVT  illustrating the importance of prophylactic measures in high-risk patients  particularly during post-surgical periods.  Community health nurses should educate these at risk patients with DVT signs  symptoms  and the importance of immediate medical attention. Healthcare providers should integrate individual risk assessments before surgery  and ensure postoperative anticoagulation prophylaxis is appropriately provided to prevent DVT incidence whenever required.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 63-year-old African-American male  a retired construction worker from Kentucky  who has recently been diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Past Medical History: His medical history reveals that he has been hypertensive for the last ten years. He has also been living with type 2 diabetes for the past seven years  which has been mostly managed through frequently monitored diet and oral diabetic drugs. Five years ago  he underwent a cholecystectomy due to gallstones.  Social History: The patient is a former smoker  with a 25-pack-year history but quit smoking around five years ago after his cholecystectomy. He enjoys a glass of bourbon at night  admitting to drinking moderately. The patient is married  with three adult children and lives with his wife. He admits to a high-fat diet  without much physical activity since his retirement.  Family History: His father died at age 75 due to a stroke  his mother passed away at the age of 78 due to age-related issues  he has an older sister who is 65  also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and his younger brother  61  with no significant medical history. Cardiovascular diseases and diabetes appear to run in the family.  Current Presentation: The patient was admitted to the hospital with swelling  heaviness  and a throbbing sensation in his left leg that started gradually and has been worsening over the last two weeks. He has no history of recent travel  surgery  or immobilization. The patient does not recall any specific injury to his leg. His left calf circumference was significantly larger than the right  and the area was tender to touch  signaling DVT.   Diagnosis & Management: A compression ultrasonography  the first-line investigation for suspected DVT  confirmed the diagnosis. The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy in the form of low molecular weight heparin. Because of his medical history  he has high risk factors for developing DVT  including hypertension  diabetes  and previous surgery.   An interdisciplinary approach will be used in managing his case involving the primary physicians  endocrinologists for the diabetes  dieticians for weight and diabetes management  and physiotherapists to help with mobilization and exercise. The patient will also need to undergo lifestyle modification  including diet changes and regular light exercise. This is to ensure proper management of his presenting condition and underlying comorbidities.  Patient education will be crucial in this case. He will need to understand the importance of medication adherence and lifestyle changes to prevent the recurrence of DVT or any other related complications.   The patient will be closely monitored  and routine follow-ups will be required to assess the progress and effectiveness of his treatment plan.   References: 1) Heit JA et al.  (2017). Racial and regional differences in venous thromboembolism in the United States in 3 cohorts. Circulation  135(8)  700-712. 2) Kearon C et al.  (2016). Antithrombotic Therapy for VTE Disease: CHEST Guideline and Expert Panel Report. Chest  149(2)  315–352. 3) Pieper B  Kirsner RS  Templin TN  Birk TJ. (2007). Differential Diagnosis of Lower-Extremity Ulcers. Advances in Skin and Wound Care  20(5)  275-286.

Patient Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Profile:  The patient is Mr. X  a 65-year-old African American male  residing in the city of Chicago. He is a retired factory worker with no adequate exercise routine and has been a pack-a-day smoker for roughly 45 years. He is overweight with a BMI of 29. His diet is high in fats and sugars  and he has a moderate alcohol intake. His socioeconomic status is lower-middle class.   Past Medical History:  Mr. X has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both currently managed through medication. He had an acute myocardial infarction five years ago. His last check-up was three months ago  and all the vital parameters were within normal limits. Mr. X has no history of any surgical procedures.  Family History:  Both his father and grandfather succumbed to heart diseases in their late 60s. His mother is alive and has type II Diabetes Mellitus. He has an elder sister who is diagnosed with hypertensive heart disease.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. X presented with complaints of swelling  tenderness  and pain in his left lower leg that has been persistent for the past few days. There is no history of trauma or injury. On further probing  he also admitted to slight difficulty in breathing when performing daily activities  which he initially attributed to his smoking habit.  Examination & Diagnostic Findings:  Clinical examination revealed observable edema in his left leg  which was markedly warmer than the other. His breathing was shallow but within safe range. Based on the symptoms and risk factors  a Doppler ultrasound was performed which confirmed the suspicion of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in the left popliteal vein.  Conclusion:  Considering the patient's history  lifestyle  and age with the recent cardiovascular complication  he is categorized as high risk for DVT. The critical concern in such a situation is the risk of pulmonary embolism  which was corroborated by the onset of breathing difficulty. The patient was admitted for further evaluation and management  including anticoagulant therapy. Long term plan includes effective lifestyle modifications – quitting smoking  adopting a healthier diet  and incorporating regular exercise for weight management.    References:  “Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).” Mayo Clinic  Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research  6 Mar. 2018  www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/deep-vein-thrombosis/symptoms-causes/syc-20352557.   Heit  John A. “Epidemiology of Venous Thromboembolism.” Nature Reviews Cardiology  vol. 12  no. 8  2015  pp. 464–474.  doi:10.1038/nrcardio.2015.83.   Zöller  Bengt  et al. “Family History of Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) and Risk of Recurrent Hospitalization for VTE: A Nationwide Family Study in Sweden.” Journal of Thrombosis and Haemostasis  vol. 12  no. 4  2014  pp. 306–312.  doi:10.1111/jth.12524.

Patient Identification:  A 58-year-old African American male  employed as a long-haul truck driver.  Chief Complaint: The patient visits the ER complaining of swelling and discomfort in his left leg.  Present Illness History: The patient states the swelling has been progressing for the past few days  accompanied by a slight ache and warmth over the area. He denies any injury or trauma to the leg but confesses to long hours of driving with minimal chances for regular mobility.  Past Medical History: He reports hypertension (high blood pressure) diagnosed ten years ago  for which he is on medication (Lisinopril). He admits to intermittent compliance with his medication use. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed five years ago  managed with Metformin and lifestyle modifications. No history of other chronic illnesses or surgeries.  Medications: As mentioned  Lisinopril for hypertension and metformin for type 2 diabetes.   Family History: Both parents passed away due to heart disease. His older brother has diabetes  and his younger sister has been diagnosed with breast cancer.  Social History: Married with 3 children. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes a day for about 30 years. He denies any alcohol or drug abuse and there's no known history of exposure to any allergens or toxins. His occupation involves long hours of driving with limited physical activity.  Examination: Physical examination reveals an edematous  warm  and slightly tender left lower limb. The overlying skin is intact. The right lower limb is normal on inspection and palpation. No other significant findings on general physical and systemic examination.  Other Relevant Data: Blood pressure on admission: 160/100 mm Hg Random blood sugar on admission: 180 mg/dl  Diagnosis and Clinical Course: An ultrasound Doppler study of the left leg revealed a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient is immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with an injection of low molecular weight heparin  followed by oral warfarin therapy.  Summary and Planning: Considering the pronounced thrombus and his known risk factors: fixed position during work  history of smoking  hypertension  and diabetes  this patient's case is not surprising. Management will include continued anticoagulation for several months. In addition  he must be educated on lifestyle changes  including weight loss if his BMI is too high  regular exercise  and most importantly  taking frequent short breaks during driving for mobility. Long term  he must work on definitive cessation of smoking and control his blood pressure and blood sugar. The patient's case signifies the impact of lifestyle choices on venous thromboembolism risk.

Patient Overview:  Our patient  Mr. John Carlsen  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  living with his wife in suburban New York. He is a retired engineer with a long sedentary history in his working environment. Over the years  Mr. Carlsen has been relatively inactive with limited physical workouts. He has been indulging in a moderately healthy diet and is a non-smoker with occasional alcohol consumption.  Presenting Symptoms & Diagnosis: Mr. Carlsen presented to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling and pain in his right lower extremity  particularly in the calf region  over the previous week. His symptoms have progressively worsened over time. On examination  the right calf was swollen  warm  and tender. There was also evident pitting edema. Given these symptoms and risk factors  he was investigated and diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Past Medical & Family History: Mr. Carlsen has a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are well-controlled with medication. He does not have any known allergies and has never undergone major surgery. As it relates to his family history  his father died of a stroke at the age of 79 and his mother died of a heart attack at the age of 76.  Risk Factors: Mr. Carlsen falls into the increased risk group for DVT  primarily due to his age  sedentary lifestyle  history of hypertension  and diabetes. In the Western population  the incidence of DVT is higher in those over 60  specifically with a male predominance. Furthermore  research shows individuals with diabetes have an increased risk of thrombosis.   Plan: Anticoagulant therapy has been initiated promptly. The first-line treatment choice for DVT is typically low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) in conjunction with a Vitamin K antagonist like warfarin. Mr. Carlsen has been advised to increase his physical activity and maintain a balanced diet to manage his weight. His progress will be monitored closely and follow-up appointments have been scheduled.  In summary  Mr. Carlsen's case illustrates the risk associated with venous thromboembolism in the elderly population with a sedentary lifestyle and comorbid conditions like hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Early detection and effective management are crucial in preventing major complications.

Patient Profile: The patient  Mr. Rodriguez  is a 68-year-old Hispanic male hailing from San Antonio  Texas. He has been living with his wife and two grown-up children in the state for over 40 years. Rodriguez is a retired construction worker and has been categorized as overweight based on his Body Mass Index (BMI). The family's socioeconomic status is classified as middle class.  Presenting Problem:  Mr. Rodriguez presented at the clinic reporting fatigue  swelling  and pain in his right leg for the past five days  which have aggravated over the past day making it concerning for him and his family.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez has a history of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He had a Myocardial Infarction three years ago  managed medically at the same hospital  and smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years.  Family Medical History: The patient's father died due to a stroke at the age of 72  and his mother passed away from diabetes-related complications at the age of 78. His elder brother had Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) at the age of 65. His younger sister is living with type II diabetes and hypertension. His two children are currently healthy with no significant medical issues.  Examination and Diagnostic Evaluation: On examination  his right calf was tender  warm  and swollen as compared to the left one. Blood pressure was found to be elevated at 150/95 mmHg. Random blood glucose was recorded at 200 mg/dL. Doppler ultrasonography of the right leg revealed a deep venous thrombosis in the right calf veins.  Diagnosis:  Based on his clinical presentation and Doppler ultrasonography findings  Mr. Rodriguez was diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Considering his chronic history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and his past cardiovascular event  he had significant risk factors for DVT. His cigarette smoking and family history might have accelerated the process leading to his current condition.   Management and Treatment Plan: Mr. Rodriguez was admitted to the hospital and was started on anticoagulation therapy with a low molecular weight heparin  specifically Enoxaparin. Meanwhile  his diabetes was managed with insulin and his hypertension with Calcium Channel blockers. Nicotine replacement therapy was initiated for cigarette smoking cessation. His condition will be closely monitored  ensuring he receives adequate treatment based on improvements or deterioration in his condition.  Plan for Follow-up:  Mr. Rodriguez will be discharged when PT/INR value reaches the desired level. He would be prescribed long-term anticoagulation with warfarin. Lifestyle modifications including dietary modification  weight loss  and smoking cessation will be emphasized. Regular follow-up after discharge  which includes monitoring INR levels  blood pressure  and blood glucose  will be scheduled. Mr. Rodriguez and his family will also be educated about the importance of medication adherence and outpatient follow-up care.  In conclusion  Mr. Rodriguez's case highlights the importance of managing multiple comorbidities effectively  since poorly controlled chronic diseases add to an individual's risk for vascular complications  such as DVT. His case also exemplifies the impact of lifestyle practices  such as smoking  on vascular health and underlines the importance of lifestyle modifications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and a 10-year history of tobacco use (smoker). He was brought in by his daughter to the local emergency room upon noticing swelling and pain in his left leg which has been progressively worsening over the past two days. His daughter also mentioned his recent long-haul flight about six days ago. Mr. Johnson is retired  lives with his wife  and is originally from the Midwest.  Medical History:  Besides the already mentioned comorbidities  he reported an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) seven years ago  with good recovery and no complications since then. He is on regular medications such as Metformin for his diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Crestor for his elevated cholesterol levels. He also uses aspirin following his TIA. He denies any known allergies.  Family History:  His father died from a heart attack at the age of 65  while his mother died at 70 from a stroke. His younger brother  now 65  is currently living with heart disease. There exists a strong family history of cardiovascular disorders and hypertension.  On physical examination:  He was found to be in mild distress due to leg pain. His vital signs showed blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate 85 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  O2 saturation 97% on room air  and a temperature of 98.6°F. Lower extremity examination showed swelling  redness  tenderness  and warmth over the left calf area with a positive Homan's Sign.  Investigations:  D-dimer level was considerably elevated  and a venous Doppler ultrasound of the left lower extremity confirmed the presence of a clot in the deep venous system  diagnosing him with acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Clinical Impression:  Considering Mr.Johnson’s already high-risk profile (due to hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes)  his previous smoking history  a recent long-haul flight  and a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases  these factors have likely predisposed him to developing DVT. Immediate anticoagulation treatment was initiated and smoking cessation counselling was provided. A referral to a Vascular Specialist for outpatient follow-up was arranged. A comprehensive plan for lifestyle modifications was also discussed for long-term management of his chronic illnesses which might reduce future thrombotic risks.  Demographic Trends:  This case falls in line with epidemiological data that suggests DVT is more common in those aged over 60  those with comorbid conditions such as heart disease and diabetes  and in people with a history of smoking. African-American men  like Mr. Johnson  have been found to be at a slightly higher risk of DVT compared to their Caucasian counterparts.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 60-year-old African American male with a history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and obesity presents to the clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in his left calf for the past several days. He describes the pain as constant  cramp-like  and increasing in severity. There is no history of recent trauma or injury. He has no known allergies and takes metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension. Recent physical activity has been limited due to COVID-19 lockdown measures. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough.   Demographics: Mr. Smith is a retired veteran living with his wife in an urban area. He has a history of smoking (1 pack/day for 20 years  quit 15 years ago). He consumes alcohol occasionally  generally limited to holidays and is not engaged in regular physical activity. His nutritional choices are poor  often favoring fast food due to its convenience.  Family History: His father had a history of myocardial infarction at an early age and his mother was diagnosed with breast cancer. None known for thrombotic or clotting disorders.  Clinical Examination: On the physical examination  Mr. Smith is obese (BMI- 32)  with a BP of 145/90 mmHg  pulse 82/min and regular  and respiratory rate of 18  regular with oxygen saturation 98% at room air. The left calf is visibly swollen and warm with mild erythema compared to the right. Palpation reveals tenderness along the course of the left posterior tibial and popliteal veins. The rest of the cardiac  pulmonary and abdominal examination was unremarkable.  Investigations:  Venous Doppler ultrasound study of the left lower extremity shows evidence of an intraluminal clot in the left popliteal vein. A D-Dimer test was also high.   Diagnosis: The diagnosis of left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is made based on clinical symptoms and Ultrasound findings and supported by high D-Dimer level.  Plan: 1) To start anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs)  as per current guidelines. 2) As outpatient management is possible  educate the patient and caregivers about the signs of DVT and Pulmonary Embolism (PE) and when to seek further help. 3) Encourage lifestyle modifications like healthier nutritional choices  regular physical activity  and maintaining optimal weight. 4) Refer to a dietitian and a physical therapist. 5) Regular follow-ups for monitoring coagulation status and adverse effects of anticoagulants. 6) Coordinate care with his primary care practitioner to optimize control of his diabetes and hypertension.  7) Long-term management will be with oral anticoagulants for a minimum of 3 months  after which the decision to continue therapy will be based on his risk for recurrence.   General demographic information has been illustrated as per statistical representation in real-life scenarios.

Patient Overview: J. Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the emergency department complaining of severe pain and swelling in his right leg below the knee. The patient works as a truck driver and leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle. He admits to a heavy smoking habit (a pack a day) and has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both his father and grandfather having had myocardial infarctions in their sixties.   Past medical history: Mr. Smith has been previously diagnosed with obesity (BMI 35)  hypertension  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for which he has been managing with oral antidiabetic medication  glycemic control diet  and antihypertensive medication respectively. He has also been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia but has been non-compliant with statin therapy. Despite multiple consultations from his primary care physician  Mr. Smith has not significantly changed his lifestyle or smoking habits. He has no known drug allergies.  Present Complaint: Mr. Smith presents with a 3-day history of worsening  unilateral leg pain  and swelling. He noted the onset after a long truck drive. Also  there is discoloration of the leg and warmth over the swelling area. He denies having chest pain  shortness of breath  or any previous episodes of similar symptoms.  Examination: On examination  his vitals are stable  but his right leg appears notably swollen  erythematous  and warmer than the left. A palpable cord is felt along the course of the deep veins. A Homan's sign was positive. His remaining physical examination was unremarkable.  Lab findings: His blood work shows D-dimer levels exceed the normal range at 750 ng/mL (normal range 0-500ng/mL). An ultrasound Doppler study confirmed a thrombus in the right popliteal vein  confirming the deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Treatment: Mr. Smith has been treated with low molecular weight Heparin (Enoxaparin) in the emergency room. He was then switched over to oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban) with suggestions for lifestyle changes and therapeutic exercises. He has been given advice regarding compression stockings  leg elevation exercises  and the importance of regular movements to avoid prolonged immobilization.   Conclusion: Mr. Smith's case is a common presentation of deep vein thrombosis  which is often associated with prolonged immobilization  obesity  and smoking. His past medical history places him at high risk for DVT. His management involves both pharmacological intervention to resolve the current DVT and lifestyle changes to mitigate future risks. Patient education regarding his condition and the importance of adherence to medication and lifestyle modifications form an integral part of his management plan.

Case Presentation:  Demographics: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. Barbara Jones.  Presenting complaint: Mrs. Jones was admitted to the hospital for severe leg pain and visible swelling in her left lower limb.   History of presenting complaint: She has been experiencing discomfort in her left leg for the past 2 ½ weeks. She described the pain as a constant dull ache made worse by walking or standing for long periods.  Past medical history: Five years ago  Mrs. Jones was prescribed warfarin for atrial fibrillation. She has been taking the medication as prescribed without any side effects. In addition  she was diagnosed with type-2 diabetes 10 years ago but is under good control with diet and Metformin. She had a transient ischemic attack about two years ago but thankfully had no detrimental residual effects.   Social History: Mrs. Jones is a retired teacher living with her husband of 45 years. She used to smoke in her younger days but quit 30 years ago. She admits to having a glass of wine with dinner. She leads an active lifestyle despite her age but has been less mobile recently due to leg pain.  Family History:  Both of her parents died in their 80s—her mother from stroke and her father from colon cancer. Her older brother is alive and has a history of heart disease and her sister died from breast cancer at age 60.  Examination: Physical examination revealed a visibly swollen and warm left lower limb. Her leg was tender to touch  particularly in the calf  and the limb was reddish-purple in color. Range of motion was limited due to pain and swelling.   Investigations: An ultrasound Doppler was ordered which confirmed the presence of a clot in the left popliteal vein  indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Issues/Presentation: Mrs. Jones is at an increased risk for DVT due to her age and history of atrial fibrillation which was being treated with warfarin. Being less mobile due to pain is a known risk factor for DVT as well. Her left-sided DVT requires immediate management to prevent possible complications  like pulmonary embolism. The risks and benefits of changes to her current anticoagulation therapy will need to be carefully weighed and explained.  We can infer that Mrs. Jones' age  history of atrial fibrillation  transient ischemic attack  type-2 diabetes  and recent immobility are predisposing factors for her DVT  and her management will have to be planned accordingly to prevent it from recurring or causing further complications. Her family history of heart disease and stroke together with personal medical history call for continuous monitoring and preventative interventions.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Z  a male aged 62 years from a suburban background came to ER with complaints of pain  swelling  and redness of his left lower leg for the past one week. He is a Caucasian male. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which were being managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. Apart from these  he also has a history of obesity with a BMI of 32. He denies history of any surgery or immobilization for prolonged periods and any recent travel. He has no known drug allergies.  He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and consumes alcohol socially. Until recently  he used to work in a setup where he had a sedentary lifestyle. Until the symptoms worsened ahead of his ER visit  patient's physical activity was severely limited due to his workload.  His family history reveals that his father had suffered from myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and his elder sister was undergoing treatment for pulmonary embolism. There was no history of malignancy  diabetes mellitus or any inherited coagulation disorders in the family.   On closer examination  Doppler ultrasonography of the left lower extremity was performed which confirmed deep vein thrombosis in the left posterior tibial vein. No signs of pulmonary embolism were presented.   Initial laboratory tests suggested raised levels of D-dimer. Complete blood picture  liver function test  renal function test and other routine investigations were within normal limits.   Considering the patient history and clinical findings  he was diagnosed with unprovoked deep vein thrombosis. His CHA2DS2-VASc score was calculated and was found to be 3 (1 for age above 65  1 for hypertension and 1 for vascular disease)  and HAS-BLED score was 2 (1 for hypertension and 1 for excessive alcohol intake)  suggesting high risk of both stroke and bleed.   The presence of unprovoked DVT along with a positive family history signaled towards a possible inherited thrombophilia  which needed further investigations.   In conclusion  Mr. Z’s complaint required an urgent yet precise approach due to his condition making him vulnerable especially with his past medical history  personal habits and family history. The healthcare professionals managed to evaluate Mr. Z with a timely diagnosis and created a treatment plan for his deep vein thrombosis which included anticoagulation therapy along with lifestyle modifications including regular exercise  healthy diet  quitting smoking and alcohol consumption.

Patient Presentation  The patient under review is a 57-year-old Caucasian female named Lisa. She hails from Miami  Florida  where she lived alone  active in her profession as an accountant. With a BMI of 29.5  she is presently overweight.   Past Medical History  Lisa's medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both effectively managed with medication for the past ten years. She had undergone a hysterectomy 15 years ago due to the emergence of benign fibroids. Her latest complete blood count  lipid profile  and liver function tests were all within normal ranges. Smoker for 20 years but quit 10 years ago. There is no history of drug or alcohol use.  Family History   Lisa’s family history is significant for heart disease; her father suffered from myocardial infarction at 65  and her younger brother has recently been diagnosed with early-onset coronary artery disease. They both have a history of cigarette smoking. Her mother is alive and relatively healthy at 85  with arthritis being her only significant health issue.   Presenting Problem  Lisa presented with an unusually swollen  painful left leg that started roughly two days ago. The pain is characterized as being constant  especially when maneuvering the step. There was no associated trauma or injury. Over-the-counter medications provided no respite. Reports associated mild shortness of breath  for the last day  that worsens at rest  but no chest pain or palpitations.  Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  Lisa's left leg was visibly swollen and warm to the touch as compared to her right leg. She exhibited a positive Homans' sign indicative of DVT. Her pain was aggravated on dorsiflexion of her left foot. The finding of an enlarged tender calf muscle  a sign of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) was noted. Her heart rate was slightly elevated at 98 bpm  but her blood pressure was within normal range. ECG showed sinus tachycardia but no signs of right ventricular strain.   Working Diagnosis  Considering Lisa’s age  family history  non-mobile work nature  and her present symptoms and clinical findings  a tentative diagnosis of Left lower extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) was made.  Further Diagnostic Steps and Treatments   Lisa was advised to undergo a Doppler ultrasound of her lower extremities to confirm the diagnosis of DVT. Treatment with low molecular weight heparin was initiated immediately to prevent clot propagation  and arrangements were made for oral anticoagulation therapy. Lisa was also educated about the importance of lifestyle modifications  weight management  and regular physical activities for long-term DVT prevention.  This case highlights the importance of considering Deep Vein Thrombosis in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling and pain  particularly if they have risk factors such as a sedentary lifestyle  advancing age  and a family history of cardiovascular events.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old African American male with a BMI of 28  non-smoker  lives in an urban area  and is a retired engineer.  Identification Data: The patient reported to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of increasing pain and swelling in his left lower leg for the past two days.  Chief Complaints: Pain in the left calf  which is 7/10 in intensity  worsening on walking  and associated with swelling in the same region. No reported fever  trauma  or recent surgeries.  History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing symptoms suggestive of left lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) for the last two days. He first noticed mild calf pain that has gradually worsened and is now associated with swelling and warmth.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known case of hypertension for the past ten years  controlled on a calcium channel blocker. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia being managed with statins and non-insulin-dependent diabetes. No previous illness suggestive of any hematological disease or coagulopathies. No history of deep vein thrombosis  pulmonary embolism  or any other cardiovascular diseases.  Family History: His father had a stroke at the age of 72. His mother suffered from type 2 diabetes and atherosclerosis. No known family history of blood clotting disorders.  Social History: He lives alone with limited mobility due to chronic arthritic pain. His alcohol intake is minimal  does not smoke or use any recreational drugs. He consumes a diet high in saturated fats and low in fiber.  Current Medications: Amlodipine 5mg daily  Atorvastatin 40mg daily  and Metformin 500mg twice daily.  Physical Examination: Left lower limb is swollen  red  and warm compared to the right. Calf muscle tenderness noted. Bilateral ankle and knee joints show chronic degenerative changes.  Investigations: D-dimer test reported high levels. An ultrasound of the left lower extremity confirmed acute DVT in the left popliteal vein.  Diagnosis: The patient is diagnosed with Left Lower Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Discussion: The patient's symptoms along with his risk factors of age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  immobilization  and family history of atherosclerosis predispose him to DVT. Reduced physical activity due to arthritis could have led to sluggish venous blood flow  contributing to the development of DVT. It is crucial to treat it promptly to prevent complications such as a pulmonary embolism.   Plan: Immediate initiation of anticoagulation  patient education regarding the importance of mobility  dietary adjustments  and better management of chronic illnesses. Request the consultation of a Hematologist for further evaluation and treatment of Venous Thromboembolism and Nutritionist for dietary recommendations. The benefits and risks of the anticoagulant therapy will be discussed with the patient to ensure understanding and adherence.   Is there a mistake or incomplete information in the representation?

Patient Profile: Name: Jane Doe Age: 55 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office Clerk Residential Area: Urban Smoker: Yes  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset pain and swelling in her left leg for the past 2 days.  Medical History: Mrs. Doe has a history of Type II diabetes for the past 20 years  is post-menopausal and is also moderately obese  with a BMI (Body Mass Index) of 32. She reports no regular physical activity. No history of past surgeries.  Family History: Her father died from myocardial infarction at 68  and her mother is alive with chronic heart failure. A recent familial death found an uncle who died after pulmonary embolism.   Investigations: D-dimer test results show high levels. Duplex ultrasound confirms the presence of a clot in the deep veins of the left leg that is consistent with DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis). Chest x-ray and EKG were normal.  Diagnosis: On the basis of Mrs. Doe's medical history  presenting symptoms  and the results of her DVT specific tests  she is diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Discussion:  The patient's risk factors for DVT includes her sedentary lifestyle (she reports no regular physical activity)  her obesity  and her history of smoking. The history of cardiovascular problems in her family could also be a contributing factor.   The patient is actively smoking  which enhances the formation of blood clots that can restrict or block blood flow and induce Deep Vein Thrombosis. Similarly  obesity is a known risk factor well-established in the literature. It increases pressure in the veins of the pelvis and legs and raises the risk of DVT. Her sedentary lifestyle may also contribute to the development of DVT.  Lastly  hormonal changes in postmenopausal women and long-term use of hormone replacement therapy can increase the risk of DVT  as seen in various studies.  Her DVT condition if untreated could also lead to a life-threatening condition known as thromboembolism (when the clot breaks away from the inner wall of the vein and travels to the lungs).  Management: Since Mrs. Doe is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis  her management should include anticoagulant therapy  lifestyle modification including smoking cessation  and regular exercise. Weight loss should also be considered.   A follow-up should be scheduled after a month  and DVT symptoms should be closely monitored throughout the treatment.   Conclusion: DVT is a common but serious medical condition  and its successful management involves reducing risk factors and continued medical care. Mrs. Doe's case underscores the importance of regular physical activity  careful observation of symptoms  and thorough medical history investigation in the diagnosis and treatment of DVT.

Patient Presentation  The patient we will be discussing today is a 68-year-old African American female  Mrs. Johnson  recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Mrs. Johnson is a retiree living in New York City  currently residing with her husband of 40 years.  She has a history of type II diabetes mellitus managed with Metformin  hypertension controlled with Lisinopril  and recurrent Varicose Veins that had not needed any surgical interventions yet. Mrs. Johnson had been taking an aspirin daily following her doctor's advice to prevent a heart event  considering her age and chronic conditions.  She has an unfortunate family history of cardiovascular diseases  with both parents having suffered myocardial infarctions in their late 60s  and her elder brother passing away at the age of 47 due to a stroke. Both her parents and her brother shared common risk factors of being overweight and having uncontrolled hypertension.  Mrs. Johnson presented to the ER with excruciating pain in the left lower limb  starting from the calf  reaching up to the thigh. The leg was swollen  bluish-red  and warm to touch. She had lost some mobility in the leg due to this and also noticed a slight shortness of breath since morning. On questioning  she revealed that she had recently traveled to Europe  a 9-hour flight  about a week ago for her grandson's graduation  and had been fairly immobile throughout.  Her prolonged immobility  existing medical conditions such as hypertension  diabetes  known varicose veins  combined with her family history and older age  immediately raised red flags for DVT. Ultrasound imaging confirmed the same  revealing a clot in the deep vein of her left leg.  Mrs. Johnson's case links the known risk factors of DVT  like older age  extended periods of immobility  history of varicose veins  and other cardiovascular diseases. Her race and gender do not significantly influence her DVT risk  but her familial history of cardiovascular diseases  obesity  and hypertension within the family cannot be overlooked. Increased awareness and active measures against prolonged immobility during travel  managing body weight  and stricter control over chronic conditions like diabetes and hypertension  could prove to be critical in preventing DVT and related complications in such patients.

Patient Profile: The patient in this case study  Mr. A.G.  is a 57-year-old Caucasian man from a middle-income background. He is a retired engineer and lives with his wife. He has three adult children and five grandchildren  and enjoys woodworking and fishing during his leisure time. The patient has a history of hypertension  which is being managed with medication: atenolol 50mg once daily.   Presenting Problem: Mr. A.G. presented to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of increasing discomfort  redness  and swelling in his right lower leg for the past two days. He also reported experiencing mild shortness of breath exacerbated by exertion.  Physical Exam & Test Results: A physical examination of his right lower extremity revealed warm skin  erythema  mild edema  and tenderness along the distribution of the calf muscles. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right popliteal vein.  Past Medical History: Mr. A.G.'s past medical history reveals that he has controlled hypertension for the past ten years. He also underwent knee replacement surgery on his right knee about 4 weeks ago. His medical history is otherwise unremarkable.  Family History: Regarding his family history  his father passed away at the age of 70 due to a stroke  and his mother died at the age of 75 due to complications from breast cancer. His sister has well-controlled type 2 diabetes.  Social History: Mr. A.G. has been a non-smoker for the past 30 years. He admits to social drinking but denies any substance abuse. He is normally quite active but his physical activity had declined after his knee replacement surgery. His diet is predominantly balanced with a high intake of fruits  vegetables  and lean proteins.  Discussion: Given Mr. A.G.'s recent knee surgery  immobility  and presenting symptoms  he is at high risk for developing DVT. His hypertension also represents a potential risk. Despite his history of controlled hypertension  his post-operative sedentary behavior combined his recent symptoms led to the development of DVT. Therefore  an individualized treatment plan which includes anticoagulation therapy and lifestyle modification is required to manage his DVT and decrease the chance of recurrence and complications. His case emphasizes the need for appropriate post-operative care and prophylaxis in preventing venous thromboembolism in patients undergoing major orthopedic procedures such as knee replacement.

Patient Profile: Patient: Mr. Hamilton Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Accountant Residential Area: Urban Suburb Marital Status: Widower  Medical History: Patient diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 diabetes for the last 15 years. His medications include oral anti-diabetic agents and calcium channel blockers. Past records show he was also treated for a coronary artery disease about three years ago  with no recent complications.   Presenting Problem:   Mr. Hamilton presented with pain  redness  and swelling in his left lower leg. He described the pain as a sharp  constant ache. Symptoms started about four days ago  and have progressively worsened. Patient also reports mild shortness of breath and chest discomfort.  Family History:  Father had a history of myocardial infarction and mother suffered from a stroke; both had a history of hypertension. The patient has a brother who is currently on anticoagulation therapy due to recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Social History: The patient is a retired accountant and now lives alone after his wife passed away a couple of years back. He is a former smoker (quit twenty years ago)  drinks alcohol occasionally and has no history of drug use. His activity level is generally low; he spends much of his day seated reading or watching television. He has a diet rich in red meat and processed foods.  Examination & Diagnostic Evaluation: On examination  the left lower limb was visibly swollen  red and warm. His vital signs were stable albeit having slightly elevated blood pressure. An urgent Doppler ultrasound confirmed the presence of DVT in the left popliteal vein. A D-Dimer test was also conducted  revealing high levels  which further supported the diagnosis of DVT. Due to his reported chest discomfort and shortness of breath  a CT-pulmonary angiography was done to rule out pulmonary embolism  which confirmed that there was no PE.  Plan: The diagnosis of DVT and risk factors like advanced age  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  diabetes  and family history of DVT certainly advocate for anticoagulation therapy. A hematologist's consult should be obtained regarding the initiation of anticoagulation therapy  possibly low molecular weight Heparin (e.g.  Enoxaparin) or a direct oral anticoagulant.  Continued monitoring of his diabetes and hypertension is necessary  and a healthier diet and increased physical activity need to be encouraged. Additionally  as Mr. Hamilton lives alone  he may need home health support  at least in the initial phase of his treatment. Regular follow-ups are also suggested with the multidisciplinary team to manage this patient most effectively.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. X is a 55 year old Caucasian male who presented to A&E complaining of acute onset pain  swelling and warmth of the left lower extremity.   Past Medical History:  He has a medical history of chronic atrial fibrillation for which he was supposed to be taking oral anticoagulation therapy  but he had stopped medication three months prior due to reasons not well-known. He also has a history of high blood pressure  which is currently managed with ACE inhibitors. He has Type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with Metformin. Moreover  he has a history of obesity with a BMI of 32 and a smoker for the past 30 years with a pack year history of 20. No known drug allergies.   Demographics:  The patient lives alone and is an insurance advisor by profession  meaning he has a mainly sedentary lifestyle. He is a widower with two adult children who live out of state.  Family History:  Father passed away at the age of 62 due to myocardial infarction and his mother  aged 80  is alive with a history of hypertension. His older brother  aged 60  had a recent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.   Clinical History:  Two days prior to presentation  Mr. X noticed increasing warmth  swelling  and pain in his lower leg. He initially attributed this discomfort to a pulled muscle from when he was trying to move his furniture. Upon noticing redness and increased swelling  he sought medical attention. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  cough or symptoms related to any other system.   Examination:  On examination  his left calf is noticeably swollen  warm and erythematous. Positive Homan’s sign on the left  but negative on the right. His vital signs upon admission were: temperature: 37.2°C  pulse rate: 85 beats per minute  respiration: 16 per minute  blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg.    Investigations:  Lab results show an elevated D-dimer level. An immediate ultrasound was carried out which confirmed the presence of a clot in the left popliteal vein consistent with DVT.   Diagnosis and Treatment:  Mr. X was diagnosed with acute deep vein thrombosis most likely precipitated by cessation of anticoagulant therapy for his atrial fibrillation  his sedentary lifestyle due to his profession  obesity  diabetes  and a potential genetic predisposition (as suggested by the brother’s DVT). He was promptly started on IV heparin and will be transitioned onto warfarin  encouraged to lose weight and quit smoking. Patient education about the importance of adherence to medication was also carried out.   Prognosis and Follow Up: Mr. X will need close follow-up monitoring for signs of post-thrombotic syndrome and pulmonary embolism. He will also need to take anticoagulant therapy for a minimum of 3 months and probably longer considering his risk factors. With lifestyle modification  the prognosis is fair and chances of recurrence can be minimized.

Patient Profile: The patient under consideration is Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the hospital complaining of severe left calf pain  which has been worsening over the past week. His body mass index indicates he is overweight  with a value of 30 kg/m2. He is a lifetime non-smoker and non-alcoholic. He comes from a middle-class socioeconomic background.  Medical History: Mr. Smith is a known case of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is well-controlled with metformin. A year ago  he underwent total hip replacement surgery after a fall in his house. His postoperative period was uneventful and continued his daily low dose of aspirin.   Family History: He has a known family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father had coronary artery disease and his elder sister was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post-pregnancy.   Present Illness: As per his statement  the pain is constant and somewhat relieved by elevating the leg. Mr. Smith's occupation as a truck driver forces him to be sedentary for extended periods during cross-country trips. Over the past week  he had been on a long trip  driving almost 6-7 hours at a stretch with little movement.   Physical Examination: Physical findings include left calf swelling which is warm to the touch and painful on deep palpation compared to the right calf. A positive Homan's sign was also demonstrated. No skin changes or ulcers were noted.   Investigations: Venous Doppler of lower extremities confirmed the presence of thrombus in the left posterior tibial vein  consistent with deep vein thrombosis. Coagulation profile showed increased D-dimer level.   Management: Intravenous Low Molecular Weight Heparin was initiated. He was admitted for further management and monitoring for complications such as pulmonary embolism. Patient's condition and symptoms started improving with the treatment.  Education and Follow-up: Information regarding his diagnosis was thoroughly explained to Mr. Smith  including the possible life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism. He was advised to follow up routinely  maintain better control of his diabetes  lose weight  and take frequent breaks during long drives for movement to prevent the recurrence of DVT.   The case presented above is a representative of a typical DVT patient  taking into account factors like age  gender  sedentary lifestyle  overweight  major surgery in the past year  and a family history of DVT which are known to increase the risk. In addition to these  his diabetic condition can cause changes in blood consistency and flow making him more susceptible to the condition.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 67 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Residence: Urban dwelling in Boston  Massachusetts  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe presented with a new onset left calf pain for 5 days  continuously differing in intensity. He also reported swelling and warmth over the same leg.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe suffers from Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the last 10 years. He is on medication for both conditions. 3 years ago  he underwent a total knee replacement surgery of the right knee after a fall but recovered well post-surgery. He is a former smoker and quit 20 years ago  with a smoking history of 30 pack-years. He also has a history of occasional alcohol use.   Family History: His father died of a stroke at the age of 75  and his mother died from breast cancer at 82. He has two siblings  a sister diagnosed with breast cancer and a brother who suffers from coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination: On examination  he displayed signs of left lower limb swelling with mild erythema. A positive Homans sign was noted. The right leg appeared normal with no swelling or signs of inflammation.  Investigations: Lab investigations revealed slightly elevated D-Dimer levels. A Doppler ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of a deep vein thrombosis in the left femoral vein.   Management & Follow-up: He was initiated on anticoagulation therapy (Low Molecular Weight Heparin followed by Warfarin)  along with instructions for leg elevation and wearing compression stockings to reduce swelling and relieve symptoms. He was also referred to a nutritionist for dietary advice related to his diabetes management  and to a physiotherapist for exercises to improve his leg strength and circulation. A follow-up appointment was scheduled for a week later to reassess his condition and the efficacy of the treatment.  Summary: Mr. Doe is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes  presenting with a 5-day history of left calf pain. He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis and started on anticoagulation therapy. His treatment strategy revolves around controlling symptoms  preventing propagation of the clot  and reducing the risk of recurrence and complications. He is due for a follow-up in a week to assess his progress.

Patient Profile: Name: Mrs. Jane Miller Age: 67 years  Sex: Female Race: Caucasian  Marital Status: Widowed  Occupation: Retired school teacher  Residence: St. Louis  MO  Chief Complaint: Progressive swelling and tenderness in the left lower limb for about one week.  History of Present Illness: Mrs. Miller has been experiencing discomfort and swelling in her left leg  particularly calf  for the past week. She did not report any sudden onset of pain  redness  or sensation of warmth in her swollen limb. No report of associated shortness of breath or chest pain.  Medical History: Diagnosed with Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus (known diabetic for 10 years). Controlled hypertension for the last five years. No previous personal history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE). No recent surgeries. She sustained a lower extremity fracture five years ago  but recovery was successful with no complications. She does not smoke and has a Body Mass Index (BMI) within the normal range for her height and age.  Family History: Mother succumbed to stroke at 75 years  noted as hypertensive. Father died of a heart attack at 80 years. Her elder sister had an episode of DVT 13 years ago. She denies any family history of inherited thrombophilias  bleeding disorders  or abnormal clotting problems. No known family history of malignancies.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the left leg was significant for swelling  particularly in the calf region. There was localized tenderness and the patient expressed discomfort when the calf muscles were compressed during the Homan's sign test. No discernible difference in skin temperature when comparing both lower limbs. No visible venous distention or varicose veins. An ultrasound examination confirmed the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower limb  involving the popliteal and femoral veins.  Medications: She is currently on Metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes and Lisinopril 10 mg once daily for hypertension.  Conclusion: Mrs. Miller's age  coupled with her known diabetic status and family history of DVT present risk factors for her diagnosis. She falls within the highest demographic for DVT (elderly  Caucasian  female). She is currently being started on a therapeutic regimen of anticoagulation therapy and lifestyle modifications.   References: 1. Heit JA  et al. Risk Factors for Deep Vein Thrombosis and Pulmonary Embolism. Arch Intern Med. 2000;160(6):809–815. 2. Silverstein MD  et al. Trends in the incidence of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism: a 25-year population-based study. Arch Intern Med. 1998;158(6):585-593.  Note: This brief presentation is based on a hypothetical patient profile.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile  Name: Anonymous Age: 67 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired  Presenting Complaint:  Patient presented with complaints of increased swelling  tenderness  warmth  and redness on his right lower leg. He reported feeling weak and experiencing mild  intermittent chest pain for several days.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and was a smoker for 40 years before he quit 10 years ago. He also reported occasional alcohol consumption. He underwent hip replacement surgery two months prior.  Family History:  His mother died from heart disease. His father had a stroke at the age of 75. His older sibling died from a pulmonary embolism.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his right lower leg was swollen  red  and tender to touch. He was afebrile  with a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg.   Investigations:  A Doppler ultrasound examination of the lower extremities displayed a blood clot in the right calf vein which confirmed the diagnosis of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). A D-dimer test was also performed which was found to be elevated  signaling the presence of an intense coagulation process.   Treatment and Follow up:  Patient was started on anticoagulation therapy immediately with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and oral warfarin. Although initially resolved  the swelling and pain started to gradually reappear. An inferior vena cava filter was inserted to prevent pulmonary embolism.   Summary:  This is a case of a 67-year-old man diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis  with risk factors including a recent hip replacement surgery and personal habits such as smoking and alcohol consumption. Early diagnosis and the prompt start of anticoagulation therapy were crucial in the management of his condition. With such demographic representation  the incidence of DVT found in literature is about 1 per 1000 per year  however  the risk of DVT increases after the age of 60-65.   Social Determinants of Health:  Considering the social determinants of health  the patient being a retired individual may have led to a sedentary lifestyle  contributing to his medical conditions. His socio-economic status might have allowed him to take on habits like smoking and occasional drinking. It has been established in various studies that these are risk factors for deep vein thrombosis. Continuing efforts remain crucial to heighten the awareness of DVT  especially among those with multiple risk factors in order to prevent morbidities and mortalities associated with complications like pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Smith  a 55-year-old African-American male  comes to the clinic complaining of a prolonged dull pain  swelling  and redness in his right lower leg since last week. He reported sitting for prolonged periods due to the nature of his work (long-haul truck driver)  which indicates a sedentary lifestyle. He is hypertensive  a condition he has been managing with medication for the past ten years. Mr. Smith admits occasional smoking and alcohol consumption. He denies any allergies or current medications.  Family History:  His mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and his father had several heart ailments  suggesting that some of the genetic and lifestyle risk factors associated with DVT are present in his family history.  Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  there is pronounced swelling of the right leg compared to the left  with the skin over the gastrocnemius muscle having a warm  erythematous appearance. The patient rates the pain 6 out of 10 on the pain scale. Breathing and heart rates are within normal ranges. No chest pain or symptoms of short breath are reported.  Investigation and Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's history and symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis is made. To confirm the condition  a Doppler ultrasound is ordered and showed a non-compressible venous segment in the right popliteal vein  confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.  Treatment Strategy:  He is prescribed oral anticoagulation therapy (Rivaroxaban) to treat the existing clot and to prevent any pulmonary embolism. Lifestyle changes are suggested. This includes cessation of smoking and alcohol  an increase in physical activities  and positional changes during his long drives. He is also made aware of the importance of regular follow-up visits to monitor his condition.  Concluding Summary:  Mr. Smith’s case is a typical example of DVT  consistent with general demographics in literature. NYC epidemiologic studies show the prevalence of DVT often related to certain factors such as a sedentary job  long sitting  and a history of vascular diseases  as seen in Mr. Smith. His African-American race heightens the risk. African-Americans are presumed to have a 30-60% higher risk of developing DVT as compared to Caucasians. Health promotion and supportive care are essential components of his treatment plan. Regular monitoring is necessary to prevent complications like post-thrombotic syndrome and pulmonary embolism. Mr. Smith is optimistic about the prescribed treatment strategy and has demonstrated commitment to adopting recommended lifestyle modifications.  Sources: 1. Zakai N  McClure LA. Racial differences in venous thromboembolism. J Thromb Haemost. 2011;9(10):1877-82. 2. Heit JA  O’Fallon WM  Petterson TM  et al. Relative impact of risk factors for deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism: A population-based study. Arch Intern Med. 2002;162(11):1245-8.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Matthews is a 50-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with complaints of pain and swelling in his right lower leg for the past three days. He also reported a sensation of warmth over the affected area. Mr. Matthews works as a truck driver for a local delivery company and has been largely sedentary due to the nature of his occupation.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Matthews has a past medical history of hypertension  for which he takes amlodipine  and high cholesterol  which is managed with atorvastatin. He had an appendectomy 10 years ago and has no other known surgical history. He has no known allergies. He smokes about a pack of cigarettes per day and consumes alcohol socially. He does not have a regular exercise regimen  and his diet is high in sodium and fats.  Family History:  There is a significant family history of cardiac diseases  including myocardial infarction and stroke in his first-degree relatives. His maternal grandfather had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after surgery  and his mother had recurrent DVT episodes. There is no known history of genetic clotting disorders in the family.  Investigations & Diagnosis:  Due to the clinical presentation and family history  a Doppler ultrasonography of his right lower leg was performed  which confirmed the presence of DVT. Over the course of the three days  his leg pain and swelling had increased and was more pronounced after long periods of sitting.  Treatment & Follow-up:  Mr. Matthews was subsequently admitted for anticoagulation therapy and close monitoring of his DVT. He was started on a regimen of low molecular weight heparin and warfarin. A plan was made to follow his progress with serial Doppler ultrasounds and regular monitoring of his INR levels. He was discharged with instructions to continue warfarin and to follow up with a vascular surgeon and hematologist to investigate if there is an underlying clotting disorder.   The patient was also educated about the importance of lifestyle modifications  such as regular exercise  a low salt  low-fat diet  quitting smoking  and reducing alcohol consumption to manage hypertension and high cholesterol. He was also advised to take regular breaks during his long drives to avoid sitting for prolonged periods.   In summarizing Mr. Matthew's case  several risk factors for DVT are evident: prolonged periods of immobility due to his occupation  smoking history  unhealthy diet  and significant family history. It further underscores the importance of considering DVT in patients with similar risk profiles presenting with an acute onset of unilateral leg pain and swelling.

Patient Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 54-year-old African-American male  5’9” and 190lbs  from Dallas  Texas presents with symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). A nonsmoker and social drinker  Mr. Smith works as an IT professional with long hours in a sedentary position.   Presenting Issue: Mr. Smith presented with a 3-day history of discomfort  warmth  and swelling in the lower left calf  which he initially attributed to a strenuous workout. However  symptoms did not improve with rest and over-the-counter NSAIDs. The patient reported no chest pain  shortness of breath  or other symptoms.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily respectively). He had no past incidents of blood clots or coagulation disorders. His last pertinent lab workup was performed six months ago  with all results within normal limits except for slightly elevated LDL cholesterol.  Family History: His father had a myocardial infarction at 62 and died of subsequent complications. His mother is alive at 80 with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes. He has one older brother who is alive and well  with no known health issues.  Physical Examination and Diagnostics: The physical examination revealed tenderness and erythema over the left calf region with a noticeable increase in calf circumference compared to the right leg. The patient's vital signs were stable. Venous Doppler ultrasound found a deep vein thrombus in the left posterior tibial vein. A D-dimer test was positive. Pulmonary Embolism was ruled out with a negative computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) scan.   Assessment and Plan: A diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis was confirmed. Immediately after diagnosis  Mr. Smith was started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin (Enoxaparin) and oral Warfarin. He was educated regarding the side effects of these medications  importance of follow-up appointments for monitoring INR  as well as the importance of early leg movements and exercise. A follow up in two weeks was scheduled for reevaluation and adjustment of his anticoagulation regimen. Lifestyle modifications and a possible reassessment of his work situation was discussed to reduce long periods of immobility.   As Mr. Smith’s case indicates  DVT can be present even in patients without significant risk factors or family history. Ensuring early detection and management is key to preventing severe complications such as Pulmonary Embolism (PE) and Post-Thrombotic Syndrome (PTS).

Patient Identification:  A 65-year-old African American female  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus on medication. She has a BMI of 35 kg/m2  which categorizes her as severely obese.  Presenting Complaint: She presented to the clinic with symptoms of swelling in the left lower leg  tenderness  and a palpable cord that is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Furthermore  she reported having difficulty walking due to the pain.  Smoking and Alcohol: Although she quit smoking 10 years ago  the patient had a history of smoking for almost 25 years. She admits to occasionally consuming alcohol on holidays and social events.   Family History: Her father died of a pulmonary embolism at the age of 75  and her mother had a cardiovascular event in her 50s. Also  she has a younger brother who is struggling with obesity and her older sister is hypertensive.   Clinical Examination: Upon examination  her left leg was notably swollen and warm to the touch. Homans' sign was positive.  Investigations: Ultrasound Doppler examination of the lower extremity confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis in the left leg. Her coagulation profile was within normal range  D-Dimer was elevated. She also demonstrated high blood glucose levels  consistent with her diabetes.  Management: She was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for initial anticoagulation  and bridged to Warfarin. The patient's diabetes and hypertension are being managed with medication adjustments. In addition  she was educated on lifestyle changes including diet  physical activity  and the importance of medication adherence.  This case highlights the importance of recognizing risk factors such as obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and family history that contribute to developing DVT. Early symptom recognition and timely treatment can prevent dreaded complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Subject: 65-year-old Caucasian Female Patient with Deep Vein Thrombosis  IDENTIFYING INFORMATION: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female from a suburban region  living with her retired husband.  CHIEF COMPLAINT: She presented with a complaint of unilateral leg swelling and pain for the last 48 hours.   HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The pain started gradually  was initially mild  but progressively intensified. Her son-in-law urged her to seek medical attention as he knew these could be signs of a serious condition called Deep Vein Thrombosis.   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: She has a history of hypertension managed with medication (Losartan)  type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with diet and Metformin  and was recently hospitalized for pneumonia three months prior. She is also a former smoker  quitting 15 years ago.  FAMILY HISTORY: The family history revealed that her mother had a stroke at the age of 75 and her father died of coronary artery disease in his 60s. Her sister was diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease.   REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: The review was mostly unremarkable  with no complaints related to any of the other systems.   PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Physical examination was mostly normal except for swelling  warmth  erythema and tenderness in the left calf  suggestive of a possible DVT.  INVESTIGATIONS: D-dimer level was raised. Ultrasound Doppler study of the left lower limb confirmed the presence of DVT in the left popliteal and femoral veins. ECG  blood sugars  kidney function  and liver function results were within normal limits.   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: The patient was admitted to the hospital and initiated on anticoagulation therapy. She will undergo a CT scan to rule out Pulmonary Embolism  a common and severe complication of DVT  given her recent history of pneumonia. The patient and her family were educated on the importance of the treatment regime  potential risks  and lifestyle modifications necessary to manage her condition effectively.   FOLLOW UP: She will need close follow-up to monitor her progress and adjust medication as necessary. She is also advised to stop estrogen therapy (used for the management of postmenopausal symptoms)  maintain physical activity  and adhere to a balanced diet.  SUMMARY: This case highlights the importance of early recognition of symptoms and swift action in managing potentially life-threatening conditions such as DVT. The management necessitates constant monitoring and patient education is pivotal in ensuring compliance to therapy and preventing complications.

Patient Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction:  Our patient  Mr. Wilson  is a 65-year-old man recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Mr. Wilson is of African American ethnicity  retired  married and lives in St. Louis  Missouri.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Wilson complained of persistent and worsening discomfort and swelling in his right calf for 1 week. He also reported slight shortness of breath  especially when walking up stairs or exerting himself.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Wilson has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are currently managed with medication. His record also indicates that he was a smoker for 30 years but quit 10 years ago.   Family History:  There is a notable family history of cardiovascular disease. His father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 70  and his older sister is living with diagnosed peripheral artery disease. There is no reported history of DVT or pulmonary embolism in the family.  Social History:  Mr. Wilson has been retired for five years after a long career as a truck driver. His retirement mainly involves sedentary activities; he enjoys watching TV  reading  and playing cards with friends. He does not engage in regular physical exercise and admits to an 'average' diet.  Clinical Examination:  On physical exam  Mr. Wilson exhibited right calf swelling  with pitting edema and mild tenderness. His vital signs were within normal limits.   Investigations:  A Duplex Ultrasound identified a clot in the deep veins of his right lower leg  confirming the diagnosis of DVT. Lab reports also showed increased D-Dimer levels. His blood glucose and blood pressure readings were slightly elevated at the time of consultation.  Management:  Mr. Wilson was started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin  coupled with at-home treatment using oral warfarin. Regular INR monitoring was scheduled to ensure appropriate warfarin dosing. He was also recommended a change in diet and an increased physical activity level.  Prognosis:  Mr. Wilson's prognosis is generally good with the appropriate anticoagulant treatment and lifestyle modifications. However  due to his previous history of hypertension and diabetes  there are potential complications including the possibility of a pulmonary embolism that should be continuously monitored. Regular follow-up appointments will be necessary for INR monitoring  medication adjustments  and to ensure his symptoms are improving.  This case provides an opportunity to recognize the importance of early DVT detection and the need for continuous patient risk factor assessment  particularly in patients with known chronic conditions. Further  it demonstrates the need for comprehensive patient education and lifestyle changes in DVT management.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 62 year old Caucasian female  named Ms. Smith  who resides in suburban New York.   Presenting Problem: Ms. Smith presented with increasing pain  redness  swelling  and warmth in her left lower leg  which she noticed had been getting progressively worse over the past few days. On physical examination  her left calf was significantly larger than her right one.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Smith has a past history of type 2 diabetes managed with metformin and hypertension managed by a low sodium diet and daily lisinopril. She had undergone a total knee replacement surgery two months ago. She also has occasional migraine headaches for which she takes over-the-counter ibuprofen. She is allergic to sulfa drugs  which cause rash.   Family History: There is a significant family history of venous thromboembolic events; her mother had an unprovoked deep vein thrombosis at the age of 65  and her brother experienced a pulmonary embolism at the age 55. Her father  at age 68  experienced a stroke.   Psycho-Social History: Ms. Smith is a retired teacher who lives alone. She stopped smoking a decade ago and drinks alcohol on social occasions only. According to her  she has been spending most of her time in bed or sitting on her couch since her knee surgery.   Current Medications: Her daily medications include metformin  lisinopril  and a multivitamin tablet. She occasionally takes an ibuprofen tablet for her migraine.  Assessment: Based on the symptoms  family history and her recent knee surgery  a venous doppler was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a DVT in the left popliteal vein.  Plan: Ms. Smith was hospitalized and started on intravenous heparin therapy. She was also counselled about the importance of mobilization and leg exercises during her period of immobilization due to knee surgery. A plan was made to switch her to warfarin therapy  with the dosages adjusted according to INR. Patient education was made a priority  regarding the signs of DVT  importance of medication compliance and follow-up appointments.  Given her family history  a referral was made to a hematologist to further investigate whether there may be a hereditary component to her condition  which could influence future treatment and prevention plans.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Lorraine Wilson Age: 65 years old Sex: Female Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Marital Status: Widow Present Residence: Urban area  lives alone  Presenting Concern: Mrs. Wilson visited the clinic with complaints of swelling  redness  and unexplained pain in her right leg that had been persistent for the past week.   Past Medical History:  She has a history of intermittent leg cramps and varicose veins for which she has been wearing compression stockings on and off. Mrs. Wilson was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago  which is controlled by insulin and dietary modifications. She also has high blood pressure  managed with medication.  Family History: Her mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  and her paternal uncle suffered a stroke. There are no other significant hereditary diseases or conditions in the family.   Clinical Examination: On examination  the right calf was found to be tender  warm to touch  and swollen  raising suspicion for DVT.   Investigations: Mrs. Wilson was sent for a Doppler Ultrasound that confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the right popliteal vein  diagnosing her with Deep Vein Thrombosis.  Treatment: She was initiated on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) followed by long-term oral anticoagulants. Considering her age  diabetes  and hypertension  the treatment was also supportive  including leg elevation  compression stockings  and exercise as advised by the physical therapist.  Risk Factors:  Advanced age  lengthy immobility  previous varicose veins  diabetes  high blood pressure  family history of DVT and stroke  and her genetic predisposition all contributed to her risk of developing DVT.  Preventive Measures: Mrs. Wilson was advised to comply with her medication regimen strictly and to consult with her healthcare provider before discontinuing any medication. She was instructed to regularly monitor her blood sugar levels and blood pressure and adjust her medication under her physician's guidance. She was advised to get regular exercise to improve her blood circulation  given advice on dietary modifications  and recommended to wear compression stockings daily.  Follow up and prognosis:  Mrs. Wilson is scheduled for a follow-up visit after two weeks to monitor her response to the treatment. Special focus will be given to her lifestyle changes  considering her medical history and family history.  This case highlights the importance of awareness and early detection of DVT  especially for patients with known risk factors. It emphasizes the need for rigorous management of existing health conditions like diabetes and hypertension to prevent complications like DVT.

Patient Introduction: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  living in a suburban setting  diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Past Medical History: In the past  the patient has been admitted for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are well-controlled. He has a 20-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day. His BMI is 29  indicating overweight status  and he leads a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Family History: His family history is significant  with his father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55  and his maternal grandmother with a known history of DVT. No history of genetic disorders has been identified.  Recent History: The patient recently underwent a left total knee arthroplasty after suffering from osteoarthritis for several years. He was admitted to the hospital 4 days ago due to swelling in his left leg  accompanied by a heavy ache and slight breathlessness. Through duplex ultrasound  DVT was confirmed in the popliteal vein passing through his calf.
