Assessment: His vitals reveal a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. His weight is 85 kg. His physical examination reveals mild non-pitting edema in the left calf.  Blood Investigations: Lab parameters showed a D-dimer level of 1000 ng/ml (normal <500 ng/ml)  supporting the diagnosis. His fasting blood sugar was 130 mg/dL  post-meal 180 mg/dL  and HbA1c 6.5%. His lipid profile indicates mild hyperlipidemia. His international normalized ratio (INR) was 1.2  less than the therapeutic goal for patients with DVT.  Social history: He is retired  lives with his wife  and has two adult children  all of whom are in good health. He does not exercise regularly and has a diet high in salt and fat.  Given the patient's recent surgery  sedentary lifestyle  smoking history  family history of cardiovascular diseases  and uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  he stands at a high risk for DVT  which tenably precipitated this acute episode. The medical team will proceed with anticoagulation therapy and lifestyle modifications to manage the situation.   (Note: The details given are suggested and may not consider all possible diversity of life situations or health status. This is an assumption of a case based on the literature and demographic representation.)

Patient Profile: Mr. Richard Johnson  a 66-year-old African American male  presents with pain and swelling in his right lower extremity. He is retired and lives with his wife. As an ex-smoker  he has prior medical history of diabetes and hypertension  typically managed with oral medications.  Presenting Condition: Two days prior to his visit  he noticed progressive pain and swelling in his right lower leg  which became more pronounced during walking. His pain is non-radiating with a severity of 5/10. He expressed mild feverish feelings  but denied chest pain or shortness of breath. There is no history of trauma or injury to the leg.  Vitals & Physical Examination: His vital signs show a BP of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 85 beats/min  respirations of 16 breaths/min  and temperature 98°F. The physical examination reveals slight tenderness  redness  and palpable warmth in the calf of his right leg. No superficial veins are seen. His heart  lungs and abdomen were unremarkable on auscultation.  Laboratory Findings: His D-dimer assay was positive. The lipid profile  renal function  and liver functions tests are within the normal range. His latest HbA1c was 7.5 and the fasting blood glucose was 134 mg/dl.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a history of Type 2 diabetes for the past 10 years and hypertension for 15 years. He quit smoking about 5 years ago but smoked for about 30 years prior to quitting. He was on Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin which he states he takes regularly.  Family History: There is a strong family history of diabetes and cardiovascular diseases. His father suffered from coronary artery disease and passed due to myocardial infarction at the age of 68. His mother is a well-controlled diabetic.  Additional Notes: Ultrasound Doppler confirmed the presence of a thrombus in the right calf deep vein. Owing to the absence of respiratory symptoms  no further investigations were needed to exclude pulmonary embolism. However  the patient was counselled regarding the significance of sudden breathlessness  chest pain  or hemoptysis.  Management: Mr. Johnson was advised hospitalization. The cardiology team started him on Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) for immediate anticoagulation along with Rivaroxaban for long-term control. Post discharge  he will continue to receive oral anticoagulants and his condition will be monitored regularly. In addition  a reference for lower limb physiotherapy was given for improving muscle strength and venous return.  Patient Education: Mr. Johnson was educated about the seriousness of his condition  its potential recurrence  and the possibility of worsening to pulmonary embolism. He has been advised to maintain good blood glucose and blood pressure control. Instructions on foot care  symptoms to watch for  medications  compliance  and follow-up visit schedules were provided. He was advised against long periods of immobility and to elevate the affected leg while resting.  Prevention is essential for Mr. Johnson due to his high-risk profile of having a recurrence of DVT. Thus  a coordinated approach involving his primary care physician  cardiologist  and other health professionals is crucial in managing his health condition.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Details:  Mrs. Maria Gonzalez  a 65-year-old Hispanic female.  History of Presenting Illness: Mrs. Gonzalez presents with a 2-day history of progressive left leg swelling and mild discomfort. She denies recent injuries  long term sitting or travel history. However  she has been relatively immobilized for the past week due to a bout of a severe respiratory tract infection.  Medical History: She is a known diabetic for 15 years and is currently controlled on metformin. Additionally  she has a history of hypertension which is controlled on Lisinopril. She was also diagnosed with obesity (BMI of 32) 5 years ago. She has no history of surgery or cancer.  Pharmacological History: On a prescription of Metformin 500 mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10 mg once daily. She takes over-the-counter multivitamins.  Family History: Mother passed away due to complications of diabetes at age 72  and her father passed away from a myocardial infarction at age 68. She has two older sisters  one has diabetes and the other has a history of breast cancer.  Social History:  Retired schoolteacher  non-smoker  and occasional alcohol use. She lives with her husband and is not physically active due to pain and swelling in her leg.  Physical Examination: On examination  her left leg is visibly swollen compared to the right leg. Inferiorly there is pitting edema up to the knee. She has a moderate degree of tenderness along the distribution of the left calf muscle.   Investigations: She has an elevated D-dimer and an Ultrasound Doppler of the leg reveals a lack of compressibility of the left posterior tibial and peroneal veins  indicative of deep vein thrombosis.  Clinical Impression: Mrs. Gonzalez is diagnosed with left leg Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The contributing factors may include recent immobilization due to her illness  obesity  her history of diabetes and hypertension  and genetic predispositions.  Plan: Anticoagulation treatment is initiated with low-molecular-weight heparin. She is counseled to lose weight  increase her physical activity as tolerated  and monitor her blood sugars regularly. A referral to a dietician and physiotherapist are recommended for her. She is asked to return to the clinic in one week to assess her symptoms and adjust her treatment accordingly.  This case is notable for demonstrating the interplay of risk factors leading to DVT in an elderly Hispanic female with multiple risk factors. Optimal management requires both acute treatment and addressing chronic risk factors  including obesity.

Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old African American male  currently residing in San Antonio  Texas. He was previously employed as a truck driver but has been retired for the last two years. He lives with his wife and youngest daughter who is 18-year-old. He is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago but has a history of alcohol abuse. He reported a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Johnson presented with new-onset swelling  pain  and warmth in the left lower extremity  specifically in the calf region. He also mentioned recurring cramp-like discomfort.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension; both conditions are well-controlled with medication. He also has a history of gout. He is following up regularly with his primary care physician for the same. He underwent a hernia repair surgery five years back.   Family History: His mother died from stroke at the age of 72  and his father had a lung cancer diagnosis  passing away at age 78. In terms of siblings  he has a 64-year-old sister with breast cancer and a 59-year-old brother with no known illnesses. No known family history of blood clot disorder.  Demographics: Mr. Johnson’s family is from a middle-class background. He is well educated  having completed his Bachelor's degree. His wife is employed as a nurse.  Clinical Assessment: On physical examination  the circumference of the left calf was increased compared to the right  with slight erythema and tenderness. Doppler ultrasound demonstrated a clot in the posterior tibial and peroneal veins confirming a diagnosis of acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Treatment and Recommendations: Mr. Johnson was immediately commenced on anticoagulation therapy; specifically low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and Warfarin. He was advised to use compression stockings and elevate his leg to help reduce the swelling. He was also encouraged to mobilize and refrain from remaining in a static position for prolonged durations. Lifestyle modifications like regular exercise and alcohol cessation were emphasized.   Given Mr. Johnson's risk factors including age  sedentary lifestyle  and existing comorbidities like hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  focus on preventive actions against DVT recurrence was prioritized. Further genetic screening for clotting disorders and regular follow-ups were planned to prevent potential complications like pulmonary embolism.  Ethical Considerations: All treatment decisions were made with the patient's full consent after thoroughly explaining his medical condition and the pros and cons of each treatment option. Regular follow-up care was arranged to help provide continuous  holistic care and manage any potential complications.  Note: This case represents a typical representation and does not necessarily reflect any specific individual's personal or medical history.

Patient Information: Patient Initials: A.B. Age: 67 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Insurance: Medicare  Presenting Problem:  The patient presents with discomfort and noticeable swelling in his left lower limb. He described a pulling sensation in the back of his thigh and calf  consistent with symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Past Medical History:  His past medical history reveals a sedentary lifestyle due to his job which he recently retired from as an accountant  no history of significant illnesses or hospitalizations but he is overweight with a BMI of 31. He is an ex-smoker and has been diagnosed with hypertension and managed with medications.  Family History:  History of cardiovascular diseases in his family. His father died from a stroke in his seventies. A.B's older brother had a heart attack in his sixties. No known genetic disorders.   Social History: He lives with his wife in a suburban home. He used to smoke a pack of cigarette a day but quit five years ago. He has a tendency towards sedentary habits with lack of physical activity in his daily routines. He occasionally drinks socially but no history of substance abuse.  Current Medications:  A.B. has been prescribed Lisinopril (10 mg daily) for hypertension.  Physical Examination: On physical exam  his left calf was tender consistent with Homans’ sign and noticeably swollen when compared to the right. Vital signs are stable. Cardiovascular examination shows controlled blood pressure and regular heart rate. There were no peripheral stigmata of chronic disease noted.  Clinical Impression: Given the clinical presentation and patient’s risk factors (lack of physical activities  age  hypertension  family history of cardiovascular diseases)  a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is suspected.   Diagnostic Testing: The patient has been sent to have a D-Dimer test and Duplex ultrasound which confirmed the diagnosis of DVT.  Plan: The patient was started on anticoagulant therapy  specifically with Rivaroxaban initially  then it was planned to switch to Warfarin with regular PT/INR monitoring at the clinic. He was also educated about the need for lifestyle changes including regular exercise  a balanced diet to lose weight  limiting alcohol  and increased mobility. Follow up visit was scheduled for vascular surgery evaluation and to regularly monitor his condition.  The patient was also explained about potential complications of DVT including pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome. He was given instructions to report immediately for shortness of breath  chest pain or uncontrolled bleeding.   Patient Education: A.B is counselled on the importance of medication adherence and lifestyle changes. He expressed understanding and readiness to engage in physical activities regularly and improve his diet. His wife will be instrumental in providing support on these changes.   Given the family history of cardiovascular disease  his other family members are recommended to undergo health screening to assess their respective risks and take necessary precautions.

Patient Presentation  The patient  Mr. Allen  who is a Caucasian man of 67 years old presents to the Emergency Department with a complaint of unilateral swelling and pain in his right lower extremity. He has a history of being physically inactive due to his sedentary lifestyle. He had a total knee replacement surgery 2 months ago  after which he has been largely bed-bound since his recovery has been slow. His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension that are well-managed with the help of medications and a controlled diet. There are no known drug allergies. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for about 30 years but stopped at the age of 55. His family history is remarkable for his father having stroke at the age of 74.  His physical examination reveals that the circumference of his right calf is 2 cm more compared to the left  there is purple discoloration  and it's warm to the touch. There is no fever or other major systemic symptoms. On Doppler Ultrasound of right lower extremity  a thrombus in the right posterior tibial vein is found. This leads to a provisional diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.  He is admitted to the hospital for further investigations and management of deep vein thrombosis. The laboratory findings showed elevated D-dimer levels and complete blood count  liver function test  kidney function test  and blood electrolytes all within normal ranges.   Hypertension  old age  recent major surgery  prolonged immobilization  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and history of smoking are his primary risk factors for DVT. From the family history of stroke in father  there may be a possibility of genetic predisposition too.  Mr. Allen’s treatment was initiated with anticoagulants and measures to reduce leg swelling  including leg elevation and compression stockings. He responded well to the treatment with reduction of his symptoms over the following weeks. He is advised to mobilize when possible  keep hydrated  and weight management. Control and management of diabetes and hypertension are equally stressed. Anticoagulation treatment should be continued for at least three months to prevent recurrence or post-thrombotic syndrome.

Patient Presentation  I. Demographics The patient is a 67-year-old African American male named Mr. Johnson. He is a retired firefighter  married  and lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. Mr. Johnson is slightly overweight with a BMI of 28.6. He is a non-smoker but indulges moderate alcohol consumption.  II. Presenting Complaint Mr. Johnson came to the emergency department complaining of a 3-day history of progressive pain and swelling in his right lower leg. He also noticed increased warmth and redness in the area.  III. Past Medical History He has a long-standing history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is under control with metformin. Additionally  he suffered from hypertension  managed with quinapril. He is also on low-dose aspirin for cardiovascular protection. Mr. Johnson has previously undergone a hip replacement surgery ten years ago.  IV. Family History He has a significant familial history with both his father and older brother having suffered from episodes of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and his mother who died due to a stroke.  V. Current Medications He is on metformin 500mg twice a day for his diabetes  a daily dose of 20mg quinapril for hypertension  and 75mg of aspirin as a prophylaxis for cardiovascular diseases.  VI. Clinical Findings and Diagnosis Upon physical examination  his right calf was swollen  tender  and warmer compared to the other leg. The circumference was measured to be 3cm greater than the left. A positive Homan's sign was also observed. No other significant findings were identified from the systemic examinations.  Given the profound clinical suspicion of DVT  an urgent Doppler ultrasound was arranged which confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis in his right lower limb.   VII. Management  Following the diagnosis  Mr. Johnson was started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin to help dissolve the clot and prevent it from propagating further. He was also given guidance to elevate his leg to help decrease swelling and to wear compression stockings.  VIII. Discussion Deep vein thrombosis is a common condition with risk factors including immobility  recent surgery or trauma  malignancy  and previous DVT or PE. This patient’s risk factors include his family history of DVT  a sedentary lifestyle since retirement  and his past medical history  notably his previous hip replacement surgery.  IX. Conclusion Mr. Johnson's case emphasizes the importance of comprehensive medical history detailing and being mindful of individual risk factors  such as genetic predisposition and the interplay of multiple comorbidities which predispose to deep vein thrombosis. This case also illustrates the importance of public awareness about this potentially fatal disease  especially recognizing the symptoms and seeking medical attention promptly.  (Sources: Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) - Clinical Features and Diagnosis  BMJ Best Practice; Deep vein thrombosis - Symptoms and Causes  Mayo Clinic; Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) - Diagnosis and Treatment  American Heart Association)

Patient Presentation: Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: White (Given the fact that DVT is equally common in most races  however  rates are somewhat lower in Asian populations) Occupation: Retired military officer  Presenting Problem: Mr. Doe presented with a 3-day history of pain  swelling  and redness in his left lower leg. He also mentioned feelings of warmth over the affected area. He denied any trauma or injury to the area. There was no history of fever  night sweats  palpitations  or shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension under control with medication (Amlodipine 5mg daily). He underwent right knee replacement surgery around 2 years ago. He also had a myocardial infarction 5 years back which was managed conservatively. He is an ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago but has a 30 pack-year history. No known drug allergies are reported.  Family History: Father died at the age of 75 due to a stroke. His mother is alive with diabetes and hypertension. He has one younger brother who has no significant medical conditions. There is no known family history of thromboembolic or genetic diseases.  Social History: Mr. Doe leads a sedentary lifestyle  living alone in his home. He has a caregiver who visits him daily. He enjoys reading and watching television. He quit smoking 10 years ago but consumed alcohol occasionally.   Physical Examination: On examination  his temperature was 37.2°C  blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  heart rate 82/min  and respiratory rate 18/min. His left lower leg was swollen  warm  and tender on the posterior side. There were no visible veins or palpable cords. Pulses were equal in both the legs. Cardiovascular  respiratory  and abdominal examinations were unremarkable.  Laboratory investigations: The D-dimer test was positive.   Diagnosis: Considering the clinical features and past medical history  a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in the lower left leg was made.   Discussion: Mr. Doe is at a higher risk of DVT due to his age  sedentary lifestyle  history of surgery  and cardiovascular diseases. Further diagnostic confirmation such as Duplex ultrasound or Venography would substantiate the diagnosis. Anticoagulation therapy should be considered as an initial treatment option.  This case highlights the importance of identifying risk factors in elderly patients who present with unilateral leg swelling and pain. Adequate follow-up and patient education is vital to preventing potentially life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism relating to DVT.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Peter who works as an English professor. Peter lives in Nebraska  and has a sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of his job and his hobbies which include reading and writing.  Medical History: Peter has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type II diabetes. He is a non-smoker and non-drinker. His medication history includes Insulin therapy for diabetes  Lisinopril use for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. However  his compliance to medication is poor. He also has a history of routine medical check-ups without any previous surgical history.  Present Complaint: Peter presented with a two-day history of a painful  swollen  warm right leg. There's no history of trauma. Nonetheless  he admits to having returned from a long-haul flight a week prior.  Family History: There is a substantial family history of cardiovascular disease. His father died of myocardial infarction in his late 70s  while his older brother had a stroke at the age of 65. Detail's concerning his mother's health are unknown as he has been estranged from her since his early adulthood.  Physical Examination and Lab Tests: On examination  Peter’s leg was observed to be red  swollen  and warm to touch. A blood test was done revealing a significantly elevated D-dimer level. Symptoms combined with elevated D-dimer levels suggested a high clinical probability for DVT. An ultrasound of the leg was recommended for confirmation.  Diagnosis: Based on the signs and symptoms and high D-dimer levels  Peter was diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) following which he was immediately started on anticoagulant medication. The definitive diagnosis of DVT was later confirmed with an ultrasound of the leg which showed a clot in the deep veins of the right leg.   Patient Education and Follow-Up: Peter has been educated about the DVT and the need for strict adherence to medication to avoid possible complicated outcomes. Lifestyle modifications to include regular physical activity and balanced diet are advised. He will need to take the anticoagulant medication and follow up with the doctor in a week. The patient has also been advised to look out for symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism  a life-threatening complication of DVT. His hypertension and diabetes will need better management. His case has been referred to a dedicated nurse to ensure the patient understands the importance of medication adherence. Regular follow-up has been advised for monitoring anticoagulation levels.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Smith is a 65-year-old African American male  recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He presents with a 4-day history of increasing pain and swelling in the left lower leg  which prompted a visit to the local ER.  Demographics: Mr. Smith is a retired truck driver residing in Atlanta  Georgia. He lives alone and is a widower with two adult daughters. He is a non-smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father had a stroke at age 70 and his only brother had a heart attack at 62.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  for which he uses oral anti-diabetic medication. He has been diagnosed with hypertension managed with medication as well. He had a past history of right leg DVT five years ago and was poorly adherent to preventative recommendations and medication due to fear of side effects and misunderstanding the seriousness of the condition.  Presenting Symptoms: On examination  there was significant left calf swelling and tenderness along the path of the deep veins. The leg was warm to touch and mildly erythematous. Systemic examination was normal. His blood pressure was 140/90 mm Hg.   Investigations and Diagnosis: The patient was subjected to a D-Dimer test which was positive and an ultrasound Doppler of the left leg confirmed the diagnosis of DVT.  Management Plan: Mr. Smith was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin and oral anticoagulants. He underwent patient education about the need for medication adherence. Moreover  a plan to enhance physical activity and follow a balanced diet was discussed given his co-morbid type 2 diabetes and hypertension.  Long-term considerations for Mr. Smith will include continuous monitoring and management of his DVT  hypertension  and diabetes. His daughters will be educated about his conditions to ensure that they can provide the necessary support. Genetic counseling is also recommended for his daughters due to the hereditary nature of cardiovascular diseases in the family.  This case emphasizes the importance of medication adherence in patients with DVT and the role of patient and family education in managing chronic conditions.

Patient Presentation  The patient  Mr. A  is a 62-year-old African American male  shown to be the demographic group with a relatively higher risk for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in numerous studies. He is a resident of Atlanta  Georgia and works as a computer engineer  a largely sedentary job requiring long hours of sitting. He is a non-smoker and moderate drinker. He lives alone and does not participate in regular physical activity.  Medical History  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been well-controlled with amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively. He denied any prior surgeries or hospitalizations. He has no known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaint   Mr. A arrived at the clinic with complaints of increasing discomfort and swelling in his right leg over the past week. No chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. On further evaluation  it was revealed that he recently took an international business flight of 19 hours duration about 10 days ago. He reported limited mobility but did not report any calf pain or warmth.   Family History  Mr. A’s father  late at 67  had a medical history of coronary artery disease; his mother  alive and well at 80  has type 2 diabetes and hypertension. One of his two brothers was diagnosed with DVT at the age of 60 after a similar long-flight journey.  Patient Assessment  Upon examination  the patient's right calf appeared larger than the left and was slightly warm to the touch. No notable systemic symptoms. His vitals were stable  with a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg and a heart rate of 72 beats per minute. His BMI was calculated to be 31  classifying him as obese. Peripheral pulses were normal  and no skin ulcers were present.  D-Dimer test was ordered which came back positive  increasing the likelihood of DVT. Based on the initial clinical examination  a comprehensive risk factor assessment  and the D-dimer test results  venous duplex ultrasonography was scheduled to confirm the diagnosis of DVT.   Final Comments  This case highlights a typical presentation of DVT in an individual with sustained periods of immobility. Further  it emphasizes the importance of considering prolonged travel as a potential risk factor for thrombosis. As per his reported symptoms  medical  and family history  the possibility of DVT is highly probable  hence warranting appropriate investigation and management. However  multiple factors may impact the final diagnosis and treatment plan considering this patient’s ethnicity  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  and vascular disease family history.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith  living in an urban setting in New York City. He is a retired school teacher  widowed  with two adult children. He has a 30-year history of smoking but stopped 15 years ago. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 27  indicating overweight status. He reports occasional alcohol intake and no illicit drug use.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith's medical history includes Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) controlled via Metformin  Hypertension managed by Lisinopril  and Hyperlipidemia treated with Atorvastatin. He had a myocardial infarction (MI) at the age of 62  which led to a successful coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). Mr. Smith does not have a known history of coagulopathy or any predisposing factors for thromboembolism except for his age  sedentary lifestyle  and obesity.  Family History: The patient's family history reveals a mother with T2DM and a father who passed away at 65 due to a stroke but who also suffered from hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Smith presented to his primary physician’s office complaining of gradually worsening left calf pain and swelling over the past week. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. He has not recently traveled or had any surgeries. His vital signs are stable  and an ultrasound confirms left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Initial Diagnosis and Plan: Given the clear presentation of deep vein thrombosis in the left leg  the patient was started on anticoagulation therapy in the form of Enoxaparin and later transitioned to long-term Warfarin. He was also advised to wear compression stockings for symptom management. Following discharge  he was referred to an outpatient vascular clinic for follow-up and continuation of his anticoast therapy. He has also been advised to engage in regular mild exercise and take measures to manage his weight  given his sedentary lifestyle.  This case shows an older adult with multiple risks for DVT  such as age  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle. Therefore  healthcare providers should consider these factors while performing the evaluation  diagnosis  and management of a patient.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 65-year-old African American male who arrived at the out-patient department of our hospital complaining of increasing pain  swelling  and warmth in his left lower leg which started five days prior. He has stated that he noticed the swelling after an 8-hour road trip. He has a BMI of 29.1  indicative of being overweight. A non-smoker  he drinks alcohol only occasionally.  Medical History  The patient has a medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which has been managed by Metformin for the past 15 years. He also has hypertension and takes Amlodipine 5 mg/day. Three years ago  he was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia for which he is taking statin medication. The patient denies any recent surgeries or hospitalizations. He also mentioned difficulty in walking due to pain in his leg  making him less physically active lately.  Family History  Both his parents died in their seventies from cardiovascular diseases and his father also had Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. He has one older brother who was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and one younger sister who is healthy.  Clinical Assessment  Physical examination revealed a slightly erythematous  edematous  and warm left lower leg compared to his right. His vital signs upon examination were: temperature 98.6°F  pulse 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  blood pressure 145/85 mmHg  and SpO2 98% on room air. His body mass index (BMI) was calculated to be 30.1  indicating obesity.  He was subsequently sent for a Doppler ultrasound  which confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left popliteal vein. Other routine blood tests were within normal limits  including renal function tests and coagulation profile.  This patient falls into a high-risk category for DVT due to his history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  long sedentary travel  advanced age  and African-American ethnicity. Research shows that African-American ethnicity has been linked to a heightened risk for DVT  this increased risk seems to be related to a higher prevalence of obesity  hypertension  and diabetes.  The case is complicated given the combination of his conditions and the fact that he had delayed seeking medical attention. The patient was initially treated with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) as an outpatient  and his therapy was transitioned to warfarin later. He was educated about the importance of physical activity  maintaining a balanced diet  regular medication  and regular follow-ups.   The literature recommends that those with a history of DVT should be followed up consistently  given that the risk of recurrence remains substantial even after successful resolution of the initial event.   A referral for the patient to see a dietician was done to help him with his diet and obesity  which are important risk factors for DVT. Changes in lifestyle and diet will be critical to manage his overall health condition.

Patient: Mrs. Sarah Smith Age: 67 years old Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Residence: Urban setting (Midwestern United States) Insurance Status: Medicare   Chief Complaint:  Mrs. Smith presented with unilateral left leg pain and swelling that has progressively worsened over the past week.  Past Medical History: 1) Hypertension (diagnosed 10 years ago) currently on Lisinopril. 2) Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: diagnosed 7 years ago currently on Metformin and diet controlled.  Surgical History:  Right hip replacement surgery 5 years ago.  Family History:  Mother with history of stroke at age 72  father deceased from heart disease at age 70. One older sibling has a history of venous thromboembolism.  Social History:  Mrs. Smith is a non-smoker but reports moderate alcohol use. She lives with her husband and is independent in her activities of daily living.  Presentation: On physical examination  her left leg was noticeably swollen with a circumference significantly greater than the right. It was erythematous  warm to touch  and tender along the line of her deep veins. No signs of superficial thrombophlebitis. Vital signs were: Blood pressure: 135/85 mmHg  Heart rate: 83 bpm  Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per min  Oxygen Sat: 98% on room air  Temperature: 98.7 F.  Investigations: A duplex ultrasound of the left lower limb showed a non-compressible segment in her left femoral vein  confirming the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis.  Discussion: Mrs. Smith had several risk factors for DVT including her age  recent immobility  history of surgery  and a significant family history. Her hypertension and diabetes may also indirectly increase her risk of cardiovascular diseases such as DVT.   Management: She was admitted for anticoagulation management  starting on a course of heparin with a plan to bridge to warfarin for long-term anticoagulation. Her response to the treatment was closely monitored. Some discussion was started about considering the placement of an IVC (inferior vena cava) filter given her history of surgery which could potentially limit her mobility during the recovery period thus predisposing her to clot formation.  Given her confirmed diagnosis of DVT  she will also require thorough patient education about the signs of pulmonary embolism due to the potential risk of DVT resulting in a life-threatening PE.   Follow-up: Appropriate follow-up arrangements were made at an anticoagulation clinic to continue the management of her DVT and monitor for any signs of post-thrombotic syndrome.  Mrs. Smith's case highlights the importance of considering deep vein thrombosis in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  especially those with multiple risk factors. Prompt diagnosis and management can prevent serious complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Subject: 62-Year-Old Male Diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Demographics: Our patient  Mr. Tim Reynolds  is a 62-year-old Caucasian male currently residing in New York City. He lives a relatively sedentary lifestyle with a part-time job in office management. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  but continues to consume alcohol moderately. He lives with his only son while his wife passed away a few years ago.  Medical History: Mr. Reynolds has a past medical history significant for hypertension and Type 2 diabetes. He was diagnosed with both conditions 8 years ago and has managed his condition with medication (Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes) and lifestyle changes. Mr. Reynolds also has a history of intermittent claudication; however  vascular evaluation performed five years ago did not reveal any significant occlusive disease. He also has a history of chronic low back pain and takes over-the-counter ibuprofen as needed.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Reynolds has come in with complaints of a painful  red  swollen left calf that has been getting worse over the last two days. He denies recent trauma  surgeries  prolonged immobilization  or previous similar episodes. He also denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or other worrisome symptoms.  Examination: On examination  his vitals were normal  but there was evident calf swelling  warmth  and tenderness on the left side. He exhibits positive Homan's sign (pain in the calf upon dorsiflexion of the foot).  Investigations: D-Dimer assay came back positive  following which he underwent Doppler ultrasonography confirming the presence of a non-compressible left popliteal vein  indicative of deep vein thrombosis.  Family History:  Father died at the age of 72 due to myocardial infarction  and his mother lived until 88 with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has one brother  aged 60 years  who suffers from asthma. There is no known family history of bleeding disorders or venous thromboembolism.  Summary: In summary  Mr. Reynolds is a 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension  diabetes  and intermittent claudication who has presented with typical signs and symptoms of DVT  which was confirmed through imaging studies. Given his history of known risk factors (e.g.  age  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  prior episodes of claudication)  it's crucial to promptly initiate appropriate anticoagulation therapy while also addressing his risk factors to prevent the progression or recurrence of the disease. Additionally  patient education on symptom recognition and when to seek medical attention is paramount.

Patient Profile  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 61 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Residence: Urban  Ohio  USA  Case Presentation  Mr. John Doe  a 61-year-old Caucasian man  was admitted for investigation of pain and swelling in his right leg for the past week. On examination  his right leg was swollen and tender  particularly in the calf area. These symptoms lead to suspicion of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Previous Medical History  Mr. Doe has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension for the past 15 years. He smokes approximately one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years and does not practice regular physical exercise. He takes Metformin for his diabetes  Lisinopril for Hypertension  and Atorvastatin for elevated cholesterol levels.  Family Medical History  His family history is significant with a father who had coronary artery disease and a mother who had a stroke  both in their 60s. His younger brother was diagnosed with DVT a few years ago.   Social History  Mr. Doe had been a truck driver for almost 30 years before retiring. He currently lives with his wife and enjoys a mostly sedentary lifestyle since retirement. He consumes alcohol occasionally and does not have any known drug habits.  Current Clinical Assessment  An ultrasound was performed after initial physical assessment  which confirmed the presence of DVT in the right lower leg  showing a partially occlusive thrombus. CBC  creatinine  electrolyte  and liver function tests showed results within normal limits. His blood glucose level was slightly elevated (145 mg/dl)  and his blood pressure was moderately high (145/90 mmHg). His BMI is 29.5 kg/m^2  which indicates that he is overweight.  Given Mr. Doe's history of chronic conditions  his lifestyle considerations (including his smoking and sedentary behaviors)  and his family history  it is reasonable to conclude that these factors contributed to his heightened risk for DVT. Elevation of his leg and comepression stockings were initiated  and he was started on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) and warfarin for DVT treatment  with dose adjustments planned according to his INR level.   Dietary control for his diabetes  and modification of lifestyle including smoking cessation  weight reduction  and regular exercise is urgently advised. He is also recommended for a regular follow-up with his endocrinologist  cardiologist  and primary care doctor.   Thus  Mr. Doe's case illustrates the importance of lifestyle modifications for preventing vascular diseases like DVT  particularly for individuals with known chronic conditions. Further  his case highlights the significance of appropriate action and timely medical intervention in case of DVT.

Case Presentation  Patient Information: Mr.Robertson  a 65-year-old African-American male  presented to the hospital with complaints of increasing pain  swelling  and a heavy feeling in the right lower limb. He reported a recent history of prolonged bed rest post-hip replacement surgery due to osteoarthritis. His body mass index (BMI) is 30  indicating obesity.  Past Medical History: Mr. Robertson has a medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He had a myocardial infarction five years ago but recovered well after receiving percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) therapy. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. He is also on Aspirin as prophylaxis.  Family History: Mr. Robertson's father suffered from coronary artery disease and had a history of thromboembolic events. His mother was hypertensive and diabetic.  Social History: Mr. Robertson is a retired truck driver  living with his wife in an urban setting. He has been a smoker for over 40 years but quit after his myocardial infarction. He occasionally drinks alcohol  primarily in social settings.  Clinical Examination and Diagnostic Assessment: Physical examination revealed swelling  redness  and warmth in the right calf area. His vitals were stable. The Doppler ultrasonography of the lower limb confirmed the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis with a blood clot in the posterior tibial vein.  Laboratory tests showed increased D-dimer levels (1200 ng/mL  normal <250 ng/mL). His HbA1C was 7.5%  suggesting suboptimal glucose control. Lipid profile was significant for elevated LDL levels.  Management: Mr. Robertson was initiated on anticoagulant therapy with heparin in hospital  which was switched to oral rivaroxaban upon discharge. He was educated about the symptoms of pulmonary embolism  a potential complication of DVT. Measures to prevent DVT like mobilization  leg exercises  and wearing compression stockings were explained. Considering his comorbidities  he was referred to a dietitian for weight reduction and diabetes management through diet. He was also advised to stay engaged in physical activities to prevent DVT and optimally manage his comorbid conditions. Regular follow-up visits were scheduled for reassessment and monitoring of the therapeutic response.  References: 1. Beckman  M. G.  Hooper  W. C.  Critchley  S. E.  & Ortel  T. L. (2010). Venous thromboembolism: A public health concern. American journal of preventive medicine  38(4 Suppl)  S495–S501.  2. Anderson Jr  F. A.  & Spencer  F. A. (2003). Risk factors for venous thromboembolism. Circulation  107(23_suppl_1)  I-9.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Ms. Anna Peterson Age: 68 years Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Marital Status: Widowed  Presenting problem: Ms. Peterson has been noticing a dull ache in her left leg accompanied by slight swelling and warm sensation over the past week. She reports prolonged sitting during a long-haul flight from New York to London about ten days ago.  Past medical history: She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and is on medications including amlodipine (5mg  once daily) and atorvastatin (20mg at night). She reports no known allergies and has never been hospitalized before. She was diagnosed with varicose veins in her left lower limb five years ago for which she wears compression stockings.  Family history:  Her husband died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. Her father also suffered from coronary artery disease and her mother had type 2 diabetes. She has two sons who are alive and well with no significant medical history.  Social history: Ms. Peterson is a non-smoker and rarely drinks alcohol. She lives alone post her husband's death but has a close network of friends and both of her sons visit regularly. She is relatively active and goes for a walk every morning.  Physical Examination: On examination  the left leg appeared slightly swollen as compared to the right  with a positive Homan's sign. Her vitals include blood pressure 145/85  pulse 90  temperature 98.6°F  and respiratory rate 18.   Investigations: The D-dimer test results were significantly high  and a subsequent Doppler ultrasound confirmed a clot in the left popliteal vein consistent with deep vein thrombosis.  Management: Ms. Peterson has been started on anticoagulant therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin and will be transitioned to warfarin in the following days. She has been advised to elevate her leg and continue wearing compression stockings.  Discussion: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is common post long-haul flights due to prolonged immobilization. Age  personal or family history of venous thromboembolism  presence of varicose veins  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and female sex recent postmenopausal status are all risk factors which could contribute towards developing DVT. Timely detection and management are crucial to prevent fatal complications like pulmonary embolism.  Patient Follow-up:  Ms. Peterson will be closely followed up  including monitoring her International Normalized Ratio levels (INR) while on warfarin therapy. Given her medical history and the recent DVT  she will also be referred to a dietitian and physiotherapist to reduce cardiovascular risk factors and improve leg strength and mobility  respectively.

Patient Identification:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian woman  Mrs. Smith  living in Missouri  USA. She is a retired teacher  married  and has two sons. Her husband has a history of heart disease.  Presenting Concern:  Mrs. Smith was brought into the ER with complaints of increasing pain and redness in her left calf of three days duration  which has worsened in the last 24 hours. She's also experiencing shortness of breath on exertion.  Past Medical History:  She has been relatively healthy with only a 5-year history of Hypertension  controlled with diet and medication. She was diagnosed as Type 2 Diabetic two years ago and maintains her sugar levels with Metformin. She underwent a total knee replacement on her left knee due to osteoarthritis 5 years ago. Her BMI is 28  which classifies her as overweight. She quit smoking 10 years ago.  Family History:  Her mother suffered from heart disease and stroke  while her father had similar diseases combined with diabetes. Her elder sister passed away due to lung cancer. Her younger brother is healthy.  Clinical Assessment: Physical examination revealed left calf swelling  erythema  warmth  and tenderness. The Pain was amplified when her leg was lightly tapped. Lower extremity duplex ultrasound revealed occlusive thrombus in the left popliteal vein  confirming deep vein thrombosis.  Treatment:  Mrs. Smith was admitted to the hospital due to the risk of pulmonary embolism. She has been started on intravenous Heparin and will be transitioned to Warfarin for long-term management. Further risk factor assessment and management of underlying conditions are ongoing.  Critical Analysis: Given Mrs. Smith's history of knee surgery  diabetes  hypertension and family history of cardiovascular diseases  her risk for DVT was elevated. Unmanaged  this could result in pulmonary embolism  which can be life-threatening. Comprehensive patient evaluation and timely treatment intervention were crucial in this case.  The case emphasizes the importance of early detection and prompt management of DVT. It is also highlights the need for individualized treatment plans  considering various factors like the patient's age  comorbid conditions  lifestyle  and family history. Additionally  it underscores the need for patient compliance and adherence to long-term anticoagulation therapy and lifestyle modifications. Also  it shows the importance of regular physical check-ups  especially among patients with a high risk of deep vein thrombosis.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male retired accountant  living in urban/suburban environment. He is a married non-smoker  drinking alcohol socially and moderately. The patient's body mass index is 28.2  with a sedentary lifestyle and is not engaged in regular physical activities.  Past Medical History: The patient has a background history of hypertension and Type II diabetes  maintained on Metformin and Ramipril. He underwent knee replacement surgery three weeks ago and was discharged from hospital after 7 days. He reveals that he drove long distance for work earlier in his career  but was not physically active thoroughly. There are premature heart diseases in his family history.   Key Complaints: The patient came to the emergency department complaining of acute onset of unilateral swelling of his left lower leg with moderate to severe pain for a day. He states the pain did not improve in various positions or with over-the-counter pain medication and has been worsening over the last few hours. He also reported a slight fever. Difficulty to walk was noted due to severe discomfort. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  undue fatigue  cough  or palpitations.  Teaching Points: This case is designed to teach the students to: 1. Recognize the signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). 2. Understand the importance of past medical and surgical history (hypertension  diabetes  recent lower limb surgery). 3. Note the significance of lifestyle (sedentary behavior  prolonged immobility). 4. Consider deep vein thrombosis as a differential diagnosis in patients with unilateral leg swelling and pain.  5. Understand the importance of immediate medical intervention to prevent major complications of DVT such as pulmonary embolism.  6. Understand the need for prophylactic anticoagulation in high-risk individuals. 7. Stress on lifestyle modifications to avoid risk factors that contribute to DVT.

Case Report   Patient Demographics:  Mr. James Smith  a 64-year-old African-American male  retired truck driver  weight 98 kg  height 5’10”  married with three children. He is a moderate smoker since his early 30s  physically not very active and consumes alcohol socially. Recently diagnosed as pre-diabetic.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been hypertensive for the past 10 years  controlled on medication (Lisinopril 10mg BID). Six months ago  he was diagnosed with pre-diabetes but remains non-compliant with lifestyle modification advice. He had a minor MI at age 55 with a cardiac stent placement. He also has mild osteoarthritis in his left hip since the last few years.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Smith came into the ER complaining of a sudden onset of pain and swelling in his left leg  that started a couple of days ago. He denies any trauma  fever  chest pain  dyspnea or recent surgeries. He admits that he had been sitting for prolonged periods during a recent road trip. He has noticed increased warmth  redness over the calf and the pain appears to increase while walking. He reports no issues in his right leg.  Remarks: This case is designed to highlight key demographics at risk for deep vein thrombosis such as African-American ethnicity  male gender  obesity  age  and recent sedentary behavior. The patient's other risk factors include hypertension  smoking  pre-diabetes  and past history of myocardial infarction increasing his propensity for thromboembolitic events. His lifestyle  including his occupation and lack of physical activity also contribute to the risk for DVT.  It is also important to notice his lack of adherence to prescribed treatment and healthy lifestyle changes  as this is an issue medical professionals often encounter in real-world practice. So  considerations regarding patient education  behavior modification measures and regular follow-ups are key to better prognosis.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  This case revolves around a 68-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Johnson.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has been suffering from hypertension and Type II diabetes for the past decade. He is a retired bank manager and used to smoke heavily during his youth  but has been abstinent for about 20 years. He is also obese with a BMI of 34. There's a positive family history of venous thromboembolism in his elder brother and mother. His medications include metformin  angiotensin II receptor blockers  and aspirin.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Johnson has recently returned from an international business trip  during which he had a long  non-stop flight. Over the past week  he has been complaining about progressive pain  swelling  and warmth in his left leg. He also mentioned sitting for prolonged periods during his journey and at the meeting. Today  he has come in with complaints of increased pain in his left leg and shortness of breath.  Please note that this overview of Mr. Johnson's case has been simplified for easy understanding and does not detail all aspects of his health profile.  *It should be recognized that while DVT can occur in anyone  certain conditions and lifestyle factors increase the risk. They include long periods of bed rest  smoking  being overweight or obese  pregnancy  birth control pills or hormone replacement therapy  a genetic predisposition  and age  among others. Mr. Johnson's profile includes several of these risk factors  which should be considered when devising his treatment plan.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Adam Thompson  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  retired professor residing in Seattle  Washington.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a history of obesity (BMI 31)  type 2 diabetes managed with oral hypoglycemic agents  and hypertension under control with medications. He has been a non-smoker for the last ten years  but there is a history of 30 pack-years smoking prior to cessation. He underwent a total right knee replacement surgery six weeks ago. His postoperative period was complicated due to decreased mobility and limited access to physical therapy due to the COVID-19 pandemic.   Key Complaints: In the last two days  Mr. Thompson has been experiencing progressive pain and swelling in his right lower leg which he initially accounted to overexertion during a session of physical therapy. However  the increase in the intensity of pain and worsening swelling  accompanied by a low-grade fever  prompted him to seek medical attention immediately. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath or coughing.  The case represents key risk factors for deep vein thrombosis including advanced age  obesity  history of recent surgery  limited mobility  and previous smoking history. Mr. Thomson's complaints of a progressively painful  swollen lower limb post-surgery are indicative of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) pending further examination and diagnostic tests. The absence of respiratory symptoms minimizes the chance of a pulmonary embolism  however  it should not be discounted and further evaluation should be recommended.   This case allows medical students to evaluate multiple risk factors leading to a typical case of DVT. It also shows the importance of time-sensitive management and the readiness to anticipate potential complications  particularly among higher-risk patients. Furthermore  the case points out how factors beyond the patient's direct medical history  such as limited access to physical therapy (a social determinant of health)  can impact the patient's health outcomes.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Demographic Information:  Patient: Mrs. Elizabeth Martinez Age: 63  Gender: Female Race: Hispanic Occupation: Retired teacher  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Martinez visited the outpatient department complaining of marked pain  swelling  and warmth in her left leg  which has progressively worsened over the last week. She also mentioned a mild heaviness in the chest and recent shortness of breath  particularly when climbing stairs.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension for the past 10 years  controlled with medication.  - Type II diabetes  diagnosed 8 years ago  managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. - She underwent total knee replacement surgery on her right knee six weeks back.  Family History: Her mother passed away due to a stroke (ischemic) at the age of 70 and her father had a history of varicose veins.  Lifestyle Information:  Mrs. Martinez is a non-smoker and she does not consume alcohol. She lives with her daughter and is fairly inactive due to her recent surgery. She mentions gaining some weight in the past year.  Observations: On physical examination  the left calf appears significantly swollen and red compared to the right. There is tenderness upon palpation. Her blood pressure reads at 140/90 and her body mass index (BMI) is calculated as 30  which falls into the category of obesity.  These symptoms prompt suspicion of deep vein thrombosis  which is occasionally seen post-surgery and exacerbated by her sedentary lifestyle and possible genetic predisposition. The shortness of breath and chest discomfort also indicate a possible pulmonary embolism which requires immediate investigation.  Note: The purpose of discussion around this case would be to teach medical students about the pathogenesis  risk factors  clinical features  diagnosis  complications  and management of deep vein thrombosis. Based on representation  it is worth noting that DVT does not discriminate by ethnicity  and individuals with diverse backgrounds can be affected. It's important to consider social determinants of health in the prevention and management of DVT.

Case Title: Assessment and Management of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics:  Patient Initials: T.M. Age: 60 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Software Engineer (sedentary job) Residence: Urban area  Past Medical History:  T.M. has a past history of hypertension  being controlled with lisinopril 10mg once daily. The patient had undergone a total right hip replacement due to osteoarthritis two years ago. He has no known allergies. T.M. has a 25 pack-years smoking history and occasionally consumes alcohol. His father had a history of myocardial infarction and his mother had a stroke.  Chief Complaint:  Patient presented to the outpatient clinic with complaints of gradual onset of pain in the left lower leg  which he describes as a constant  'heavy'  aching pain. Additionally  he reported mild swelling. The pain worsens with walk and eases when he raises the leg. Denies any chest pain  hemoptysis  recent travel or immobility  and trauma. No previous episodes of similar complaints.  Discussion:  This case is representative of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) for several reasons. The patient's age falls into the approximate range where incidence of DVT begins to increase significantly  with majority patterns reported in individuals aged between 50 and 60. Additionally  the patient is male and Caucasian  which reflect demographic trends reported in DVT cases.   His overall sedentary lifestyle as a software engineer  combined with his past surgical history  hypertension  smoking  and a family history of cardiovascular diseases further classifies him as predisposed to a prothrombotic state. The patient’s symptoms of left leg pain and swelling correlate with typical DVT symptoms  with the lack of chest pain and hemoptysis making pulmonary embolism less likely – though it should still be a consideration with any DVT.   This case could help medical students understand the risk factors  symptoms  and approach towards diagnosis and management of deep vein thrombosis. It's crucial to emphasize the importance of early recognition and treatment of DVT to prevent serious complications  such as pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Williams. He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban community. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history  quit smoking ten years ago. Drinks socially  on occasion.   Past Medical History: Mr. Williams has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily) and occasional hypercholesteremia controlled with diet and exercise. He has no known drug allergies. In addition  the patient had an uneventful right total knee arthroplasty performed eight weeks ago. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; father died due to myocardial infarction at age 73  and a brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his mid-60s.  Key Complaints: Mr. Williams presents with a four-day history of increasing pain  swelling  and redness in his right leg  the same leg where he had his recent knee surgery. He denies any history of trauma to the leg or any strenuous physical activities. He mentions that he has been mostly sedentary since his surgery  spending a lot of time sitting or lying down. He further reports experiencing mild shortness of breath for the past day but no chest pain. He hasn't experienced any recent fevers  chills  or other symptoms.   This case aims to highlight the risk factors for DVT  such as surgery  immobility  age  and tobacco use. Additionally  the signs and symptoms of DVT and potential complications such as pulmonary embolism are embodied in Mr. William's presentation. This scenario will offer learners the opportunity to discuss differential diagnoses  necessary diagnostic tests  and optimal management strategies for DVT  acknowledging the balance between anticoagulation and the risk of bleeding.   [Note: The objective of this case is solely for educational purposes and to reflect a common presentation of DVT. Patient details are fictional and any resemblance to real patients is purely coincidental.]

Patient Profile:  Name: John Pierce   Age: 68 years   Ethnicity: Caucasian (White)   Gender: Male   Occupation: Retired corporate executive   Location: Lives alone in a suburban setting    Past Medical History:   - Type 2 Diabetes  - Hypertension - Had total knee replacement surgery one month ago. - Known smoker for the last 40 years  currently trying to quit. - No known drug allergies  vivid family history  and negative for HIV status.  Presenting complaints:   John came to the emergency department with the chief complaints of: - Sudden onset of swelling in his left calf which started two days ago  with increased size. - Persistent pain described as throbbing in nature  more pronounced in the left leg. - Increased skin warmth and redness over the left lower leg. - Shortness of breath  particularly when climbing stairs or on exertion. - Intermittent chest pain for past 24 hours  characterized as a dull ache localized at the center of the chest.  The main objective of this case report is to educate medical students about deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's age  particularly post-surgery immobility  history of smoking  and other comorbidities like Diabetes and Hypertension make him relatively high-risk. The nature of symptoms also strongly suggests DVT. The case will unravel how to diagnose  manage such patients  and prevent complications. The students can also understand the need for prophylaxis in high-risk cases. This case should be adequately representative as the literature often cites older  immobilized  and post-surgical patients with comorbidities as high risk for DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis Training Case  Patient Information:  Name - Mr. Brian K. Age/Sex - 68-year-old male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaints:   The patient reports sudden onset moderate to severe pain in his left calf for the past one week. Additionally  he complains of increasing swelling of the affected leg and notes that his calf feels warm to the touch. There are no associated complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or hemoptysis.   Medical History:   Mr. Brian has a known history of Type-2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension. He is a former smoker who quit five years ago. He mentioned undergoing a right total knee arthroplasty 3 years back. There is no known history of coagulation disorders or previous venous thromboembolism.   Medications: Metformin 500mg twice daily  Lisinopril 20 mg once daily  Aspirin 75 mg once daily   Family History: His father suffered a stroke at age 70  and his mother has osteoarthritis. No known family history of deep vein thrombosis.   Lifestyle: He consumes alcohol occasionally and leads a sedentary lifestyle. His BMI is 31 indicating obesity.  This case was developed with an emphasis on demographic information consistent with findings in the literature. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)  the annual incidence of deep vein thrombosis is highest in those aged 60 years and older. Caucasians have been found to have a slightly higher incidence of DVT compared to other ethnicities. Several risk factors are included to illustrate the often multifactorial pathogenesis of DVT  including age  obesity  a sedentary lifestyle  recent surgery  and chronic medical conditions such as hypertension  diabetes  and smoking.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  previously desk job with minimal physical activity Lifestyle: Sedentary  non-smoker  light-to-moderate alcohol use   Past Medical History - Unilateral Total Knee Replacement 8 weeks ago - Controlled Hypertension for 25 years - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled with oral hypoglycemics - Mild Obesity (BMI - 30.5 kg/m2)  Presenting Complaints - Pain  swelling  and redness in right lower extremity  progressive over the last three days. - Mild difficulty in moving the right leg due to pain and discomfort. - No history of any recent trauma or injury. - No complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or any other systemic symptoms. - Heightened anxiety due to symptom progression.  Patient risk factors for the case of DVT include age  post-surgical status  prolonged periods of immobility due to sedentary lifestyle and recent surgery  controlled hypertension  obesity  and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  This training case is designed to prompt medical students to suspect deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in patients presenting with these symptoms and risk factors. The students should account diagnosis  investigation  treatment  and prevention strategies in their discussions.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)   Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Peterson Age: 63 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired mechanical engineer Living Situation: Lives alone   Past Medical History: Mr. Peterson has been managing type II diabetes for the last 15 years  which is relatively well-controlled on current regimen. Six years ago  he was diagnosed with Hypertension managed on Lisinopril. Four years ago  he had a cardiac stent inserted following a myocardial infarction. Since retirement two years ago  he has been sedentary and obese with a BMI of 30. There were no previous instances of DVT. He also reports a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years. He quit smoking after his MI four years ago.  Chief Complaints: Patient presented with a 3-day history of left unilateral leg swelling  redness  and tenderness. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough or light headedness. He also reported no overnight travels or prolonged bed rest. There's no history of injury to the swollen leg. Pain and swelling were not relieved by over-the-counter pain medication.   This case has been specifically designed to allow students to train on deep vein thrombosis. DVT is relatively common and is a critical medical condition. It's important to remember that some demographical groups (like elderly  obese individuals with a sedentary lifestyle and other risk factors like smoking and co-existing conditions such as diabetes and hypertension) are more at risk than others. The case also provides an opportunity to address the adverse effects of uncontrolled diabetes and importance of lifestyle measures like quitting smoking and maintaining a healthy weight.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  A 62-year-old African American male  employed as a long-distance truck driver  living in an urban setting.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of obesity with a BMI of 32  controlled hypertension  and smoking (1 pack/day for past 35 years). He does not lead an active lifestyle and has no history of surgeries. He has no known drug allergies. The family history reveals a father who died of a myocardial infarction and a mother with a personal history of deep vein thrombosis.  Chief Complaints: The patient presents at the Emergency Department with a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling in the left lower leg. He also reports a slight shortness of breath over the same period.  Present Illness: The patient reports mild  dull discomfort that began in the left calf 3 days ago  which has progressively worsened. He notes that the leg has become more swollen and appears more reddened than the other. He has noticed an increased shortness of breath particularly when climbing stairs  which was never an issue before.  Other symptoms include a mild chest discomfort and he noticed a low-grade fever last night. He denies any recent injuries  unexplained bleeding  or bruising. He also denies any fainting  severe headaches or abdominal pain.   Given these factors - including his sedentary profession  obesity  smoking habits  and personal family history of cardiovascular disease and DVT - the patient is at high risk for developing DVT  making it a key area of focus in his medical assessment and subsequent treatment.   Conclusion: This case report offers an opportunity for medical students to understand the risk factors  recognize the symptoms  and develop a comprehensive treatment plan for Deep Vein Thrombosis. The diverse background and lifestyle of the patient may also aid in understanding and addressing health disparities in veinous thromboembolism occurrences.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics- Name: Mr. Parker Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired computer engineer Location: Urban  Midwest USA  Past Medical History: 1) Hypertension - diagnosed 8 years ago  currently on medication (Lisinopril) 2) Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Diagnosed 6 years ago  managed with Metformin 3) Obesity - BMI 32.1 4) Past smoker - quit 4 years ago  smoked 1 pack/day for 35 years  5) Recent knee replacement surgery - underwent surgery 3 weeks ago still in recovery period.  Key complaints: Mr. Parker presents to the emergency department with a complaint of increased swelling and pain in his right leg  which has been progressively worsening over the past 2-3 days. He also mentions a light feeling of breathlessness and an occassional chest tightness. No associated fever  nausea or lightheadedness.  This case presents a typical picture seen in DVT cases of an elderly white male with past medical history of hypertension  diabetes and recent surgery (considered high-risk factors). He is obese and was a smoker  which are additional risk factors for the development of a thrombus. The unexplained leg swelling and pain warrant a high index of suspicion for DVT. His chest symptoms may indicate an advanced stage i.e. pulmonary embolism  which is a serious complication of DVT. It is important that the medical students learn to recognize the key symptoms and correlating risk factors to diagnose and treat DVT appropriately.   Further evaluation using diagnostic tools like D-dimer test and Duplex Ultrasound can confirm the suspected DVT and for pulmonary embolism  a CT pulmonary angiogram or a V/Q scan would be definitive. Understand that quick diagnosis and treatment initiation is vital in preventing potential lethal complications like Pulmonary Embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. D James  an African-American male aged 63 years old  lives in a suburban neighborhood in Atlanta  Georgia. He is a retired bus driver  leading a primarily sedentary lifestyle. He is married with two adult children and maintains a smoking habit of 20 cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. Overweight  with a BMI of 31 kg/m2.  Past Medical History:  Mr. James has a significant medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia which are reasonably controlled through medication. He had an incident of left lower extremity DVT 6 years ago. After hospitalization  he was treated with anticoagulation therapy for several months. There's no familial history of clotting disorders. He also had an appendectomy at the age of 22  no other previous surgeries noted.  Key Complaints:  The patient complains of acute onset pain and tenderness at the site of last DVT  his left lower leg  since waking up this morning. The pain has become progressively worse and is associated with swelling and redness. Despite attempts at alleviating the discomfort with over-the-counter analgesics and rest  the pain persisted. There is no fever  chest pain  or shortness of breath. He denies any recent trauma to the leg  prolonged periods of immobilization  or recent travels.  Note:  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) occurs in approximately 1 of 1 000 patients annually  commonly in elderly patients and slightly more frequently in males. The black population appears to be at a relatively higher risk of first-time VTE. Obesity  smoking  and a sedentary lifestyle are significant risk factors for DVT. Comorbidities such as diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia further increase the risk. A previous episode of DVT drastically elevates the chance of a recurrent DVT.   This training case represents a typical population profile  thus providing a realistic clinical scenario  emphasizing high-risk factors  accurate demographic representation  and common symptoms typical to DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Robert Turner Gender: Male Age: 62 Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Truck Driver  Medical History: Mr. Turner has been previously diagnosed with Type II Diabetes a decade ago. He is a former heavy smoker having quit 7 years back but admits to episodes of binge drinking. He reports being overweight and leading a sedentary lifestyle. He has not had any surgeries in the past. There is a family history of clotting disorders  with his elder sister diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) a few years back.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Turner presented to the emergency room with chief complaints of unilateral leg swelling and pain localized in the left calf for the past two days. He also reported shortness of breath that had recently worsened. The patient denied any recent travel  trauma  suppressive therapy  immobility  or oral contraceptive use.  On examination  the left calf was significantly swollen  warm to touch  and reddened with a distinct tenderness on palpation compared to the right. There was a marked difference in the circumference of the affected and unaffected leg. On review of systems  the patient presented with mild chest discomfort and shortness of breath  indicative of possible pulmonary embolism  a serious complication of DVT.   Reason for Case Study: This case highlights a typical profile of a patient at risk for DVT. Certain demographics  such as being a middle-aged Caucasian male  increase the risk. Lifestyle factors  such as obesity  sedentary living  smoking and alcohol consumption  also contribute to the risk profile. A familiar history of DVT is also important. Finally  the mild symptoms of pulmonary embolism should be noted for their high morbidity and mortality rate. This case can help students identify risk factors  suggest suitable diagnostic procedure  provide appropriate treatment  and offer prevention advice for patients susceptible to DVT.   Sources: 1. Grosse SD  Nelson RE  Nyarko KA  Richardson LC  Raskob GE. The economic burden of incident venous thromboembolism in the United States: A review of estimated attributable healthcare costs. Thromb Res. 2016;137:3-10.  2. Heit JA. Epidemiology of venous thromboembolism. Nat Rev Cardiol. 2015;12(8):464-474. 3. Kearon C. Natural history of venous thromboembolism. Circulation. 2003;107(23 Suppl 1):I22-I30.

Case Report   Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in an Elderly Caucasian Male  Patient Demographics:  Initials: M.J  Age: 68 Years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Banker Residence: Urban area  lives alone  Medical History:  M.J has had a usually good bill of health until five years ago when he was diagnosed with Type-II Diabetes Mellitus. He has been on metformin to control his blood glucose levels. He also has a history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril and Amlodipine. For the last 7 years  he has been on statins for his moderately high cholesterol levels. He does not have any known allergies to medications. M.J is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally. He leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle  with minimal physical activity. Family history includes a mother with a history of stroke and a father who died of heart attack.  Key Complaints:  M.J reports acute onset of pain and swelling in his right lower extremity  more specifically in the calf muscle  which he noticed this morning. He described the pain as a ""pulling sensation"". The pain has progressively gotten worse through the day. He reports no recent injuries  travels  or prolonged periods of immobility. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or any other systemic symptoms. He also denies any history of similar episodes in the past. Upon further questioning  he recalls that he has been experiencing more fatigue than usual and some unintended weight loss over the past few weeks.  As per current literature  males aged 65 and above have a higher incidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Lifestyle factors  such as sedentary behavior  along with the presence of comorbidities like hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  which MJ possesses  also increase the DVT risk.
