Early identification and management of DVT in older patients are crucial to prevent complications like pulmonary embolism  which can be potentially life-threatening.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics Name: Mr. Albert Brown Age: 65 years  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired school teacher Phys Address: 34 Pheasant Street  Hingham  Massachusetts  Past Medical History: Mr. Brown underwent a total knee replacement surgery on his right knee 4 weeks ago due to severe arthrosis. Notably  he has a history of hypertension and is currently on daily medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). He also takes low-dose aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular diseases. He is an ex-smoker and quit 10 years ago. However  he drank alcohol socially but in moderation. From his lifestyle details  he leads a sedentary life and lacks physical exercise on a regular basis. There are no known allergies.  Key Complaints: Mr. Brown visited the ER complaining of acute onset  unilateral swelling  and pain in his right lower calf region progressively worsening over the past 2 days. Redness and warmth over the affected area are also reported. Upon inquiry  he mentioned breathing problems intensifying with deep breaths and discomfort in his chest for the past several hours. He denied experiencing fever  recent trauma to his leg  or any family history of blood clots. He hasn’t reported any significant weight loss or unhealthy changes in his dietary routine. For the past few weeks post his knee surgery  he has been mostly confined to bed rest with limited mobility.  Additional Information: The fact that Mr. Brown is an elderly  post-arthroscopic  sedentary individual puts him at a high risk for deep vein thrombosis. The symptoms like shortness of breath and chest discomfort may indicate the possibility of a serious complication like pulmonary embolism. Therefore  he must be urgently evaluated and  if indeed a DVT is found  promptly treated.  Reference/Evidence: According to many studies  surgical patients have a 60% risk of developing a DVT as compared to the general population due to factors like immobility  vascular trauma  and hypercoagulable state. Also  important to note is the high risk associated with the elderly population and those with a sedentary lifestyle. [Source: Geerts WH  Pineo GF  Heit JA  et al. Prevention of venous thromboembolism: the Seventh ACCP Conference on Antithrombotic and Thrombolytic Therapy. Chest. 2004;126(3 Suppl):338S-400S.]

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Patient Initials: M.B. Age: 69 Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired accountant  living with her husband  Past Medical History: - Underwent knee replacement surgery 2 months ago - Diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago  under medication - No history of cardiovascular diseases - Occasional smoker  - No known allergies to medications  Key Complaints: Mrs. M.B. presented to the emergency department complaining of a swollen  red  warm leg. Her left calf specifically had worsened over three days  causing a lot of pain and discomfort while walking. She also reported a handful of instances of dyspnea over the last few days. She denied any chest pain  cough  or bleeding problems. There were no reports of recent trauma  prolonged travel  or family history of coagulation disorders.  ---  Note: This case scenario was developed based on the fact that deep vein thrombosis commonly affects the older population  particularly those who have undergone recent surgery or immobilization. As there's a higher prevalence among women than men  a female patient was chosen. The scenario also takes into consideration common risk factors like age and hypertension and provides a good basis for discussion about the diagnosis  management  and complications of venous thrombosis. This notably includes the potential for pulmonary embolism  indicated by the patient's dyspnea. Finally  the fact that she is Caucasian is representative of the higher prevalence of venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in individuals of European descent.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics ---------------------- Name: Mrs. Elaine Thompson Age: 45 years  Sex: Female  Ethnic Background: Caucasian (As per literature  the incidence rate of DVT is high among Caucasian women) Occupation: Corporate lawyer (mostly sedentary work)  Past Medical History ---------------------- 1. Overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. Obesity is a known risk factor for DVT. 2. Non-Smoker. 3. No known family history of DVT  but maternal grandmother had a history of stroke (potential non-genetic thrombotic risk factor). 4. No known history of malignancy. 5. No known allergies. 6. Regular Medications: Oral contraceptive pill for the previous 15 years.  7. Recently had an orthopedic injury (a broken ankle) 2 weeks ago  for which she underwent open reduction and internal fixation under general anesthesia. postoperative period unremarkable  she has been immobile since the surgery.  Key Complaints ---------------- Presenting to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of right leg pain  redness  warmth  swelling all over the calf region  and low-grade fever. She also complained of a pulling sensation in the leg with a mild  dull ache that intensifies with standing or walking. Denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitation.   Notes for the Medical Educator - -------------------------------- This case scenario provides an excellent tutorial for your medical students to learn about DVT as it encompasses various risk factors  including obesity  exogenous estrogen use (oral contraceptive pill)  recent surgery (orthopedic)  and immobilization. Furthermore  it provides an opportunity to teach about DVT's potential complications (like pulmonary embolism  post-thrombotic syndrome)  its diagnosis (history  physical examination  and investigations like D-dimer test  Doppler Ultrasound of affected region)  and its management (anticoagulation therapy  use of compression stockings  thrombolytic therapy etc). The students can also be taught about DVT prophylaxis in high-risk individuals. This case rightly represents common demographic traits as seen in clinical practice and would be beneficial for their future patient encounters.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information  Gender: Male Age: 62 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Taxi Driver (indicates prolonged periods of sitting)  Background and local demographic facts: According to scientific literature  the incidence of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is higher among the Caucasian population  older adults (above 40)  and those with sedentary occupations or lifestyles.   Past Medical History  - Non-Insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus for 15 years  controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents - Hypertension for 10 years  controlled with antihypertensive medications - Ex-smoker  quit 5 years ago - Had a minor stroke 2 years back with full recovery - Father and elder brother had history of DVT - Patient has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30  indicating obesity  Key Complaints  - Severe aching pain in right lower leg that started 2 days ago - Swelling and redness in right calf region - Mild fever and malaise for last 2 days - Feeling of warmth over the skin of the affected area - Unexplained shortness of breath started a few hours ago - No chest pain or palpitations  On examination  the right calf is found to be swollen  red and warmer than the left. The patient’s vitals are stable apart from a slightly elevated heart rate.   Teaching Notes: This typical case is designed to prompt students to: 1. Identify the risk factors for DVT (age  ethnicity  sedentary occupation  long-term chronic conditions such as diabetes and hypertension  family history of DVT  obesity and previous thrombotic event — minor stroke). 2. Recognize the common symptoms of DVT and relate the symptom of shortness of breath to a possible pulmonary embolism  a life-threatening complication of DVT. 3. Propose appropriate diagnostic tests (D-dimer blood test  Ultrasound  Venography  etc) 4. Propose a relevant management and treatment plan based on clinical guidelines  involving anticoagulant therapy and lifestyle changes to control risk factors. 5. Discuss the possibility of Preventive measures for DVT particularly in high-risk patients.

Case Report  Patient Name: Ms. Linda Jones Age: 53 years Sex: Female Race: White Occupation: Corporate Lawyer  Residence: Chicago  Illinois Insurance: Private Insurance  Past Medical History: 1. Obesity (BMI 30.3) 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  well-controlled on oral hypoglycemic agents for the last 5 years. 3. No history of any surgeries or hospitalizations. 4. Non-smoker and occasional alcohol use.  Family History: 1. Father passed away due to myocardial infarction. 2. Mother diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes. 3. Younger brother diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Presenting Complaints: 1. Gradual pain and swelling in the left calf for the last two weeks  which has been progressively increasing in intensity. 2. Warmth and redness over the area of pain and swelling in the left calf. 3. Shortness of breath started 2-3 days prior  more prominent when climbing stairs or doing other exertions. 4. Palpitations intermittently  started around the same time as shortness of breath. 5. No history of trauma or injury to the leg. 6. No history of recent immobilization or travel. 7. No history of chest pain  syncope  or loss of consciousness.  Taking into consideration that DVT is twice common among people older than 50 years  and the incidence rates are higher in females  the patient's demographics are designed. Ms. Jones's occupation indicates a prolonged sitting duration increasing the risk for DVT  and attributes like obesity and her diabetes history are common risk factors for the same. Her family history of cardiovascular ailments and diabetes further justifies the risks. Her symptoms are classic for DVT and possibly a pulmonary embolism: the most serious complication of DVT.   Sources: Kearon C. et al. Antithrombotic Therapy for VTE Disease. Chest. 2016;149(2):315-352.  White RH. The epidemiology of venous thromboembolism. Circulation. 2003;107(23_suppl_1):I14-I18.  Fang MC  et al. Advances in the diagnosis of venous thromboembolism. JAMA. 2008;300(12):1464-1474.   National Institute for Health and Care Excellence. Venous thromboembolic diseases: diagnosis  management and thrombophilia testing. June 2020.

Case Report  Subject: Training Case for Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:   The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  named Michael  who is a retired office worker. He is slightly overweight with a BMI (Body Mass Index) of 27. Michael is a former two-pack-a-day smoker but quit a decade ago.   Past Medical History:  He had a history of right leg total knee arthroplasty about a year ago due to osteoarthritis. He also suffers from chronic hypertension  controlled with daily medication. His family history discloses his father’s death from a pulmonary embolism at age 75.  Presenting Complaints:  Michael presents with complaints of a red  warm  swollen  progressively painful right lower leg which started two days ago. He denies any injury  insect bite  or rash. He feels a slight shortness of breath when walking  but no chest pain. However  due to current COVID-19 pandemic  he delayed his hospital visit. His last long travel was his tour to Europe six months ago.  Background:  Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) occurs more frequently with increasing age  with a reported annual incidence of ~1 per 1 000 persons in the general population. It has previously been associated with a personal history of venous thromboembolism  recent surgery or trauma  malignancy  pregnancy  estrogen use  certain genetic conditions  prolonged immobility  and increasing age. Obesity and smoking are also considered risk factors. A DVT which affects the leg can cause symptoms such as pain  swelling  redness  warmth  and a heavy ache.  This case report of a 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of knee arthroplasty  hypertension  former smoker  and overweight status represent typical risk factors for DVT. Participants should be prompted to initially consider a DVT in the differential diagnosis due to these factors and presenting symptoms.   This case aims to provide requisite knowledge and understanding for medical students about the risk factors  signs  symptomatology  and diagnostic approach of Deep Vein Thrombosis as it is a highly prevalent and potentially fatal condition if not diagnosed and managed efficiently.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  non-smoker. She reported that she is sedentary most of the time and socially drinks alcohol. She is a widower with three grandchildren. She lives alone but has a support network of friends and family. She is 5 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 160 pounds  with a BMI of 27.5  which is considered overweight.   Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  controlled with lisinopril. She also has type 2 diabetes managed with metformin and diet control. She has been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia for which she takes atorvastatin. The patient has no known drug allergies. She reported no previous surgeries or hospitalizations. Her mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis.   Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented to the emergency department with a 3-day history of gradually worsening pain and swelling in her left lower leg. The swelling is localized and does not extend to the entire leg. She also reported warmth over her calf. She has not experienced any symptoms such as chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  or fainting. She denied recent travel  surgery  or immobilization.   This case report is intended to represent the fact that the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) increases with age. According to the NCBI  ""two-thirds of all VTE events occur in individuals aged 60 and over"" with the occurrence being slightly higher in females. The patient’s older age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and genetic predisposition (mother with DVT history) make her more prone to DVT. Furthermore  her chronic conditions such as hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  which are common in the older population  give an opportunity to discuss the potential risks and complications in such patients.

Patient Case for Clinical Training: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Presentation: Patient: Mr. Johnson  Age: 62 years old Gender: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Patient's Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has been previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. He is also a former smoker and quit smoking 5 years ago. He has a BMI of 28 and has been labeled as overweight.  According to his records  Mr. Johnson had a minor heart attack two years ago  for which he was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention. Mr. Johnson's medication history includes that he is on metformin for diabetes  atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and low-dose aspirin  which was started following his heart attack.   Patient's Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson is presenting in the Emergency Department with a complaint of sudden onset  unilateral  severe calf pain and swelling in his right lower leg. He notes that the swelling has worsened over the last three to four days  so much so that it's hindering his mobility now. He also mentions that the leg feels warm to the touch and he's noted a slight change in the skin color to a reddish-blue tinge. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or any recent travels or immobilization.  Mr. Johnson's wife  who accompanied him to the hospital  noted that he's seemed increasingly fatigued over the past week  something unusual for him.  Summary: This case is of a 62-year-old overweight male who has a history of type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and previous myocardial infarction. He presented with typical symptoms indicative of a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). These include calf pain  limb swelling  warmth  and discoloration all localized to one leg  specifically the lower limb. His risk factors include his age  obesity  and his medical history. This case is meant to highlight the presentation  risk factors  and management of a DVT  as well as the potential for serious complications  such as pulmonary embolisms  which this patient is at higher risk for given his cardiac history.    Note: While the patient hasn't mentioned any recent travels or immobilization  it's crucial to remember that medical history often involves details that can sometimes be overlooked or forgotten  and these could potentially alter the management and outcomes dramatically.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information: -The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe. -He is a retired postal worker  currently living with his wife in a suburban area. He has a 35-pack-year history of smoking but has no known alcohol or illicit drug use.  -His family history is significant for stroke in his father at the age of 70 and myocardial infarction in his mother at the age of 65.  Past Medical History: -John has been diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 7 years.  -He is currently on oral antihypertensive medication (Amlodipine Besylate) and oral antidiabetic medication (Metformin).  -No previous surgical history is present. -John is a frequent traveler and recently returned from a transatlantic flight 4 days prior to presenting to the hospital. -He does not engage in physical activity regularly and is predominantly a sedentary individual.  Presenting Complaints: -John's primary complaint is a swollen  reddish  and painful left lower limb that has been worsening over the past two days.  -He also mentions experiencing a mild shortness of breath. However  he denies any associated chest pain  light-headedness  palpitations  or cough. -He acknowledges that he hasn’t been drinking adequate fluids during his recent travel.  Based on strong epidemiological evidence  John's age  sedentary lifestyle  smoking history  recent long-distance travel  and current symptoms point towards a high index of suspicion for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). The mild shortness of breath could indicate a possible pulmonary embolism  which is a known complication of DVT. The case should focus on the appropriate diagnostic workup and treatment plan for DVT alongside engaging students in the discussion of patient education on risk factor modification and disease prevention.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Patient Name: Ms. Johnson  Age: 55 Gender: Female Race: Caucasian (White) Occupation: Office worker (sedentary job)  Past Medical History: Ms. Johnson has a past medical history of obesity (BMI 32)  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She is a former smoker who quit about 10 years back and has no known blood clot or bleeding disorders. She uses an estrogen-progestogen combined oral contraceptive. She is not diabetic  does not consume alcohol and she has no family history of thromboembolic diseases. Two years ago  she had an arthroscopic knee surgery. Postoperatively  she developed deep vein thrombosis which was treated with anticoagulation therapy. The patient did not have any recurrent thrombotic events post-therapy.  Key Complaints:  In the past week  Ms. Johnson has been experiencing discomfort in her left calf. The discomfort has gradually worsened  and it is now a dull aching pain in her whole leg. The left calf also seems to have become swollen in comparison to the right. She reports no warmth or redness over the area but notices that her left leg appears to have become slightly discolored  obtaining a bluish hue. She has no associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or any other systemic symptoms.  It's important to note that deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a common disorder  with incidence rates in the general population of around 1-2 per 1000 individuals annually  but the risks are higher in older people (aged > 60 years)  and those with certain risk factors (e.g.  obesity  immobility  surgery  trauma  malignancy  pregnancy  or certain inherited or acquired thrombophilias).    Case based on these demographics and symptoms suggests a likely recurrence of deep vein thrombosis. Factors that would make the diagnosis likely includes her sedentary lifestyle  the use of combined oral contraceptives and her history of a prior DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics:  Ms. Fernandez  a 67-year-old Hispanic female  retired school teacher living in Santa Ana  California along with her 70 years old husband  who is her primary caregiver. She is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol.  Past Medical History/Relevant Family History: Ms. Fernandez has a validated medical history of obesity (BMI 32.2 kg/m2)  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hypothyroidism. She has been compliant with her medication regimen including Metformin  Lisinopril  and Levothyroxine. She also reports a family history of cardiovascular disease  as her father had a cardiac bypass surgery in his 60s  and her mother  who died at 72  suffered from stroke.  Key Complaints: Ms. Fernandez presented to the clinic with a principal complaint of increasing discomfort  warmth  and swelling in her left leg that she noted 2 days ago. The symptoms progressed  with the pain growing worse when she tried to move her foot. She also mentioned recent mild shortness of breath that started roughly at the same time as the leg pain. However  she denied chest pain  cough  seizures  fever  or recent trauma. She also mentioned she hasn't been able to exercise for the past few weeks and has spent most of her time sitting due to the ongoing pandemic and her fear of exposure.  Learning Points: 1. The clinical presentation of Ms. Fernandez indicates symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) associated with several risk factors like advanced age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and other comorbidities. Studies show that Hispanics are less likely to develop DVT than non-Hispanic whites  but there are several individual factors beyond race/ethnicity contributing to her risk. 2. The presence of shortness of breath alongside symptoms of DVT could indicate a possible pulmonary embolism  which warrants urgent diagnostic testing. 3. It’s important to take a patient-centered approach when deciding on testing and treatment. It should involve discussions around risks  benefits  and patient preferences. 4. The importance of DVT prevention strategies  particularly in those deemed to be high risk  should be emphasized to further reduce the incidence and subsequent morbidity and mortality associated with DVT and PE. 5. Patient education and awareness about maintaining a balanced diet and active lifestyle even during pandemic restrictions would be beneficial in managing obesity  diabetes  and reducing the risk of DVT.

Subjec: DVT  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Maria Gonzalez Age: 65 years old Sex: Female Race/Ethnicity: Hispanic  Past Medical History: Mrs. Gonzalez has significant history of: 1. Hypertension for 10 years - currently on Lisinopril 10mg. 2. Type II diabetes for over 13 years - managed by Metformin. 3. Recently had an elective total knee replacement surgery 1 week ago.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Gonzalez visited the ER complaining of acute onset pain and swelling in her right lower leg that has been progressively worsening over the last 1-2 days. The pain increases when she tries to flex or extend her leg. She has rated the pain at an 8/10 severity. She denies any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  or lightheadedness. She has been noncompliant with her post-operative leg exercises and inappropriately discontinuing her prophylactic anticoagulants.  Rationale: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is most common in elderly patients  especially in postoperative periods (as in our case of knee replacement surgery). Factors such as obesity  history of previous DVT  immobilization  malignancy  history of spontaneous abortion or stillbirth  recent trauma or surgery  and oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy use risk factors for DVT. This medical case is a demonstration of both underlying risk factors  i.e.  obesity  past surgery and age-related slower recovery along with patient's non-compliance to anticoagulation as a trigger factor. Although DVT can occur in any ethnicity  Caucasians and African Americans are generally at higher risk. However  it is essential to remember that it can happen in any racial or ethnic group  as in our patient of Hispanic ethnicity.   Additionally  this case allows the students to practice their diagnostic and clinical decision-making skills. The teaching case provides the opportunity to discuss the risk and factors for developing DVT  to explore the symptoms and signs of DVT  and to identify the need for immediate treatment.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Patient Name: James Thompson Age: 63 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired civil servant Marital Status: Married State of Residence: North Carolina  Past Medical History: - Hyperlipidemia treated with statins - Non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin - History of smoking – 1 pack daily for 30 years  quit 10 years ago - Sedentary lifestyle  - No previous surgeries - No known drug allergies  Key Complaints: The patient presents with a 2-day history of swelling  redness  and persistent pain in the left calf  rating the pain as 7 on a scale of 1-10  making it hard for him to walk. No reported fever or recent trauma. No chest pain  dyspnea  palpitations  syncope  or other systemic symptoms. Concerned about the sudden onset  he consulted due to his family’s history of cardiovascular diseases.   Clinical Findings: On examination  the left calf is visibly swollen and warm to touch with mild erythema. He has a palpable cord along the distribution of the left popliteal vein. The Homans' sign is positive. His vitals are stable  and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   Note: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) has a higher incidence in men than women  and the risk increases with age. DVT most frequently occurs in patients aged 60-80. Caucasians are more frequently affected than any other racial group.   To present a balanced demographic representation  subsequent cases should introduce patients from different racial backgrounds  sexes  and age groups.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics:  - Name: Mr. Johnson - Age: 69 years old - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian (This demographic has been selected based on studies indicating higher prevalence rates of DVT among the population of white race.) - Occupation: Retired Bank Manager - Place of Residence: Urban area  Past Medical History:  - BMI: 33 (Obese) - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - Hypertension - Hypothyroidism - Former smoker (quit 5 years ago) - Underwent right hip replacement surgery a year ago  Key Complaints:  - Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department complaining of discomfort in his right leg  which has been progressive for the last three days. - He states that the pain grew increasingly worse  especially when standing or walking. - He further mentions experiencing unilateral leg swelling  redness  and warmth over the right calf area. - He denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness. - He said that he had been relatively sedentary recently  spending a lot of time sitting and reading due to being housebound given the pandemic situation. - Post-hip surgery  he had been on blood thinners but stopped taking them around six months back  on his own.  This case is designed to simulate a real-life scenario where a senior patient  following major orthopedic surgery with other risk factors like obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and non-compliance to anticoagulant therapy  presents with typical symptoms of DVT. It enables students to put into practice their knowledge and demonstrate their skills in history taking  examination  diagnosis  and prophylactic treatment of DVT. The case also highlights the importance of patient adherence to medication and post-surgery care  which are crucial aspects of managing chronic conditions. It will help in creating more engagement and awareness among students about the complexities of managing DVT in the clinical context.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Patient is a 60-year old  overweight Hispanic male. He is a retired truck driver  married with three grown children  and lives in an urban setting. He is a moderate smoker for the last 30 years and consumes alcohol socially.   Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of uncontrolled Type II diabetes and hypertension  which have been managed with medications for the last 10 years. Six months ago  he underwent a total knee replacement surgery following a severe fall. The post-surgery rehab consultation indicated that the patient was not fully compliant with physiotherapy. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his elder brother was diagnosed with DVT at age 58.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a 3-day history of swelling  redness  warmth  and pain in the calf of his right leg. The pain has been progressively worsening and is particularly noticeable when he tries to walk. He also reports having episodes of mild shortness of breath since yesterday. He notes that these symptoms have been causing significant discomfort and preventing him from carrying out his daily activities.   Clinical Suspicion:  There is a high likelihood of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) given the patient’s risk factors like his past major orthopedic surgery  prolonged immobility  obesity  advanced age  family history  and other comorbidities posed by diabetes and hypertension. The shortness of breath could indicate a possibility of a pulmonary embolism. An immediate diagnostic evaluation and if confirmed  follow-up treatment is necessary to prevent further life-threatening complications.  (Sources: Based on demographic representation from the American Journal of Medicine  Archives of Internal Medicine  and British Journal of Surgery).   **Please note that this case is an educational example and should not be used as a guide for real patient assessment or management. The management of each patient should be individualized after considering the appropriate history  physical examination findings  and diagnostic test results.**

Patient Case: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Scenario: A 60-year-old Caucasian male named Bob comes to the clinic complaining of swelling  pain  redness  and warmth in his left lower leg.  Demographics: The patient is married  retired  and lives in a suburban area. He is a former smoker  has a history of moderate alcohol use  but quit smoking 10 years ago.   Past Medical History: Bob has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medications. He has recently been on a long-haul flight of about 8 hours from Europe to the United States. He underwent right hip replacement surgery a year ago due to osteoarthritis. He reports he is not physically active and spends most of his time at home reading and watching television  which makes him relatively sedentary. His BMI is 28  marking him as overweight. Bob's father also experienced DVT in his early sixties.   Key Complaints: Bob describes his lower leg pain as a heavy ache or cramp that gets worse when he walks or flexes his foot. He further explains that the pain appeared suddenly  about two days ago. He says the swelling also appeared around the same time and has progressively worsened. The patient reports no fever  cough  chest pain  or shortness of breath. On examination  his left calf circumference is greater than his right calf.  Note: The demographic and history details highlight some of the common risk factors for DVT. These risk factors include age  obesity  immobility (due to surgery and sedentary lifestyle)  prolonged travel without movement  family history  and existence of other medical conditions like hypertension and diabetes. This scenario is designed to aid in diagnosing DVT and strategizing treatment according to the patient's unique risk factors and health conditions.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Demographics: The patient is a 62-year-old African American male retired from his job as a truck driver and currently leading a slightly sedentary lifestyle. He is a smoker with a 45-pack year history.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  controlled with medication  and Type II diabetes mellitus for the past ten years  which is moderately controlled with oral hypoglycaemic agents. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease  his father experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 68. The patient had a hip replacement surgery 5 weeks ago and has been less active since then.  Key Complaints: The patient complains of having an increasing swelling  pain  and warmth in the left calf over the past 48 hours. He denies having any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations. He has had no bleeding or bruising. He states he has been strictly adhering to his medication regimen.  Reason for Admission: Considering the patient's demographics  past medical history  lifestyle  and current complaints  he was admitted for a suspected Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). No signs for Pulmonary Embolism (PE) were present  but it needs to be ruled out due to a common pathophysiology between DVT and PE.   Clinical evaluation  D-Dimer test  and compression ultrasonography can confirm the diagnosis. The sensitive nature of diagnosis and high-risk factors such as postoperative status  advanced age  African American descent  smoking history and the presence of comorbid conditions signify the severity of the case.  The clinical presentation of this patient aligns with the common demographic representation of DVT patients  as evidenced in the literature  which states that DVT is more prevalent in the elderly  smokers  postoperative patients  those with an inherited blood clot disorder  obese individuals and those with long-term health issues such as diabetes and hypertension.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis Training  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. Margaret Davis  residing in an urban area. She is a retired teacher who lives independently. She reports a sedentary lifestyle with occasional walks around her neighborhood. She has a body mass index (BMI) of 28.3  suggestive of overweight. Her socio-economic status falls into the middle-income bracket.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Davis has a history of hypertension  for which she has been on medication (Losartan 50mg once daily)  and recurrent varicose veins for which she has had two surgeries in the past. She also has a 15-year history of smoking  although she ceased completely 5 years ago. She does not report any history of cancer  autoimmune or hematological disorders. She has not had any recent surgeries or hospitalizations  and she has no known drug allergies.   Furthermore  she has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; her mother passed away due to a myocardial infarction and a paternal grandmother who suffered from a stroke. She is up-to-date with all necessary immunizations for her age group and receives regular preventive care.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Davis presents with complaints of increasing pain  warmth  and swelling in her left leg  particularly in the calf  for over a week. She denies any trauma or injury to the region. She also reports experiencing intermittent shortness of breath and light-headedness in the past three days. She does not report chest pain or heart palpitations. Her symptoms seem to be getting progressively worse  which prompted her to seek medical attention.  Validity Note: The chosen patient's demographics and health concerns were designed mindful of data indicating that older  overweight females are among those with higher risks for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Moreover  conditions such as hypertension and varicose veins  history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of cardiovascular diseases make her an appropriate candidate for a DVT scenario. Incorporating these specific details aims to provide realistic and practical case training for medical students studying DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics:   - Name: Mr. Luis Gonzales - Age: 51 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Hispanic - Occupation: Long-haul truck driver - Place of residence: New Mexico  USA  Past Medical History:  - Former smoker  quit 10 years ago - Moderate alcohol consumption - Body Mass Index (BMI): 32 (obese) - Hypertension  under treatment with beta-blockers - Family history of venous thromboembolism  Primary Complaint:   Mr. Gonzales has reported experiencing a dull  aching pain in his left lower leg for the past four days. The pain intensifies when standing or walking. Upon examination  localized warmth  erythema  and edema are noticed in the left calf region. There is no associated chest pain or shortness of breath. However  he recalls two recent events where he was immobilized for extended periods due to his job. First  he had a cross-country delivery assignment two weeks ago and recently  a breakdown scenario led to sitting for prolonged periods in his truck.   Considering the patient's profiles and symptoms  this could be a case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Various risk factors such as prolonged immobility  obesity  former smoking  and a family history of venous thromboembolism collectively precipitate the possibility of this diagnosis.  If literature is referred  DVT is commonly seen in individuals aged 40 and above  with increasing age being a strong risk factor. Men have slightly greater risks than women. Further  long-haul truck drivers are at higher risk due to prolonged immobilized state during long routes. Obesity  sedentary lifestyle  smoking  and usage of certain medicines also contribute to increased risk. In Mr. Gonzales's case  these demographics and risk factors are accurately represented. Furthermore  his Hispanic ethnicity warrants consideration because literature suggests that there is a lower prevalence of DVT in Hispanic populations compared to other ethnic groups which could lead to potential underdiagnosis  reinforcing the need for a high index of suspicion.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  **Patient Demographics:**  Name: Mr. Hampton Age: 68 years Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired  Location: North Carolina  USA  **Past Medical History:**  Mr. Hampton has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus. He also has a 20-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. The patient underwent total knee arthroplasty three months prior  and he also reports a family history of pulmonary embolism.  **Presenting Complaints:**  The patient came to the emergency department reporting a three-day history of progressive left calf pain with associated swelling and mild warmness. He hasn't faced any traumatic injury recently. The symptoms worsened during the periods when he had to sit for a prolonged duration. He also complained of a slight shortness of breath.  **Physical Examination:**  On examination  he had a temperature of 98.6°F  blood pressure of 135/88 mmHg  a pulse rate of 84 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. His left lower leg was noticeably swollen with mild erythema. Popliteal and calf tenderness were noted on palpation of the left leg.   The case thus elaborates the clinical presentation of a patient suspected of Deep Vein Thrombosis. The subsequent learning and teaching will revolve around pathophysiology  risk factors (including sedentary lifestyle post-surgery  age  smoking  hypertension  diabetes)  necessary clinical assessments  diagnostic strategies (like D-dimer  compression ultrasound)  treatment options (anticoagulation therapy)  prevention strategies  and potential complications evolving from DVT (like pulmonary embolism  post-thrombotic syndrome).

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  - Patient Initials: J.S. - Age: 68 years - Sex: Female - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaints: Swelling  pain  redness  and warmth in the right lower leg  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 3. Hypercholesterolemia  Detailed Past Medical History: The patient  J.S.  is a 68-year-old Caucasian female. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago and hypertension 6 years ago  controlled in both cases via oral medication. She was also diagnosed with Hypercholesterolemia 1 year ago  maintained with dietary changes and medication.  J.S. is a former smoker  having quit 5 years ago but smoked 1 pack a day for 40 years. She maintains a BMI within the obese range  despite dietary changes. She is a retired school teacher and now leads a sedentary lifestyle. She reported a long plane journey of about 12 hours approximately 10 days ago. No known allergies reported.  She has no history of cancer  heart disease  or genetic blood disorders. No family history of clotting disorders  though her father and a brother both suffered from cardiovascular diseases.  The patient has been on oral antihypertensive medication (amlodipine) and oral hypoglycemic agents (metformin). For her cholesterol  she’s been taking atorvastatin.  Key Complaints: J.S. attended the clinic with complaints of a painful  swollen right lower leg that had been progressively worsening over the last few days. The skin over her leg was warm to touch and slightly reddish. She also mentioned a mild fever and general fatigue. She has no complaint of chest pain  shortness of breath  hemoptysis  or similar symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism.  Conclusion: Considering J.S.'s age  obesity  recent lengthy travel  sedentary lifestyle  and history of smoking  there might be a high index of suspicion for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Further investigations (like Doppler ultrasonography  D-dimer levels) and management should be done based on clinical guidelines.  Note: This case was built based on data stating higher DVT prevalence in individuals over 60  female gender  Caucasian race  and those with co-morbid conditions  including hypertension  obesity  diabetes  and a history of smoking. Also  long duration travels are a known risk for DVT.

Case Report on Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: JM  a 60-year-old African American male  working as a truck driver for 25 years  presents for an office visit. He is a former smoker and quit smoking about five years ago. He lives with his wife in a suburban area. He has a BMI of 32  which means he falls in the obese category. Recent literature indicates that this demographic tends to have a somewhat higher risk of DVT  with obesity  advanced age and prolonged immobility as major risk factors.  Past Medical History: Mr. M has a medical history of type 2 diabetes  for which he is controlling with diet  exercise  and metformin. He has hypertension well-controlled with lisinopril. He does not have any known genetic clotting disorders but has a family history of DVT with his father. His surgical history is unremarkable; he had a cholecystectomy 10 years ago due to cholelithiasis with no complications. He takes aspirin 81 mg daily as prophylaxis for cardiovascular health. He denies any drug allergies.  Key Complaints: Mr. M presents with complaints of progressive left calf pain over the last four days  which is worsened by standing and walking and relieves partially on elevation. He noticed it first after sitting for a prolonged period at his office desk. He also reported swelling of the same calf and mild warmth around the region. He denies experiencing any recent trauma  chest pain  shortness of breath  or other major complaints.  Evaluating these complaints and considering his risk factors (obesity  prolonged immobility due to his job  older age  family history of DVT); a hypothesis of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is highly suspected. A comprehensive diagnostic and management plan is essential to avoid associated complications like pulmonary embolism. This case would further train medical students on how to approach and manage such patients effectively.    Reference: - ""Risk factors for venous thromboembolism"". Circulation. 2008 May 20;117(20):2671-8. doi: 10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.107.709204. Epub 2008 May 12.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Identifiables: Mr. Edward Harris Age: 68 years Sex: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian Address: Atlanta  Georgia  USA  Past Medical History: Mr. Harris is a retired military veteran who is generally in good health with his only past medical challenge being hypertension  diagnosed about five years ago  which is managed with regular medication. He also underwent a hip replacement surgery 6 months prior due to a motor vehicle accident and has also been treated for mild lower extremity peripheral artery disease two years ago. Mr. Harris is also an active smoker for the last 30 years and lives a relatively sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Harris presents with a three-day history of increasing pain  swelling  and warmth in his right calf. Today  he noticed increasing redness and the calf has become substantially swollen and tender. He denies trauma but notes prolonged periods of sitting due to recent cross-country car travel.  This case has been designed to provide a realistic and comprehensive case scenario of deep vein thrombosis in the context of the patient's demographics and medical history. As per the literature  the prevalence of deep vein thrombosis is higher in older adults (above 60)  with risk factors including prior surgery  prolonged periods of immobilization  and an active smoking history. This case report will enable medical students to understand the key signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis  appreciate the significance of a patient’s lifestyle  the impact of previous medical history and take into consideration the risk factors while diagnosing and suggesting appropriate treatment.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. X  Age: 59 Sex: Male Ethnic Background: Caucasian  Occupation: Long-haul truck driver Location: Midwest  United States Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle  smoking pack a day for the past 40 years  overweight (BMI: 30)  Past Medical History: He has been treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the last 5 years  maintained on Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for which he takes Metformin. No history of allergies or surgical procedures is reported. Family history reveals his mother suffered from varicose veins and his father died of a myocardial infarction at age 65.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. X presents to the hospital with complaints of progressive left leg pain and mild swelling that has persisted over the last three days. The swelling looks more pronounced towards the end of the day. He also shares that his leg feels unusually warm to touch and slightly red. He denies having chest pain  breathing difficulty  recent trauma  or surgery.   The case aims to train medical students on identifying  diagnosing  and managing deep vein thrombosis (DVT). High suspicion of DVT should be maintained because of the patient's advanced age  sedentary job  obesity  smoking habit  and history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Diabetes Mellitus  all of which are factors that increase the risk for deep vein thrombosis. This case will require understanding of how to conduct a physical examination  order appropriate diagnostic testing  and consider possible treatment options for the management of DVT.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: - Age: 60 years old - Gender: Female - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Office job  sedentary lifestyle  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history that includes hypertension  obesity (BMI 33)  and type-2 diabetes  which is being managed with lifestyle adjustments and medication (Insulin). She is a former smoker  quitting about 5 years ago after 30 years of smoking. She is also on oral contraceptives for menopausal symptoms. She has had no previous episodes of DVT or pulmonary embolism  and no known family history of coagulation disorders. Recently the patient had fractured her ankle which has limited her mobility significantly.  Key Complaints: On presentation  the patient complained of:  - Pain and swelling in her right calf over the past two days  growing progressively worse. - The calf is warm compared to the other leg and appears slightly red. - Mild shortness of breath  but no chest pain. - No fainting episodes. - No other areas of swelling or discomfort.  Reporting this case study prompts the learners to identify and understand risk factors of deep vein thrombosis such as obesity  age  prolonged immobility  hormone therapy  smoking past  and co-existing conditions like diabetes and hypertension. The main focus is to recognize the signs and symptoms of DVT  adopt appropriate diagnostic procedures  and manage the condition effectively.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information:   Mr. James Walsh  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  is a retired truck driver who lives with his wife. He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago. He is generally healthy  with only mild hypertension managed with lifestyle modifications rather than medications. He has no known drug allergies  and his BMI is within the healthy range. His father had a history of DVT and pulmonary embolism (PE).   Chief Complaints:  Mr. Walsh reports an aching  cramping pain in his right calf that began suddenly five days ago. He says the pain is sometimes severe and worsens when he walks. He also reports mild swelling and redness in the same leg. He notes no chest pain  shortness of breath  or fainting  indicating no apparent symptoms of PE. However  he admits to sitting for prolonged hours in his hobby of bird-watching with little leg movement.  Emphasizing Factors:  The patient’s age  sedentary lifestyle  and the family history of DVT and PE should be highlighted in this case as these are significant risk factors for DVT. Also  consider the fact that DVT often presents with non-specific symptoms  so a high level of suspicion is necessary. The apparent lack of PE symptoms should not exclude DVT.   Note:  Real-life patient populations may vary  but this concise case study encompasses the majority of risk factors associated with DVT. According to literature  DVT is most common in adults over 60 and in people with prolonged immobility  major surgery or trauma  cancer  pregnancy  estrogen use  previous DVT or PE  and certain inherited or acquired disorders that affect blood clotting. It should be noted that DVT can also occur in individuals who don't fall within these risk factors  particularly those with underlying genetic predispositions.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented with sudden onset swelling  redness  warmth  and pain in his left lower extremity  specifically in the calf muscles. He complained of a heavy ache which intensified when he stood or walked.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a past medical history of hypertension  controlled with medication  and Stage 1 Chronic Kidney Disease. He is a former smoker  having quit five years ago  but has a 30 pack-year smoking history. He reports a sedentary lifestyle and Recently  he had a total knee replacement surgery on the left side. Additionally  he holds a personal history of a myocardial infarction 8 years prior.  Social History:  Mr. Smith is retired and lives alone  although nearby to his daughter and her family. He admits to frequent alcohol use  usually about two beers every evening.  Family History:  His father died of a myocardial infarction  his mother was diabetic  and one of his sisters suffered from a pulmonary embolism.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination revealed  in the left leg  an edematous calf  with erythema and localized warmth. Popliteal and pedal pulses were palpable. No changes in consciousness  breath sounds are clear to auscultation without any wheezes or crackles  and cardiovascular examination was unremarkable with a regular rhythm and no murmurs.  Summary:  This case focuses on a 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a surgical history and sedentary lifestyle  who has presented with symptoms suggesting deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's age  prior surgery  personal and family history showcase an elevated risk for thromboembolic diseases  including DVT and its potential to progress into a pulmonary embolism. Considering the patient's age and demographics  this scenario is consistent with literature reporting individuals over 60 years  specifically postoperative  sedentary individuals  as being more susceptible to developing DVT.

Patient Information: Mrs. Dorothy Fisher  65-year-old African American female.   Past Medical History: Hypertension  Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 (on Metformin)  past smoker (quit 10 years prior)  and morbid obesity.  Chief Complaints: Mrs. Fisher presents to the emergency department reporting a 3-day history of increasing left calf pain and swelling. She states that the pain is constant and describes it as a deep ache. She also mentions intermittent sensations of heat in the leg. She denies any recent lower extremity trauma  recent surgeries  or long-distance flights.  In order to complete the case  this additional information can be considered:  Family History: Mrs. Fisher's older sister reportedly suffered from a blood clot in her 70s.   Physical Examination: On examination  Mrs. Fisher’s left calf appears markedly swollen  red  and warm to touch compared to the right. There is a tenderness along the distribution of the deep venous system.  Investigations: Coagulation screening + D-Dimer test  Doppler Ultrasound of lower extremity  Chest X-ray in order rule out Pulmonary Embolism.  Concepts to Discuss: Process of diagnosing a deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  consideration of differential diagnoses (Baker's cyst  cellulitis)  risk factors for DVT (e.g. obesity  older age  personal or family history of DVT or PE  African American race  and presence of co-morbidities like hypertension and diabetes)  importance of DVT prophylaxis  treatment strategies such as anticoagulation therapy  and potential complications like a pulmonary embolism or post-thrombotic syndrome.  NOTE: This case representation is illustrated based on the demographic and comorbidity factors associated with increased risk of developing DVT  as mentioned in several studies. This case does not aim to stereotype or stigmatize any racial group. The aim is to provide a training case for medical students to understand and gain insights into DVT management and patient care effectively.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Demographics:  Patient X is a 68-year-old African-American male  married  a retired accountant  and lives alone in Trenton  New Jersey. He is a non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol use.   Past Medical History: Patient X has a history of hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago. Both conditions are well-managed with medication (lisinopril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes). He also occasionally takes ibuprofen for arthritis pain. His surgical history includes a unilateral total knee replacement surgery 6 years ago due to osteoarthritis. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a myocardial infarction at age 72  and his brother had a stroke at age 70.  Key Complaints: For the past week  Patient X has been experiencing increasing pain and swelling in his right lower leg. He reports it as a constant  dull ache that intensifies when he stands up or walks. He notes that his right calf appears to be visibly larger than his left calf and has become somewhat red and warm to the touch. He denies any recent injuries to the area. He also reports feeling a bit short of breath for the past 3 days  which he initially attributed to his age and lack of exercise. He has no chest pain  palpitations  or syncope. He did mention recent bouts of moderate to severe night sweats.   Given the patient's demographic and past history of knee replacement surgery  there is a high index of suspicion for a deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  since this is seen more frequently in African-Americans  the elderly  and those with a history of surgery or immobilization. The newly developed shortness of breath when considered in combination with the potential DVT could indicate possible pulmonary embolism  a serious complication. Therefore  this case necessitates urgent and suitable investigations and interventions.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information Name: John Smith Age: 60 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired corporate accountant (sedentary lifestyle) Residence: Urban environment  Northwest USA  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension and type-2 diabetes 5 years ago  both of which are being managed by medication. He also had a right total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago due to osteoarthritis. Smith was a smoker for over 30 years  but quit 7 years ago. He lives alone and has no known allergies.   Key Complaints: The patient visited the emergency department complaining of increasingly severe pain in his right calf  which started a few days ago. He also noted swelling in the calf with redness and warmth over the area. The patient reported no chest pain or shortness of breath but mentioned some discomfort while walking. He has no fever or pointing symptoms suggestive of infection at the surgical site. His calf was mildly edematous  but not grossly swollen.   Note: DVT is more common in older adults (especially those over 60 years old)  and this patient's age  previous surgery  and less mobile lifestyle further increase the risk. Caucasians tend to be at increased risk  specifically those with co-morbid conditions such as diabetes and hypertension. The risk of DVT can also increase after an orthopedic surgery  such as a total knee replacement. It is important  as medical students  to consider these risk factors when evaluating a patient's symptoms and medical history.   Next steps in this case would involve a DVT risk assessment  a physical exam  and likely some diagnostic tests such as a D-dimer test  or a Duplex ultrasound.

Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Background: This case is designed to help medical students practice diagnosing and managing Deep Vein Thrombosis. It also highlights the importance of assessing risk factors for the development of DVT.  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 62-year-old African-American female. She is a retired school teacher and lives with her husband.  Past medical history:  The patient has been diagnosed previously with Type 2 diabetes and hypertension. She is currently on medication for both with generally good control. She underwent a right total knee arthroplasty 4 weeks ago. She has a smoking history of 20 years  and ceased 5 years ago. She reports no known drug allergies.   Key complaints: She presents with a 3-day history of progressive right lower leg swelling and moderate pain  along with the leg feeling warm to touch. She denies any trauma to the lower extremity. She states the discomfort is hamstring and calf pain which feels “deep” and is made worse with walking or ankle flexion. There are no other associated symptoms such as chest pain  shortness of breath  or changes in skin color.  Summary: This case is aimed at teaching students how to evaluate and manage a potentially life-threatening condition - deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's age  race  sex  surgical history  chronic conditions  and former smoking habit present a realistic scenario  as these are common risk factors associated with DVT. Postoperative patients  particularly after hip or knee arthroplasty  have a significantly increased risk of developing DVT. The patient's complaints of deep leg pain  limb swelling  and warmth further suggest the likelihood of this diagnosis. Following the case  clinical evaluation  imaging  and management plans can be discussed.   Additional emphasis can be given to the importance of recognizing the potentially fatal complication of pulmonary embolism  which can result if DVT is not diagnosed promptly and treated correctly. The discussion can also lead to prevention strategies of DVT in high risk patients.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Emma Martinez Age: 74 Sex: Female Race: Hispanic  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension for 15 years  controlled with medications. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  managed with oral hypoglycemics. 3. Hyperlipidemia for 8 years  managed with diet and statin therapy.  4. Treated breast cancer  post-chemotherapy and radiation 5 years ago.  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Martinez presented with swelling  pain  and redness in her left leg that developed over the past two days. She added that she had restricted mobility due to pain and tenderness. The patient also mentioned having a low-grade fever.  Discussion Points: 1. Primarily  the learner should identify the risk factors for developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  i.e.  age  history of cancer  immobility  etc. They should understand that Mrs. Martinez’s medical history places her at an elevated risk of blood clot development. 2. Next  understanding the typical presentation of DVT will involve identification of the symptoms Mrs. Martinez has presented with  which are classic symptoms of DVT. 3. The learner should focus on identifying appropriate diagnostic tests for identification of DVT. 4. Lastly  case discussion will center around understanding the first-line of treatment and management for DVT along with prevention measures.  The intent of this case is to provide the learner a holistic understanding of DVT  its risk factors  presentation  diagnostic measures  and treatment protocols. The case representation is accurate as per demographic data  showing that DVT often occurs in older adults and is more prevalent in individuals with a history of cancer. The patient also has other medical conditions that independently increase her risk profile. These comorbidities are common in real life settings  adding authentic learning value to the case study.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Patient Y is a 65-year-old African-American male who lives in a suburban community in the Mid-Western United States. He is married and lives with his wife. He used to work as a truck driver  but recently he retired. He has a history of smoking (20 years) but quit ten years back. He is moderately overweight with a BMI of 27 kg/m2 and follows a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History:  Patient Y has a medical history of hypertension under control with medication. He is also prediabetic for the last 2 years  managed with lifestyle changes. The patient has reported occasional episodes of arrhythmias (atrial fibrillation) lately. He has mentioned suffering a minor accident 6 weeks back  where he sustained minor injuries though it resulted in reduced mobility for three weeks. He has no known allergies to medication.  Key Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute onset  progressive left lower leg pain  and swelling for the last two days. He also reports the area seems warmer than his other leg. Additionally  he has been feeling occasional shortness of breath  especially when doing strenuous activities. He denies any recent traveling  surgery  or history of similar problems.  Teaching Note: The case highlights common risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) such as age  obesity  recent immobility due to injury/accident  past history of arrhythmias like atrial fibrillation  and smoking. The presentation with unilateral leg symptoms points towards DVT though confirmation and further management will require processing investigations like D-Dimer blood test  Ultrasound or venogram if required  along with patient's management for controlling symptoms and preventing further complications like pulmonary embolism.  This case allows learning on the importance of risk stratification based on clinical probability of DVT  use of Wells score for DVT  understanding and interpreting investigations for DVT  lifestyle modifications  management strategies  and complications of deep vein thrombosis.

Case Subject: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: Mr. Henry Santos  African-American male  aged 56  blue-collar worker involved in heavy lifting tasks at a construction site. He lives with his wife and two kids in downtown Detroit  Michigan and is a smoker for the last 35 years. He is 5’9’’  weighs 240 lbs  BMI- 35.5 (obese).  Past Medical History: Mr. Santos has a background of Hypertension for the last 12 years  controlled on medication and has a familial history of cardiovascular diseases. He also has known Type 2 Diabetes mellitus moderately controlled on oral hypoglycemics. Apart from these  he has led a relatively healthy life  with no major surgeries  injuries or known allergies.  Key Complaints: Mr. Santos presents to the ER with a 2-day history of painful  swollen right lower leg. He first noticed the symptoms while doing his normal routine physical activities. He recalls carrying heavy loads and a slight stumble but denied any notable injuries. He also reported a dull aching pain in his leg which increased over time. The pain is not radiating and does not alter with the change in position.  During the past 24 hours  the lower leg pain got worse  and the leg has become significantly red and warm. Additionally  the patient reported mild shortness of breath on exertion. However  he has no complaints of chest pain  coughing  hemoptysis  or fever. He also mentioned increasing fatigue and unexplained weight loss during the last few weeks. The patient also complained of occasional night sweats. He denies any recent travel  stays mostly sedentary at home  and follows an unhealthy diet.  Note: This case represents a higher-risk demographic particularly susceptible to DVT considering factors like age  race  obesity  smoking habits  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  and Diabetes. All these factors are consistent with specific demographic data found in related literature. The combination of these predispositions and the patient's key symptoms outlines a clinical scenario potentially indicative of Deep Vein Thrombosis(DVT).

Case Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in Postmenopausal Woman   Patient Information:  - Name: Mrs. Anita Smith (Pseudonym) - Age: 70 years old - Sex: Female - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher - Marital Status: Widowed   Patient Medical History: - Diagnosis with Hypertension - 15 years ago  managed with medication (amlodipine) - Diagnosis with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - 5 years ago  managed with medication (metformin) - Diagnosis of Rheumatoid Arthritis - Managed with NSAIDs - Surgical History: Total knee arthroplasty of the right knee - 2 years ago - Marital History: No use of contraceptives; 2 pregnancies with routine deliveries - Postmenopausal: On Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT)  Patient Complaints: Mrs. Smith has come in complaining of a painful  swollen left calf which she noted 3 days ago. She describes the pain as a constant  dull ache that worsens with movement and is not relieved by over-the-counter pain medication. She also reports feeling generally unwell and a bit more lethargic than usual  but denies any fever  chest pain  or breathlessness.  Note: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is often seen in elderly patients  particularly postmenopausal women  due to the hypercoagulable state induced by hormone replacement therapy. Additionally  the presence of chronic diseases such as hypertension and diabetes  along with previous history of surgery and potentially immobility  contribute to the risk factors for DVT. Therefore  Mrs. Smith's case accurately represents the typical demographic and medical profile for DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female. She is an American  lives in an urban setting  retired from a sedentary job (desk-based with little to no physical activity)  and belongs to the middle-income group. She is 5'5"" tall  weighs about 180 pounds  putting her in the obese category. She is a former smoker and drinks occasionally.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus (on metformin)  and hyperlipidemia. She also had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) around 10 years ago with complete recovery and has sustained an ankle fracture 5 years ago (treated surgically  without complications but causing partial mobility issues). She is on low-dose aspirin for stroke prevention  and simvastatin for her hyperlipidemia. She has a familial history of thromboembolic disease - her mother had a pulmonary embolism  and her elder brother suffered from deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She is not on any form of hormonal therapy.  Key Complaints:  The patient complains of progressive left leg swelling for the past week. The swelling is associated with discomfort  mild redness  and a warm sensation but no fever. She got concerned when she noticed her leg getting more swollen and increasing pain  making it difficult for her to walk properly or comfortably wear her shoes. The symptoms did not improve with rest or over-the-counter analgesics. She denies any recent travel or trauma to her legs but has been relatively immobile due to quarantine from the COVID-19 pandemic.+  Note: This case represents demographics and risk factors (age  obesity  sex  immobility  personal and familial history of thrombotic episodes) commonly associated with DVT based on numerous epidemiological studies. However  keep in mind that DVT can affect anyone regardless of these factors.

Patient Case:  Patient Information: - Sex: Female - Age: 67 - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired school teacher - Residence: Anchorage  Alaska  Past Medical History: - Past smoker (quit 15 years ago) - Type II Diabetes (Diagnosed 10 years ago) - Hypertension (Diagnosed 7 years ago) - BMI: 30 (Classified as obese) - Family history of cardiovascular disease  - No previous history of thrombotic events - Regular medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and low-dose Aspirin   Presenting Complaint: The patient came to the ER complaining of a sudden onset of unilateral pain and swelling on her left leg  along with warmth and redness over the area which started approximately 8 hours prior to arrival. The pain became progressively worse  prompting her presenting to the hospital. She also noticed her left leg was noticeably swollen compared to the right one. No complaints of chest pain  dizziness  recent injuries  or travel.  The patient fits within the demographic and medical profile most commonly associated with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) according to current literature. With old age  obesity  diabetes  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle being risk factors  she will now undergo diagnostic procedures to confirm or rule out DVT. Following a complete patient work-up  we will proceed to discuss the plan of care  highlighting the necessity of multidisciplinary input in the management of DVT.   This training case will ideally prove useful to medical students in identifying risk factors  presenting symptoms  and the course of care related to DVT. As further learning objectives  we will discuss the issues around prophylaxis  ways to reduce the risk of DVT  and the importance of patient education on the signs and symptoms and when to seek help.   Note: Ensure in your teaching that the cause of DVT is not oversimplified - this patient demographics forms part of the Virchow's Triad: stasis of blood flow  endothelial injury and a hypercoagulable state  all contributing to thrombus formation.

Patient Case: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Jane Doe Age: 65 years Sex: Female Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Teacher Location: Urban Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: 1. Car accident with fractured femur requiring immobilization (6 months ago) 2. History of breast cancer  treated with mastectomy and chemotherapy (2 years ago) 3. Smoker for 30 years (1 pack/day)  quit 10 years ago 4. Hypertension (5 years) 5. Oral contraceptive use during reproductive years 6. No known family history of coagulation disorders  Presenting Complaints: 1. Acute onset of unilateral right leg swelling and pain starting 2 days ago. 2. Pain has progressively worsened becoming constant. 3. She notes that her right leg appears redder and feels warmer than the other leg. 4. Mild fever (38°C / 100.4°F)  This case is representative of the population most typically affected by DVT ie.  elderly patients with comorbidities  history of surgery  long periods of immobilization  certain medications  and tobacco use. This case allows students to explore important diagnostic procedures  risks  prevention methods  and management strategies for DVT.   Such as: 1. Clinical prediction rules for DVT. 2. Importance of D-dimer testing and compression ultrasonography. 3. Role of anticoagulants  duration of anticoagulation  and the balancing of the risk of bleeding. 4. Importance of physical movement and mobility in preventing DVT  especially in post-operative patients or those at risk.  5. Potential complications such as post-thrombotic syndrome and pulmonary embolism. 6. Public health implications: smoking cessation  proper use of contraceptives.

Case Report:   Patient Information:   Ms. Amelia  a 52-year-old African-American woman from a middle-class socio-economic background.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Amelia was diagnosed with Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago and is regularly on medications. She has a family history of myocardial infarction and stroke. She had a total knee replacement surgery about one month ago. She is a non-smoker but reports occasional alcohol intake.  Key Presenting Complaints:  She presents with complaints of marked swelling  warmth  and tenderness in her left lower leg  which has been progressively worsening over a week. The patient also reports a mild increase in shortness of breath  occasional mild to moderate chest discomfort  and anxiety. She also noticed an unexplained weight loss  despite no changes in her regular diet or diabetic control.  Case Direction:  The case should be designed around the possibility of Ms. Amelia developing a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post-orthopedic surgery  which may have led to a pulmonary embolism  given her symptoms. Follow-up symptoms suggest potential complications such as a postphlebitic syndrome or chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.  Discussion Points for Students:   Instructor can guide the medical students to discuss prevalent risk factors of DVT such as female sex  African-American ethnicity  older age  obesity  prolonged immobility  and post-surgical state. A focus can further be provided to the relationship of DVT with other common medical conditions such as hypertension and diabetes.   The case can also be utilized as an opportunity to discuss the role of prophylactic measures in patients post orthopedic surgery and their importance in preventing complications like DVT  paying attention to the need for patient education on early symptoms and timely medical intervention.  The students should be guided to understand the importance of a holistic approach towards patient care  considering both physical symptoms and related psychological issues such as patient anxiety.  Note: This case represents an approximation of potential real-life scenarios by synthesizing elements from various reported cases. Any resemblance to actual persons or events is purely coincidental.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian male  who is an office worker by profession. He is a former smoker and leads a sedentary lifestyle. The patient is overweight (BMI: 29)  overconsumes alcohol  and has a family history of blood clots.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications. He had an orthopedic surgery (hip replacement) 6 months ago and was immobile for a few weeks post-surgery. He has no known allergies.  Key complaints: The patient presented to the clinic with complaints of swelling in his left leg that started 5 days ago. He rates the pain as a 6 on a scale of 10. He also described the pain as a dull ache  concentrated more on the calf region. The pain seemed to somewhat ease when he raised his leg.  He also reports occasional shortness of breath over the past couple of days and mild discomfort in the chest. No noticeable fever  cough  or other symptoms were reported.   Note: Based on literature  risk factors for DVT include age over 40  obesity  personal or family history of DVT  smoking  surgery  and prolonged immobility. DVT is more common in men than women  and while it can occur in any race or ethnicity  it's more prevalent in whites than in non-whites. Therefore  the patient's demographics in this case are consistent with the reported epidemiology of DVT.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mrs. Janice Watkins is a 62-year-old Caucasian female. She works as a retired school teacher and lives with her husband in a middle-class suburban neighborhood.  Presenting Complaints:  Janice complains of left leg pain and swelling that has gradually increased over the past five days. The pain intensifies when standing and walking  making it difficult for her to manage her daily chores. She also mentions a slight increase in warmth over the swollen area compared to the right leg. However  she denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or coughing/sneezing episodes.  Past Medical History:   Janice is known to have Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the last 15 years  managed conservatively with medication. She has Hypertension controlled with Atenolol for the past ten years. She had a Total knee replacement of the right knee two years ago and recovered successfully. Janice had also been on hormone replacement therapy (HRT) post-menopause for relieve vasomotor symptoms but stopped them a year ago. No history of any coagulation disorder or previous deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  pulmonary embolism (PE)  or other significant conditions.    Social History:  Mrs. Watkins is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. She leads a sedentary lifestyle due to her joint issues. Janice recently flew back from visiting her daughter in another state  which involved approximately four hours air travel each way.  Medications:  Janice regularly takes Metformin for her diabetes and Atenolol for hypertension. Occasionally  she takes over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to manage her knee pain.  Family History:  There is significant family history of cardiovascular diseases  with her father dying of myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and her younger brother being diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.
