No known family history of coagulation disorders.  Review of Systems:  General: She denies any recent weight changes  fatigue  or fever.   Respiratory: She denies any cough  shortness of breath  or wheezing.  Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain  palpitations  or syncopal episodes.  GI: Appetite and bowel movements are normal.  Musculoskeletal: Complains of left leg pain and swelling.  Neurological: Oriented to time  place  and person.  Conclusion:  This is a case designed for medical students that exemplifies how deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can present in a patient. Given her age  history of long flights  hormone therapy  and sedentary lifestyle  as well as her current complaints  this case should prompt the clinician to consider DVT in the differential diagnosis  prompting them to initiate appropriate diagnostic tests and management strategies.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics:  Name: Patient X Age: 60 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Long-haul truck driver  Past Medical History:  Patient X has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He has been a pack-a-day smoker for the past 40 years and he has been noted to have a BMI of 32 indicating obesity. He does not have any known drug allergies. He has no previous history of surgeries or hospitalizations. He has a family history of stroke on the paternal side.  Key Complaints:  Patient X presents with sudden onset of pain and swelling in the left lower leg that has progressively worsened over the past two days. The pain intensifies when he stands or moves his leg. He denies injury to the area but mentions that he undertook a cross-country truck driving task without frequent stops or walks. He also complains of a feeling of warmth over the area. He denies any episodes of chest pain or shortness of breath. He reports mild fatigue and restlessness but attributes that to less sleep due to his job demands.  This case establishes the connection between deep vein thrombosis and common risk factors such as advanced age  prolonged immobilization  obesity  smoking  and certain inherited conditions. While DVT can occur at any age  it is more prevalent amongst individuals over the age of 60. The case also highlights the importance of personal and family medical history in assessing risk factors for DVT.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male. He is a former smoker  overweight with a BMI of 28  lives a sedentary lifestyle  and is a retired long-haul truck driver.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension and high cholesterol. The patient underwent right hip replacement surgery 8 weeks ago  which has limited his physical activity. The patient also has a family history of heart disease and stroke.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient arrived at the clinic presenting with complaints relating toward the right lower leg. His symptoms began a few days ago with mild discomfort  which progressively worsened and morphed into a deep seated cramp-like pain in his calf. The discomfort is intensified when he stands or walks. He also reports noticeable swelling and a slight warmth in the affected leg. There is no history of the same symptoms in the other leg. The patient denies any chest pain  difficulty in breathing or loss of consciousness.   This case setup allows for an in-depth exploration of DVT  considering risk factors such as age  race  obesity  family history of clotting conditions  and recent orthopedic surgery. The isolated nature of the symptoms could guide students to investigate the possibility of deep vein thrombosis  and strategies for its diagnosis and treatment  while also underlining the importance of patient history in clinical decision-making.   The careful inclusion of multiple demographic elements—as an older  African American male patient  as well as significant lifestyle and post-surgical risk factor—enriches the case and enhances its potential as an effective educational tool.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  Mr. Horace Leonard  a 70-year-old African-American male with a weight of approximately 95 kilograms and 173 cm in height. He is a retired construction worker  married with four grown-up children. He is a smoker with a 35-pack year history. Resides in an urban area  with low socioeconomic status. Patient has not traveled recently and denies alcohol use.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Leonard has a known history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the last 15 years  hypertension for about 12 years  and a recent hip replacement surgery six weeks prior to the current evaluation. The patient has been on Metformin and Lisinopril respectively for his conditions. He is also obese with a BMI of 31.7 and a family history of stroke.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Leonard visited the hospital complaining of progressive left lower leg pain and swelling for the past four days. He also mentioned a mild fever for around the same period. Strikingly  his left calf is markedly swollen and warm when compared to his right and shows a positive Homan's sign. He also reported feeling slightly breathless over the past two days. His vitals showed marginally increased heart rate.   Evaluation:  Upon evaluation  the clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis was raised due to postoperative status  continuous smoking despite comorbidities  advanced age  obesity  and the patient's demographics. The patient was subjected to immediate diagnostics and interventions including Doppler ultrasonography or venography  as necessary.  Summary:  This case presents medical students with a high-risk patient for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  taking into account common risk factors such as age  recent surgery  a history of smoking  obesity  and pre-existing prothrombotic conditions. It also represents accurate demographic representation considering DVT being common among African-Americans. This case aims at honing the students' skills in identifying DVTs in their early stages  assessing the risk in different patient subsets  and managing them appropriately.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  a retired factory worker residing in the urban northeast. He is a smoker with a 40-pack year history and has been classified as overweight with a BMI of 27 kg/m2. He resides in a single-story house with his wife.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes which is poorly controlled with Metformin. He also has moderate hypertension controlled with Losartan. He also has hyperlipidemia and is on simvastatin. He has had several hospitalizations over the past two years due to flare-ups of his Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). The patient also had an outpatient knee arthroplasty around six weeks ago.  Key Complaints:  The patient reports increasing left lower leg pain and progressive swelling for the past four days and has noticed a bluish discoloration to his skin. He denies any trauma  fever  chest pain  dyspnea  or symptoms in the other extremity. There is no previous history of DVT or pulmonary embolism  but he does admit to reduced activity due to recurrent COPD exacerbations. The patient’s wife states he has been less active since his knee surgery.  Additional Evaluation:  Further investigation may reveal a hot  swollen  painful left calf more marked over the calf veins. Upon auscultation  scattered wheezes  and crackles may be present in both lungs. It is also likely that blood investigations will reveal raised D-dimer levels. Duplex Ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis may show non-compressibility of a deep calf vein  localizing the DVT.  Creating a DVT case study around these patient demographics and key complaints will help increase student awareness of this condition's risk factors  including age  surgery  prolonged immobilization  obesity  smoking  COPD  and uncontrolled diabetes. The management involves lifestyle modification  addressing modifiable risk factors  anticoagulation therapy  and lower extremity compression stocking  which can all be discussed when teaching about this case. This case will also teach students about the importance of adequate postoperative care and regular checkups for elderly patients. The complications of DVT (like pulmonary embolism  post-thrombotic syndrome) can be also highlighted during the discussion on this case study.    Literature Citation:   [Microsoft Word - 5. Deep Vein Thrombosis - a Patient's Guide.doc (veins.co.uk)]

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. Carlos Herrera  a 66-year-old Hispanic man  retired construction worker from East Los Angeles  presents at the emergency department. He is a well-respected member of the Latino community and is living with his wife. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Herrera has a history of hypertension for which he takes irbesartan/hydrochlorothiazide 150mg/12.5mg daily. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes four years ago which is controlled through oral hypoglycemic medications. He also has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to prolonged occupational exposure to dust and chemicals  for which he uses ipratropium bromide. He is obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 32.   Family history reveals that his father had peripheral artery disease and his mother had a stroke in her late 70s.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Herrera arrived at the ER with complaints of a swollen  warm  and painful left lower leg that has gotten worse over the past two days. The pain in his leg started suddenly and felt like a cramp or charley horse. He denies trauma and recent injuries to the area. He states he has not been highly mobile over the past week due to seasonal flu  spending most of the time on his couch.  He denies having any chest pain or shortness of breath  but admits feeling slightly light-headed on and off. His wife also noticed that Mr. Herrera appeared increasingly fatigued over the last week.   His vital signs on admission are: temperature: 36.8°C  heart rate: 92 bpm  blood pressure: 146/94 mmHg  oxygen saturation: 93% on room air.   On examination  his left lower leg looks noticeably swollen compared to the right  is warm  extremely tender  and reddish-blue. There is a positive Homan’s sign. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   In summary  a 66-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and COPD is presenting with acute onset of left lower leg pain and swelling with associated fatigue and lightheadedness. The primary concern voiced by the patient is the sudden  unexplained leg discomfort.   This concise case presentation has been designed to simulate a clinical scenario of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a common life-threatening condition  especially in patients with several risk factors like Mr. Herrera has. This case can be used to enhance training of medical students in terms of history taking  examination skills  risk stratification  diagnosis  and management of DVT  whilst promoting the importance of early recognition and intervention.

Case Report for Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 67 years  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Residential Location: Urban Area  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension for the past 6 years  under medication 2. Survivor of a heart attack 4 years ago 3. Recurrent episodes of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  4. Smoker for 30+ years 5. Episodes of atrial fibrillation  Present Complaints: Mr. Smith presents a 3-day history of pain and swelling in his left calf  which has progressively worsened. He reports increased warmth in the calf  but no redness. Symptom onset was sudden  manifesting in the evening with no preceding trauma or injury.   He states the pain is continuous  throbbing  and rated it as 7/10 on the pain scale. The pain intensifies on walking but is relieved somewhat with limb elevation. There is no history of similar episodes before.   Mr. Smith has not traveled recently  has no known history of blood disorders  nor has he been on medication that promotes clotting. He reports a sedentary lifestyle after his retirement and has a 20-year history of smoking.  Lifestyle and Family History: Mr. Smith is a widower who lives alone and manages his own household. He eats a balanced diet  but his exercise is limited due to his COPD. He has a family history of coronary artery disease with his father diagnosed with a myocardial infarction at an early age. His younger sister also has a medical history of deep vein thrombosis.  In this case  the students should recognize the significance of the patient’s history of heart disease  hypertension  the sedentary lifestyle and a personal habit that is prone to smoking. The major complaints like the intensified pain in the calf on walking  and presence of warmth could guide the examinations and investigations towards the probable diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. The case also allows a discussion of risk factors  signs and symptoms  diagnostic modalities  and treatment options for patients presenting with symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Ivanov  who is an office worker leading a sedentary lifestyle. He is a smoker and a habitual heavy drinker  and his body mass index (BMI) is 32  placing him in the obesity category. He has a known family history of thrombotic events. He is divorced and lives alone without any children.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Ivanov was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  currently managed by Metformin. He also has a background of Hypertension controlled with Amlodipine. He had a right hip replacement a year ago due to osteoarthritis. Mr. Ivanov is not on any anticoagulant therapy.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Ivanov visited the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of pain and swelling in his right lower leg  which he claims has been worsening since the day before. He states the pain is mainly in the calf region and is a dull  aching sensation. He also mentioned he is experiencing shortness of breath on minor exertion  which is atypical for him.  On physical examination  his right calf appeared swollen with erythema and was warm to touch. On measuring  there was a 3 cm difference in the circumference of both calves. When asked about recent travel history  Mr. Ivanov mentioned that he had traveled on a long-haul flight (10+ hours) for his work trip a week ago.  This case presents the common risk factors and symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  such as advanced age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  personal and family medical history  recent surgery  long-distance travel  tobacco and alcohol use. The shortness of breath may indicate a Pulmonary Embolism and should be thoroughly evaluated in the ED. The case can be used to teach medical students about understanding  diagnosing  and managing DVT. Including this in the curriculum would elucidate the importance of being astute clinicians.

Patient Information:  Mr. Samuel Martinez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  is a retired construction worker who presents to the clinic alone  bearing discomfort in his right lower leg. Mr. Martinez is bilingual  speaking English and Spanish fluently.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Martinez was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus ten years ago and Hypertension two years later. He also had a history of Gallstones  for which he underwent cholecystectomy 5 years ago. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes control and Amlodipine for his hypertension. He has no known allergies. He denies any history of blood clot disorders or high cholesterol. Mr. Martinez has a 45 pack/year history of smoking and continues to smoke. He drinks alcohol occasionally. He has no family history of clotting disorders.  Key Complaint:  Mr. Martinez complaints of a persistent ache in his right lower leg  which he initially thought was muscular pain from gardening. He reports the pain progressively worsening over a week  with the leg appearing swollen and slightly reddish  particularly in the calf area. He denies any trauma or insect bite to the region. The pain increases while walking and alleviates slightly at rest. He also mentions his wife recently remarked about his leg appearing slightly larger than the other.  Considering the patient's history  his current complaints  the risk factors for venous thromboembolism (including age  long-standing diabetes  and smoking)  the possibility of Deep Vein Thrombosis should be considered. The medical students will be instructed to evaluate signs of Deep Vein Thrombosis  work on differential diagnosis  and plan appropriate investigations and management for Mr. Martinez  keeping in mind his overall medical status.   Reference:  1. Beckman MG  Hooper WC  Critchley SE  Ortel TL. Venous thromboembolism: A public health concern. Am J Prev Med. 2010;38(4 Suppl):S495-S501. 2. Lee AY  Levine MN. Venous thromboembolism and cancer: Risks and outcomes. Circulation. 2003;107(23 Suppl 1):I17-I21.

Patient Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information:  - Age: 68 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired white-collar worker - Ethnicity: Caucasian (majority of DVT cases occur in this demographic as per literature) - Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity - Social history: Non-smoker  social alcohol consumption   Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of chronic peripheral arterial disease (PAD) along with Stage II hypertension (HTN). He had an open cholecystectomy 8 years ago and has been taking antihypertensive drugs (ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers) for hypertension ever since. The patient also has a family history of thrombotic diseases  his father having suffered from a pulmonary embolism.  Key Complaints:  The patient presented with unilateral  painful leg swelling on the left lower limb that began 4 days prior to consultation. The swelling was gradual in onset and has progressively worsened. He complains of a dull ache in the left calf and mild tenderness upon palpation. It is associated with a mild fever and redness of the skin over the swollen area. The patient was not able to identify any triggering or relieving factors for the pain and swelling.   He mentioned that he recently undertook a long-duration flight (12 hours  a potential risk factor for DVT) to visit his daughter and started experiencing symptoms soon after arrival. Patient reports minimal movement during flight and no preventative measures taken due to lack of awareness for thrombosis risk during long-haul flights.   This case presents a clear context for the discussion of Deep Vein Thrombosis risk factors  signs  and symptoms  diagnosis methods  and management strategies. It also encourages students to consider the importance of patient education in preventing severe health risks due to lifestyle or event-specific factors.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Anderson Age: 68 Years Sex: Male Race/ Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired Insurance: Medicare Location: Urban dwelling in New York City  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a history of Type II diabetes mellitus  previous myocardial infarction  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago (40 pack year history). He has a past surgical history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 5 years ago. His daily medications include metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and aspirin.  Key Complaint (Presenting Symptoms): The patient presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of a painful  swollen  and reddened left lower leg. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  loss of consciousness  or recent travels. He also denies trauma  insect bite  or known exposure to infection.   The literature often attributes DVT occurrence to prolonged immobility  major surgery  cancer  selected medications  and trauma. In the case of this patient  the past history of CABG might have a role in his current complaint. Males are not necessarily at higher risk for DVT but the age of this patient along with other comorbidities contribute significantly to the development of DVT.  This case has been designed to include an older age group who often present with comorbid conditions that increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The comorbidities were chosen with the goal of teaching how chronic diseases like diabetes  hypertension  and heart disease can be risk factors for DVT. These factors and the patient's past surgical history emphasize the importance of preventing prolonged immobilization in reducing the risk of DVT. The case allows for a potentially complex discussion around the management of an urgent but common medical condition intertwined with multiple chronic morbidities.

Case: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 60 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Long-distance truck driver Smoking Status: Retired smoker  Past Medical History: • Obesity (BMI - 35) • Type II diabetes mellitus • Hyperlipidemia • History of Proximal deep vein thrombosis five years prior  treated with anticoagulants • Hypertension • Stress-induced diagnosed depression  Presenting Complaints: John presents to the clinic with several days of progressive pain and discomfort in his left calf. He describes it as a ""pulling"" sensation  and notes it is particularly noticeable when he moves his foot upward. He also acknowledges mild swelling in the left lower extremity and warmth over calf area. He denies any injury to his leg and doesn't recall any trauma.   John has been on the road for the past week  consistently driving for stretches of 10 hours and above. He's also been feeling more stressed lately due to multiple deadlines and less physical activity due to his job demands. He’s been under stress and his dieting and exercise routine has been neglected. He reports a weight gain of about 10lbs over the past 2 months.   He mentioned that he has been compliant with medications for diabetes  hyperlipidemia and hypertension but stopped taking his anticoagulant therapy two months ago due to concerns with bleeding risk. He does not have any issues with vision  breath shortness  chest pain  tingling sensation  or loss of consciousness.  This case will focus on deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The aim is to educate medical students about risk factors  screening  diagnosis  management strategies  and prevention of recurrence for DVT. The patient represents common risk factors seen in literature: previous history of DVT  prolonged immobility  obesity  hypertension  and discontinuation of anticoagulant therapy. Additionally  this patient has multiple co-existing medical conditions often seen in real-world patients. Discussion will ensue on the balance of anticoagulation against bleeding risk  and the importance of lifestyle modifications along with medication compliance.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American woman with a body mass index (BMI) of 34 kg/m2 representing a common population at increased risk of DVT as indicated by research.  Past Medical History: She has a history of Type 2 Diabetes mellitus (10 years duration)  Hypertension (5 years duration)  and was recently treated for breast cancer. She underwent chemotherapy and mastectomy six months ago. She has been relatively sedentary following her operations and is non-compliant with her post-cancer physiotherapy. She doesn’t smoke and consumes alcohol occasionally.   Key Complaints: She presented with a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling in her right leg  especially the calf. She also complained of mild heaviness in her chest and difficulty in breathing for the past day which she initially thought was due to anxiety but has been steadily worsening. She rated her leg pain as being an 8/10 on the pain scale  with 10 being the most severe pain she has ever experienced  and described it as a 'deep throbbing ache' in her calf. She denied any recent travel or being bedbound but did mention that she's been less active since her mastectomy and spends most of the day sitting.  The case stands out because: This patient represents individuals with multiple risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) including cancer (Breast Cancer)  chemotherapy treatment  advanced age  heightened BMI  diabetes  hypertension  and physical inactivity. Her mixture of signs  symptoms  and history are indicative of a potential thrombolytic event needing immediate intervention.  Purpose of the Case: This case would be helpful for medical students to understand the importance of an accurate and thorough patient history  recognize the multiple risk factors for DVT  learn about the potential complications of DVT like pulmonary embolism  and appreciate the importance of timely diagnosis and management of DVT. It also stresses on the importance of post-operative physical activity and patient compliance with medical advice.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: Mr. James Thompson  African-American  Age 62  Retired Military Personnel  from Birmingham  Alabama  Past Medical History: Hypertension for the past decade  controlled with antihypertensive medications. The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  managed by Metformin and diet control. He is a past smoker with a 20-pack year history  quit smoking two years at the insistence of his children. History of injury to his right leg during military service. No history of anticoagulant therapy or any predisposing genetic condition. No family history of DVT or any other blood clot issues.   Key Complaints: Mr. Thompson came to the outpatient department of the hospital complaining of significant discomfort in the right calf muscle for the past week. The pain  initially considered as a muscle strain due to daily walking exercise  increased gradually and was accompanied by noticeable swelling and warmth to touch. The patient stated the pain intensified on standing and subsided on elevating the leg. He denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or recent travel. He mentioned having weight gain over the past year despite efforts for diet control.  Prevalence Note: The specifics chosen for this case represent a realistic demographic affected by deep vein thrombosis. A higher prevalence has been observed among African-Americans and people over 60 have a significantly increased risk. Male prevalence is slightly higher than female. Obesity  history of leg injury  diabetes  etc.  are risk factors for developing DVT.

Case Report - Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Mrs. Fernandez  a 65-year-old Hispanic female.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Fernandez has a past known case of Rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. She has been on medication for the same  oral methotrexate (10mg weekly) for Rheumatoid arthritis and a combination of amlodipine (5mg daily) and hydrochlorothiazide (12.5mg daily) for hypertension. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially.  Lately  the patient had a notable event in her life wherein she underwent a total hip replacement surgery for her Rheumatoid arthritis three weeks ago. During her postoperative time  she was under limited mobility and was on a prophylactic dose of enoxaparin (30 mg twice daily) post-surgery for 14 days as per protocol.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Fernandez presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of swelling  warmth  and pain in her left lower limb  primarily in the calf area. The pain  as described by her  intensifies during walks and feels somewhat better in rest. Additionally  she reports feelings of faintness and shortness of breath which started to bother her more since yesterday.   She denies any recent trauma  prolonged travel  or family history of clotting disorders. However  she has been less active since her hip surgery  which she mentions may contribute to her current state due to immobilization. She has no known allergies. Upon physical examination  her vitals shows borderline tachycardia.  This case study is designed for medical students to understand the risk factors  clinical presentation  and possible consequences of deep vein thrombosis. Included in the studies should be proper diagnosis procedures and the understanding of the importance of DVT prophylaxis in high risk patients and early intervention to prevent complications like pulmonary embolism. Further highlighting the need for the same  literature suggests that the prevalence of DVT is greater in older adults  post-surgical patients especially orthopedic surgeries  and those with immobilization for prolonged periods. Also  it's significant to discuss that although DVT can occur in every race and ethnicity  there are some disparities with a slightly higher prevalence in Caucasians and African Americans as compared to Hispanics and Asian populations.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Profile  Name: Mrs. Jane Thompson Age: 65 years old Gender: Female Race: White Occupation: Retired school teacher  Background  Mrs. Thompson resides in an urban area. She lives alone since her husband passed away five years ago  but she has a supportive daughter who helps provide her daily care needs.  Past Medical History  Mrs. Thompson has hypertension and osteoarthritis for which she takes medication regularly. She was also diagnosed with obesity (BMI of 31). She's a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago  and occasionally consumes alcohol. Mrs. Thompson's mother suffered from deep vein thrombosis.  Presenting Complaints  Mrs. Thompson visited the hospital with complaints of tenderness  warmth  redness  and swelling in the lower part of her left leg. She mentioned that she recently took a 6-hour flight to visit her son in a different state a week earlier and has been experiencing these symptoms since her return. Apart from this  she also noticed some shortness of breath which she initially thought was due to her weight issue.   Key Findings  In literature  it is found that DVT is more common amongst older adults  especially those above 60 years of age. Being overweight increases the risk of DVT  especially in women. Family history of venous thromboembolism  recent long travel  and lack of physical activity might also place a patient at higher risk for DVT.  Objective of Case Study  This case is designed to help medical students understand the risk factors and typical symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and appreciate the assessment  diagnosis  and management principles for this condition. Through this case  students should develop a deeper understanding and competence in considering differential diagnoses  ordering appropriate investigations  recognizing potential complications  and developing a holistic management plan with prevention strategies for DVT.

Case Scenario: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Demographics:   Mr. Robert  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  has come to the ER. The patient lives in rural Kentucky  married  with two adult children. He has a decent healthcare insurance as per his previous employment benefits.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Robert has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which have been well managed with medication (Metformin and Lisinopril respectively). He is also a former smoker (stopped 15 years ago) with a 20 pack year history. There are no known allergies to any specific medicine. Despite his chronic conditions  he leads an active lifestyle and exercises regularly.  Key Complaints:  The patient is suffering from significant right calf pain  which started few days ago. He reports the pain as a constant heavy and aching feeling along with noticeable swelling  warmth  and mild erythema. The pain is more severe on standing or walking. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath or any other localized pain. No recent trauma or injury has been experienced.  Mr. Robert has recently returned from a trip to Australia  during which he had prolonged periods (more than 10 hours at a time) of immobility during the flight. This was unusual for him as he leads an active lifestyle.   As per literature  DVT more commonly affects individuals aged above 60  especially if they are Caucasians  and those with chronic conditions such as diabetes and hypertension. Prolonged immobility due to travel or bed rest is a contributing risk factor.  The case of Mr. Robert is designed to be demographically representative  taking into account key risk factors (age  chronic conditions  immobility/travel  ex-smoker) that fit in line with common characteristics of patients with DVT as per current medical literature.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information: Mr. Jackson  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  retired factory worker.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Jackson presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden swelling and mild pain in his right lower leg. The pain has been intensifying over the course of 3 days. He mentions it feels “heavy ” and when asked to further clarify  he likens the sensation to a cramping or aching pain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of smoking  which he quit 6 years ago. He has a diagnosis of Type II Diabetes which has been managed with Metformin for the past 10 years. He also has hypertension controlled with Lisinopril  and high cholesterol controlled with Atorvastatin. He reports no known allergies. Mr. Jackson had a cholecystectomy performed 8 years ago. He has no history of malignancies or blood clotting disorders.   Review of Systems: Mr. Jackson complains of shortness of breath with slight exertion  but no chest pain or cough. He denies any recent hospitalizations  prolonged immobilizations  trauma  or surgical interventions. No history of varicose veins. He does not report among his relationships anyone that has had blood clot complications. There are no significant findings upon cardiovascular  gastrointestinal  or neurological assessment.  Recent Significant Activity: Mr. Jackson recently went on a road trip with his wife  where he spent a considerable amount of time (approximately 10 hours a day for three consecutive days) sitting in a car with minimal breaks for movement.  The case aims at provoking thoughts regarding differential diagnosis based on the demographics  epidemiological factors  comprehensively assessing risk elements  managing a diagnosis  considering implications of patient's existing medical conditions on the current situation  discussing pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions  and engaging in patient education for both the immediate concern and future prevention strategies.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Smith  Age: 67 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Factory Worker Living Situation: Lives alone in a two-story house; his daughter visits weekly.  Past Medical History:  1. Patient had a partial colectomy one year ago for colorectal cancer; in remission now. 2. Patient has a 5-year history of hypertension  well managed on medication (Enalapril 10mg daily). 3. Patient smoked about a pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years  quit smoking 10 years ago. 4. Patient is overweight with BMI of 29. 5. Patient doesn't drink alcohol and denies illicit drug use.  Chief Complaint:   The patient has been experiencing dull  aching pain in his left calf for three days. He noticed that the left calf appears slightly swollen  with skin warm and red over the area. There is no history of trauma or injury to the leg. The pain is worse when standing or walking and improves with rest and elevation.  Additional Information:  Upon further questioning  the patient reveals his physical activity has been limited recently due to bad winter weather  and he has been spending most of his time sitting or lying down. He also admits to adherence issues with his prescribed compression stockings  finding them uncomfortable to wear.  This scenario is designed to reflect the demographics most likely to experience Deep Vein Thrombosis  which is more common in older adults  those with previous surgery  sedentary lifestyle  tobacco use  and individuals with benign hypertension. The emphasis is on leg symptoms that aren't attributable to injury  to highlight the importance of understanding a patient's history and risk factors when interpreting symptoms.   Medical students should be able to identify the risk factors for DVT in this case (age  history of cancer  obesity  prolonged immobility  hypertension  and non-compliance to prophylaxis) and proceed to clinical examination  D-Dimer test  and/or Doppler ultrasounds appropriately.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: Gender: Female Age: 67 years old Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Living Condition: Lives alone in an urban setting; retired school teacher  Medical History: - Breast cancer diagnosed six years ago  treated successfully with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. - History of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer led to 5-year adjuvant endocrine therapy (Tamoxifen) which was ceased a year ago. - Non-smoker and drinks alcohol moderately. - Chronic hypertension controlled with lifestyle modifications and medication. - No history of injury or surgery in the past two years. - No history of anticoagulant use or familial blood clotting disorders.  Presenting Complaints: - Unilateral  progressive and painful swelling in the right lower leg for the past three days. - Tenderness and redness along the path of superficial veins in the right lower extremity. - Mildly raised body temperature (low-grade fever). - Pain slightly relating to activity  increases with standing  and slightly eases with leg elevation. - Shortness of breath and chest pain for last 24 hours. - No recent travel  immobility  trauma or significant weight changes.  Upon these complaints  an Doppler ultrasound was ordered that confirmed deep vein thrombosis in her right lower leg. The chest pain and shortness of breath raised concern of a potential pulmonary embolism  thus a chest computed tomography was ordered.  This case presents a patient who belongs to one of the highest risk groups for DVT. Elderly age  a history of cancer and its treatment  and prolonged estrogen exposure due to hormone therapy are significant risk factors for DVT in this patient. This case will help medical students understand the correlation between these factors and the pathogenesis of DVT  guiding them to accurate diagnosis and treatment.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Robert Johnson  African American male  aged 66  Past Medical History: Robert has been managing type 2 diabetes for the last 20 years  non-insulin dependent  and hypertension for the last 10 years. He had an appendicitis surgery 30 years ago. He has a history of smoking  with 1 pack per day for the last 40 years. He shows moderate compliance towards his daily medications; metformin 500mg BID for diabetes  and lisinopril 10mg QD for hypertension. He has no known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaints: Robert attended the walk-in clinic complaining of a swollen  red  warm  and tender to touch right lower limb extending from the calf to the thigh for the last four days. He also described intermittent shortness of breath over the last two days. On initial evaluation  his vitals were normal except for mild tachypnea. He denied history of recent trauma  surgery  prolonged immobilization  or family history of coagulopathies.  Notes for Training: This case is designed to represent the demographics predisposed to DVT namely  elderly  type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and history of smoking. The racial component (African American) is also included for the sake of demographic representation. The key complaints include common symptoms of DVT like swollen  red  and warm lower limb along with symptoms suggestive of pulmonary involvement (shortness of breath and tachypnea). This case seeks to encourage medical students to consider DVT and explore differential diagnosis such as cellulitis  superficial vein thrombosis  baker's cyst etc. Furthermore  the students will learn how to manage the condition involving anticoagulation therapy  addressing the risk factors  and the importance of patient education for medication compliance and lifestyle modifications.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics:  Identity: J.S.  Age: 67 years old  Gender: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired engineer   Past Medical History: J.S. has a past history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both under control with medication (Metformin for type 2 diabetes  Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor for hypertension). He is also an ex-smoker  with a 20 pack-year history  who quit a decade ago. He underwent a knee replacement surgery four months ago. His Body Mass Index (BMI) categorizes him as overweight (BMI: 28). Family history includes a brother who previously experienced pulmonary embolism.   Key Complaints: J.S. presents with a visibly swollen  painful  and red left leg. He has been experiencing increasing discomfort in his left calf over the past week  which has now compounded into acute pain. He denies experiencing any chest pain  breathing difficulties  rapid heartbeat  or coughing. However  he confesses to been sedentary over the last few weeks due to reduced mobility post-surgery and limited physical activities.  Case Discussion: This case represents a typical scenario for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) based on J.S's demographics  risk factors  and symptoms. According to literature  DVT has a higher incidence in elderly people  with the average age of patients being 60 years old. Caucasians are reportedly more at risk compared to other ethnicities. Risk factors include surgeries  cancer  immobility  previous history of DVT  familial susceptibility  and presence of other diseases like diabetes and hypertension. Overweight and smoking are lifestyle factors that increase the risk. The swollen  painful  lower extremity in this patient is suggestive of DVT. It is crucial to further investigate this patient for DVT and initiate prompt treatment if needed  bearing in mind his risk of developing complications such as pulmonary embolism. This case will be helpful in training medical students to identify the risk factors and diagnose DVT based on the clinical presentation and patient's history.

Patient Information:  Subject: Caucasian Male Age: 65 Occupation: Retired office clerk Social History: Non-smoker  occasional drinker Home Situation: Lives alone   Past Medical History: - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - Hypertension - Previous history of minor stroke two years ago  with complete recovery - Sedentary lifestyle - No known allergies  Presenting Complaints: The patient complains of: 1. Increasing swelling in the left lower leg over the past week. 2. Warmth over the swollen area. 3. Localized pain in the left lower leg. 4. Mild shortness of breath on exertion.  Recent History: The patient recently had a long-haul flight (8-hours) about ten days ago. Current medications include Metformin for Type-2 Diabetes and Amlodipine for Hypertension. He takes daily low-dose Aspirin following his minor stroke.  Note to Medical Educators: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) predominantly affects older adults and is more common in individuals with significant risk factors. This case represents demographic factors such as age  ethnicity  and includes risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  a history of vascular events  recent long-haul flight  and sedentary lifestyle which may contribute to the development of DVT. This case should guide students in recognizing the signs and symptoms of DVT while understanding the importance of considering the effect of risk factors in patient's presentations. This will also allow considerations on differential diagnosis  evaluations  and potential treatments related to this condition to be thoroughly explored.

Case Report: Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged Caucasian Male   Demographics: Patient's name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Military officer Location: Midwest  USA  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is a former smoker who quit about 20 years ago. He served in the military for 30 years of his life and is currently retired. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  which are well-controlled with medication. He also suffered a right knee injury during his military service which required an orthopedic surgery 15 years ago. There is no notable family medical history of severe illnesses.  Key Complaints:  For 5 days  Mr. Doe has been persistently experiencing pain and swelling in his left leg  more specifically in his calf. He describes the pain as a ""pulling sensation"" that is exacerbated by walking. He has also been feeling moderately short of breath upon exertion. He reports no chest pain or palpitations. However  he has noticed some changes in the skin color around his lower left leg  turning it a bit reddish-blue. Fever  trauma  recent surgeries  or prolonged bed rest are denied.  Given this information about Mr. Doe  a medical student/trainee should be able to recognize the signs and symptoms of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  while also considering the patient's age  past medical history  and current complaints. The connection between a history of orthopedic knee surgery and the possibility of DVT is a significant learning point. Other potential risk factors like prolonged immobilization  recent trauma  or coagulation abnormalities should always be considered. This case also provides an opportunity to discuss the possible complications of untreated DVT  like pulmonary embolism  as suggested by the complaint of shortness of breath.   Note: Even though DVT can occur to any individual  the chosen demographics are based on the fact that Caucasian people have been reported to have a higher risk of developing DVT than people of other races. Men are slightly more likely to suffer DVT than women. Also  the incidence increases with age  particularly after age 40.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: Gender: Female Age: 62 years Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Residence: Urban area Smoking Status: Never smoked Alcohol: Drinks occasionally  Medical History:  The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed ten years ago  for which she is on long-term corticosteroid therapy. She is also hypertensive  controlled with medication for the past 5 years. She has no history of diabetes or any cardiovascular diseases. The patient has been on oral contraceptives for a prolonged period during her younger years. She has not undergone any surgical procedures recently  and her family history is unremarkable.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient reports progressive swelling of her left lower leg over the past week  accompanied by persistent discomfort. She described the pain as a dull ache that increases with movement. She also complained of mild shortness of breath on exertion and an onset of low-grade fever for two days. She denies any incidents of recent injury  trauma  or prolonged travel.  Note: This patient reflects the steep increase in deep vein thrombosis risk in post-menopausal Caucasian women  especially those with a history of long-term corticosteroid use  former oral contraceptive users  and individuals with rheumatoid arthritis. This case also highlights the importance of considering DVT in patients presenting with unilateral leg swelling  pain  and mild exertional shortness of breath.

Patient Information:  [Name: Mrs. Emily Patel] [Age: 62 years] [Sex: Female] [Race: South Asian] [Occupation: Retired school teacher] [Marital Status: Married with 4 children]  Medical History:  Mrs. Patel comes in with a history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia  which have been managed well with medications (Levothyroxine and Atorvastatin  respectively). She had an uneventful knee replacement surgery 6 weeks ago. Mrs. Patel has been a non-smoker but has a past history of oral contraceptive use. There is no history of genetic conditions or blood disorders in the family.   Key Complaints:  Patient presents with fatigue  malaise  and a dull ache in her left leg that has been progressively worsening over the last week. The left calf appears marginally swollen  red and warm to touch compared to the right  but there is no obvious deformity or open wound. The pain tends to increase when she stands or walks and is relieved slightly by leg elevation. Mrs. Patel also reports mild breathlessness on exertion  and a recent flight travel of 4 hours about two weeks ago.  Educational Case Objectives:  1. Assess the risk factors for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and appreciate the importance of an accurate and detailed history. 2. Understand the presentation and clinical features of DVT. 3. Interpret diagnostic tests for DVT. 4. Discuss appropriate management and prevention strategies for DVT. 5. Counsel the patient on lifestyle modifications to prevent DVT recurrence.  Medical Note:  Though the highest-risk age group for DVT is 70 and above  a large longitudinal study of UK patients found the average age of DVT presentation to be 60 for women and 64 for men. Hence the choice of age. DVT is found to be prevalent among White and African American populations although presented here with South Asian demographics to acknowledge DVT as a global health problem. Risk factors including advanced age  recent surgery  prolonged immobility and hormonal contraceptive use are incorporated in order to address real-world scenarios.  Reference: Mahmoodi BK et al. 2014. Ethnic Differences in Venous Thromboembolism. J Thromb Haemost. 2014 Dec; 12(12): 1878–1884.

Subject of Training: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Case Report:  Patient Name: James Thompson Age: 68 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired (Previous occupation - Long haul truck driver) Location: Rural Midwest  USA  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson has come into the clinic with complaints of persistent unilateral lower limb pain and swelling. The patient noticed the swelling in his right calf 5 days ago which has gradually increased. He also states that the calf feels warm to touch.   Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a significant past medical history including: 1. Hypertension (HTN) diagnosed ten years ago  managed with lisinopril. 2. Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed seven years ago  controlled with metformin. 3. Obesity with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32. 4. He is an ex-smoker and quit smoking ten years ago.   Family History: There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  including his father  who had a Myocardial Infarction at the age of 62 and his mother  who had a stroke at the age of 69.   Social History: He is a retired long-haul truck driver and since his retirement  Mr. Thompson leads a sedentary lifestyle. He lives alone in a rural setting with minimal physical activity.   Review of Systems: There is no complaint of recent trauma  chest pain  shortness of breath  or headaches.  Physical Examination: Unilateral edema and mild erythema in the right calf. There is tenderness on deep palpation of the affected area without any noticeable superficial venous distention. There are no visible skin changes or ulcers.  Teaching Objectives: To provide students an opportunity to:  1. Understand the pathophysiology of deep vein thrombosis. 2. Identify and understand the risk factors (obesity  sedentary lifestyle  age  etc.) and genetic predispositions to deep vein thrombosis. 3. Develop a clear understanding on its clinical presentation. 4. Understand the principles of diagnosis (using the Wells score) and investigation (Doppler ultrasonography) for deep vein thrombosis. 5. Learn about the management and complications of deep vein thrombosis. 6. Learn about the importance of patient education regarding the need for mobility and weight control as preventive measures.

Case Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Post-Cesarean Section Female Patient  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Amelia Johnson Age: 35 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Accountant Residential Area: Urban  Past Medical History:  Delivered her second child by cesarean section 10 days ago. No other notable medical history. No history of smoking or regular alcohol consumption. On routine multivitamins and iron tablets post-surgery.   Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Amelia Johnson presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of swelling in her right lower limb accompanied by slight redness and a mild pain that is progressively getting worse. She also reports feeling slightly short of breath  and a minor pain on the right side of her chest.  This is a common scenario you might encounter as per the literature - deep vein thrombosis (DVT) occurs in about 10-20% of patients within 3 months of major gynecologic surgery. It is also reported that DVT symptoms can often be non-specific and can range from mild discomfort to severe pain.  Objective for medical students: Identify the possible signs and symptoms of DVT in a post-surgical patient and understand when to order the appropriate diagnostic tests to confirm the diagnosis.  Resources: 1. Heit JA. Epidemiology of venous thromboembolism. Nat Rev Cardiol. 2015;12(8):464-474.  2. Rodger MA  Kahn SR  Wells PS  et al. Identifying unprovoked thromboembolism patients at low risk for recurrence who can discontinue anticoagulant therapy. CMAJ. 2008;179(5):417-426.  3. Beckman MG  Hooper WC  Critchley SE  Ortel TL. Venous thromboembolism: a public health concern. Am J Prev Med. 2010;38(4 Suppl):S495-501.  4. Kearon C  Kahn SR  Agnelli G  et al. Antithrombotic therapy for venous thromboembolic disease: American College of Chest Physicians Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines (8th Edition). Chest. 2008;133(6 Suppl):454S-545S.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Demographics: The patient  referred to as Mr. Simmons  is a 62-year-old Caucasian male of moderate income. He is a retired marine engineer living in an urban area with his wife.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Simmons has been previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He takes oral hypoglycemic agents and anti-hypertensives regularly. He has a 20-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally but has no known drug allergies. He is not on any regular exercise regimen and describes his diet as ""balanced."" He has no family history of blood clotting disorders  heart diseases  or cancer. His father died of a stroke at 76  and his mother has well-managed osteoporosis at 85.  Key Complaints:   Mr. Simmons came to the clinic complaining of gradually increasing left leg pain and swelling for the last one week. He noticed his leg turned slightly red and warm recently. He describes the pain as a deep ache that gets worse when walking or standing. He also noted mild shortness of breath  particularly when climbing stairs  but initially attributed this to lack of exercise and old age. He denied chest pain  cough  hemoptysis or any recent trauma or injury to the leg. He hasn't undergone any recent surgical procedures or prolonged bed rest.  In the presented case  Mr. Simmons partially fits in the typical demographic profile for Deep Vein Thrombosis commonly seen in clinical settings  bearing the common risk factors like older age  obesity  lack of physical activity  and pre-existing conditions (hypertension and diabetes). Even though smoking is a significant risk factor  in this case  he quit smoking five years ago. While deep vein thrombosis can affect anyone  understanding key demographic trends is crucial in preparing medical students to recognize  diagnose and manage this complex condition.  (According to several published medical reports and studies  DVT commonly affects older adults  particularly those over 50. Obesity  a sedentary lifestyle  and conditions such as cancer  heart disease  and lung disease can also increase the risk of DVT. A history of smoking is also mentioned as a significant risk factor.)   *N.B: Patient Demographics are made up for the purposes of the educational case and bearing in mind access to healthcare factors. They do not intend to stereotype or bias towards any particular group.*

Case Report:  Patient Profile  Name: Mr. Theodore Smith Age: 68 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired school teacher Location: Suburban Midwest   Medical history: Patient has a past history of type II diabetes which is managed with metformin. He was also diagnosed with stage 1 hypertension two years ago and has been on Losartan ever since. The patient had a total right hip arthroplasty four weeks ago. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and is a former smoker (20 pack-years).   Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with complaints of gradual onset of swelling  redness and increasing warmth in the right leg  slightly above the knee and calf  over the past week. Additionally  the patient mentions a mild-moderate level of discomfort in the same region towards the end of the day. No signs of fever  chest pain  or breathlessness.   This case would then go on to clinical examination  diagnostic tests  and further management focusing on Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). It covers the main risk factors for DVT namely elderly age  major surgery (hip arthroplasty)  immobility  diabetes  hypertension  and past history of smoking.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics: - Patient Name: Mr. Lewis Martin - Gender: Male - Age: 58 - Ethnicity: African-American - Occupation: Long-haul truck driver - Marital Status: Married - Current Residence: Charleston  South Carolina  Following the literature  DVT is more common among African-Americans  the elderly (over 60 years)  overweight individuals  and those with immobile jobs or lifestyles. Our creation of an African American  long-haul truck driver aged 58 will help accurately represent these high risk groups linked with DVT in the literature.  Past Medical History: Mr. Martin is obese (BMI 32) and has a history of hypertension controlled with medications. He also was treated for prostate cancer two years ago with no recurrence. He is a former smoker but quit 10 years ago. He has a family history of genetic thrombophilic disorders  specifically his father had Factor V Leiden mutation causing a DVT once. He has no history of lung or heart diseases  and his cholesterol levels are within normal limits.  Key Complaints: Mr. Martin presented to the clinic with dull aching pain in his left calf which he initially ignored thinking it was due to driving for long hours. However  the pain progressively worsened over a week making it difficult for him to walk. He noticed that his left calf had become noticeably swollen  tender  and warm to touch. He also reported a feeling of heaviness in his leg and these symptoms were not relieved by over-the-counter meds. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  recent injuries  or traveling  but does report prolonged sitting due to his work demands.  In conclusion  the case of Mr. Martin should provide students with a challenging scenario of DVT. His risk factors - being overweight  prolonged periods of immobility due to his job  hypertension  and a family history of genetic thrombophilic disorders - make his case an ideal learning opportunity. These characteristics  combined with his specific symptoms  should encourage students to consider proper assessment  diagnosis  and subsequently  the appropriate treatment regimen.

Case Presentation: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Profile  Full name: John Doe Age: 63 Years Old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: •	Ex-smoker for 10 years  30 pack-years •	Hypertension - controlled with Lisinopril 10mg daily •	Type II Diabetes - on Metformin 1000mg twice daily •	Thrombophilia •	Post-TKR (Total Knee Replacement) – right knee 5 days ago •	Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31 (Obesity)  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents to the outpatient clinic with pain and swelling in the right lower limb  more severe in the calf area. He describes the pain as a constant severe aching. He also noticed that his right leg appeared redder compared to the left  and felt warmer to touch. He denies any recent long journeys. He has no known allergies.  Examination: Upon examination  his right lower limb was swollen  erythematous  and warm to the touch  with calf circumference significantly larger compared to the left. His vital signs were within the normal range. His cardiovascular and respiratory examination showed no abnormalities. No superficial vein engorgement or ulcers were detected. The Homans sign was positive.  Assessment: The patient’s post-operative status  personal history of thrombophilia  sedentary lifestyle  and obesity are significant risk factors pointing towards DVT. The classic signs of pain  swelling  redness  and increased warmth reinforced the suspicion of DVT. Doppler ultrasound of the right lower limb was immediately ordered.  Discussion Questions: 1.	What is the relevance of the patient’s past medical history to the case? 2.	What approach would you use in diagnosing DVT? 3.	What are the risk factors for DVT and how do they apply to our case? 4.	What is the standard treatment for DVT? 5.	What measures can the patient take to reduce the risk of future DVT episodes? 6.	How would you monitor and ensure the effectiveness of the treatment administered?  This case encourages medical students to take a holistic view of the patient's history and symptoms in formulating a plan for investigation and management of probable DVT. It demonstrates the relevance of exploring lifestyle factors  genetics  and previous medical history in diagnosing and managing clinical conditions.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Demographics  Name: Mrs. Rachel Martinez Age: 65 years old Gender: Female Ethnicity: Hispanic Occupation: Retired public school teacher Marital Status: Widowed  Past Medical History  Mrs. Martinez is a nonsmoker but has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes  both well-controlled with medication. She has had no prior surgeries or hospitalizations  has no allergies  and reports occasional alcohol consumption. Mrs. Martinez's mother died at a relatively early age from a heart attack. Her father had a stroke in his late 70s. Apart from these  there is no other significant family history.  Key Complaints  Mrs. Martinez came to the emergency room complaining of sudden and severe pain and swelling in her left calf that started 3 days ago. The pain increased while walking and was accompanied by a mild fever. She also has intermittent chest discomfort with shortness of breath. On further inquiry  she reports that she recently had a long-haul flight two weeks ago  after which she remained largely sedentary at home due to jet lag.  Conclusion  Given Mrs. Martinez's recent long-haul flight  followed by a fairly sedentary lifestyle afterwards  as well as her presenting symptoms  these cues should be alarming for conditions like DVT. On top of that  her age  hypertension  and diabetes are acknowledged risk factors associated with DVT. Consequently  medical students should be guided to corroborate these hints and guide the patient down a diagnostic pathway for DVT  which may include an ultrasound of her lower limbs or D-dimer test  among other potential steps. It is crucial for them to understand that quick identification and treatment of DVT can potentially prevent a life-threatening pulmonary embolism.   According to research  DVT is common in older adults (>55) with a higher risk in individuals with previous history of venous thromboembolism and certain genetic conditions. Her ethnicity (Hispanic) carries a lower risk compared to Caucasians; nevertheless  the existence of additional risk factors like obesity  prolonged immobility  and others like cancer and trauma should always be considered during the diagnostic process.

Patient Case: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  In this case  we have a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John who is a retired school teacher.  Demographics: Gender: Male Age: 65 years  Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired (Former School Teacher) Marital Status: Married Residence: Suburban area in North Carolina Insurance: Medicare Language: English Primary  understands a little Spanish  Past Medical History: He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 15 years ago  which has been managed with Metformin and lifestyle changes. He underwent a total right knee arthroplasty three weeks ago due to severe osteoarthritis. He's a former smoker  who quit 20 years ago  and he drinks alcohol socially. He's physically active with daily morning walks and regularly practicing yoga. His BMI is slightly above normal- 26. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases: his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 67 and his older brother underwent angioplasty at 60 years old. John doesn't have any past history of hypertensive or ischemic heart disease.  Key Complaints: Today  he presents to the emergency department with his wife  complaining of progressive swelling in the right leg  which began around 18 hours ago and increased gradually. He denies any trauma but admits to having spent most of his time in bed since returning home post-operation. He also complains about mild to moderate pain in his right calf  rating it as an 8 on a scale of 1 (no pain) to 10 (worst imaginable pain). He is anxious  as his right calf seems warmer  with a dull aching pain. He mentions that his leg seems slightly reddish and is harder than usual.  This is a typical scenario in which deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can manifest  following orthopedic surgery in an elderly individual with risk factors including Diabetes Mellitus and a family history of cardiovascular diseases. It emphasizes the importance of probing into a patient's medical history and lifestyle habits during diagnosis. It also highlights the need for educating patients about the signs and symptoms of DVT following orthopedic surgery.

Case Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis in a Middle-aged African American Female  Patient Demographics: Patient initials: N.D  Age: 50 years old  Sex: Female  Race: African American  Occupation: Office job (long hours of sitting)  Weight: 90 kg  Height: 170 cm  Past Medical History:  -N.D. has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managed by diet  exercise  and Metformin. -Family history of cardiovascular diseases  including deep vein thrombosis. -Previous episode of DVT in her early 40s.  Key Complaints:  -N.D. has presented with complaints of swelling in her left leg that she has been noticing for about a week.  -She describes an area in her left calf that's warm to touch  red  and tender. - She complained about some mobility issues due to intense pain and discomfort  i.e.  difficulty in walking. -She also reported mild shortness of breath over the past two days. -N.D. also mentioned her concern about recent long hours at work where she sits for more than 6-7 hours at a time with minimal movement.  Please Note: In the literature  research shows the high prevalence of DVT in middle-aged  slightly overweight African Americans  and those with a family history of cardiovascular diseases. It’s not unusual for individuals with sedentary jobs or lifestyles  diabetes  or previous history to develop DVT. Hence  this case tailored for these key considerations.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Patient Information: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. He is a non-smoker  and he has a desk job as an accountant which requires prolonged periods of sitting. He weighs 265 lbs and is 5’8” tall  which represents a BMI of 40.3 and qualifies as obese. He is a frequent traveler and recently returned from a long transatlantic flight.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  managed with lisinopril. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago  controlled with metformin. He has no history of cardiovascular diseases  surgeries  or traumas. The patient's family history reveals a sister who had been diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis after a surgery two years ago.  Current Prescriptions: The patient is on long-term medication of lisinopril (10mg daily) and metformin (500mg twice daily).  Chief Complaint: The patient complains of a swollen right lower limb that has persisted for the past week. He has also started feeling occasional calf pain that increases with standing for extended periods or walking. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the limb. He also denies any chest pain or shortness of breath.  This case represents the common risk factors associated with DVT including age  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  long-haul travel  and family history of DVT. The prominence of DVT in white individuals and males is also mirrored in this patient's demographics. Keep in mind that this context is paramount in discerning DVT from other differential diagnoses.   Note: Before proceeding with examinations or procedures  make sure to provide students with relevant literature on DVT. Encourage them to consider the entire clinical picture: patient history  risk factors  physical examination  diagnostic testing  and potential complications. This will aid in their comprehensive understanding of the diagnosis  management  and prevention of deep vein thrombosis.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information:   Mr. Rogers is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a desk job and lives with his wife in Seattle. He has led a fairly sedentary lifestyle in recent years due to his job and enjoys recreational activities like reading and cooking.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Rogers is a former smoker  having quit smoking about 20 years ago. He has a 10-year history of well-controlled Type 2 Diabetes that he manages with metformin and maintains a healthy diet. Furthermore  he has a history of hypertension  for which he takes a daily dose of atenolol. He has also been diagnosed with obesity  with a BMI of 31. However  there are no prior incidences of deep vein thrombosis  any pulmonary disorders  or recent surgeries.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Rogers reported swelling  warmth  redness  and tenderness in his left lower leg after he returned from a long-haul flight one week ago and noticed the symptoms have been steadily worsening. He had discomfort in his left calf during ambulation  but no definite pain. He reported feeling more fatigued than normal but didn't have any breathlessness  cough  or chest pain. He also denied any recent fevers  chills  or other systemic symptoms.  In literature  deep vein thrombosis is most common in individuals over the age of 60 and presents with risk factors like obesity  prolonged immobilization (such as long-haul flights)  and comorbidities such as diabetes and hypertension. This case of Mr. Rogers accurately represents such demographics and risk factors associated with DVT  to provide medical students with a perfect training scenario.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years old  Gender: Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension for 10 years  managed by medication (Lisinopril 10mg/day). 2. Type 2 Diabetes for 8 years  regulated with Metformin 500mg twice daily. 3. History of smoking 1 pack/day for 30 years  quit smoking 10 years ago. 4. Had a right hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. 5. No known history of coagulation disorders  no prior episodes of venous thromboembolism.  Presenting Complaints:   1. Unilateral swelling  redness  warmth  and pain in the right calf that started abruptly. 2. Slight fever and general feeling of being unwell. 3. The right calf appears larger than the left one.  Note: The patient demographics and case mimic the common risk factors and clinical presentation of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Literature suggests advanced age (over 60)  obesity  previous major surgery  chronic conditions (like hypertension and diabetes)  extended periods of immobility and smoking history all increase the risk of DVT. The history of hip replacement surgery  in particular  further enhances the risk due to prolonged immobility post-surgery.

Case Report: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information:  - Age: 66 years old - Gender: Female - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher  Chief Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department with a three-day history of progressive  severe pain and swelling in her left lower leg. The pain  initially described as mild and consistent  had become sharp and intensified. She did not report any accidents  arduous activities  or known injuries that precipitated this.  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension managed for the last ten years with Lisinopril. - Estrogen Replacement Therapy for post-menopausal symptoms for five years. - Episodes of varicose veins treated conservatively. - Two pregnancies without complications. - Former smoker who quit six years ago. - BMI of 33. However  no documented history of diabetes or dyslipidemia. - Her mother experienced an unprovoked Deep Vein Thrombosis in her late 60s.  The patient led a physically inactive lifestyle since her retirement two years ago  and her nutritional habits are lacking dietary fiber and high in cholesterol. In her profession as a school teacher  she had prolonged periods of standing  and her family history includes a mother who suffered a DVT. Although she has tried lifestyle modifications  control of her hypertension has been suboptimal. She denies any history of cancer or recent surgical procedures. Her only travel history is a six-hour flight about three months ago. She has no history of alcohol or any illicit drug use.

Title: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Case Report  Patient Profile: Patient Initials: M.S. Age: 68 years  Sex: Gender Male Ethnicity: African American  Occupation: Retired Factory Worker  Past Medical History: M.S. has a history of type-2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. Additionally  he is a former smoker  having quit 8 years ago after a 35-year pack-a-day history. He also has moderate obesity with a BMI of 32 and was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago. M.S. was hospitalized for a right hip arthroplasty two weeks ago and has been mostly bed-bound since the surgery. His medications include metformin  statins  and antihypertensive drugs.  Chief Complaints: Upon a follow-up visit to the hospital  M.S.  presents with acute onset of unilateral  progressively worsening pain and swelling in his right leg  predominantly around the calf region. The patient reports his pain as 7/10 on the pain scale  stating it increases with walking or standing. He denies any recent trauma  fever  or chest symptoms. No signs of superficial vein thrombosis  skin colour changes  or leg ulcers are noted.  In this case  the demographics of the patient reflect the epidemiology noted in studies. Older age  post-surgical state  obesity  and prolonged immobility coupled with conditions like diabetes and hypertension augment the risk for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). Gender-wise  studies indicate a slightly higher prevalence of DVT in men. Ethnically  African Americans have notably higher rates of venous thromboembolism. Through such a case  the trainee/student is expected to engage with the diagnostic and management strategies for DVT considering the patient history and risk factors.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mrs. Martha Gomez  a 67-year-old African American female  resident of Tennessee.  Patient Background: Mrs. Gomez is a retired school teacher  living with her husband. She is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. Her BMI is 28 and she leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle due to her arthritis. Her diet lacks in proper fiber content and is high in saturated fats.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Gomez was diagnosed with Type-2 diabetes 12 years ago and osteoarthritis 5 years ago. She also has a family history of heart diseases; her father passed away due to myocardial infarction and her elder brother has been diagnosed with angina pectoris.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Gomez came into ER with her main complaints as sudden swelling in her left leg  redness  warmth  and tenderness localized to the calf area. In addition  she has been experiencing general fatigue and an unusual shortness of breath on exertion over the past week. Upon enquiring  she also mentioned that she recently had a long-haul flight (over 4 hours) a week ago  post which she noticed initial tenderness in her left calf.  Given the patient's age  past medical history including prolonged diabetes (known to affect blood vessels)  sedentary lifestyle furthering chances of stasis  family history of cardiac issues  recent long-haul flight promoting immobility  and the sudden presentation with symptoms  it is crucial to consider the possibility of Deep Vein Thrombosis in Mrs. Gomez and proceed accordingly with her examination and investigations. An early and accurate diagnosis can significantly reduce complications such as the post-thrombotic syndrome and life-threatening pulmonary embolism.   Note: The above case presents the demographics as observed in the literature. The African American race is slightly more prone to DVT than other races. The female gender  although generally at less risk than males  can show increased DVT risk after menopause as seen in Mrs. Gomez's case. The professions involving sedentary lifestyle (such as her teaching job) also add to DVT risk. The age group above 60 gives a higher incidence of DVT due to various risk factors including immobilization  comorbid conditions  and decreased venous return. The case also takes into account common risk factors including diabetes  obesity (BMI>25)  and prolonged immobility due to long-haul flights.

Case Report: Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information:  Name: Mrs. Ruth Taylor Age: 62 years old Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired schoolteacher Location: Suburban  North Carolina  USA  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 6 years ago  on medication (Lisinopril 10mg  daily). 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 11 years ago  managed with oral medication (Metformin 1000mg  twice daily). 3. Previous Distal DVT: 4 years ago  treated with anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin). 4. Hypothyroidism: Diagnosed 8 years ago  controlled with levothyroxine (75 micrograms  daily). 5. Non-smoker  occasional alcohol (1-2 glasses of wine per month). 6. Family history of DVT and pulmonary embolism.  Presenting Complaint:  Mrs. Taylor presented at the emergency department complaining of a sudden swelling  redness  warmth  and pain in her left calf which began 48 hours ago. She denies any recent injury  long-distance travel  or periods of prolonged immobility. The pain seemed to worsen when she flexed her foot or stood for extended periods. She additionally mentioned a slight shortness of breath when performing minor household chores  which was unusual for her.    NOTE: This case focuses on deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a common but serious medical condition. The choice of a patient in her sixties reflects statistics indicating that DVT is most common in adults over 60. The patient's history of hypertension  diabetes  and previous DVT should prompt medical students to consider her high risk  and her recent symptoms are suggestive of a potential DVT recurrence. Furthermore  her slight shortness of breath could indicate a possible pulmonary embolism  a common and serious complication of DVT. The scenario allows medical educators to discuss the evaluation  diagnosis  and management of DVT.

Case Study: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Details:  Name: Mr. Louis Warren Age: 68 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired businessman  Chief Complaint: Mr. Warren presents with worsening pain in his right lower leg  which he describes as a deep  aching sensation. He also notes some swelling and redness  but denies fevers  chest pain or shortness of breath.   Past Medical History: Mr. Warren has a significant past medical history of type II diabetes and hypertension  managed with metformin and amlodipine respectively. In addition  he has a history of chronic arthritis managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatories and occasional steroid injections. He lacks any record of previous clot or bleeding disorders and is not on anticoagulants. He's a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago and has a moderate alcohol intake.  Recent events: 2 weeks ago  Mr. Warren had a total knee replacement surgery on his right leg for severe osteoarthritis. His post-operative period was complicated by a urinary tract infection for which he was treated with antibiotics.  His mobility was impaired due to prolonged bed rest during his recovery period.  Family history: His father passed away due to a heart attack and his mother had a stroke.  Context: Caucasian people  particularly those over 60 and with comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension  face a higher risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). DVT occurrence further becomes more significant following major orthopedic surgeries such as total knee or hip replacements  largely due to immobilization periods. It is important for all medical students to understand the demographic risk factors  history cues and presenting symptoms of DVT in order to initiate swift management procedures to prevent further complications such as a pulmonary embolism.

Patient Profile:  Patient Name: Mr. Thomas Jefferson Age: 55 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Long haul truck driver Residence: Portland  Oregon  USA Marital Status: Married Social History: Former smoker  quit 5 years ago; occasional alcohol consumption  Past Medical History:   Mr. Jefferson has a history of hypertension  which he has been managing with medication (amlodipine 5mg daily) for the past three years. He hasn't been diagnosed with any other chronic disorders. He has been generally fit with an active lifestyle until recent changes in his work arrangements.  He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Jefferson presented with a complaint of increasing and persistent pain in his right lower leg  especially in the calf region. He described it as a “deep-seated soreness” that worsened over 5 days. There was associated mild swelling and redness as well. His recent job requires him to drive long distances without many breaks  which has been a significant change as compared to his previous more active daily routines.  He also reports a recent unexplained weight loss and a decreased appetite over the past two months.  The persisting pain  redness  and swelling point towards possible deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The associated unexplained weight loss and appetite changes raise concerns about possible malignancy leading to a hypercoagulable state resulting in DVT.  While this case focuses on a Caucasian male (they are more likely to suffer from DVT as per the literature)  it's important to note that deep vein thrombosis can affect people across all ages  races  and genders. This case represents a commonly seen demographic  but medical students should understand that DVT doesn't discriminate and can present in any patient demographic.
